headline: My Beauty Uniform: Laura Barrett
content: ['<p>Laura Barrett is a professional nail artist and nail genius. A native of London and a New York City mom, she’s also the founder of The Beauty Genius Project, a website that looks at the world’s best beauty products and brands, including Joanna Sebastian, Anna Barnardo and Caroline Stapleton. Here, she shares five nail accessories she uses, her favorite hair care line and five secrets to living your life really well…<p><p><p><p>Wrap: After my baby arrived, Laura moved from her mother’s family to pursue beauty. Her parents taught her to use a very modern makeup line, but she still wore makeup. When I was six, she started dressing in her dad’s T-shirt and T-shirt, which helped her express herself more, she said.<p><p><p><p>Dress: Mango, similar. Boots: similar. Necklace: similar. <p><p><p><p>Rings: vintage, similar.<p><p><p><p>Rings: similar.<p><p><p><p>Vacation mask: similar. Purse: similar. <p><p><p><p>Glasses: similar.']

headline: New England Adventure: The Farm
content: ['<p>As our guests have pointed out, Toby and I haven’t been to New England. Toby spent the winter outside, sleeping on the roof and having a panic attack while wearing a backpack. We got into a shouting match with a bunch of local boys over the weekend, and Toby spent much of his time sleeping on the side of a wooded hill (which he said he saw in the afternoon!) and using the backseat of his truck as a platform to pee.<p><p>On a recent evening, after our honeymoon, I took Alex on our first leg across the Maine coastline, the beautiful Evergreen National Forest.<p><p>We spotted a little green patch on the edge of the forest, which makes it look like a huge forest, or something, I thought. But instead of glowing red, it actually looked like a cloudless sky. It was beautiful to see — almost a million trees blooming on the forest floor.<p><p>Afterward, Toby walked around the village with his dog, and we all fell into conversation. Toby loved to sing along to his beloved "I Got a Gun" and played around with woodcutters’ sticks and hammers, which he said were the best he could find.<p><p>On the afternoon, we headed up the ridge to the lighthouse, and it was beautiful. It was just a small cove with little pools, but the views were incredible, especially after a huge wave.<p><p>Meanwhile, we ate dinner, watched a movie, and played ping pong.<p>']

headline: City Guide: New Orleans
content: ['<p>New Orleans is a city with gorgeous streets, but there’s something refreshing about finding one that’s really tucked away in the middle of nowhere. There are so many beautiful restaurants, beaches, playgrounds, museums and playgrounds, yet the city seems grounded in its roots.<p><p>Have you been to New Orleans? We’d love to hear!<p><p>P.S. The French Restaurant in the Old City, and a hilarious wedding in a French restaurant.<p><p>(Photo by The Sartorialist)<p> ']

headline: Bike rental
content: ['<p>Last fall, we posted about how to rent bikes in San Francisco. It felt like we were all in love. Now, two years later, bikes are everywhere. Here are six affordable rental options…<p><p><p><p>City Bike Rentals: The San Francisco bike rental website places three basic rental options: bike racks, bike racks with bikes, and bike racks with wheels.<p><p><p><p>Parked bikes <p><p><p><p>Citywide Bike Rentals: The citywide bike rental site has bike racks, bike racks with bikes, and bike racks with wheels. A bike rack is a separate bike from a bike rack, with a handlebar that slides down. A bike rack with a handlebar sits in the middle of a bike rack, and a bike rack with a handlebar slides down to the bottom. The bike racks also have two bikes inside of them, and a third bike sits outside. (Parked bikes are more common.) <p><p><p>']

headline: A New Hope for Girls
content: ['<p>It’s been a wonderful couple of weeks for the Girls and the City Project, which is launching a New Hope in downtown Manhattan this week. On the one hand, it’s offering an inclusive environment where kids can explore the places they’re from and learn about culture and history (including the great Alexei Morissette).<p><p>On a bigger level, the girls have been inspiring us to explore and share their stories — some of them touching, some of them sad, some of them touching…<p><p>What kind of music did you listen to at the beginning of the trip?<p><p>What is your take on the new song "Shining Lights," from the upcoming album, A New Hope for Girls?<p><p><p>Did you have a curfew? Yes, but it’s really easy for me to remember that. I’m a planner, so it’s just about staying in touch with what I have.<p><p>What kind of artwork do you have for kids’ playgrounds? It’s not something that I want to do, but it’s something I wanted to do for kids. We wanted the children to explore the playgrounds, too.<p><p>']

headline: My Beauty Uniform: Lisa Han
content: ['<p>Lisa Han is an associate professor of dermatology at UCSF and a bestselling author. Here, she shares her love of lipstick, the best product for acne and the secret to long-lasting nails…<p><p><p><p>How did you start taking good care of your nails?I started my career as a nail salon and nail technician at age 12. I learned how to make good choices and how to use natural chemicals — something I learned over and over. Today, I’m a director at Clinique in San Francisco and have been using their natural ingredients since. As a mom of three grown-ups, I really have a hard time understanding the limits of how much I can give or take. I’m always amazed by how much I can take with me — especially on my nails. I love that they have both natural and organic ingredients that I can use as a preservative. I’m always amazed by their affordable prices and the variety of colors and products they have.<p><p>What about you about beauty?In the past, I have been obsessed with nail polish and have been searching for products that would be affordable and have the perfect combination of natural and chemical properties. So I started using this color treatment that has long been available on sale. It has lasted me around 25 years. In recent years, my life has also changed, and I don’t want to be living a boring life. I’m inspired by the beauty of my grandma, who made such beautiful nail polish. She gave her daughter the beauty she deserves to live. I love her attitude, she always looks great and wears a bow tie. <p>']

headline: 1.50% off $10 Gift Card
content: ['<p>This adorable card goes for just $10. You get five (!) days of free shipping and returns. It’s also great for weddings, holidays and trips.<p> ']

headline: Vacation Photos: NY
content: ['<p>Last fall, my family and I were visiting our friend in New York City. We were going out to dinner, when suddenly, as we were walking down the street, we saw a dude with an iced tea.<p><p>I jumped at the chance to chat with Alex. Here are a few more photos from that trip…<p><p>…<p><p><p><p>One day, I decided to do some shopping, and found these awesome pieces of vintage clothing from a local vintage store. Alex brought them with him for Christmas (I usually don’t wear sweaters, but it was a treat to get to wear the pieces). Alex made these little bags for us (he always leaves his phone in the bag in case of a trip) and ordered all the new ones for me at a low price.<p><p><p><p><p>We also made two other friends over at Sommelier.com, and our friend Emily had the best tea I’ve ever had. We sat on a patio overlooking the beach, where he had a delicious white one, which he poured right off the top of his mug. We ended up tasting and drinking that special kind of tea, which would get us hooked! We took photos afterward of my friends everywhere: cars, beaches, apartments, restaurants, and every restaurant we visited. (Also, I LOVE the orange and blue stripes on these bags!)<p>']

headline: Stroller seatbelt
content: ['<p>Have you ever worn a stroller? It’s so comfy! So comfy, in fact, that I’ve been running around my mom’s house in my grandmother’s Stroller seatbelt. Now I have a stroller seatbelt and it still looks good. And it works really well. Will you wear one?<p><p>P.S. The other day, I had a little crush on this little mom-and-pop stroller…<p> ']

headline: 'Bunnytail' Season 2
content: ['<p>In the past, Toby and Vanessa have been meeting on the run from the supernatural, and this season, they’re traveling the world together, traveling with their partner (Elle Kelly) and their cat, Puffy. They can’t stop laughing!<p><p>Puffy: My mom is from Sweden, and she loves Toby and Vanessa. She likes Toby to have his sense of humor — that’s the way she has always been! — but she has never seen him that funny in her life. He’s just too cool, which he’ll have to deal with over the course of the next season, and she’s seeing that too. They’re hoping that when Toby gets back, he’ll start laughing again.<p><p>Puffy: She’s the sweetest person ever, and she was just like, “You know what? You should have known better” — but now she’s like, ‘You know what? I’m sorry, okay? What did I do wrong?”<p><p>(Photo by the wonderful Sarah Jessica Parker)<p> ']

headline: Sleeping Bag
content: ['<p>Have you ever been to New York City, but don’t want to? We got hitched at the city (well, not really, but that’s another story) and we love to walk around the city, so it was a pretty wild trip. We rented an old VW camper van with rental cars and slept in a tiny, oversized sleeping bag (they were both giant). What a rad place.<p><p>P.S. How to pack a suitcase.<p><p>(Photos by D.C. Photography. Styling and design by J.D. Dye.)<p> ']

headline: Fashion: Yves Saint Laurent
content: ['<p>Yves Saint Laurent is a fashion blogger who loves to make quirky clothes. The designer lives in Paris with her husband and four young children, so it’s perfect for dinner dates or afternoon picnics. Here, Yves shares five gorgeous pieces that she’s worn the most…<p><p><p><p>White dress: Lululemon. Crew dress: Lululemon. Necklace: Tarte. Earrings: Madewell. Necklace: Madewell.<p><p>“I grew up on the side streets of Paris, so I didn’t know much about French fashion. The first time I walked into a boutique was my twenties. I found the clothes there and loved them. I’ve never worn a dress of this style before, so I never expected to get compliments! The people there always say ‘the French are good at everything,’’ so it’s nice to have something authentic. I have a twin sister, who is from France, and their style is completely different. My French friends all say, ‘How do you feel about French girls wearing jeans?’ The French girls are so pretty and graceful.”<p><p><p><p>Classic earrings: Madewell. Necklace: Madewell. Earrings: Madewell.<p>']

headline: Bike Bikes
content: ['<p>Today, we’re psyched to announce that the Atlanta-based bike shop Bikes, is bringing their line of bikes to Brooklyn. “This will be the first bike shop to open in Brooklyn,” says the shop’s website. It’s their first bike shop in New York and it’s inspiring to see how Brooklyn cyclists and pedestrians are reacting. The shop will offer bikes with a low profile, and bikes with a high profile can be used for family picnics and bicycle rides. And Bikes will have bikes with a high profile—at least from my perspective.”<p><p>What are your plans for visiting Brooklyn this fall? Would you be planning to bike to work this summer?<p><p>(Photos by The New York Times)<p> ']

headline: The Perfect Summer Dress
content: ['<p>Everlane recently posted a great video of a bunch of cool dresses…<p><p><p><p>Orsay<p><p><p><p>Orsay<p><p><p><p>Ribbed<p><p><p><p>Ribbed<p><p><p><p>Dress of the Week<p><p><p><p>Dress of the Week<p><p><p><p>Striped<p><p><p><p>Topless<p><p><p><p>Sleek<p><p><p><p>Shoe<p><p><p><p>Bead<p><p><p>']

headline: Pleasant flooring
content: ['<p>This summer, while visiting friends in London, I stopped by a Parisian restaurant. They looked like Parisian street style. My friend Caroline asked about the rosewater wallpaper. It was soft and laid-back and would be perfect for picnics and hikes, or afternoon walks in the garden. I was sold! It felt fresh and pretty.<p><p>P.S. Paris is having an annual spring collection, and an all-natural nail polish!<p><p>(Photos by Ana Gambuto)<p> ']

headline: What Happens When You Get Married?
content: ['<p>This summer, after years of trying to plan ahead, I finally did some research. As a married couple, we typically go to weddings with the intention of raising a family. As a single woman who has had three children, and the new baby in tow, I feel like the perfect mom for her four-year-old, I can’t wait to show you how to get married! Here are five easy steps…<p><p>1. Take photos. I use my iPhone to send photo cards, but if I want to go all out, I would also send a couple photos instead, so I can take photos of my bride’s legs. That way, when she comes over, I can send her photos in the future.<p><p>2. Set up a table for your wedding, if needed. As a couple, we don’t typically do anything for guests unless they’re absolutely certain we want to have the ceremony and dinner planned.<p><p>3. Check in with the bride. We generally get a good look at the ceremony before going to sleep, so I check it in advance. This takes us two to three hours!<p>']

headline: A Guide to Spring Bags
content: ['<p>My darlings, my lovelies, my fellow students, the world’s most awesome Spring Guide is finally here. In its first 100 days, the Guide has inspired tens of millions of readers around the world, and we’re thrilled to share with you its findings, including its surprisingly simple and fun recommendations for packing in your beloved bags. Here’s what we discovered…<p>']

headline: Dance Dresses
content: ['<p>We’re excited to share our new dresses, which we’ve been wearing since we moved to New York. So excited to wear them!<p><p>P.S. Our French guide to traveling with a baby, and our secret to dancing forever.<p><p>(Via Black Dresses)<p> ']

headline: Ouch. I <PAD> ’m not a star. It’s a black hole. A galaxy. It could have been a gas giant. A black hole. I don’t know, but I can understand why they didn’t like me.” Star-biting, I suspect. “I guess what’s going on?” He says. “I’m sorry about it. I’m sure you wouldn’t believe what I said. I know, I’d be so ashamed about it. But I’m not in the mood to try.” His voice has a sense of a sadistic nature. “You’re trying to say things that you don’t want to hear. You’re trying to tell me what you’re thinking.” “What’s the point?” Star-biting. “Why’s it so tough for you, Star-Busters?” “Why’s it so tough?” “What’s your reason?” Star-biting. “Why did you just go off on me like that?” Star-biting. “Why’s the reason?” Star-biting. “I’m sorry, but I’m not really sorry.” He says. “So I did what I said and I said it. I said that’s what I meant by it.” ‘That’s what I wanted to say.” Star-biting. “It’s like when I started talking to my girlfriend, because that’s how I got into dating her. It was kind of surreal. ‘Why were you talking to me like that?” Star-biting
The next generation of vaccines to fight polio: a guide
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A team of researchers is developing vaccines that will stop a polio-causing virus in saliva, saliva droplets and in the urine to prevent its spread to others.<p><p>Researchers at Washington University in St. Louis think they can find ways to prevent polio from entering other parts of the body through vaccines such as the MMR vaccine that are being developed in Europe.<p><p>“Our aim is not only to vaccinate the polio vaccine system but also to prevent the virus from spreading to other parts of the body through vaccines,” said co-author Dr. Thomas M. Pugh, a professor of neurology at the U.S. Army War College and lead author of the study published on Monday in the Journal of Translational Medicine.<p><p>Pugh’s team is co-leading the effort to produce vaccines from genetically modified organisms, or GMOs, that are engineered to produce antibodies against the polio virus. They are testing the anti-sporadic effects of GMOs on a strain of Escherichia coli, a strain of the virus that causes the disease.<p><p>The researchers have developed vaccines specifically designed to prevent polio from entering other parts of the body. The work will be led by J. Scott Heins, a scientist at Johns Hopkins University and lead author of the research published on Monday in the Journal of Translational Medicine.<p>']

headline: Biden's space agency blasts NASA for not offering early Mars samples
content: ['<p> - U.S. space agency NASA blasted off from Cape Canaveral on Wednesday for a six-day tour of the International Space Station, an annual trip to the red planet intended to establish new partnerships between American and foreign spaceflight.<p><p>NASA said last week it will announce its plans for the launch of a new robotic test vehicle to carry the crew to the station by 2024 and test its ability to extract and return samples of Earth’s atmosphere and surface during a voyage through space.<p><p>The launch is the first for NASA since President Donald Trump’s abrupt exit from the race to clean up NASA’s botched space shuttle program in March.<p><p>NASA plans to send the crew home within three to four years, though delays could hamper a scheduled $1.2 billion investment in the newly built space station in 2024.<p><p>“We will not put our crew back on the ISS until a robust mission system is in place to ensure the return of crew to the station and to the human race as a whole,” U.S. deputy administrator Megan Kennedy told reporters after the launch.<p><p>NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine said it was important that NASA, in keeping with its longstanding commitment to a safe and secure environment for astronauts, continues to develop its human spaceflight program to help bring Americans and partners closer to the moon.<p>']

headline: U.S. space agency to develop next generation of satellites
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A top U.S. space agency is developing a new generation of space-based sensors designed to detect asteroids and other dangerous asteroids in the early stages of human space exploration, as the U.S. prepares to launch astronauts to the International Space Station next year.<p><p>The U.S. space agency NASA is developing a suite of space-based satellites to help it establish a foundation for an eventual manned mission to the moon, the centerpiece of its effort to revive humankind’s space station.<p><p>U.S. Vice President Mike Pence, who is on a tour of NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center, said a prototype of the U.S. satellites would be built by the end of the year and would be used for space missions in future missions to Mars, Venus or Saturn.<p><p>A U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that NASA was working with NASA and private sector partners to develop a “multi-module system” that would be capable of detecting space debris and other debris within days, as well as tracking the path of a rocket or spacecraft as it flies.<p><p>NASA officials said they were working on an initial prototype of the system before commercial launch in late March, and that the system, dubbed Artemis, will include sensor systems similar to those being developed by Lockheed Martin Corp. in its Orion spacecraft, which will ferry humans to the space station under a mission dubbed Starship II.<p>']

headline: Pence signs tax increase: USA Today
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Donald Trump on Wednesday signed legislation intended to cut tax increases for the wealthy, ending the U.S. government’s ability to raise taxes on the wealthy, and the government announced plans to raise taxes on the middle class for businesses, lowering its standard-setting threshold.<p><p>The new law will boost the federal budget and require companies to report annual adjusted return returns for their net worth to the government by the middle of next year.<p><p>The Trump administration, which has said it wants to raise the standard-setting threshold, has said the new law will create a “goldilocks” of revenue to stimulate the economy.<p><p>As lawmakers debate how to fund the government over the next several years, some economists say the change is crucial to Washington’s long-term economic growth goals, particularly in a time of global instability.<p><p>“The president’s actions today will spur economic growth in the United States and help boost middle-class competitiveness,” said Thomas Stokes, chief economist at the Center for Economic Policy Priorities.<p><p>“The middle class is being battered by a resurgence of financial inequality, as well as rampant inequality and a widening gap between the richest and poorest among Americans. It would be nice to see more focus on middle-class jobs, and more investment in quality manufacturing.”<p>']

headline: Rescue workers on board EgyptAir plane take off and land in remote Egypt desert
content: ['<p>BEIRUT  - A rescue team from a Russian-owned EgyptAir flight has made it to the city of Beit Al Ghar, near the town of Kfar Makhachkala, to board a plane bound for Saudi Arabia’s King Abdullah II plane, officials said.<p><p>Kfar Makhachkala, which is about 150 km (120 miles) east of Cairo, is among the most dangerous areas in Sinai to try to extract an oxygen mask from.<p><p>The mission comes days after a series of fatal plane crashes in the Sinai that forced two of the pilots to postpone their flights until mid-December, the deadliest since the 9/11 attacks.<p><p>Kfar Makhachkala’s mayor, Mohammed Bin Rashid al-Mansouri, had said a team had arrived at the airport to retrieve the oxygen mask.<p><p>A spokesman for Emirates, which runs Egypt’s largest airline, said on Wednesday it would provide the plane’s flight crew with fuel and supplies.<p><p>EgyptAir, a subsidiary of Airbus A320, has been accused of failing to perform vital safety checks on the plane, a problem that has been linked to the country’s heavy toll-sharing network that has drawn criticism from international aviation.<p>']

headline: On the outskirts of Chicago: A glimpse at Chicago's historic South Side
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - In the heart of the South Side of Chicago, a dusty, desolate, industrial wasteland and littered with cars, bridges and buses, the remnants of the past are the backdrop to one of Chicago’s most acclaimed and diverse histories.<p><p>Architects, laborers, businesses and other residents from the 1950s to the 1960s and 70s all moved here in recent decades to provide a backdrop to a city-wide history of immigrant lives in the city.<p><p>The story of Chicago, a vibrant city on the south side of Chicago, has been a flashpoint in recent years with the emergence of Trump administration initiatives to crack down on illegal immigration.<p><p>On Wednesday, as a group of mostly young people from a mostly white South Side neighborhood watched the demolition of an iconic African-American neighborhood, a small group of volunteers from the South Side Historic Commission (SHC) convened at a neighborhood gallery for an interactive panel discussion that invited passersby and former residents to participate in some of the most popular and enduring stories of Chicago’s South Side.<p><p>SHC member Sandra Thompson, whose last name was retired from the city last year after serving as city director for two decades, said history teaches us that people living in South Side neighborhoods are not just outsiders - they are special people.<p><p>“In South Side neighborhoods, the story is very personal, so it’s kind of hard to forget people’ stories from South Side neighborhoods,” Thompson said.<p>']

headline: Furquarian disease can help improve quality of life
content: ['<p>MEXICO CITY  - Doctors who studied the symptoms of a rare type of fungus that causes severe arthritis in cats and dogs say it can help cut a path to recovery for ailing cats and dogs.<p><p>Furquarian disease - a virus that causes severe arthritis, strokes, heart failure and diabetes - affects about 8 percent of the world’s population, but experts warn it could also hasten the end of some people’s life.<p><p>Some 80,000 cats and 60,000 dogs are known to have antibodies that make them more susceptible to the coronavirus, which they infected with the fungus D. melanogaster.<p><p>They need surgery, antibiotics and intensive care unit care, with treatment often lasting months.<p><p>The coronavirus can also cause severe inflammation in the body, which can lead to death or even death of people infected with the fungus.<p><p>The coronavirus has also been known to affect certain skin types including the hands, feet, lips and eyes.<p><p>A virus that can infect people with it can also infect people with other types of infection and cause infertility, infertility treatment or cancer treatment.<p><p>It was first identified in China in 1976.<p><p>Experts say there are only about 100 cases reported annually of the disease, and that they need to be checked annually.']

headline: China's Space Launch System rocket, called L-1B, completes test flight
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - A test flight of an unmanned Chinese launch system that will launch satellites into space for the first time on Sunday provided a rare glimpse of the capabilities of a system that could cut reliance on foreign space companies for American astronauts and pave the way for a future of reusable launch vehicles.<p><p>The U.S. Air Force, the Chinese National Space Administration and the International Space Station each have their own launches of new satellites that test the technology, according to people familiar with the matter.<p><p>L-1B, called the L-1B Origin Rocket, is one of several planned domestically built rockets launched by China, which has been pursuing an accelerated space program.<p><p>The launch is the second of its kind under China’s accelerated program, following SpaceX’s debut rocket in May which successfully launched a satellite into orbit on its Falcon 9 rocket.<p><p>The launch has been delayed due to an anomaly in China’s satellite navigation system, and delays have also been reported in recent days by Chinese news agencies.<p><p>L-1B was also the target of a U.S. government “procedure” in late December that would allow the military to certify the system to be capable of carrying U.S. astronauts to the International Space Station, the U.S. military said in a statement.<p>']

headline: Obligation may help curb COVID-19: study
content: ['<p> - Scientists have found a way to get COVID-19 antibodies in people who are at high risk for getting COVID-19 - and the drugs could help in the fight against the virus.<p><p>In a paper published on Tuesday, the researchers describe the technology as a method of treating a patient with a type of antibody - known as non-proliferation - that prevents the antibodies from getting through.<p><p>Scientists reported on Wednesday in The Journal of Medical Virology that antibodies that are produced by the immune system cannot be taken seriously, and are therefore unlikely to protect against disease. The antibodies can also block certain drugs that affect the blood.<p><p>The research team at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, in Los Angeles, studied 3,500 COVID-19 cases in about 700 patients, who volunteered to take part in a randomized trial, which included more than 1,000 volunteers. They found that some patients with antibodies that could neutralize the COVID-19 antibody were more likely to have severe disease. Those who developed antibodies that could neutralize the non-proliferation antibodies had a significantly lower incidence of infection with the antibody compared to those who got the antibody alone.<p><p>Overall, 3,300 patients were treated with the non-proliferation antibody, compared with just 1,700 patients who got it alone. The median annual hospital stay for COVID-19 patients who got the antibody was 3 days.<p>']

headline: How well does a vegan chocolate chip taste?
content: ['<p> - A vegan chocolate chip tastes good in your mouth, thanks to its high levels of antioxidants, less sugar and less salt, researchers found.<p><p>The chocolate chip is derived from the plant-based cacao nut and is a staple in many kinds of dishes and foods, while chocolate chips are sold by many brands.<p><p>As the dieter in high places like the U.S. and Australia, I tend to eat the chocolate chip without much effort because it tastes like it tastes just right and not salty, the researchers said on Wednesday.<p><p>As you eat it, your body will absorb more sugar from the sugar-packed chips because it has higher levels of fiber and iron. The researchers suggest you should try eating a whole chocolate chip instead, especially for those who consume fewer calories.<p><p>The chocolate chip was not tested on any other animal products, but the researchers also found that some chocolate chips contain cholesterol.<p><p>They tested chocolate chips with peanut butter, peanut butter plus plain yogurt and chocolate chips with cocoa butter.<p><p>They found that chocolate chips contain fewer proteins than vegan chocolate chips.<p><p>A typical chocolate chip contains 8 grams of sugar and about 1.5 grams of protein. A vegan chocolate chip contains 12 grams of sugar and 4 grams of protein.<p>']

headline: Moses, Galileo, Copernicus and Galileo at the height of their technological genius
content: ['<p>ORLANDO  - When Thomas More, a Greek scientist who invented the sun, made the first observations of the cosmos about 11,000 years ago, he was hailed as the greatest physicist of his time.<p><p>But Galileo, whose name comes from the Greek Κgus, the sixth priest and astronomer of Alexandria, was just beginning to get into science.<p><p>More was working on his machine, the Arianespace, the first super-computer and an instrument that would allow the world to see the sky. He had already invented the first computer in 1783.<p>']

headline: Chinese space programme 'wakes up' scientists on earth
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s space programme has woke up its scientists on earth, a scientific commission said on Monday, announcing the creation of a “scientific research laboratory” in a remote area of space.<p><p>The research laboratory will be located on the southern island of Hainan, the space agency said.<p><p>The research laboratory will collect scientific data and perform experiments in an area known as the “Golden Gateway” in the form of “computer simulations, ‘high-resolution simulations and simulations of various aspects of space and space science”, according to the mission.<p><p>The mission, the first of its kind for China, has been beset by a series of setbacks including a series of technical problems caused by a faulty test computer used by an official in 2018.<p><p>One of the “most serious” was the loss of one of the “deep space windows” in the Chinese Long March 5 rocket, the mission said.<p><p>The new mission will be “intensive, and it’s going to take a long time,” the commission said, according to a live broadcast by the China Academy of Sciences.<p><p>The mission’s principal investigator, Shunghyun Wang, a senior research scientist at the China National Science Administration (CNSA), will be at the site for the first time since the accident in August.<p>']

headline: SpaceX crew to take first flight to moon in December
content: ['<p>JERUSALEM  - Israeli astronaut Nick Hague and Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin will take the first flight to the moon this month, the Israeli space agency Roscosmos said on Thursday.<p><p>The flight, which is scheduled for mid-December, marks the beginning of Israel’s plans to bring its manned space program to the moon, a key objective for the United States, Russia and China to take in the long-sought candidate.<p><p>Hague’s Crew Dragon capsule will lift off from a base on the edge of the moon on December 20. The space agency said a second crew was due to fly from March 31 to June 30.<p><p>The two space agencies hope to launch missions to the moon this summer as a result of the United States’ decision to withdraw from the International Space Station in 2019.<p> ']

headline: A new gene-editing gene may be the answer to disease' mystery
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Researchers have solved the mystery of how and why a gene called DBE2 encodes certain genes that are involved in disease, the latest scientific breakthrough in the field comes in a paper published on Wednesday.<p><p>DBE2 - the acronym for the discovery gene encodes a protein called protein kinase 3 - may be pivotal to determining the nature of the problem with modern medicine.<p><p>The scientists first spotted DBE2 in 2003 using DNA sequencing and gene engineering experiments and had tested the gene by comparing it with other proteins on animals or humans.<p><p>Their new discovery came in the paper published in the journal Nature Genetics.<p><p>A protein called ERK1 encodes the protein kinase, which makes up a key part of protein-protein interactions and determines the amount of oxygen in the blood. The protein is thought to be involved in blood clotting and is often used in the treatment of patients with advanced liver disease.<p><p>The new study involved comparing three different versions of the protein to each other using a gene-editing technique known as CRISPR/Cas9.<p><p>The CRISPR/Cas9 version encodes the same gene encodes DBE2 but encodes a different protein called CK2 that encodes the same gene encodes DBE2 but encodes DBE2 encodes CK2 but not CK2.<p>']

headline: Innovations in human genome editing that alter COVID-19 susceptibility: UK
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Scientists are experimenting with an inexpensive and environmentally friendly way to edit the DNA of COVID-19 survivors, but they say the technology is far from perfect.<p><p>Researchers said on Wednesday the enzyme called COVID-19N2 was responsible for the gene-editing actions that are known to modify the human genome.<p><p>The research involved editing a genetic code that controls proteins that are needed to generate antibody proteins. By editing the code, the scientists can inject COVID-19N2 into the immune system of infected cells.<p><p>They hope to produce antibodies for other potential diseases, including those that include MS, as well as those that could result from the genetic modification.<p><p>Some existing therapies for COVID-19 are currently limited to editing the DNA of patients.<p><p>But the use of COVID-19N2 could also be applied to vaccines to target or reduce viral loads on cells, which can lead to improved safety.<p><p>Researchers at Imperial College London, who studied the human genome editing process for the first time, described it as “far from perfect” and said they were “hoping that this technology can be tested for COVID-19 survivors,” adding it was a “long-term objective”.<p>']

headline: Boris Johnson to join space agency
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Boris Johnson said on Thursday he intends to work with Britain’s space agency Rocket Lab to develop a privately owned spacecraft to carry humans to the International Space Station, as the Labour leader seeks to break into the White House’s rocket business.<p><p>In his speech at the Conservative Party Conference, Johnson said he had plans to seek Cabinet office as early as next week to make Britain the fifth country to send a space probe.<p><p>He said there would be no change to the current policy towards Russia and added: “We will start a private space programme.”<p><p>The Labour leader said he hoped Britain would become the third country to send a human into space after the United States and the United Kingdom.<p><p>“I will say to Boris and to my colleagues on the government, this country will start to put its mind to the task ahead of a programme that would allow people to live in peace, not war,” he said.<p><p>“I’m hoping I’ll achieve something that will send us into space, which is not a distraction but a chance to be better,” he added.<p><p>“I will see you on our space station next month,” he added, using a reference to the International Space Station.<p>']

headline: Boeing scraps U.S. military's plans for stealth jet and puts first crew on moon
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Boeing Co said on Monday it will skip plans to launch a “minor” manned spacecraft into space as part of its long-term plans to develop unmanned aircraft and send humans to the moon by 2024, citing a risk of “a significant increase in risk to NASA”.<p><p>Boeing said the “launch window” at a NASA agency briefing was opening in early March.<p><p>The Boeing’s Space Falcon One rocket, dubbed the Space Launch System, or SLS, is being developed in partnership with NASA to put humans into lunar orbit and then send people to the moon by the end of 2023, the company said.<p><p>Boeing and NASA are planning separate trips to the lunar surface by 2024.<p><p>Boeing, whose Falcon One program received $7 billion in federal and private incentives for development in 2020, is competing with Lockheed Martin Corp, Northrop Grumman Corp and Raytheon Corp to develop their manned capsules capable of landing and crewing on the lunar surface, U.S. Air Force officials said.<p><p>“We’d better do what we can to put more people into lunar orbit,” Air Force spokesman Patrick Lockhart told reporters.<p>']

headline: Boeing rockets test launch abort
content: ['<p>Boeing engineers are on the cusp of completing the first test flight of its Crew Dragon, a reusable launch system designed to ferry small satellites into orbit for the first time since the rocket exploded in April.<p><p>“We’re in an atmosphere where the test is progressing and where it’s important to ensure that the spacecraft is ready to put satellites into space,” Brian Lutz, executive vice president of Boeing’s Crew Dragon program, told Reuters.<p><p>The first Crew Dragon is due to launch in August for testing in the desert near Cape Canaveral. After that, NASA will put the first Crew Dragon into orbit for the first time in 30 years, Lutz added.<p><p>“We’ve got a long list of test launches in the pipeline,” Lutz said. “But one of the most important is getting it ready to go into orbit, and that’s not always possible.”<p><p>The next Crew Dragon test flight, scheduled for early 2019, is being planned as a test of Boeing’s new reusable launch vehicle known as Crew Dragon 2, Lutz said, though he did not disclose the number. The company is also working to develop the reusable rocket design, which could bring more satellites into orbit in a short time and give it a larger payload space footprint.<p> ']

headline: Lionsgate says satellite launch delayed for 'fringe' reasons
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The London-based satellite navigation firm Loomar announced in April that it had halted the launch of its UK rival Global Positioning System (GPS), citing safety concerns.<p><p>The announcement, however, did not explain why global positioning satellites were delayed, or the reasons behind the delays.<p><p>Global Positioning Systems, whose network of satellites in more than 20 countries is dependent on Russian-made GPS, announced in April it was to be reviving its global positioning network for the first time in three years.<p><p>“A large percentage of global positioning systems and other satellites rely on the GPS network,” Loomar Chief Executive Patrick Mullen said.<p><p>“Therefore, this means that we have made a decision to halt the launch of Global Positioning Systems.”<p><p>The company said the “very large number of issues that have been identified” with the current constellation, called Arianespace, meant the launch could occur soon.<p><p>“We are working hard to address these issues,” Loomar said.<p> ']

headline: The European Space Agency has launched a probe to the moon for the first time after spending 26 years exploring the planet, a move that will give it the capability to explore in lunar orbit for the first time. NASA announced on Thursday that the unmanned Artemis mission, slated for early 2018, will be used to explore the moon’s interior and its water environment. Artemis is the name of Artemis’s science lab. The probe, a NASA astronaut named Artemis-B, will conduct ground-based and land-based robotic surveys of the moon and Mars. Artemis-B will arrive on the surface of the moon on Nov. 8.
content: ['<p><p>The mission marks a historic shift in NASA’s plan for humans on the moon, focusing on the lunar surface and its water reserves, while also encouraging international partners to participate in its mission.<p><p>The European Space Agency (ESA) said in a statement that Artemis, the European Southern Gateway (ESG), had completed the first nine lunar landings on its Artemis-B probe, including the first of a series of landings in the Indian Ocean off the coast of Kazakhstan, on Jan. 25.<p><p>“Since the Apollo program ended in 1972, ESA has undertaken more than 12,000 landings on the moon, more than 100 of which were landings off the coast of Hawaii,” ESA Director-General Patrick Moynihan said in a statement.<p><p>“We are committed to achieving long-term lunar exploration for all humanity, while also ensuring a successful return to the moon in 2023.”<p> ']

headline: Dennis Koehler on NASA's new “go-to” space probe: 'It’s all good
content: ['<p> - American astronaut Dennis Koehler, the first U.S. astronaut to fly into orbit without help from Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin, has called on NASA to provide the craft with crucial scientific data before the end of the 2022 fly-by of the International Space Station.<p><p>Koehler, the only American to have traveled to the space station since 2006, plans to spend weeks aboard NASA’s “Star Gateway” spacecraft orbiting the orbiting laboratory while NASA considers options for future robotic rovers to help revive the International Space Station.<p><p>“We’re a team built to be a part of the future,” Koehler told reporters at the launch site in Colorado.<p><p>NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine said on Friday he has asked NASA to prepare an online survey that will ask questions such as “Does the spacecraft have the science that we need to understand the science of other spaceships to help us safely return humans to the station in 2023,” Bridenstine said.<p><p>“I do not think we’ll be able to continue on as a partnership,” he said, adding that NASA has invested $200 million in the project.<p><p>Koehler said he was surprised NASA would let him stay on. “The ISS is a huge priority for me, but NASA can do better than that.”<p>']

headline: Soyuz spacecraft lands in Kazakhstan, leaving first crew stranded for more than two months
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Soyuz spacecraft carrying Russia’s first crew successfully landed on Sunday, making it the first American crewed space vehicle to attempt a landing in Kazakhstan since the Soviet Union’s collapse in 1991, the space agency said.<p><p>The unmanned Progress spacecraft lifted off at 8:02 a.m. local time from Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on a mission designed to carry a crew of three people, including the crew member, in a rare mission for Russia to be at the front of its Western allies, the U.S. space agency said.<p><p>“We are very happy to have landed the Soyuz-FG-1 spacecraft on the Kazakh steppe with the second crew,” Space Agency Chief Executive Alexei Ovchinin said on Twitter after the spacecraft’s landing.<p><p>The mission marks the latest in a series of missions that Russia and the United States launched in recent years in what it describes as a “soft” mission to build a relationship between the two countries. Russia’s space program has spanned a decade with a goal of establishing a permanent presence on Earth by 2024.<p><p>On Saturday, Progress deployed a camera to the space station to document and monitor the landing.<p><p>Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin tweeted that the mission underscored the importance of Russia’s participation on international space-related issues in order to build a relationship with the West.']

headline: Scientists study 'virus-sucking' genes
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - Scientists have determined genes involved in producing antibodies to cause autism and other conditions that can damage DNA, including genes in a key piece of the genetic code.<p><p>A gene called CRISPR-Cas9 - or CRISPR-CoV-2 - appears to contribute to some of the more extreme features of autism and other common psychiatric disorders.<p><p>But researchers said on Thursday that their findings - the first in human genetic studies - were preliminary. They needed to test the hypothesis that this CRISPR-Cas9-induced vulnerability can impair the integrity of the genome.<p><p>The researchers studied 1,017 genes, including 26 of the six key ones that were critical to the immune system’s ability to attack the body’s most vulnerable genes, including two that were responsible for the immune system’s immune response against the virus.<p><p>That indicates a strong immune response when there are no other drugs or vaccines available, they said.<p><p>“This research suggests that an important component of the immune system’s ability to attack such genes, and especially when there are no other proteins that are also involved in those attacks, may be compromised by the presence of CRISPR-Cas9 in a gene,” said study co-author Benjamin Schimmelmann, director of the European Molecular Oncology Laboratory at CITES, one of the U.S. institutions that conducted the study.<p>']

headline: Cancer-induced breast cancer survivors can still face stigma
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Breast cancer survivors who want to speak up about their experiences of stigma and disease are still likely to face stigma, according to new research, researchers said on Thursday.<p><p>The findings, published in the journal Cancer Respiratory Research, also suggest that some people may not be fully aware of how common cancer is among women and can also face discrimination and stigma, researchers said.<p><p>The research, by researchers from Harvard Medical School and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, analyzed data from 4,000 breast cancer survivors whose symptoms were first reported to the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in 2012 and 2013, when they were at least 39 years old.<p><p>The findings suggest that while stigma may not be widely held in society, it still affects a small subset of survivors, said research coauthor Dr. James Schilling of the Harvard School of Public Health and the University of Arizona School of Public Health.<p><p>“It’s a sensitive question, especially for survivors of cancer who are still recovering from it,” Schilling said. “Even if they have access to supportive care, stigma still exists.”<p><p>As the number of women and girls who are cancer survivors declines, stigma is also diminishing, researchers reported. That means it is hard for those survivors to face the full range of care they need for their cancer, they added.<p>']

headline: Tiny, light weight, and relatively light weight - NASA
content: ['<p> - The International Space Station may soon be able to catch up with the space agency’s bigger rockets for the first time, NASA said on Thursday, announcing a milestone test flight for the space agency’s next generation of astronauts and a new space station designed to rival the space shuttle.<p><p>NASA launched the Space Launch System (SLS) to space on a Falcon 9 rocket, carrying the crewed mission to its destination in Kazakhstan, on Jan. 20.<p><p>SpaceX’s new Falcon 9 is capable of carrying a payload of about five tonnes into orbit for the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration.<p><p>NASA’s next-generation crew capsule - designated the Space Launch System J, or Starboard, - is due for launch in March, and a first test flight is due for early next year.<p><p>“In addition to the launch capabilities that will enable SLS to carry out operations beyond the launch vehicle’s original launch vehicle, SpaceX’s Falcon 9 will also be able to carry additional payloads into orbit for NASA, including a satellite for NASA’s National Science Foundation, the first U.S. astronaut crewed mission to orbit other countries, or a remote sensing instrument for GPS for Japan, the space agency said.<p>']

headline: New Horizons spacecraft flies past Pluto's icy moon Titan
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A New Horizons spacecraft is nearing the edge of the icy moon Titan, one of the solar system’s most distant moons, with a new mission aimed at tracking its environment, the spacecraft’s lead engineer told Reuters on Friday.<p><p>“We want to know whether that means collecting data for us to study on the surface, whether there’s a chance that Titan is actually there,” said Dan Biddle, a University of Arizona assistant professor of geosciences and astronomy who is leading the project. “We know there is, but we don’t know exactly what.”<p><p>Teaming up with the European Southern Observatory’s European Planetary Orbiter (EPO) on Thursday morning to fly close to Titan and photograph it with a lander from a European Space Agency (ESA) spacecraft, the spacecraft is aiming to reach the dwarf planet at about 30 minutes (16.25-23.25 am EDT), or about one hour later, Biddle said.<p><p>The spacecraft will be able to survey Titan’s atmosphere, the atmosphere generated when it roamed the moon 50 million years ago.<p><p>The European Southern Observatory (ESO) is a partnership of the European Union’s Roscosmos mission and the United States. It will fly the spacecraft between Titan’s two south pole moons, Enceladus and Perseverance, about 825 miles (13,841 km) away.<p>']

headline: NASA astronaut rides off to space in historic Soyuz mission
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - NASA astronaut Bob Behnken and Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin are due to fly aboard an ISS crewed by NASA’s next-generation Crew Dragon spacecraft, the agency said on Friday.<p><p>Boeing Co BA.N is also due to fly crewed missions to the International Space Station, though the astronauts won’t be able to fly aboard the crewed Soyuz-FG-001 rocket due to crew-to-satellite separation issues that have been resolved.<p><p>The astronauts, both of whom wore NASA’s first black suit during the space shuttle program, will be seated in front of a camera while conducting tests on the cosmonaut’s capsule, the agency said.<p><p>NASA on Friday said Crew Dragon is designed to support a planned four-man crew for a mission lasting 20 years with the mission expected to include NASA astronauts Jim Bridenstine, Bob Behnken and Vladimir Solovyov.<p><p>NASA has awarded contracts to Aerojet Rocketdyne BA.N. and Lockheed Martin Corp LMT.N for Crew Dragon and Exploration and Propulsion Systems.<p><p>NASA launched a new Crew Dragon spacecraft last month with the goal of putting humans back on the International Space Station by 2024.<p>']

headline: Fossils of the dinosaur Triassic Period at Pompeii
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Fossils of the dinosaur Triassic Period dinosaur Triassic Period (TCR) were found at Pompeii, Italy, according to scientists, with the bones apparently belonging to a large number of dinosaurs.<p><p>The fossils unearthed in Pompeii are the biggest ever found in Italy. The species of the dinosaur came from a large group called Dioscorides that dominated the dinosaur assemblage around Pompeii, some 150 million years ago.<p><p>Scientists have been studying the fossils of Triassic Period dinosaurs in Italy.<p><p>The fossils, unearthed in Pompeii on Dec. 24, were discovered in the sedimentary rock of a cave. A team led by Andrea Nettori, a research scientist at the Italian Academy of Sciences, said it confirmed the presence of dinosaur teeth.<p><p>The fossils were found in a shallow sedimentary rock bed known as the Pileus basin.<p><p>“The teeth belong to a group called Dioscorides that included the largest number of dinosaurs to have ever been discovered there, and with a combined population of about 20,000 to 25,000, including the first Triassic group of herbivores, we believe they represent the first vertebrates to have been discovered there,” Nettori said.<p><p>The Triassic Period dinosaur fossils, about 70-80 million years old, are among the oldest known vertebrates in the world.<p>']

headline: 'Rise of the beast': Scientists find evidence of dinosaur bones
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - In the latest analysis of bones unearthed in Mongolia’s Namibian desert, scientists said on Thursday they found traces of bones of a fearsome beast known as “Rise of the beast” and its relatives, boasting fearsome teeth.<p><p>The bone fragments, which were taken on Friday from the site, indicated that the group lived in what is now southwestern Mongolia.<p><p>“It is unusual to find bones of an animal so massive - the biggest in the world - on a human head,” said University of Cambridge paleontologist Svante Bolasheva, lead author of the research published in the journal Scientific Reports.<p><p>“It is an odd coincidence that the bones are so diverse,” Bolasheva added, adding that more researchers are needed to study the species.<p><p>“We suspect the group had a diet that included meat, fish and other animal products, as well as herbivorous plants and fruits. They lived in environments dominated by animal-eating mammals, including herbivorous plants, and a small group of invertebrates including birds, reptiles and amphibians,” Bolasheva said.<p><p>“We are hopeful this finding will shed light on how and why ‘Rise of the beast’ appeared, which gave us clues about the life cycle of this group.”<p>']

headline: On Thursday, U.S. President Donald Trump condemned Russia as a "space criminal" who has made numerous provocative and provocative statements about U.S. astronauts and has encouraged a new wave of Russian space agency launches. (bit.ly/3EyJfD)  - A week after the United States’ first launch of a rocket from U.S. soil against the backdrop of the global financial crisis, Russia’s Deputy Prime Minister Dmitry Rogozin said on Thursday his country was preparing to launch a “space criminal”. Rogozin told a news conference he had heard from U.S. diplomats that he believed Russia was preparing to launch a “space criminal”. (bit.ly/3EyJfD) - The Kremlin on Wednesday accused the United States of being a bystander when it launched a ballistic missile capable of reaching Europe in 2019 and then carrying out a simulated rocket launch later that year. (bit.ly/3EyJfD) - The U.S. National Security Council on Thursday called on Russia to refrain from carrying out provocative and provocative actions while in the country’s orbit. (bit.ly/3EyJfD) - The New York Times reported that Trump had called Russian President Vladimir Putin a "space criminal." Later, the news agency said, Trump had ordered U.S. Air Force One to conduct a new “space countermeasures mission against Russia” that will include intercepting ballistic missiles, warning against any use of U.S. assets in space. (bit.ly/3EyJfD) - The Russian Academy of Sciences on Thursday called for scientific collaboration on the development of space flight, claiming that the development of the ‘space flight’ was a key step in developing technologies to support spaceflight, including satellites. (bit.ly/3EyJfD) - The European Union on Thursday ordered Russia to halt all domestic experime
A new type of moon-bound spacecraft enters interstellar space
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have identified the first ever “sub-atomic particle” in interstellar space, allowing researchers to launch a high-energy laser probe from Earth into low-Earth orbit for the first time.<p><p>The newly identified “quantum particle” is believed to form when two electrons or protons collide in space, causing them to emit a single electron.<p><p>While the particles are relatively rare and therefore unknown, they have fascinated scientists for decades because they have been the focus of a “multibillion-dollar ‘quantum leap” in science.<p><p>Using the latest research, scientists say they have the first evidence of an interstellar particle capable of triggering a “major supernova” during a brief burst of radiation in a collision with a star.<p><p>“We are going to build a new ‘sub-atomic particle’ to help us understand the nature of this event,” said Michael Pfeiffer, a physicist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California who led the research published on Thursday in the journal Nature Astronomy.<p><p>The new findings are important for understanding the origins and dynamics of matter and its origins.<p><p>The particle, called rheumin, is produced in a nuclear fusion reaction that leads to the decay of hydrogen atoms and helium atoms, the building blocks for hydrogen and helium in interstellar space.<p>']

headline: How to tell the difference between COVID-19 and AIDS?
content: ['<p>A small study published on Monday in The Lancet Infectious Diseases suggests that the risk of contracting COVID-19 has risen over the years, especially among young people, who have received chemotherapy.<p><p>COVID-19 is a medical emergency caused by a virus causing AIDS, according to a paper posted on Sunday on Science and Medical Oncology. The paper says that between 2011 and 2013, the number of COVID-19 cases among young people dropped by more than 10%. The proportion of young people who reported having been exposed to the virus jumped by 17%, to 1.2%.<p><p>Among older people with chronic disease, the proportion fell to 0.7%, to 1.5% - nearly twice the previous estimates, said study co-author Dr. Matthew Rannenfelser of Duke University Medical School in the United States. The risk of contracting COVID-19 increased in older people living with asthma and heart disease. He estimated the risk was five times higher among older people with milder conditions.<p><p>The study also found that COVID-19 infections are associated with poorer mental health, less sexual health and lower socioeconomic status. The researchers say the prevalence of COVID-19 can also be linked to poverty, joblessness and drug use.<p><p>A small trial on more than 1,500 people in Brazil found that COVID-19 was significantly linked to poorer mental health and poorer educational outcomes among young people with HIV/Aids. The study also found that among those who had a pre-existing medical condition, the prevalence of HIV increased by 29%.']

headline: Bosnia wins World Cup final against Slovenia
content: ['<p>Slovenia are set to host the 2019 World Cup final in BOSNIA - the highest-profile soccer event in northern Bosnia and Herzegovina - after winning the final against Slovenia.<p><p>Slovenia’s victory over Slovenia on Friday night ensured a victory for the former World Cup champions but a narrow second-half defeat by the Slovenian side will leave Bosnia and Herzegovina out of the competition.<p><p>Slovenia will host the 2019 World Cup final in BOSNIA and Slovenia are set to host the 2019 World Cup final in 2019, a year after becoming the third country to win the 2018 World Cup.<p><p>The winners’ win over Slovenia would give them a third consecutive title with Bosnia, a side that won four in a row at the 2018 World Cup, a top-flight European tournament.<p><p>Croatian goalkeeper Zlatan Ibrahimovic won the 2014 World Cup but the Slovenian squad that finished second in 2014 and qualified for the 2019 World Cup and the following year were champions.<p><p>The World Cup and the next four years would make Bosnia and Herzegovina the fourth country to win the World Cup, joining Russia and Estonia.<p><p>Bosnia and Herzegovina are also the third country to have won the 2019 World Cup.<p><p>World Cup winners Sweden and Germany have won the previous seven in succession.']

headline: Gardening new evidence on the origins of animal life
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The following is a brief roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the origins of life on Earth, the natural history of life and the origins of intelligent life on Earth.<p><p>NEW YORK  - An international team of scientists has unveiled the new evidence supporting the existence of life on Earth, which scientists say has helped scientists shape the thinking about the origins of animals and plants.<p><p>The new findings come as scientists begin to examine the fossil record of animals, plants and insects in the past 50 years. The new evidence is based on what is known about the earliest stages of life on Earth, beginning in the last few million years and continuing through the Cretaceous Period, according to the researchers.<p><p>“We’re seeing evidence of animal evolution from the Mesozoic Period, including evidence of plants and insects evolving from primitive plant groups and from a new group called dromaeosaurids called carcharodonts,” said Michael Bloom, an evolutionary biologist at the Natural History Museum in Los Angeles and co-author of the research published in the journal Nature Communications.<p><p>“The discovery that we have uncovered is that life was first appearing in primitive plant groups around 100 million years ago. So the Mesozoic period is when it took these animals many, many years to be recognized. And we’re showing,” he said.<p>']

headline: NASA to launch satellite with the first human lunar landing in 2023
content: ["<p> - NASA has landed its first human lunar lander on the moon after it successfully landed a Soyuz spacecraft in the Kazakh steppe, a launch mission the agency says it has a key to in its ambitions to develop for long-term human space travel.<p><p>The Soyuz spacecraft -- named Yudovatorn in Russian - touched down in the Kazakh steppe on Monday in a special event called the International Space Station, marking its fifth unmanned mission by a manned spacecraft to the red planet.<p><p>The spacecraft, called Artemis, will launch in mid-2019, providing the agency with more information on its capabilities as it goes on its way toward the moon.<p><p>“This has been a big achievement and a great achievement in our quest to put a human back on the moon and send humans back there,” NASA Chief Executive Jim Bridenstine said at a news conference on Tuesday. “The humans on the moon are some of the smartest and most complex things on the planet,” he said.<p><p>The United States and Russia have been competing for space rides on the Soviet-era moon since the 1960s, with the United States claiming on last year\\'s Expedition 43 that it has been “the most ambitious program ever undertaken by humankind.”<p>"]

headline: SpaceX launches U.S. astronaut mission to space station
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Three U.S. astronauts lifted off safely to the International Space Station on Wednesday with the launch of a NASA crewed mission into the International Space Station’s second floor.<p><p>The six-man crew from Boeing Co BA.N, Lockheed Martin LMT.N and United Launch Alliance (ULA.O) will set out on a four-day journey from Florida to the space station in the first unmanned mission from ULA since a SpaceX rocket failed in March.<p><p>The two-man crew have already arrived in Russia, where the two-man crew will spend the next two weeks at the space station, where they will test out SpaceX’s Crew Dragon capsule to conduct a series of experiments to help the space station improve its science and safety.<p><p>The four-member crew - astronaut Nick Hague, Nick Hague and Japanese astronaut Minoru Noguchi - completed a six-day stay on the space station’s protective surface and are due to launch from Cape Canaveral in a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying them to the space station on Wednesday.<p><p>The four-man crew made history in 2013 when the crew of astronauts Doug Hurley, Neil Armstrong and Dave Bridenstine reached the space station for the first time in their lives.<p><p>They will participate in an exercise, dubbed “Space Camp” - or ‘Space Day” - on Feb. 15, the U.S. space agency said in a statement.<p>']

headline: Rice scientists say they may be the first human to walk on water’s edge: Nature
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have said they have made history by putting a man in the water, and they’ve added a new wrinkle: it’s an animal that may be on the brink of extinction.<p><p>Researchers on Wednesday compared frozen specimens of a male and a female freshwater turtle that lived in a semi-arid coastal plain in Papua New Guinea to images of a newly discovered freshwater animal named Ahab that was discovered in 1972.<p><p>The turtles were both larger and smaller than humans, and their fossils showed they possessed adaptations to survive the low-oxygen environment and were a major threat to human fisheries, said study leader Dr. David Sink, a geology professor at the University of Portsmouth in England.<p><p>“The fact that they lived in a shallow plain that was protected from the sea by the ocean and the sea water is so unique and we have to be cautious about that,” he told Reuters.<p><p>“In a sense, that’s not so surprising given the history of amphibians like us, and the way that these amphibians are adapting.”<p><p>“They’ve gone beyond the natural boundaries that we’ve set for them and moved in different directions,” Sink said. “And the fact that we have these same anatomical differences as frogs and turtles is a huge accomplishment.”<p> ']

headline: Billionaire billionaire dies at age of 70
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Billionaire businessman and entrepreneur Sheldon Adelson, founder of the Las Vegas casino magnate casino empire, died at age 65 on Thursday at age 70 after battling cancer, his wife and her husband said.<p><p>The Adelsons, who were married for 54 years, had been battling the disease known as B.C.-induced COVID-19.<p><p>Billionaire Adelson was diagnosed with a form of advanced cancer and was hospitalized for about six weeks before his death.<p><p>Adelson, who has a wealth of $25 billion and a reputation for philanthropy, was diagnosed with the disease in 2013 at age 70.<p><p>The Adelsons’ daughter, Nicole, said Adelson was always a part of her family.<p>']

headline: Boeing test pilot on mission to space station
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - Boeing Co\\'s first astronaut capsule blasted off from Florida on Wednesday for a test flight to the International Space Station (ISS), after which the crew was placed on a stretcher in preparation for a splashdown.<p><p>Boeing astronaut Nick Hague is slated to join the space station crew in a final test mission to “expedite the atmosphere” in the event the rocket fails, a Pentagon official said, adding the crew was on its way back to the station shortly after 4 p.m. ET (0400 GMT).<p><p>NASA’s space agency, NASA, on Thursday asked Boeing’s engineers to conduct the test so they can establish whether they can safely dock the craft aboard the space station and return it to Earth before the end of the 2022 fiscal year, which begins on Dec. 31.<p><p>In August, the U.S. Air Force launched a probe into space for NASA and U.S. military space missions. The probe, the Orion Space Launch System, has carried out more than 700 space-related tests on behalf of the agency since 2006.<p><p>“This test is not a test mission. This is a crewed test,” Jim Bridenstine, the deputy director of NASA’s human spaceflight program, said in a statement. “Engineers are working hard to get this to the full operational capability of NASA before the end of the fiscal year.”<p>"]

headline: Virus and food are likely linked: WHO
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - The United Nations expects that a surge in the global population and a rising number of imported diseases, with some expected to be linked with a rise in HIV infections, to produce an increase in food imports.<p><p>The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization expects that a rising number of infections and foodborne disease outbreaks would increase imports to $1.7 trillion by 2030, with food imports estimated to account for half of that increase.<p><p>It says food imports account for more than 4.5 percent of global GDP, making them likely to lead to a sharp rise in global hunger by 2050.<p><p>The new findings, published on Friday, come as U.N. officials work to unpack a picture of food imports that are likely to have an impact on global health.<p><p>“Demand for food and crop crops is predicted to exceed supply by 2050, potentially leading to a significant increase in the global burden of food insecurity and to a significant increase in malnutrition worldwide,” said U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization (UNFPA) head Raul Camara in a statement.<p><p>“Food security and nutrition are not only critical for global health but also for development of food security and resilience,” Camara said.<p><p>In developing countries, food imports account for 42 percent of total imports, nearly double the share from China and India.<p>']

headline: Billionaire investor says Trumpomics 'has done more to destroy' U.S. manufacturing sector
content: ['<p>MEMORANDO, Switzerland  - Billionaire investor Donald Trump’s proposed U.S. manufacturing blueprint would require the federal government to establish an industrial base, slash its workforce and make manufacturing non-competitive globally, his investment advisory group said on Thursday.<p><p>Trump’s blueprint, which would set “robust, sustained, high-productivity and high-wage manufacturing..., would require the creation of new high-productivity and high-wage manufacturing plants across the country, creating more jobs and a pathway to sustained economic growth,” it said.<p><p>“While I think Donald Trump and other U.S. corporate leaders have accomplished more than I can count, America’s manufacturing base has certainly been destroyed over the past several years,” it added.<p><p>Trump’s campaign website touted his plan, dubbed Trump’s Industrial Strategy, as an opportunity to create a “national industry that grows and creates a high-paying, highly skilled workforce worldwide.”<p><p>The plan would require the creation of thousands of new plant and equipment manufacturing facilities to create a total of about 1.9 million jobs, according to the website, and would require 20% less of U.S. manufacturing jobs to come from foreign nations than the previous 15%.<p>']

headline: Tiny planets are making sense of Earth's magnetic field
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Tiny planets in our solar system might be making sense of Earth’s magnetic field, researchers said on Thursday, as the research reveals another big issue facing Earth.<p><p>The researchers determined that a planet, called Jupiters-1214, orbits a pair of rocky planets called Kuiper Belt asteroids that are so hot that their atmospheres would burn up on impact.<p><p>This rocky planet, called Triton 942, orbits at roughly the same distance from Earth and is a bit smaller than our sun, making it a very good candidate as a candidate for the Earth-sized solar system.<p><p>“In principle, if a star are to be orbiting a rocky planet, the surface of the planet should be a thin layer of rock,” said study leader and NASA scientist Shannon Smith, of the Max Planck Institute for Solar System Sciences in Munich, who was not involved in the research. “However, we still need to prove whether planets are around and around with the same energy.”<p><p>“These findings help us understand how the Earth was shaped by the solar system,” Smith added.<p><p>Jupiters-1214, a planet in a region called the solar disk, would make use of a special electromagnetic field emitted from inside its planets to shield them from gravitational radiation.<p>']

headline: 'Naked' woman: Egyptian archaeologists hunt for fossilized bird
content: ['<p>MEMPHIS  - Egyptian archaeologists have found a fossilized bird with a reptile face and a reptilian tail embedded in its fur.<p><p>The findings - from an excavation of a necropolis in the eastern desert north of Cairo - help scientists understand how a bird evolved from a small mammal to a giant.<p><p>“I want to remind the public that we live in a nation that doesn’t respect the fossil record,” said Dr. Mohammad Alwan, head of the team that retrieved the remains in April.<p><p>He told Reuters he planned to attend a public meeting in Cairo on Thursday where people would “be surprised to find these findings.”<p><p>“It was a huge step in our research.”<p><p>It has yielded the first fossilized human leg bones, along with a jawbone, at the site of a pyramids at the time, according to al-Shaykh al-Islam, who led the excavations.<p><p>“The leg bones were buried with a crane in the open fields of the pyramids, so that we can see what the bird did. And, the tail,” al-Shaykh said.<p>']

headline: Lars von Trier
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The three-time Olympic medal-winner, a former Formula One World champion who won 12 golds at the 1972 and 1975 Olympics, was also a fierce critic of Britain’s nuclear weapons program.<p><p>“You can’t tell the difference between the Germans and Soviets,” he said in a Facebook Live interview.<p><p>“That’s something that they were not able to put into practice until Britain and their allies started doing it.”<p><p>The London 2012 Games also had the same complaints about Britain’s commitment to arms control.<p><p>“It’s a country where we were told to build up our nuclear deterrent by 2020,” said Sir John Smith, head of the Security Council and the former foreign secretary, in November.<p><p>“I don’t think anyone in Britain can believe the lengths we went to build up our nuclear deterrent.”<p><p>Smith was in Britain at the height of the Cold War but his criticism of the UK was only made public last week.<p> ']

headline: Warnings and warnings for coal-fired power plants: study
content: ['<p>The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>Scientists warn of potential health risks posed by the new coronavirus<p><p>Warnings and warnings for coal-fired power plants are needed to ensure their emissions from burning fossil fuels are not rising too rapidly, an influential report warned on Wednesday.<p><p>In its report, the IHS Jane Goodall Institute said coal-fired power plants - where the new coronavirus-carrying bacteria have been discovered - could be vulnerable to COVID-19 and other respiratory and other respiratory diseases, as well as risks from increased heat, pollution and increased heatwaves.<p><p>It said that coal plants with a high level of COVID-19 exposure also needed to improve cooling, ventilation and power plant facilities. It said that the number of respiratory and cardiac infections in coal-fired power plants must be reduced.<p>']

headline: The future of space exploration: How a handful of countries are taking space exploration seriously
content: ['<p>LONDON  - One of the most ambitious projects underway by governments around the world is to set out the roadmap for commercialisation of space, launching a pilot programme that promises to transform a handful of small-government spaceships and eventually send them to the moon.<p><p>With $30 billion a year to go before governments launch a programme of commercial launch of satellites and crewed spacecraft into orbit, the government of Indonesia is stepping into the role of “space station” - a reference to the rocket-like spaceships that are the basis for a range of space programs.<p><p>The development of commercial launch systems under the new Outer Space Treaty (OSTA) is being watched closely by other nations involved in international space activities.<p><p>“We think that at the end of the day, we have the technology and the means to send humans to the moon,” said John Hurley, director of the Centre for Innovation at the University of Edinburgh. “We just need the right mix of people with the right experience to achieve this.”<p><p>The International Space Station’s first crewed mission is due to be launched in March 2019 with an initial $500 million budget and an initial $850 million budget to carry out a second, unmanned mission in 2022.<p>']

headline: U.S. hopes to resume nuclear weapons development by 2030, but not by accident
content: ['<p> - U.S. Vice President Mike Pence on Wednesday said the United States and other allies are planning to resume the development of atomic weapons, but not by accident.<p><p>Asked if the United States still planned to halt the development of atomic weapons, Pence said: “It would probably have to have an accident,” but added: “It’s very much a contingency plan,” adding that the White House “continues to work with all of our partners and partners as we always have,” and said the United States still aims to make its goal of reducing nuclear weapons to only one-tenth the size of the current Soviet Union in 2035.<p><p>Pence also said the United States will continue to fight a variety of terror activities against Iran and its ballistic and nuclear programs.<p><p>Speaking in Washington, Pence said he “strongly believe” in the Iran nuclear agreement with Iran, which he said he had signed in 2013 but which has “no application.”<p><p>The U.S. President said he was hopeful that Iran “will find ways to resume peaceful activity and the peaceful development of nuclear weapons,” but did not provide details.<p><p>Pence said he would “still welcome the continued development of Iran’s nuclear program.”<p>']

headline: Warm up your skin with an antiviral
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - The most popular antiviral drugs in China have been tested on mice with no detectable inflammation and researchers say a combination of both treatments can help protect against type 2 diabetes.<p><p>Researchers from the Chinese Academy of Sciences said on Thursday they had tested more than 1,700 of the new drugs in mice, which had been given the same treatment, as they had in mice.<p><p>Both drugs contained antibodies to the so-called CRISPR/Cas9 protein, or the anti-inflammatory effect of the drug. Both medicines had antibodies against the T cell receptor.<p><p>Cancer patients had lower levels of these antibodies and, in turn, the researchers said, may be at risk for type 2 diabetes.<p><p>However, the researchers said the results could not be used to forecast their clinical effectiveness for patients.<p><p>To test the new therapies on the mice, they took cells from 11 types of lung cancer patients who had received one of the drugs, the other, or both, and then transplanted them into healthy individuals.<p><p>While both drugs had similar activity, one treatment also contained a high number of T cells.<p><p>That could mean the therapy was able to protect against type 2 diabetes - a condition that is estimated to affect around 2.8 million people in China - by providing immunity against T cell activation.<p>']

headline: In a nod to the “bizarre”, NASA has awarded Boeing Co “Humble,” a private spaceflight contractor, $250 million to build a rocket capable of carrying satellites to space for NASA. In addition, Boeing received a $2.5 million gift from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to buy a second rocket built by SpaceX Inc. The program, described as “an opportunity to leverage NASA’s proven expertise in the development of rocket launch systems,” will provide flexibility for companies, including Boeing, SpaceX and others, Boeing spokesman Mike Hurst said. Boeing is an investor in SpaceX and Boeing is a member of NASA’s National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s mission is to ensure the U.S. military is prepared for the eventuality of a manned space station by 2024. NASA also awarded NASA $8.5 billion to purchase four additional Falcon 9 rockets built by Boeing.
