Boeing previously was part of a consortium of four companies to build three new rocket launch systems, called the SpaceX Super Heavy, that will propel the U.S. military and commercial space travelers to and from the International Space Station. SpaceX founder Elon Musk’s space company, Space Exploration Technologies, has said it is developing a space station for the first time. Boeing has a contract to build two Falcon 9 rockets for SpaceX but no plans for one yet. The award, announced on Tuesday at the White House, marks the latest round in NASA’s efforts to build reusable launch vehicles. Since 2012, NASA has awarded Lockheed Martin Corp $7.2 billion to build a separate launch system that can be launched and landed by SpaceX and Boeing. That was the first step for SpaceX and Boeing. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s mission is to provide flexibility for companies to buy rockets developed by SpaceX and Boeing and to develop a commercial launch system bu
Rioting to mark 50th anniversary of aborted baby shower
content: ['<p>MUNICH  - A crowd of mourners gathered outside the Munich hotel where hundreds of baby showergoers made their mark on Thursday night as part of a commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the birth of a baby girl born prematurely on Wednesday.<p><p>The woman, named Maria Schüller, weighed 115 pounds (102 kg) when she was born prematurely on Wednesday in Munich.<p><p>Her mother, Kristina Schüller, 45, the widow of the aborted baby, said her son had been suffering from a variety of diseases including a rare disease called tetrapathycaemia.<p><p>“He was feeling sick,” she said.<p><p>“He is just being very sick with pain.”<p><p>The baby shower, part of the Munich birth registry, commemorates the birth of a girl born prematurely in 1903, the fifth child of a single woman in Europe.<p><p>The last time a baby shower was held there was in 1903 when only the two oldest of three babies were produced.<p><p>But there was only one shower held by all three women in Munich, and there were only two showers for girls in the entire country.<p>']

headline: In what is the first satellite study of a planet formed from an asteroid, scientists create 'giant dust clouds' on Earth to help detect methane
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists on Wednesday released their first global images of an asteroid formed from a large impact event, the first such study of a planet that could harbor liquid methane.<p><p>The discovery was made using a telescope aboard NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft, which is slated to dock with New Mexico on Oct. 3 and close up on a giant, dust clouded world near the planet’s equator on Oct. 5.<p><p>Researchers used the telescope’s three-dimensional laser-tracking equipment to measure the thickness of the gas and dust clouds on the planet, revealing a vast amount of water vapor,’s main characteristic.<p><p>“Giant dust clouds are massive structures of debris floating around,” New Horizons principal investigator Thomas Burke said in a statement.<p><p>“These particles of gas and dust were made up of organic compounds and methane, which were produced by the massive impact,” he said.<p><p>The findings suggest methane, one of the most potent greenhouse gases, is the underlying ingredient for greenhouse gases.<p>']

headline: A key test of SpaceX's new Falcon 9 rocket has failed, with the rocket having to abort after its booster rocket failed in a fiery explosion.
content: ['<p> - A key test of SpaceX’s rocket’s debut vehicle has failed to abort after a booster launch from Florida, according to SpaceX’s engineers and a SpaceX official on Thursday, a milestone test of the company’s new low-cost rocket.<p><p>The failure occurred after the booster booster, a two-stage booster roughly the size of a football, failed in a fiery blast at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.<p><p>The mishap occurred before a scheduled debut flight to the International Space Station would begin on Feb. 12, two weeks before SpaceX begins testing its second-generation Falcon Heavy rocket for the first time, its chief executive, Elon Musk, said.<p><p>SpaceX is working to return to Earth’s orbit for a test launch of its Crew Dragon capsule, a heavy-lift rocket built by Boeing, SpaceX and Lockheed Martin.<p><p>“The initial failure was not caused by a faulty booster system, but an explosive failure at the end of the test sequence,” SpaceX said in a statement.<p><p>“The launch was aborted after three consecutive rocket failure tests,” the company added.<p><p>The rocket-to-be-launched test was designed to carry SpaceX’s first domestically produced test rocket, the company said.<p>']

headline: A new way of measuring gravitational radiation has been invented. Researchers can now test different ways of measuring gravitational radiation in a laboratory using a machine called a pulsed-field tomography (PPT). Using the machine, they can get a better look at the gravitational radiation produced by stars and other celestial bodies. That is, if they can understand how they interact with matter and radiation in the presence of gravity. (bit.ly/35Bq5Hb) (bit.ly/3wXJyMj) (nature.com/3wGp5NT)
content: ['<p> - A new way of measuring gravitational radiation in a laboratory has been invented. Researchers can now test different ways of measuring gravitational radiation in a laboratory using a pulsed- <PAD>  tomography (PPT), using a device called a pulsed-field tomography (PPT). Using a PPPT, researchers can get a better look at the electromagnetic radiation produced by stars and other celestial bodies and measure the relative strength of electromagnetic radiation. For example, a star that is 100,000 times as massive as our sun has a relatively weak magnetic field when subjected to a pulsed-field tomography. Another star has a stronger magnetic field when exposed to a pulsed-field tomography. These tests would prove more accurate. (bit.ly/35q5JzR)<p><p>Pulsed-Field Tomography <p>']

headline: Soyuz's rocket mishap postponed launch of new probe
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia’s Soyuz rocket and its twin-engine crew failed on Friday after an unmanned mission to the International Space Station failed to reach orbit, state news agency RIA cited a Russian news agency as saying.<p><p>The Soyuz 1 mission is to carry humans and 3 Russian cosmonauts to the International Space Station and fly back to Earth, the RIA cited a news release as saying.<p><p>The crew member of the mission was not identified.<p> ']

headline: 'Proteus' star is the first ever to be identified in the Milky Way
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - NASA’s Voyager 2 probe on Thursday spotted a new star at the center of a long-sought “Proteus” galaxy - a galaxy roughly the size of the moon - with an area roughly the size of China about one-tenth the size of New Mexico.<p><p>The newly discovered star is 1.5 billion light years from Earth, dwarfing the Milky Way’s largest galaxy, the Milky Way.<p><p>“Proteus’ may be the first galaxy ever found in the Milky Way, and in particular the first stellar body with this large body of starlight,” said planetary scientist and Voyager 2 principal investigator David Brinkley, a Johns Hopkins University astronomer and study co-author.<p><p>“The fact that the star is at the center of a star-formation galaxy like that of the Milky Way means that we are seeing the first stellar bodies from a distance in the galaxy that we previously did not know existed,” Brinkley said.<p><p>“We had to scramble to find these stars as quickly as we could, but we also have to make some preparations. It’s a little surprising, especially considering the massive amount of energy that we are going to get out of them.”<p>']

headline: Boeing 747 jet crashes in New Mexico; FAA investigation continues
content: ['<p> - Boeing Co’s 747-200ER airplane crashed during a test flight of its newly designed high-altitude space capsule on Wednesday morning, according to an FAA statement, adding further details on the investigation.<p><p>The 747-200ER, named after billionaire entrepreneur Charles Koch, touched down on a dry lake bed at 4:58 a.m. local time (1100 GMT Friday), the statement said.<p><p>Officials said in a statement that the airplane’s flight safety and reliability had been significantly improved, while at the same time Boeing’s test flight was being conducted to ensure aircraft safety and reliability.<p><p>“We are confident that safety is of the utmost importance to Boeing, and we are continuing to monitor the results of the investigation and make every effort to recover the aircraft in a safe and efficient manner,” the statement said.<p><p>The 747-200ER, named after Koch, is being developed by Boeing Co’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), with support from Lockheed Martin Corp and Lockheed Martin.<p><p>The 747-200ER also features the world’s heaviest single-aisle airplane, powered by a twin-turbo jet engine, with up to 16 times the fuel capacity of a 737 MAX.<p><p>A Boeing spokesman did not immediately return a request for comment.<p>']

headline: I want to be a biologist, but I don <PAD>  science. So it is with a grain of salt," she says on a trip to Oxford University in Berkshire in March. She is working on a book on animal life, one she has already shared with her husband. Her work is focusing on how animals benefit from natural selection. Her approach is to find ways to improve their health and well-being without raising ethical issues. She sees her work on the book as a positive change for humanity.
content: ['<p><p>“The question is how we get to know the animals better.”<p><p>The book offers a comprehensive guide to animals, but not a comprehensive history of how animals have evolved, the origins and evolution of traits like hearing and sight, brain size and so on. And, it takes the idea of evolution from an evolutionary concept into a biological concept - something that can be used for research on human health.<p><p>The idea of evolution as something that can be used for good or bad is one of the defining questions of the field - with the science jargon that is often used for it - which is a big step in the right direction.<p><p>I met Lucy in Oxford on a trip to the Oxford Zoo in January when the world’s oldest dinosaur - the Triceratops - was being played in the museum’s open door at the end of a busy day.<p>']

headline: In space, science fiction's greatest mysteries might still be solved
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Astronomers have solved a mystery that has baffled scientists for decades: why humans sometimes leave our solar system to go on Mars.<p><p>The discovery, made by an international team led by U.S. space agency NASA, provided insight into the fate of a key part of the Earth’s atmosphere called SOFTA that helps regulate atmospheric temperatures, sending a signal back to Earth that the planet might be about to become a hot, humid, dry place.<p><p>“This is a major new finding. It’s not just a matter of chance, it’s the laws of physics that make a huge difference,” said Peter Smith, a NASA associate administrator for science and astronomy who led the research published in the journal Nature Astronomy.<p><p>SOFTA is a dense layer of CO2 and methane that is kept in the Earth’s atmosphere to help regulate the atmosphere of the planet.<p><p>The researchers first detected the SOFTA in 2004. In 2009, NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine announced plans to send the probe to Mars in 2022, bringing the total number of people who have visited or stayed on that surface to 1.6 billion people.<p>']

headline: A new breed of black hole scientists says NASA's new Kepler space telescope is one of the brightest ever to be built
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists on Tuesday said they have developed a technology to build artificial light sources at the edge of a new category of extreme supermassive black holes, potentially paving the way for an eventual “supermassive black hole” to take over the universe, sparking a debate over the nature of the universe.<p><p>A new study from the University of California’s Max Planck Institute of Space Physics found that light beams travel in parallel but cannot always pass in the same direction. The results, published in the journal Nature Physics, also pointed to a new theoretical possibility of the black hole and a possible role for gravitational waves in the universe’s dark energy.<p><p>“In general, the question arises whether our black holes can generate the same amount of gravitational radiation and gravitational radiation that we generate on our Milky Way galaxy’s very distant cousins, the Milky Way’s Milky Way’s dwarf planet Milky Way. It is the limit of our knowledge of the fundamental laws of gravity,” said University of California graduate student Shannon Gwynn, lead author of the study published in the journal Nature.<p><p>The research is the latest step toward a fully automated black hole - one in which a star collapses under gravitational influence and stars grow larger to become the nucleus of a star - that can not only destroy star systems but also leave them imploding, potentially destroying planets and potentially life.<p>']

headline: Mammoth spiders, manticores and snakes inhabit coastal deserts, ancient oceans
content: ['<p>Mammoths, black-legged manticores and snakes inhabit coastal deserts, ancient oceans and the desert plain of the Mediterranean Sea.<p><p>Scientists have found fossils of more than 70 different species in Europe’s most comprehensive study on their evolution, revealing their evolutionary origins. The scientists described the discovery at the Palaeoecological Society meeting in Munich on Wednesday.<p><p>The researchers said the findings were a landmark in understanding the complex ecological relationships of various groups of insects, snakes, marine reptiles, birds, mammals, insects, fungi and fungi.<p><p>“Our knowledge of the origin of species and evolution in insects, snakes, marine reptiles, birds and mammals is just a start,” said Dr. Martin Böhme of the Museum of Natural History of Munich, one of the researchers involved in the study. “We also learned from the discovery of manticores that there are many different species of manticores, that these insectivorous snakes and other reptiles inhabited the deserts and seas. This knowledge will aid us in our study of the origins of different groups of manticores and reptiles, and thus, our efforts to understand the evolution of life on Earth.”<p><p>Among the more than 100 species that remain from Europe’s vast Mediterranean region, the most complete were known from southern Italy, southern Spain and northern Italy, the researchers said. Some include snakes, sea lizards and sea spiders. Other groups include crabs and shrimp.<p>']

headline: 'Alien' robot is just a prototype of future robot - scientists
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A humanoid robot called BAIREB, whose name means “alien robot,” is on track to become a key component of the human race in the next decade, leading to challenges such as the feasibility and safety of robotic testing.<p><p>BAIREB, or Biobotter, is an example of a robotic arm being developed that could soon be used in human surgery or as a diagnostic tool. The humanoid-like robot could be used to assess the body of a patient, monitor blood flow and monitor blood chemistry, according to MIT Technology Review.<p><p>The BAIREB was designed with a “super motor” system that could spin autonomously without human intervention. Its design also allowed the robot to work in a controlled manner, unlike traditional robotic arms, which rely on two humans. BAIREB is the same size as a human but uses a four-wheeled machine instead of the four-wheeled system that humans use. The new BAIREB machine, built by Swiss robot startup Nalgene Technologies in Switzerland, is powered by lithium ion batteries instead of a battery.<p><p>BAIREB’s body consists of two bony arms, a small sensor on the sides, and a large bone at the end to absorb shock forces and provide a “bump” on top of the robot’s core to propel it toward a moving chair.<p>']

headline: In a world of digital-fintech giants and emerging companies, big data could shake up consumer choices
content: ['<p> - In the world of big data, analytics could play a key role in shaping consumer preferences in a way that could shake up digital services, new research suggests.<p><p>Data analytics, which can help people track and analyze data across a broad range of industries and industries, can give brands new insights into how consumers and businesses might choose to use technologies, researchers say.<p><p>“Big data is one of the areas where consumer choices and consumer perceptions will change,” said Andrew M. Hennig, director of research and policy at the Center for Automotive Innovation at Columbia University in New York. “As consumers start to be more transparent about their shopping, their grocery shopping is a great place to begin as companies look for new ways to deliver more personalized shopping.”<p><p>Data can give brands information about how consumers use the devices they buy and use them, but it can also help them prioritize what data they need, Hennig said.<p><p>Big data could be instrumental in determining how to best improve consumers’ choices about where to shop and the use of devices, as well as determining how to offer products in a particular market, Hennig said.<p><p>Data analytics could also inform how companies manage and prioritize new products and services that would be offered in their stores and provide insight into consumer preferences, he said.<p>']

headline: U.S. Air Force's Starliner to fly astronauts on U.S. missions from Cape Canaveral
content: ['<p> - A new Air Force Starliner mission will take U.S. astronauts on a voyage to the International Space Station, landing aboard SpaceX’s rocket to ferry them to Florida’s Kennedy Space Center aboard the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s new Crew Dragon spacecraft for the first time.<p><p>Starliner’s mission is scheduled for mid-2019, SpaceX officials said on Friday. Starliner, a privately built capsule, will ferry astronauts on its new Crew Dragon rocket from Kennedy Space Center in Florida.<p><p>NASA astronaut John Glenn, the first U.S. passenger to land on the orbiting outpost since 1969, was to return to Earth in February 2019 aboard a SpaceX Dragon capsule, the company said.<p><p>NASA’s Crew Dragon capsule is expected to launch in mid-2019. U.S. Vice President Mike Pence on Saturday said he would be flying NASA astronauts to space in the next few years.<p><p>The space agency is aiming to send astronauts to the station for the first time in 2023.<p><p>The Starliner crew capsule will carry Glenn on a six-month flight to the space station, SpaceX said, aiming for the orbital port at about the same time as NASA’s space shuttle program is wrapping up.<p><p>NASA originally planned to send astronauts to the space station in February 2022, but NASA postponed the date to 2021.<p>']

headline: Exclusive: How NASA's Mars rover Kepler got its name wrong
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The nickname Kepler, a small, blond humanoid robot that scientists say has turned out to be too complex for humans, came from a botched search for the correct name for its sister, the tiny white dwarf planet Kepler-186.<p><p>It was a mistake, NASA said on Wednesday in a news release, prompting a ferocious criticism from experts and scientists across the world.<p><p>“Kepler’s nickname should be “exactly the right one”, the U.S. space agency said. “Kepler’s name may not have been correct,” it said. “It’s unfortunate that we never got to meet it.”<p><p>It is the second robot made by a joint U.S.-government space agency after NASA’s Apollo missions to the moon and the Voyager probes. The mission, which landed on Mars in 1977, was launched from Florida by the U.S. Air Force in 2009.<p><p>Kepler was initially identified as the female name “Explanitia” in 2012, though an incorrect spelling was discovered in subsequent scans.<p><p>Kepler’s name was not changed until its scientific name was re-examined, a move that was later reversed, the news release said. The name “exactly the right one” was re-examined as well.<p>']

headline: 'Babies don\'t need vaccines' - scientist suggests babies\'s immune systems can 'help fight off disease
content: ["<p>PARIS  - An immune system-building protein called lysosomal protein kinases that are present in the brain and spinal cord is helping doctors treat a host of diseases, researchers said on Monday.<p><p>Researchers at the Max Planck Institute for Brain Research in Germany found that lysosomal protein kinases (LPS) that play a crucial role in regulating the immune system and its ability to fight off infections can actually boost immunity against diseases like HIV and diabetes, said study leader Dr. Thomas Bäck, a postdoctoral fellow at the Max Planck Institute.<p><p>The results of the study - published in the journal Science Advances - are encouraging as the immune system in children is not yet fully developed, he said, explaining why LPS can help protect against HIV and diabetes.<p><p>(This story corrects spelling of “Babies don\\'t need vaccines”)<p><p>“Our studies suggest that we can protect the immune system and regulate the number and size of antibodies in the brain and spinal cord,” Bäck added, adding that further research is needed to fully understand this protein.<p><p>“The brain and spinal cord, as the brain and spinal cord are developing, are not yet fully developed, so these findings can be generalized and may help guide treatment strategies in the future,” Bäck said.<p>"]

headline: China's Chang’e-4 rocket successfully landed on moon; China plans for second manned moon mission
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - China’s space agency said on Thursday its Chang’e-4 rocket successfully landed on the moon on a lunar surface in a test of its rocket technology, paving the way for a lunar mission by the 2030s.<p><p>The Chang’e-4 rocket, launched in November from the Jiuquan space center in the eastern province of Hainan, is China’s third lunar mission after the first launched in 2003 from the same base.<p><p>China’s space agency said it had not yet carried out the second test but the Chang’e-4 mission would be the first of its kind, although it has also done so in the past.<p><p>China, the world’s sixth country, has launched six of its own satellites, including two from U.S. soil.<p><p>In May this year, a Chinese man put on the first lunar landing under the NASA program, successfully landing in the south pole of the moon.<p><p>China has successfully completed two separate launches of its own rockets - the Chang’e-4 and the Chang’e-5 - but is still under development.<p><p>The Chang’e-5, which will carry China’s first manned lunar mission by 2022, is expected to reach the moon’s south pole in the next two years.<p>']

headline: Sino-British robot: Robots might one day walk the moon
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A humanoid robot named Invertebrate Society may one day walk the lunar surface, roboticist Simon Breen told Reuters on Wednesday.<p><p>Breen, who was also a senior researcher at Nasa’s robotic arm Mars rover Curiosity, said advances in technology could help humans achieve the next level of human exploration: a robotic journey to Mars.<p><p>“At the end of the day, you’re going to have to build a robot that can’t walk the moon,” he said. “If we can learn more about how we walk the moon, it’s going to be more possible.”<p><p>Breen said it was likely that people would someday be able to walk on the lunar surface, or even fly there. But that was still far from a reality, and he also predicted there would be “numbers of people” who did not want to do it.<p><p>“We’re living in the 21st century where we’re in a world that’s very artificial,” he said. “We’re seeing more people do it, and the question is, will people be able to do it?”<p><p>Breen, a professor of biology at Cambridge University who co-led the project, said people were starting to look at alternatives to walking on the lunar surface.<p>']

headline: 'Giant asteroid' impacts Ceres, NASA mission aims for “bigger rocks and larger rocks”
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have successfully mapped an asteroid’s surface in what is likely the biggest impact ever to impact Earth, launching an ambitious mission to study the asteroid and potentially make its eventual journey a “giant asteroid”.<p><p>Asteroids are tiny and hard to observe, but in this case they formed at the same time as the Earth’s solar system, and so Ceres, roughly the size of Jupiter, has been dubbed the “biggest asteroid ever found,” according to NASA, whose spacecraft is in orbit around the asteroid.<p><p>Scientists hope to collect sample samples in August or September and plan to submit them to the Planetary Science Institute, or PIRI, which in November would award it a $200 million contract to survey the asteroid.<p><p>The PIRI’s mission is part of a broader effort by NASA to determine if other bodies have formed at the same time, and to better characterize such impacts.<p><p>“I think it’s a big step forward to come,” said James Hansen, the lead scientist on the mission. “If it’s on Mars, it’s very exciting. If it’s not on Venus, it’s very, very unlikely that we could have detected it on Earth.”<p>']

headline: NHL's Markstrom and Montreal Senators play in first NHL playoffs since 1985
content: ['<p>TORONTO  - The San Jose Sharks will host the Nashville Predators on Thursday in the first ever NHL playoffs, the team announced on Friday.<p><p>The Senators’ home opener is played in front of the NHL’s Pacific Divisional All-Star Game at the TD Garden in Toronto on Thursday night.<p><p>The Kings will host the Los Angeles Kings on Sunday in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference Final at Staples Center in Los Angeles.<p><p>“The first time we played in a playoff series with each other on an NHL team was a great start to a new era for the franchise,” coach Dave Bolland said after the series against the Lightning.<p><p>The Kings will also face the New York Islanders in Game 7 at Starfire Arena in Los Angeles on Saturday.<p><p>The Sharks return to their home rink on Saturday in Game 7 against the Los Angeles Kings to open the regular season against the Colorado Avalanche in the first NHL playoffs since 1982.<p><p>“This is an opportunity for us to be in the playoffs,” Bruins captain Patrick Marleau said after the game. “We played very hard and played with the puck. We played on our side. They played on our side.”<p><p>The Sharks play the New York Islanders on Tuesday in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup Playoffs at Starfire Arena.<p>']

headline: In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA's U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980 <PAD> s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite program. (Thomas Johnson/Reuters) In the early 1980s, U.S. satellites were the prime targets for NASA’s U.S. spy satellite prog
UAE astronauts on collision course with'space tourism'
content: ['<p>SAIRO  - One of the crew members on an Australian mission to the International Space Station has passed away, with one of them, a former astronaut, leaving behind a legacy of pioneering missions.<p><p>“It’s a sad day for all of us,” said Sue O’Neill, who commanded the unmanned mission from Canberra at the end of October, at the age of 93.<p><p>O’Neill, a former astronaut and flight instructor at the International Space Station, was the youngest Australian on the station at the time, joining George Hogg, who died in 1992.<p><p>O’Neill became the first person to carry on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft while in orbit around the Earth after leaving the Soviet Union in 2003.<p><p>She has written to her husband and children to express their condolences.<p><p>“All the people who went through this can be touched by the messages that you shared with us today,” she said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Lithium-ion batteries can help boost energy efficiency
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Lithium-ion batteries that produce the highest level of energy efficiency can help reduce power consumption as low as 70% by 2025, researchers said on Tuesday, helping cut electricity demand and saving energy.<p><p>Lithium-ion batteries offer the same high-grade battery material used in lithium-ion batteries to produce more energy efficient than lithium-ion-based batteries, but they produce less energy in contact with the ground, as opposed to having a lower density.<p><p>“We’re here to show that low-tech lithium-ion batteries can be a key part of the battery manufacturing strategy to make it more efficient,” said Chris Russell, a senior scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.<p><p>A lithium-ion battery is usually designed to be high density, with a relatively small battery. The lithium-ion material has been shown to reduce voltage spikes, improve efficiency, and increase the flow rate of electrons.<p><p>“Low density batteries are going to become a more common solution. They need to be more compact, better insulated from heat and moisture, and they need to be smaller than their lithium-ion counterparts to keep the voltage up.”<p><p>“Our findings on low density batteries demonstrate that low density lithium-ion batteries can save power, but they are still a bit too small for a wide range of applications. So, low density batteries have to be tailored to their respective applications,” Russell said.<p> ']

headline: The U.S. Air Force is offering a cheaper alternative to Russia's Soyuz rocket engine that has caused concern among U.S. space agencies.
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Air Force on Monday unveiled a plan to revive a much-maligned, three-stage rocket called Soyuz in an effort to reduce its reliance on Russian engines and reduce dependence on U.S. rockets.<p><p>The program, which will cost nearly $400 million, would cut costs on both Russian and U.S. rocket fuel by 50%, Air Force Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. David Hartsock II said at the annual Air Force Air Force Science and Technology Review hearing.<p><p>The U.S. space agency is developing engines, systems and services that can deliver more thrust to U.S. satellites, but still run much quieter than the engines of other Russian-built Soyuz rockets.<p><p>At the end of 2017, U.S. astronauts “are sitting in their capsule” at the International Space Station, as it orbits around the earth, with their rocket engines at an 80% efficiency.<p><p>A key factor in determining the cost of an alternative is whether it meets a “commonality of technologies” that allow space exploration and are expected to cost less than the engines of existing U.S. rockets.<p><p>The Air Force estimates the cost of a more modern version of its two-stage rocket will be about $5.8 billion.<p>']

headline: U.S. military to send astronaut to Mars - Reuters
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. military plan to send astronaut Neil Armstrong and Doug Hurley to Mars on a mission to bring back samples of the atmosphere of the moon and other key elements of Earth’s atmosphere for research and eventual human exploration, NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine said on Friday.<p><p>“This mission will allow us to make the decision of whether we want to go back to the moon, or if we want to go to Mars,” Bridenstine said in an address at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida.<p><p>“The fact that we can put this rover on Mars, which is the most advanced space vehicle on the planet, will allow us to make those decisions later,” Bridenstine added.<p><p>The U.S. space agency, with the help of a partnership between the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is currently pursuing the first two-person mission to the lunar surface from the Kennedy Space Center, the space agency said. It has been carrying out a number of other missions to the moon.<p><p>“It is a bold plan and will take many months to come to fruition,” Bridenstine said. “NASA is working hard to accomplish this mission as part of the broader mission to return to the moon by 2024.”<p> ']

headline: Boomberg-Roche enters second year of life with a new “biggest shake”
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Billionaire and biotechnology billionaire Tim Bowerman is racing to launch the largest shakeup of the world’s top research university, with a new five-year mission - making it the first private company to launch an accelerated human clinical trial.<p><p>Bowerman’s venture capital firm, Bowerman Capital, said on Tuesday it would merge two of its existing research and development teams to focus its first “biofeedback” trial and subsequent research in a clinical trial into a treatment for cancer.<p><p>But a shakeup at the U.S. research institute underscores a crucial question: Will Bowerman’s startup succeed, or will it fail?<p><p>The U.S. trial will be the first clinical trial of an antibody that can target a specific type of a cancer drug using brain imaging, a technology already popularized by Samsung and other top drugmakers, but which has been plagued by delays and limited quality of data.<p><p>In October, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said it needed to develop an accelerated human clinical trial to show that the antibody therapy works, but it has yet to be launched.<p><p>Bowerman is working with a group of researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder and the University of California, San Diego. The team is aiming for 20 patients.<p>']

headline: U.S. satellite launches more than 10,000 pounds of cargo to space station
content: ['<p>SEATTLE  - The U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) launched a record 15,852 pounds of cargo to space on Thursday, marking the largest launch ever from U.S. soil.<p><p>The payload was delivered by a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, which completed a five-day test flight on Wednesday.<p><p>The rocket lifted off at 1:27 a.m. (1427 GMT) from the Kennedy Space Center, a seven-story (20-meter) space station located at the end of the moon’s orbital highway.<p><p>Launchpad 1 - located just outside Cape Canaveral, Florida - is the fourth U.S. launch of its kind and the second by a SpaceX rocket since 2012 of a cargo ship to the space station from California in July.<p><p>Last October, SpaceX launched a three-day cargo mission from a different space station, carrying around 50 metric tons of supplies for NASA.<p><p>The United States aims to reach its goal of sending astronauts to space by 2024. The current goal is to have humans on board by 2023.<p><p>A previous launch from a NASA-owned craft in 2017 was also delayed.<p><p>Last year, the U.S. launched about 10,000 pounds of cargo from the space station in three different missions.<p> ']

headline: New findings about how animals use carbon-based fuels
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - Researchers have pinpointed when animals use carbon-based fuels to help maintain their diet and regulate their body temperature, the first such evidence to point to carbon-based fuels as an effective and sustainable form of energy in a global market set to explode in value this year.<p><p>Their study, published on Thursday in the journal Current Biology, highlights the crucial role of animal groups in climate change - whether it is as important as the climate in helping to keep the planet's temperature rise or at least reduce emissions, according to a report that was presented to U.S. scientists this week.<p><p>“Our findings confirm the need for more studies, and we are proud to say we are on track for more findings this year,” said Stephanie Schoenberg, lead author of the study and a research associate at Harvard and NASA. “It’s exciting to know what our understanding is about animals that use carbon-based fuels and how that affects the global climate.”<p><p>“However, at the same time, it is important to acknowledge that in global demand for energy - and this requires a sustainable and abundant system for food production and the efficient use of energy,” Schoenberg said.<p><p>The study is part of a larger international effort to understand how animals use carbon-based fuels to reduce their carbon footprint, by comparing their body temperature and heart rate and to assess their energy use.<p>"]

headline: Viral attack disrupts the immune system in patients who have recovered from Ebola
content: ['<p> - The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>Viral attack disrupts the immune system in patients who have recovered from Ebola<p>']

headline: Wondrous 'belly-shatter': new DNA finds links between Antarctic and Antarctic ice
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists say their work on DNA and climate data has opened the way for a “belly-shatter” of genetic material that could potentially lead to breakthroughs in understanding the origins of climate and ice.<p><p>The research, published on Wednesday in the journal Nature Communications, builds on research by scientists from Sweden, Greenland and Antarctica. They analysed genetic material found in the ice cores of 13 ice cores spanning all 12 of Antarctica’s ice sheets and found traces of CO2 during the last ice age that may have been released from deep into the oceans.<p><p>The researchers said the findings help scientists understand how the planet’s environment was shaped in the first place.<p><p>“This work opens the door for new insights into climate, ice formation and other environmental processes,” said planetary scientist and study co-author Sandra Maloney, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature Communications.<p><p>The findings could help scientists better understand how the environment is changing and how ice began to form.<p><p>In a separate study, researchers from Greenland and Antarctica described what their researchers call the “belly-shatter” in Antarctica.<p><p>They found traces of carbon dioxide that may have been released from deep in the oceans during the ice age, indicating the transition from ice sheets to coastal areas.<p>']

headline: A virus that can kill people in cold-blooded animals
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - Scientists have detected a novel genetic variant of the Ebola virus that can infect cold-blooded animals, helping them identify key factors in how the virus infects humans.<p><p>Researchers on Wednesday said the mutation of the Ebola virus that causes the coronavirus in humans is not limited to people, but extends to animals living in captivity or in animal breeding facilities, as well.<p><p>Researchers sequenced all of the mutations - a mutation that allows the virus to infect cells in the blood - in two of the six wild chimpanzees residing at the California Department of Laboratory Animals’ laboratory in Los Angeles.<p><p>They identified eight of 17 genes called "RK2" that play a role in the Ebola virus’s spread across the continent, with four in Africa and one in the Americas.<p><p>The research was published in the journal Cell.<p><p>The new variant affects about one-half of the virus in humans and is a major concern for experts on disease transmission, the virus.<p><p>That’s a big deal because it’s important to determine how the pandemic affected the animal kingdom, said University of California, Davis professor of virology and head of the branch of virology who led the study.<p>']

headline: Titanic moon returns home as our own planet
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Astronomers have announced the birth of our own planet, Titan, located in a relatively new and unique manner that will eventually change the history of life beyond Earth.<p><p>Titan is the third planet of the asteroid belt, after Mercury and Venus, with the moon also being the third planet orbiting our sun.<p><p>Titan is one of the three rocky planets in our solar system, with our planet Saturn and its moon Titan being the others. The sun orbits the moon and Titan is a close relative of both.<p><p>“Titan has a planet-sized core, so it orbits Saturn. This is a planet with a core larger than Neptune. Titan orbits Titan’s core,” said planetary scientist Paul Tippit of the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington. “We think that this is a planet that belongs to our solar system and to the ancient solar system and that it’s located in this very unique location.”<p><p>The new planet, known as an icesativ-3 or IS-3, orbits roughly twice the distance from Earth to the sun and possesses a composition of helium.<p><p>Its name means “The Giant Planet” in Greek, which means “The Giant Planet in Greek.”<p><p>The new planet, roughly 8,800 miles (13,200 km) in diameter, has a diameter of about 8,800 miles (13,200 km), Tippit added.']

headline: Iris, now available in Europe
content: ['<p>HARARE  - The world’s top science adviser to the EU said he would make the most of a crisis in the European Union if a new anti-vaccine law would be introduced, adding there was a need to protect people’s personal health.<p><p>Speaking to Reuters, Ioannis Dimitriou, the head of scientific adviser to the European Commission, said the EU needed to work in a "new way" to protect children and their families from dangerous variants of the virus that causes the illness pertussis and other respiratory diseases.<p><p>“I think there is a fundamental conflict of interest with the European Commission to push forward anti-vaccine legislation in the new framework,” Dimitriou said on the sidelines of an annual meeting of the EU Commission, the bloc’s headquarters.<p><p>“If there is an amendment to the legislation, then the EU is ready to take it,” he said. “But,” added Dimitriou, “the anti-vaccine legislation is a very strong piece of legislation,” adding the Commission was also considering drafting new anti-vaccine legislation.<p><p>The Commission and Dimitriou have since been criticized by U.S. President Donald Trump, who has accused the bloc of meddling in a U.S. election. Trump on Friday directed the U.S. National Institutes of Health to investigate possible links between vaccines and autism.<p>']

headline: Pilgrims from around the world travel across the cosmos to find out what they were like in the past. Now you can join them. (This May 22 story corrects typo in paragraph 2)
content: ['<p>(This May 22 story corrects typo in paragraph 2)<p><p>The following is a brief roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the origins of life, its development, and whether or not life may have been created.<p><p>The researchers behind this study were able to demonstrate that the existence of the Neanderthals may have been more common than previously thought.<p><p>“It was definitely more common among us than we might initially think,” said lead author Thomas Gough of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology and the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany. “Now we can study the Neanderthals and determine if there were differences in their appearance.”<p><p>The researchers used a mathematical algorithm that measures a square of the square of an inch (cm) in length. They then used the same algorithms to calculate the distance to the nearest light emission source that fits the model of how life evolved.<p><p>“This was not the simple calculation that scientists would have made for Neanderthals,” said study co-author and professor of evolutionary genetics at University College London, John O’Connor. “This was the most comprehensive statistical approach we could use.”<p>']

headline: Exclusive: NASA's Pluto mission fails because Pluto is too small to reach Earth
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A crucial instrument in NASA’s plan to explore the moon and Mars to map the evolution of life on other worlds could be stuck at the wrong planet, as the space agency is weighing whether to postpone the next manned mission to send back detailed maps of Pluto’s immense size.<p><p>The mission was due to launch on Oct. 20, 2018 from Florida’s Cape Canaveral Air Force Station and was to blast off on SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket from Florida’s Cape Canaveral. It will attempt to land in mid-July.<p><p>The next crewed mission is due in 2020 to return more than 3,000 images, detailed as Pluto, in roughly 20,000 years, of the planet’s interior, researchers said on Wednesday.<p><p>“We’ve known for years that the only way we’d be able to reach Pluto is if we’re not sending a mission to Pluto at the correct time,” said David Niekrodt, a planetary scientist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California. “But because this spacecraft is so large, the time constraints are even greater,” Niekrodt added.<p><p>A previous planned visit to Pluto would have been postponed two years and cost $20 million, the new research team said.<p>']

headline: Jurassic Period paleontologist suggests asteroid impact may have contributed to extinction
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have pinpointed the origins of a series of events, including a key asteroid impact 66 million years ago that wiped out a large chunk of Earth’s crust and may have helped set off the extinction of some dinosaurs 66 million years ago.<p><p>“The asteroid impact that we have found may have contributed to extinction in part to dinosaurs’ extinction 66 million years ago,” said Michael Soderbergh, a planetary scientist at the University of California, Berkeley and co-author of the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>“However, the asteroid impact is unlikely to have been a catastrophic event,” Soderbergh added. “The impacts we find in the asteroid impact are much more complex and complex, so we cannot rule out this impact as the contributing factor,” he said.<p> ']

headline: China to study 'black hole' theory
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China and its space agency will conduct a feasibility study in 2019 on a black hole, state media reported on Sunday, citing the National Astronomical Office.<p><p>The feasibility study would be conducted in collaboration with the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the paper said.<p><p>The research project is known as “Binary black hole theory” as it covers a number of topics.<p><p>China has said it plans to send scientists to study the “black hole” as soon as 2024, but Beijing has rejected any such idea as the theory holds promise for space travel.<p><p>While some scholars consider the theory to be “incomplete” and the possibility of a black hole being created more or less inexorably in the future, the Chinese government has also denied it being a real possibility.<p><p>“Black holes are thought to possess some of the characteristics of black holes,” said Nanyang Prefecture Astronomy Observatory chief Liu Yuhua.<p><p>The theoretical theory, however, has not been tested with real-world experiments.<p><p>Liu said China would conduct research in the scientific field to help its space exploration program and make advances in the field, while also conducting other research such as studying the gravitational pull of distant objects.<p>']

headline: China's space program ramps up test runs
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China on Tuesday embarked on a high-profile test of its space program to make it more competitive for U.S. firms in a potential satellite navigation boom, stepping up its program to rival the United States in the search for lunar material and other valuable science supplies.<p><p>The Chang’e-4 lunar probe - or “Jade of Mars” - is due to enter orbit for a two-year, $74 million launch in late 2017, according to state media.<p><p>China has used its space program to launch satellites from other nations to help develop the nation’s space technologies.<p><p>President Xi Jinping has called for space exploration to increase by 2 billion yuan ($2.5 billion) per year, with the aim of increasing that by at least 2 billion yuan annually.<p><p>China has invested $20 billion to develop its own satellite navigation system and has already launched its own communications satellite in orbit.<p><p>China has been developing its own satellite navigation system, known as the Chang’e-5 Global Positioning System, to rival the United States.<p><p>“Jade of Mars is a critical part of China’s strategy of creating a global navigation platform to provide information from space to the benefit of mankind,” a statement by China Aerospace Science and Technology Corp (CASC) said.<p>']

headline: Marlins clinch first playoff appearance since 1918
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The New York Yankees defeated the Washington Senators 6-3 on Sunday to clinch a return to the playoffs for the first time since 1914 and the first time since 1918 when they beat Washington 6-2 in Game 2.<p><p>“This game is a great reminder of how we want to go,” Washington coach Bruce Allen said.<p><p>Allen leads the Canadian National Team in goals and tied a franchise record with four, including an 18-save shutout against Pittsburgh on Wednesday.<p><p>“This was a wonderful game, especially for the Senators,” Washington captain and third baseman Jonathan Toews said. “They came out with their backs to the wall. They played very well and we were able to take those 2-1 lead-ins in the ninth and win the game in our best fashion.”<p><p>The Washington Senators, ranked No. 1 in the Pacific Division, had won seven of nine in the seventh.<p><p>But their goaltender James Paxton (upper body) suffered a lower-body injury during an 8-2 loss to the Boston Bruins in Game 3 on Friday and Allen missed the second period with the knee ligament injury.<p><p>The Senators, whose record was 2-6 after the break, have won four straight and will face a Boston team that has won four of their past five.<p>']

headline: Fossilized fossils of a giant bird from southern Europe were found in caves in central France on Thursday. They show that the bird - called Oryza crickets - inhabited an area called Neopta in what is now Bavaria and had a number of traits, including traits likely to have belonged to a member of the phalanx. (bit.ly/2K4RgGZ)’s researchers said. (bit.ly/3EyMtZ)
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A fossil found in Belgium shows that a giant bird from southern Europe inhabited a site believed to be called Neopta, and scientists are hoping that its skeleton might hold clues to the origins of modern birds.<p><p>The study, published on Thursday in Nature, was the first to show that the bird, which weighed about 40 kilograms (63 lbs), lived in a cave near the town of Neopta. That cave was well-preserved with bird-eating vegetation including trees, shrubs and mosses.<p><p>“Neopta was a land and sea ecosystem with lush grasses and trees growing as well as a wide variety of plants, animals and people,” said study co-author Hubert Bremner of the Natural History Museum in Munich in Germany, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature Ecology & Evolution.<p><p>“This means that Neopta is a bit like modern birds in this respect and might be closely related to the modern birds of North America, although the size difference is small,” Bremner added.<p>']

headline: Losing weight may help combat obesity, according to study
content: ['<p> - A study of 939 obese adults who underwent weight loss therapy found they were 50 percent less likely to develop type 2 diabetes, according to new research.<p><p>The findings are based on a group of 11 young adults who had lost weight as a result of their treatment for obesity. They reported their results online on Tuesday in The Cochrane Library of Science.<p><p>Only one in 15 people with diabetes are healthy, which means that losing weight can be a potentially life-threatening condition for many.<p><p>Researchers reported in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition that the treatment had minimal benefit for people with type 2 diabetes. Other studies have suggested that more weight loss could be achieved by increasing the volume of fat on fat cells that are in the fat cell wall, a process called liposuction.<p><p>The researchers noted that only about 30 percent of patients with type 2 diabetes lost weight, compared with 40 percent of those without diabetes. The rate of diabetes in those with diabetes was highest in men and lowest in women.<p><p>“We need to make changes to our approach, to look at the type of fat that we have, and the treatment itself,” said study co-author Dr. Richard Hildebrandt of the Wellcome Trust, lead author of the study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition. “It needs to be well understood how well the therapy works in terms of clinical relevance.”<p>']

headline: U.S. plans to launch second satellite from U.S. soil
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States plans to launch its second satellite from U.S. soil on Wednesday, a program meant to help astronauts launch U.S. astronauts into space, U.S. astronaut Scott Kelly said, as he prepared for a test launch of an Orion space probe in the coming weeks.<p><p>“We’re going to test the waters,” Kelly, chief executive officer of Boeing Co BA.N, said in an interview with Reuters Television, referring to a test program called NASA’s Artemis program that would ultimately be the last human spaceflight attempt to reach the moon.<p><p>“It’s a test flight, it’s a test flight, and hopefully we can get to it.”<p><p>Kelly told Reuters that NASA has a “very good schedule” for a launch of the first satellite of its kind and called for its first unmanned mission.<p><p>Kelly said the Orion, which will have a crew of five and a navigation system similar to the one used on Apollo 15, is a prime candidate for a launch.<p><p>“Once the next set of sensors are in place, it’s going to take us another three years to launch the first spacecraft and get into orbit,” he said.<p>']

headline: Fairytale: How a whale got the name 'Chowder'
content: ['<p>PALMATY, Fla.  - A sea monster called Chowder is believed to have been a sea urchin called “Chowder” that lived off Florida’s southeastern coast.<p><p>A video obtained by Gulf News Service on Friday shows the whale with its mouth covered in fur in the form of a red bar.<p><p>Chowder, known in the Pacific Ocean as Chunko, lived in shallow waters off the coast of South Florida from 1925 until 1947. It was probably not a whale at first, but a shrew or a seal, with a mouth that looked like it belonged to a sea monster.<p><p>Scientists believe it may have been a sea monster named for “Chunko” who lived in shallow waters off Florida’s southern coast in the late 19th century.<p><p>Scientists first spotted it in 2010 during a deep dive off Key West in Gulf of Mexico.<p><p>The whale, believed to have lived in a pod or shell-like structure, apparently swallowed food that contained bacteria.<p><p>“It’s amazing to think about it, and the fact that it’s a whale shows you how great of a creature it is. It’s so much fun to explore the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico,” said Richard Nelms, a conservation biologist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) who helped develop the Chowder research.']

headline: 'Soyuz' plane crash shows the mystery of space-faring spacecraft
content: ['<p>SEATTLE  - An unmanned Russian Soyuz spacecraft that crashed into the surface of the moon on Thursday was the first confirmed evidence of a Russian space probe in orbit around the moon since 2011, but scientists said they were too soon to know the cause.<p><p>“As of now, we don’t know where the spacecraft entered the moon. Until we get a better understanding of how it landed, we will not know the cause,” said Dmitry Rogozin, associate director of the U.S. space agency NASA, referring to the mysterious crash that happened at a U.S. outpost in 2013.<p><p>“The risk here is that this spacecraft is going to slip back into the moon by tomorrow morning,” Rogozin said in an interview in the Siberian city of Yakutia.<p><p>A probe named Sochilov-2 blasted off from Baikonur in Kazakhstan on Wednesday carrying a probe to study a complex ring of lunar rock and soil that supports an array of spacecraft designed to be used to study Earth’s outer atmosphere and beyond.<p><p>NASA confirmed the accident to Reuters on Thursday but did not disclose the identity of the Russian spacecraft, citing safety concerns over debris from previous collisions.<p><p>The space agency did not say whether Russia’s Soyuz-FG spacecraft entered the lunar surface but did say it was “in good condition,” according to the agency’s website.<p>']

headline: New York City firefighters are putting on their masks and masks of terror after 'bizarre' encounter with animal
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - New York City firefighters on Thursday were on lockdown following an incident on fire where a mysterious animal appeared to be devouring its mask.<p><p>At around 9:30 a.m. (0530 GMT), a fire truck with eight crew members was sent flying over a structure just north of the World Trade Center, prompting the firefighters to “swiftly” try to break up the animal’s fire.<p><p>One firefighter told CNN, “We had to push through and everything went as planned, but it just seemed like it was burning all over the place.”<p><p>The rescue attempt went awry, as the beast’s mask and maskless mask came apart as a firefighter tried to maneuver it into the vehicle.<p><p>A fire truck with seven firefighters was sent flying to help and soon the fire department was forced to evacuate the site, which had become one of the busiest in the city.<p><p>Mayor Bill de Blasio said at a news conference that firefighters would remain on the scene until emergency responders are able to establish what caused the animal’s collapse, saying it had been "bizarre" and "unusual" for the firefighters to experience such a behavior.<p><p>De Blasio said the incident was not a “bizarre” animal attack and he condemned the city’s response as “extremely irresponsible and unprofessional.”']

headline: Jailer: 'Tiny robot' is a 'new toy' for scientists
content: ['<p>PARIS  - A robotic arm made from nanobots may help scientists harness data from human cells to design new ways of treating tumors, scientists said on Tuesday.<p><p>The robotic arm was designed to test new techniques for treating cancer patients.<p><p>In experiments involving a large crowd of patients at the French-funded National Cancer Institute in Paris, the arm will stimulate tissue from tumours on the inside of the eye and other organs using a combination of electromagnetic fields, biological signals and robotic arms.<p><p>The robot will then be activated in two stages. In one stage, the robot will inject blood into the tumor and inject a cytokine that will help the patient heal.<p><p>“The tumor is already healing,” said Charles Bourlaut, head of the French Institute of Medical Sciences. “We are getting an indication from one patient that their immune system is responding to the treatment.”<p><p>Bourlaut said the study is being conducted in an area where advances in cell technology have made it possible to generate more sensitive and precise cancer diagnoses.<p><p>“We are not only trying to understand the cancer, but to know more about how cancer is treating people,” he added.<p>']

headline: 'We need a new world': A study reveals how to unlock secrets of Mars
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A new study on the Martian landscape reveals ways to explore the world’s most advanced environments and how to make them safer, more pleasant and, importantly, more livable.<p><p>Using software developed by NASA and the European Space Agency, the researchers conducted a survey of Mars and Mars using the TerraSat system, an orbiting radio telescope set in the Martian sky that orbits the Earth and collects data from nearby planets.<p><p>In the survey, Mars and Earth are roughly the same size.<p><p>“There are lots of similarities in Mars, the climate, the landscape and what we saw. And so we are able to find out whether Mars is safe, whether the environment is livable,” study leader Andrea DiMicco told Reuters in an interview. “It’s important for us to understand how ecosystems function.”<p><p>The researchers conducted a series of analyses over the course of the summer of 2016 and 2017 on the landscape at nearly 13,500 square miles (18,000 square km) of Martian terrain, including forests, rivers, grasslands and marshes.<p><p>“We do some pretty fascinating things to find out what ecosystems work, how they change, how they react,” said DiMicco, who helped lead the research published in the journal Scientific Reports.<p>']

headline: LONDON/JAKARTA, Pakistan  - Pakistan’s foreign ministry on Wednesday condemned Pakistan’s recent drone strikes on civilian targets in Yemen, saying Pakistan should take immediate steps to counter those operations, according to a statement released on the ministry’s website. “I call on all countries concerned to refrain from use of any form of aerial weaponization to support Yemen’s security, peace and stability,” the statement said. “To ensure that the armed forces refrain from violating their civilian sovereignty and the sovereignty of Yemen, the Security Council on Tuesday adopted an emergency resolution on civilian self-defense directed at preventing civilian casualties, including by targeting aircraft and drones, and airspace in which any civilian is located.” “I call on all countries in Yemen to refrain from use of any kind of aerial weaponization.” “All civilian casualties are caused by air attacks, and the United States and the United Arab Emirates will take immediate and swift measures to protect civilian populations and the civilian population from further civilian casualties.” (bit.ly/2Qb0aSQ) (GRAPHIC) (All rights reserved) (All rights uncapped) (All rights uncapped) (All rights in re-use at the request of third parties) (All rights in reproduction without prior permission) (All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author, see COP23; All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author) (All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author; reproduction without prior request) (All rights uncapped) (All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author; reproduction without prior request of the author; reproduction without prior request) (All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author) (All rights in reproduction without prior request of the author, see COP22; Reproduction without prior request of the author, see COP19) (All rights uncapped) (All rights
Habitat change in India's desert may have roots in climate change
content: ['<p>BENGALURU  - As temperatures rise in parts of India that have been spared severe drought, a new type of tropical cyclones may have played a role in changing the climate, according to research published on Tuesday.<p><p>The researchers found that changes in the rate of precipitation and moisture in the Andhra Pradesh, Punjab and Haryana region, which experienced drought in 2016, were likely caused by different aspects of climate. Climate change may have been driven by a combination of factors including higher rates of monsoons, low rainfall, wetter conditions, and drought, the researchers said.<p><p>The researchers said that global warming - primarily greenhouse gases - could have been responsible for increasing the risk of desertification.<p><p>Moderate rainfall patterns such as in the eastern plains in the southern regions and the Punjab region in central India were associated with higher desertification. The findings also suggested the role of changes in water chemistry, which may be a contributing factor to changes in the climate, the researchers said.<p><p>Higher temperatures also may have contributed to higher frequency of desertification, with more intense rains, the researchers said.<p><p>There are currently no official research studies of the impact of climate change on desertification.<p><p>“Our observations suggest that climate change has a negative impact on desertification in this country,” said Thomas Eisenegger of University College London and lead author of the research published in the journal Science Advances.<p>']

headline: Satellite study shows rare genetic variation in African apes' forebrain
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have found that ape forebrain cells possess unique genetic variation that may explain how the mammalian forebrain functions, in a study that sheds light on how apes may have developed their forebrain traits.<p><p>Researchers from Oxford University and the Wellcome Trust said on Thursday that genes that may contribute to mental health and cognitive function in apes appear to be associated with the cognitive functions of human forebrain cells that are often associated with intelligence and ability, suggesting that the two regions may share common genetic markers.<p><p>“It is now clear that a number of important genetic differences could be contributing to the performance of forebrain cells in apes, and this would be the first evidence of behavioral, neurobiological or biological linkages between apes and humans,” said James Meehan, a study co-author and associate professor at Oxford’s School of Veterinary Medicine.<p><p>The scientists, led by Professor Tim Hogg and Professor Mark Wilson of Oxford’s School of Social Sciences, used computer simulations and an algorithm to examine the genomes of 22 African apes with and without precognition and 16 humans, as well as the genomes of two more ape species and four humans.<p><p>By examining the genomes of more than 200 forebrain cells, including the human and chimpanzee forebrain, the team found a genetic correlation between a common biological and psychological trait, a trait called the trait-likelihood ratio (TFR) or TSR.<p>']

headline: Videos: Russia says it plans to launch a satellite into space
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia said on Thursday it plans to launch a satellite into space next year, a step that will allow it to conduct scientific research without interference and pave the way for commercial applications.<p><p>The launch would be the first step in a project by Russia to send a satellite into space and establish an independent space program, according to its defence ministry spokesman, Dmitry Rogozin.<p><p>Russia was aiming to develop its space program through the creation of a space station and other space-related activities in space.<p> ']

headline: Wales to launch new flagship in 2019
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Wales will launch its flagship flagship to make its mark on the world stage by 2020, the Wales Football Federation said on Thursday.<p><p>The move follows a decade-long dispute over the viability of Wales’s bid to become a member of the World Cup 2022.<p><p>In June 2018, the League told the European Court of Justice that it considered the Wales football federation had no standing to pursue membership.<p><p>The 2018-19 World Cup was Wales’s bid to become a member of the 2022 football competition.<p><p>The Wales Football Federation said in May 2018 that it had no objection to Wales participating in the 2022 World Cup in the same way as England and Russia.<p><p>The new flagship model will be the Wales Football Federation (WFC), which will operate out of Wales’s London headquarters.<p><p>It will feature a four-storey, high-tech stadium, seven high-speed charging stations and two indoor courts.<p> ']

headline: Sloppy watermelon will never die, scientists say
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists are beginning to wonder if some types of watermelon can survive as long as the leaves of its parents.<p><p>Scientists have identified seven major cellular elements that help grow a new type of plant - a root structure that helps maintain a plant’s water content and growth during a drought.<p><p>Watermelon cells are part of the normal plant cell wall, but scientists are looking for more watermelon with different types, which could provide insight into their biology and how they grow.<p><p>The study, published this week in the Journal of Plant Sciences, analyzed the cells of 6,600 watermelon plant-eaters, from nine different species including Brazil’s rainforest-fossilized forest, Canada’s red, yellow and blue, and the European rainforest, as well as the wild and cultivated fruit trees of the Himalayas.<p><p>“Watermelon plants have a relatively small volume, but are very similar to a regular leaf plant. They have many of the same structures as regular plant leaves, so they live under very different circumstances,” said study co-author Michael Cammage, professor of entomology at the University of Alberta in Canada.<p><p>The findings suggest that some watermelon plants produce more water than usual, and can grow on more than one type of watermelon, with more watermelon plants being water-dense than regular plant leaves, Cammage said.<p>']

headline: Dennis Labadink, a NASA astronaut who parachutes into space from the International Space Station, had one last chance at “a lifetime” with NASA’s Crew Dragon capsule early Thursday morning, completing the long journey to the International Space Station from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Labadink, whose flight from space last week ended after two hours, did not return to earth.
content: ['<p><p>A NASA spokesman could not immediately be reached for comment on the capsule’s fate. “Dennis Labadink is doing great work on the ISS,” said Bob Behnken, a spokesman for NASA. “As we all know, NASA astronauts stay on the moon and it takes a lot of training and hard work.”<p><p>“The capsule is very stable in space, and we were very happy that the team at NASA and the U.S. government flew the mission safely.”<p><p>“It was a fantastic experience,” Labadink, a 25-year veteran of NASA’s International Space Station, told reporters. “There’s no stopping anybody. It’s a great journey.”<p><p>NASA astronaut Christina Koch, a retired astronaut and former astronaut, accompanied Labadink to the space station.<p><p>Koch also flew back to Earth aboard the International Space Station on Wednesday.<p>']

headline: Russia plans new satellite to offer early warning of Earth
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia’s space agency plans a new satellite to help protect the Earth and warn it of Earth-threatening radiation and weather changes that could lead to catastrophic global warming.<p><p>The Russia-made Falcon 9 rocket, called FAB-9B, will carry the Russian-made S-IoP instrument into orbit for scientists to view, transmit and analyze information about weather and temperature changes before taking it to space.<p><p>The satellite will be launched on Wednesday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.<p> ']

headline: Karen Jones, who died in August, died in April at the age of 84.
content: ['<p>(This story corrects date of death to April 18, 1983)<p><p>Karen Jones, a biographer, died in March at the age of 84.<p><p>Jones, who spent most of her life in the shadow of the South African president Nelson Mandela, died at the age of 82 in a mysterious accident at a hospice in London, where she had been interned. Her obituary on Saturday read: “I remember her courage in challenging all forms of oppression and her love of music.”<p><p>Jones died at her home in central London in April 1985, aged 77. The funeral service was held at a special coronavirus centre at Holyhead Cemetery.<p><p>The British broadcaster ITV said it had given Jones “access to the private home” of a former intern, David Ketcham, who had died two years earlier. ITV had broadcast her biographical report in a programme broadcast on air in 1983.<p><p>“We understand that some of her stories are more complex and her stories have a lot more weight in them,” it said in a statement.<p><p>Jones’ biography, commissioned by the government in 1984, shows how she became involved in the Black Panthers in the 1950s and early 1960s, the Black Panthers working in Australia, the Australian Defence Force, the Army and in the construction industry.<p>']

headline: Watson may have discovered another type of moon goddess - Pluto
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - As NASA searches for extraterrestrial life on the moon, scientists are looking for a new type of moon goddess, one that could be called “a goddess of the underworld” or “a goddess of pleasure” for the wealthy.<p><p>A study published on Wednesday suggests that Pluto’s surface may have been populated by moons, goddesses and goddesses of pleasure like Saturn, Neptune and Jupiter.<p><p>“We were able to discover some other types of moon goddesses on Pluto,” said astronomer and study co-author Paul Toussaint of the Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research (MPI) in Germany. “The more interesting possibility that there was moon goddesses is that they were very important, but this was not the case.”<p><p>“The most exciting question that we are going to be studying for the rest of the years is whether this is actually a goddess of pleasure, or ‘a goddess of pleasure,” Toussaint added.<p><p>“We know that there are moon goddesses - goddesses of pleasure - but how and where they got their names is a mystery,” he added.<p><p>“It turns out that these goddesses, rather than goddesses of pleasure, are very useful to the poor in their daily lives,” Toussaint said.<p> ']

headline: SpaceX rocket failure causes delays in SpaceX's planned launch of its Crew Dragon test rocket
content: ['<p> - SpaceX has completed the first of two test launches this week of its Crew Dragon rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida, a launch company spokeswoman said.<p><p>A second SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, planned for a mid-air dropoff from Florida’s Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on Sunday, has also completed its first test flight, a series of launch operations that SpaceX said was aimed at reducing the need for rocket launches by shortening time periods during launches.<p><p>The unmanned Atlas V rocket will provide the Crew Dragon with a payload of about $400 million and fly toward a crewed mission on Monday.<p><p>SpaceX has struggled to deliver its first crewed flight of its Dragon mission since the company made emergency landing in August amid multiple launch mishaps.<p><p>The company said the Crew Dragon booster is capable of delivering about five times the payload capacity of its Crew Dragon, compared to its current combined launch order of more than two dozen satellites.<p><p>SpaceX plans to launch the Crew Dragon with the company’s next-generation Crew Dragon launch vehicle to support NASA’s broader Crew Dragon program in the coming months.<p> ']

headline: Lithium-137 isotope detection in cancer vaccines shows promise in emerging cancer drugs
content: ['<p> - The detection of the first high-altitude atomic bomb with high-altitude atomic radiation has dramatically improved the safety and efficacy of many experimental cancer vaccines, scientists said on Thursday.<p><p>The detection of the first high-altitude atomic bomb with high-altitude atomic radiation in humans’s blood, cancer vaccine developers said on Thursday, showed promise.<p><p>“It’s not only a boon for safety, it’s also a blessing to show that vaccines are effective,” said Stephanie Krikorian, a radiology professor at the University of New Hampshire who led the research published in the journal JAMA Oncology.<p><p>The detection of this isotope in plasma from cancer patients reduced the risk of death by 90 percent versus placebo, she said. The dose-limiting effect of high doses reduced the need for chemotherapy, which can damage cells, and reduced the need for transfusions, and thus lower the risk of serious adverse events, such as death.<p><p>“The main thing is that plasma from cancer patients is extremely high,” Krikorian said. “This is one of the major advantages of vaccines. They are high in vitamin C and high in antibodies,” she added.<p>']

headline: UAE unveils new moon orbiter, first to take off and land on the moon
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - The United Arab Emirates is developing a lunar orbiter that could prove a valuable tool for U.S. national security in the long-term, the UAE’s Defense Ministry said on Monday, after the United States and Russia signed an international contract to build the unmanned spacecraft.<p><p>The UAE-backed project would enable U.S. military forces to study and land on the lunar surface and would also be able to conduct space missions beyond Earth’s orbit, it said.<p><p>“This orbital system will provide a much needed understanding of the moon’s geology and mineral resources, as well as explore future uses for resources,” it said.<p><p>The UAE-funded project, dubbed Emiratium-Masa, will be developed jointly with NASA, which is working to develop a lunar surface research station.<p><p>But there are other challenges and hurdles to develop a lunar orbiter like this one. The UAE space program will face an array of bureaucratic obstacles and bureaucratic hurdles in the short term, including a lack of budget and funding.<p><p>The UAE has set a goal to return human beings to the moon within the next decade. It estimates there will be between two to five human missions on the moon over the next 20 years.<p><p>The UAE has been preparing to resume moon rovers for decades, a project under which U.S. contractors and governments will invest in the project.']

headline: Bizarre mushroom fossils found at Colorado cave site
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have unearthed an extraordinary find at the Colorado Springs Cave, in southeast Colorado, revealing an ancient aquatic life that lived before humans stepped foot on it, the largest living animal alive today.<p><p>Researchers from the Colorado Springs Museum of Natural History say fossils from a series of underwater burrows have indicated a mysterious aquatic life that probably lived in the cave site at one of the largest in North America.<p><p>They believe it was the first large-bodied group of invertebrate plant and animal life that walked through the cave’s interior, burrowing underground to form aquatic prey like mushrooms, crabs and even other aquatic animals.<p><p>“From these fossils we have some insight into life in this cave,” said University of Colorado paleontologist and study co-author Daniel Farrar, who led the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>The discovery was made on Oct. 7, about five years after the cave was discovered.<p><p>“It is perhaps the most complete piece of evidence for life on land,” said paleontologist and study co-author Mike O’Neill of the University of Maryland Museum of Natural History. “For me this is a fantastic example of how invertebrates evolved from the land and moved in and out of the land, so they can thrive in this vast cave system.”<p>']

headline: U.S. scientists discover traces of Neanderthals in Florida fossils
