content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists in Florida have found DNA traces of Neanderthals in fossils of Florida’s iconic freshwater ecosystem that dates back over 300,000 years, revealing important insights into early human migration patterns and human origins.<p><p>Scientists from Florida’s Smithsonian Institution and Florida State University said they have unearthed evidence of human evolution by a group of roughly 2,800 individuals, most of them Homo sapiens, who first appeared roughly 700,000 years ago during a global extinction roughly the same time as the rise of the species Homo sapiens.<p><p>The new research, published on Wednesday, underscores advances in knowledge about human origins and their role in shaping the global landscape.<p><p>Researchers said the team’s work underscores how early human evolutionary forces were shaped by local climate, water availability, habitat fragmentation and hunting, as well as the intergenerational spread of multiple genetic diseases.<p><p>Among the DNA traces, researchers found traces of a new type of Neanderthal gene that has recently been linked to changes in the genome of the species Homo sapiens. The researchers said that this could be used as a tool to identify a species and its genes.<p><p>The study provides insight into how early humans interacted with the environment, through hunting and other behaviors, from building human settlements and hunting sites around the world and through the emergence of new civilizations.<p>']

headline: Virus found in chickens raised on meat
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A Russian-backed researcher has identified the cause of the chicken’s disease and warned that the meat may contain a “very high concentration” of the virus, the Russian news agency RIA reported on Monday.<p><p>The virus was discovered in the feces of the chickens raised on meat.<p><p>The researcher said he had been unable to replicate it in the samples collected, which he said was “unprecedented and unprecedented”.<p><p>“In the past, the most frequently reported case of chicken disease has been a small case of fever and diarrhoea. The poultry raised in Russia are much more well known.”<p><p>A spokesman for the International Center of Infectious Diseases, which tracks outbreaks of the infectious disease, said its team had received information that “we believe is derived from a small sample.”<p><p>The infection was most likely caused by the virus, he added.<p><p>“Vaccination efforts should be coordinated against infections caused by this new strain of the virus,” he said.<p> ']

headline: It's an exotic sight.
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - The most exotic sight imaginable - the most exotic looking thing that is possible in the universe - is an exotic looking bird.<p><p>The most exotic looking thing that is possible is an alien being.<p><p>“All animals are not just the same. All animals are different,” said Michael Krikorian, director of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California, who examined the redish-orange, partially covered, reddish-brown bird at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida.<p><p>“We’re looking at the largest bird, a big, muscular, feathered red-livered redneck, that has gone extinct billions of years ago. This is an example of a species in motion that is not seen,” Krikorian told Reuters.<p><p>“And it’s the most exotic sight in the universe.”<p><p>Scientists from Britain’s University of Bristol and the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich have spotted the creature as it traveled a distance of 4,300 miles (6,000 km) from Earth - the distance that an astronaut might travel on a long mission.<p><p>The creature has never been seen alive, but scientists said it is unusual for an animal to go extinct like this - in the solar system.<p>']

headline: Discovery of gene used in 'fossilized animals’ reveals potential for human medicine
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A gene that has been linked to cancer and other illnesses may be providing a new cancer therapy that can treat it better, scientists have said, in a breakthrough in the field of studying cancer.<p><p>A gene called rhodopsin II, a variant of the gene responsible for the production of rhodopsin II, was discovered in late June in a lab at the Wellcome Trust, a non-profit medical research laboratory in London.<p><p>Rhodopsin II is an important new treatment for the disease type BRAIN-CoV-2, which attacks an immune cell known as lymphocytes.<p><p>“It is really a big advance,” said Dr. Thomas P. Palfrey of the Wellcome Trust’s Institute for Human Genomics, lead author of the research published this week in the journal Nature. “We are seeing a very broad spectrum of potential treatment options. This is a paradigm shift.”<p><p>“There are many types of cancer,” Palfrey added. “One example that I would like to remind you of is HIV-1.”<p><p>The human rhodopsin II gene was named after the fictional animal that made up parts of a long line of dinosaurs known as platypus, a mythical creature with four legs.<p>']

headline: U.S. space agency to launch crewed rover for first time since launch
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is aiming for the first manned rover on a surface inhabited by microbial life - with its first unmanned mission in April 2021 - on a first mission to Mars by 2022, U.S. space agencies have announced.<p><p>NASA is aiming for a rover on the surface of the Red Planet called Curiosity to explore what it calls a "red planet" for clues about the origins of life.<p><p>The U.S. Mars rover Curiosity is set to drill into the rocky interior of the far side of the Red Planet’s icy desert known as Gale Crater, mapping deposits of rock, sediments, minerals and water, the agency said on Monday.<p><p>“This rover mission will characterize a deep Martian surface and the origins of life,” NASA spokeswoman Caitlin McDonough said.<p><p>Curiosity’s first mission is scheduled for late 2019, though a Mars rover mission is expected in 2021, NASA said.<p><p>Curiosity is due to arrive at its destination in mid-2023. It will be the first U.S. rover to be deployed on Mars by a crewed mission, joining a crew of other space agencies including the U.S. Air Force and the European Space Agency.<p><p>NASA plans to send its next crewed mission in 2022 after it leaves Earth’s orbit and lands on Mars.<p>']

headline: The final piece of the puzzle: The'space station' could be a hoax?
content: ['<p> - Scientists have uncovered the final piece of a mystery about the fate of the long-vanished human capsule NASA launched into orbit on Jan. 20, 1961.<p><p>A six-story-tall (16,000-meter) underground tube is about the size of a car-sized loaf of bread stacked high on top of an orbiting laboratory. It is packed with equipment and its fate is an open question.<p><p>“We don’t know whether it’s actually a hoax, or whether there are people out there that can make it happen,” said NASA deputy administrator Mike Gerst, speaking to a briefing this week on a project known as ‘space station’s final piece of the puzzle.<p><p>“There is one thing that we do not know. There is a big thing that we’ve been hoping for for for a long time.”<p><p>Space station engineers did not want to be interviewed by Reuters, but Gerst said the agency has been “very proactive in ensuring our safety,” and the final piece could be anything from the time capsule was deployed to the time of its historic launch.<p><p>The capsule, dubbed the ‘Final One”, is the first-ever unmanned mission to carry humans from U.S. soil to space.<p>']

headline: I hope you can find a way to keep them alive
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - As a father of two, the wife of a U.S. Army captain and a scientist, President Donald Trump said Monday he would soon appoint three astronauts to the International Space Station.<p><p>They would fly on board the rocket developed by Elon Musk’s SpaceX, which is building a lunar base in the United States and would carry astronauts to the moon and eventually the moon.<p><p>The United States space agency NASA is developing an interplanetary test facility at the Kennedy Space Center, orbiting the moon for about five years.<p><p>NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine called for an international commission to investigate the project, calling it “an example of the kind of partnership NASA is seeking to create to help us achieve our mission.”<p><p>The commission would study “what is the best way to keep the crew safe from potentially hostile spacecraft on the Moon,” Bridenstine told reporters at NASA headquarters in Washington. “We have three permanent ‘crews’ on the ISS,” he said.<p><p>The next lunar launch, at 3:17 a.m. ET, is planned for 2018 and is expected to cost $2.5 billion.<p><p>Bridenstine said his commission would not be tasked with building a new lunar outpost, but rather would focus on whether to develop a crewed mission to the moon.<p>']

headline: The U.S. Space Force is getting the green light to build a rocket capable of lofting astronaut missions to space — and NASA says it has approved a $100 million mission. That $100 million, or roughly $20 million per flight for the space agency, should raise competition for funds and ultimately make the Space Force a viable stepping stone to eventually landing humans on Mars. (bit.ly/2rR6QhU) (bit.ly/2rR6QhU) (This story corrects paragraph 3 to clarify that NASA received approval in July to use NASA’s Orion rocket.) (The original story corrects paragraph 4 to indicate the funding request was approved in July) (bit.ly/2r6qMhN; refs. 6, 8) (This story corrects paragraph 2 to clarify that NASA received approval in July to use NASA’s Orion rocket’s propulsion system, not in June) (This story corrects paragraph 3 to emphasize that NASA received a NASA Falcon 9 flight authorization in July) (This story corrects paragraph 3 to indicate that NASA received an April 2020 launch authorization from NASA in July) (This story corrects paragraph 3 to note that NASA received a July 2020 launch authorization from NASA and this June was in early February). -Katherine Gerstmann, Spaceflight Now, a member of the Washington-based mission development panel, originally posted this story. -Liz Rosenberg, who co-edited this story, wrote a comment. -(This story corrects paragraph 3 to emphasize that NASA approved the Space Force proposal in July and is considering an April 2019 launch authorization, not June 2019, and that NASA will receive an April 2019 launch authorization) -This story corrects paragraph 4 to note that NASA approved NASA’s Oct. 30 Orion launch authorization last month and also that NASA now receives an April 2019 launch authorization from NASA and should be in early March 2019 to participate
Scientists map blood vessels in Chinese heart muscle, lung
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - An international team of scientists has mapped the blood vessels of three Chinese heart muscle muscles in a pioneering study to find treatments for heart failure.<p><p>The study, published on Monday in The Lancet Cardiovascular Review, is the first to quantify blood flow from the central nervous system, one of the main arteries that carries oxygen to the heart.<p><p>“Our findings... were surprising given that the main arteries are made of a very thin layer that doesn’t carry sufficient oxygen, and there are only four available arteries with sufficient oxygen,” said Thomas Wu of the University of Portsmouth, lead author of the study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology.<p><p>The research involved 23 healthy volunteers, including a male patient who suffered from heart failure, who received the treatments “for a chronic condition like congestive heart failure, myocardial infarction or strokes”.<p><p>“We discovered that many of these arteries were not sufficient for circulation, and in particular, we found some of the arteries that are in the heart-reversing areas of the artery wall that contain enough of the blood to carry oxygen.”<p><p>The researchers compared the vascular network of the nine muscles to the network of arteries that supply the lungs and other organs that support the heart’s pump.<p><p>“We found the arteries’ vascular networks to be very thin,” Wu said.<p>']

headline: A rare find in Mongolia shows 'dark' moon
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Three large and roughly circular brown bodies were spotted on a vast undisturbed cave at the southwestern Tibetan plateau, which had a population of about 300,000 until scientists began mapping the place in April.<p><p>The bodies were found along with rocks, ceramic fragments, mummies and other objects buried in rock and soil in the complex at the western end of the plateau known as Hsiangkazakhtana, scientists said on Thursday.<p><p>Researchers traced the movements of the moon to a meteorite that struck the cave, but the precise location of the moon’s location remained unknown until now, scientists said.<p><p>The moon is about 4.7 billion years old, so scientists are uncertain when the moon first appeared in Earth’s solar system, a planet formed roughly 230 million years ago.<p><p>“The presence of the moon’s surface is a fascinating, unique and very important finding. It is one of the three mysterious objects in the ancient world and is one of the most difficult objects in the world,” U.S. space agency NASA’s Mars Exploration Rovers said in a statement.<p><p>The two bodies were located just east of a narrow river crossing the ancient capital Kailash, located in an area known as Palkina Lake. The Palkina lake is considered one of the driest in the world, contributing to global warming.<p>']

headline: NASA launches SpaceX's first orbital launch vehicle - 'SpaceX Dragonfly'
content: ['<p> - The NASA’s first orbital launch vehicle from SpaceX, the private rocket company of Elon Musk, will blast off at 6:02 a.m. Eastern time (0042 GMT Saturday) carrying two Crew Dragon capsules from the International Space Station into space for the first time.<p><p>The vehicle is the largest capsule ever built by SpaceX, serving the U.S. military and astronauts for nearly 50 years.<p><p>SpaceX originally planned to fly the two capsules into orbit for NASA’s Starlink constellation, a network of orbiting satellites that helps launch astronauts from American soil.<p><p>But during Sunday’s launch, it was pushed back from the schedule, to 6:02 a.m. Eastern time (0142 GMT Sunday) and a later postponement was made because the mission was being moved to Monday.<p><p>SpaceX’s new Dragonfly capsule is expected to reach its final test orbit around the moon’s equator in a two-month mission. It will join four other SpaceX Crew Dragon launches, from the first launch planned in March 2019.<p><p>The Starlink constellation is designed to relay communications between the orbiting Earth and space stations in real time. It is used to relay scientific data into orbit in a controlled space environment.<p><p>The new Dragonfly will then fly to the International Space Station and back into orbit before docking with NASA’s Long March 5 rocket.<p>']

headline: Chinese scientists discover mysterious moon crater
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese scientists have discovered an enigmatic crater carved into the moon’s surface with the help of four Russian cosmonauts - creating the first direct images of an artificial moon crater that could prove pivotal to solving the mysteries of the mysterious Moon’s origins.<p><p>The moon is believed to have formed at the end of the Permian Period, beginning with the Last Glacial Maximum, about 700 million years ago, and plunging into the surface.<p><p>The discovery, in China’s Yellow Sea off China’s East China Sea, comes at a time when China, Russia and other nations are racing to find a way to halt the accelerated development of Earth’s orbital space in the 21st century.<p><p>Chinese satellite imagery and videos have shown an ancient crater resembling the one seen on NASA’s Long March 5 probe, which was launched into space in 2011 and found no evidence of a crater on its surface.<p><p>The team behind the newly identified crater, led by former NASA deputy administrator Mike Hopkins, have said that they obtained the crater’s name, its size and the location of a lava field in the crater, as well as images of a lava flow at its base, which they said indicates that it may have been shaped like a river.<p><p>“The location and origin of the crater’s lava flow, as well as the volcanic activity surrounding it, should provide more insight into its history and its origins,” Hopkins said at a news briefing in April.']

headline: 'Black helicopters' are in the sky for NASA's first space flight
content: ['<p>MELBOURNE  - NASA’s first space flight using a private aircraft will send a drone back to the International Space Station next month, the agency said on Friday, an aircraft it said it would call a “black helicopter”, an acronym for a type of helicopter.<p><p>The United Arab Emirates’ F-15 fighter jet is expected to make its debut flight in the next month, following on from the first flight of the Boeing 747 jetliner this month.<p><p>“The F-15 is a Black helicopter, so it’s not exactly a fly-by,” Boeing Chief Executive Doug Hague told reporters, adding that in the short term the aircraft will provide data-mining and surveillance capabilities for the Air Force.<p><p>“The aircraft is in a very good condition. It’s powered by an optimized propeller,” Hague added.<p><p>A spokesman for SpaceX, the space company behind the first manned flight to the space station, declined to comment further.<p><p>The F-15s name means “spaceplane for the future.” It will follow in the footsteps of Boeing’s 747 and Boeing 737 MAX, with its first manned mission planned for mid-2020.<p>']

headline: 'Cave-dweller' with a heart disease may help find treatment options for COVID-19
content: ['<p> - Scientists on Tuesday described a cave-dweller with a rare genetic condition dubbed COVID-19 that causes the disease known as the "cave-dweller."<p><p>Researchers said the patient, named Abdusah Abdoul-Wazir in the journal Nature, had a heart defect caused by an abnormal immune response that caused her to produce fewer red blood cells, and therefore died at the age of 62. She developed COVID-19 antibodies, suggesting she might benefit from therapy.<p><p>“We think this person’s symptoms were quite unexpected,” said University of Illinois biologist and co-author Alex Griesemer. “We believe they might have something to do with her having an abnormal immune system. We think her symptoms are probably very strong.”<p><p>Abdoul-Wazir had a heart problem, but also has a kidney problem, which means she may need hospitalization.<p><p>Researchers found more than 60 genes that could explain Abdoul-Wazir’s illness - a group of genes, called COVID-19 genes, that are also seen in a range of different animals, including humans.<p><p>The researchers identified these genes as being associated with a protein called SHOCK2 that causes the abnormal heart response.<p>']

headline: Boeing Mars rover Curiosity gets first taste of the moon
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A first-ever mission to the Moon has sent back images of the surface of the moon’s interior that will help scientists better understand the deep ocean and the origins of life on Mars, a top NASA official said on Thursday.<p><p>Missions such as the lander Curiosity to the far side of the moon will help scientists understand what makes the moon a refuge for microbial life, scientists said on Thursday, a milestone in human exploration of the deep interior of Mars.<p><p>Scientists expect to collect such images within the next decade to help develop a clearer picture of the moon’s composition.<p><p>“This is the first opportunity that the European Space Agency (ESA) has to provide a fresh and scientific assessment on the moon,” said Thomas Braben, the former head of NASA’s planetary science division. “If we can get the data we want from that mission, then it will really inform our work on human exploration of Mars.”<p><p>The first images of the moon’s surface, obtained by the Viking spacecraft on Jan. 11, are set to be transmitted to the ground by the rover’s communications relay.<p><p>“The landing has been completed successfully by the rover. The landing pad is about 90 miles (150 km) from the moon and has been open for about 10 days,” NASA said in a statement.<p>']

headline: Sydney Swans v Perth Scorchers, 2-0 to win league title
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - A 2-0 victory over Perth Scorchers on Friday night sent the Swans and their opponents to a record-setting fifth-straight match for the league title, despite the Hawks notching a remarkable 2-1 victory over the Scorchers.<p><p>Melbourne v. Sydney Swans: A<p><p>“We played great today and we’ll get a chance to win the league title,” coach Greg Inglis said in the first of four-straight matches that ended with a 2-1 victory.<p><p>Sydney Swans head coach Nick Perkel said the team had demonstrated resilience and composure and the Swans were determined to take their game to the next level.<p><p>“There were times where we ran the ball, which was an area we didn’t really play,” he said.<p><p>Perkel had been asked about the importance of resilience as well as what it takes to win a big match against a team as strong as Perth.<p><p>“This was a huge victory for us.”<p><p>“It’s hard to be a manager at the age when you have got a big season,” he said. “But we’ll try and do well.”<p> ']

headline: Coyote: A scientist gets a ride on SpaceX's Crew Dragon
content: ['<p>SEATTLE  - A researcher at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California got on a Friday morning flight to collect samples for analysis after being forced to watch a NASA unmanned test flight last week.<p><p>A NASA crew member, Patrick Morin, began the journey from Los Angeles to a remote SpaceX launch pad on Friday in the first of two uncrewed missions of the “Dragon” unmanned test flight.<p><p>NASA said the SpaceX-built Dragon capsule, dubbed Crew Dragon B, performed well into the night as it carried out its initial flight testing in May.<p><p>SpaceX, founded by billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk and SpaceX founder and chief executive officer Jeff Bezos, has said it has no plans to replace its U.S. astronaut program.<p><p>NASA’s uncrewed test flight of the Dragon capsule, dubbed “Dragon Return”, touched down just off the coast of California at 9:27 a.m. EST (0627 GMT) en route to the International Space Station.<p><p>A NASA inspector saw a large hole in the center of the capsule’s upper section where its upper section would have to be replaced.<p><p>Crew Dragon’s crew capsule is designed to carry up to three astronauts to the station for scientific and safety checks, while landing missions for future crewed missions.<p>']

headline: A robot named Blue Marble has made it back on Earth: NASA
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A robot named Blue Marble has made it back on Earth, just one step closer to the origins of life on another planet, scientists said on Thursday, paving the way for the exploration of another planet whose gravity allows it to travel farther than any human has ever done before.<p><p>Bridging the gap between our first glimpse of the dawn of the solar system at the dawn of the age of man and another time when there was still light at the dawn of time, Blue Marble is a small robotic vehicle named after the biblical story of the golden calf called Ananias, whose name means “messiah”.<p><p>Scientists on Thursday described Blue Marble’s arrival at the International Space Station at about 5:45 p.m. EST (0745 GMT) on Monday in a scientific briefing in Washington.<p><p>The arrival came as NASA is racing to develop its next-generation crewed mission to Mars, with Blue Marble likely to carry humans back to the moon, and potentially to Mars in the next decade. NASA’s Orion crew capsule, a robot designed to navigate a deep space environment, will send robotic Mars probes to the Red Planet in a series of robotic missions beginning in 2023.<p><p>Blue Marble’s design - a four-meter tall humanoid robot with three arms like miniature golf clubs - was unveiled at the 2017 American Astronautical Congress in Washington by Elon Musk’s SpaceX, with NASA chief Jim Bridenstine aboard.<p>']

headline: SpaceX rocket carrying NASA astronaut back to Earth in 2019; launch pad slated for early 2019
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Two SpaceX rockets carrying NASA astronauts to the International Space Station are due to blast off in the first full-scale test of a human spaceflight mission this year, according to the company’s chief executive officer Elon Musk, who was in Washington to attend NASA’s annual summit on Thursday.<p><p>Musk also announced a planned test launch for NASA’s Orion space station later this year to test NASA’s technologies on humans in space.<p><p>“I think in the months ahead we will take it a little farther,” Musk told reporters at the White House’s National Security Council in Washington.<p><p>He said the test launch would be “the most successful launch of any sort in our history.”<p><p>A second rocket carrying astronaut Anne McClain and NASA’s Jim Bridenstine is due to blast off in May 2019 and undergo several test flights aboard one of the company’s Starliner capsules.<p><p>“It’s going to be a really special event, a demonstration of a technology that is proving its value, and we are excited about it,” said Musk, who was not present at Thursday’s event but was in Washington, D.C. “and looking forward to working with NASA and NASA at this new chapter in American space history.”<p><p>He did not elaborate.<p>']

headline: Joint German Aerospace Co
content: ['<p>German Aerospace Co’s (JAXA.PA) JAXA-FG.DE and United Launch Alliance’s (ULA.N) rocket, B-1, soared into space on Sunday evening carrying two Germanwings astronauts on a journey that has been the most extensive of any commercial launch to date.<p><p>The Boeing 747-400ER rocket that delivered the payload, which jettisoned into space at 1:48 p.m. local time (1149 GMT), reached its intended orbit approximately 90 minutes after liftoff and exploded in mid-air, flying 1,200 miles (1,250 km) above the North Pole, a video released by German television showed.<p><p>The two-man crew, who were from the Netherlands, Czech Republic, Canada and South Africa, landed safely on the ice at a height of just over 1,200 feet (200 meters), the broadcaster WDR reported.<p><p>The two-man mission will provide the German military with critical hardware to carry out its first manned orbital flight this year, part of a larger program to send U.S. astronauts to Mars in a decade, the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.<p><p>The JAXA-FG.DE payload is the most advanced of the JAXA-FG.DE-JAXA rocket’s two payloads on the German military’s Artemis program, or Artemis for short.<p><p>JAXA said it has recovered a number of fragments in the mission.']

headline: Ebola epidemic: A global perspective
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The WHO has issued a global advisory on the Ebola epidemic to advise on the treatment and containment of new coronavirus cases, urging countries to be transparent with the risks and take actions to ensure public health.<p><p>WHO Director General Jan Woollner said the report on Ebola, the virus that causes the illness, was crucial to the development of the WHO mission in Africa.<p><p>“This report, from the top of the world, will help us build a better, more stable, more integrated and resilient global health system,” Woollner told a news briefing in London.<p><p>He said the report’s authors said the number of new cases and the risk of infection with new coronavirus strains were "increasing".<p><p>“There’s more work to do to try to keep up with the pace of the epidemic and reduce the risk of further transmission,” he said.<p><p>“WHO Director General Jan Woollner reaffirms the importance of the international community to share the latest information.”<p> ']

headline: Exoplanets, too far from Earth to be hospitable for life, might be even closer to us
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Astronomers on Wednesday said they have detected the first planetary bodies orbiting distant stars that are not as close to Earth as previously thought, finding unexpected surprises in their approach to distant worlds.<p><p>Using data gathered by NASA’s Kepler space telescope, the scientists identified a group of 633 gas-mass planets, located about a tenth the mass of our sun, orbiting roughly 25,000 times closer to the sun than previously known. The planets had a diameter of about 90 percent of our solar system’s surface.<p><p>“These worlds were not planets much closer to the sun than previously thought,” said planetary scientist and study co-author Scott Sheppard, of the California Institute of Technology.<p><p>“It is interesting to look at how we could help put that information to use in this field,” Sheppard added.<p><p>“We found that they were at least 10 percent closer to the sun than previously thought. We were also able to observe a pattern in their atmosphere that makes them even more hospitable for life,” she said.<p><p>Most planetary systems are rocky, irradiated by the Sun, and they undergo many types of atmospheric and star formation. The planets that orbit them were almost all made of water ice, possibly of water or ammonia.<p>']

headline: One in six people believe suicide is a gateway drug; new study suggests it is safe
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Americans are less likely to use a safer drug to combat addiction than people in other developed countries, new research suggests.<p><p>The report, published on Wednesday in the journal Current Biology, suggests that people are less likely to use a safer substance and more likely to use opioids if they have a history of substance abuse problems, a finding that may be significant given the high rate of substance use disorders in many developed nations.<p><p>The results, published by the University of California, Berkeley researchers and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, show that in several countries, including Indonesia, India, Singapore, Thailand and Zimbabwe, more people are now using drugs like opioids than they used to - and fewer are taking them.<p><p>Researchers analyzed data on 4,600 people from eight countries studied by the journal Current Biology, including the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, Ireland and the United States.<p><p>The researchers found that only two countries (U.S., the UK and Thailand) have taken measures to reduce the use of opioids in the public and private sectors. In Britain, people were more likely to use opioids compared to non-opioid users. However, while people were more likely to use opioids with depression than with addiction, the prevalence rate was higher among people in these countries and lower among people in other developed nations.<p>']

headline: Insects in the womb may provide clues to human origins
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Insects may have provided biological pathways for human evolution, as scientists have identified an important evolutionary pathway that paved the way for our species.<p><p>This evolutionary pathway may have resulted in early mammalian domestication, as a group of insects evolved in South Asia, with human relatives in North America, Asia, Europe, Australasia and Africa, the scientists said on Thursday.<p><p>Human ancestors spread throughout Asia and Africa, but the evolutionary origins of other insect species are still unclear.<p><p>Researchers examined DNA from 33,914 insects that lived at various stages of human evolution, including those that made the leap from insects to birds and other birds in the mid-twentieth century. Insects were associated with early human migrations to the Americas and Asia, the researchers said. Insects also provided routes for food production in South America, Africa and Australasia.<p><p>They found that a large number of insect species that had ancestral lineage with humans - including birds - differed from those that shared evolutionary lineage with insects. Birds are one of the few insect groups to have been widely distributed across the globe, with up to two-thirds of them currently living in the Americas.<p><p>The researchers said that human populations spread from North America to South America, Asia, Europe and Africa, but they are unclear if there was genetic material shared with other insects such as the moths or beetles. Some insects - echidnas and horned spiders - have been associated with migrations to North America, Africa, Asia and South America.']

headline: UAE's first female astronaut landed safely in space
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - The first female astronaut from the United Arab Emirates landed safely in space after being deployed from a mission to the International Space Station on Thursday, state news agency SANA said.<p><p>The Emirates’ first woman astronaut from the Arab Emirates landed safely in space after completing an extended mission to the space station.<p><p>A French astronaut on the mission had to undergo mechanical rehabilitation and her parachute failure, SANA said.<p><p>A Russian cosmonaut will remain on the space station and fly back to earth after a two-year stay.<p> ']

headline: Caveat: Scientists have discovered a'secret sauce' that turns fat into energy
content: ['<p>CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  - Scientists have found a secret sauce that turns fat into energy and is poised to help cut the COVID-19 epidemic, according to scientists who have found an ingredient they say is the key to solving the global pandemic.<p><p>The ingredients in the new sauce were discovered in Chile’s Chicas Cave last week, but were not tested in humans before being synthesized and isolated by an international team of researchers.<p><p>“Our study shows that this essential fatty acid, called fat, can be made to play a very important role in our metabolism. In fact, when we consume our natural products, we burn these products to make energy,” said University of Naples chemist Peter Bochez, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature Communications.<p><p>The researchers analyzed the fat’s composition by comparing it with the chemical composition of plant protein from chickens to cows and concluded that it possesses “the necessary hydroxy acids that activate cell membrane proteins to release carbon dioxide as energy.”<p><p>This is important because the “secret sauce” - made by burning the fats in the fat and then combining that with an amino acid in the fat to make the energy in the sauce - gives COVID-19 survivors energy even as they have died, according to the researchers.<p><p>“Our findings provide new molecular tools to study the natural processes by which fat plays a key role,” Bochez added.']

headline: Jody McParland, a senior adviser on national security, said: "We are very concerned about China's growing military presence and activities in the East China Sea. China will continue to challenge its claims in this issue. “China should be able to use all options to protect its citizens and property from any threat and we urge all parties to refrain from actions inconsistent with international law and common sense”. “This is especially important for U.S. policy as the United States remains committed to the defense of China,” McParland added. “China’s provocative actions in the East China Sea threaten regional peace and stability.” “The United States has committed itself to a robust global defense posture and we urge China and all other claimants to take immediate, serious, and measured steps to ensure the stability and security of their maritime claims,” he said. (bit.ly/2hcO7w9) (L4NTk5p) (The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to track down the virus) (reut.rs/32JbXg4) (bit.ly/2fV0Ww4p) (story updated at 8: <PAD> ; first published on Monday) (story also on Monday) (bit.ly/35Bh3JjL) (story on Monday) (story on Monday) - China launches second anti-satellite missile system in test at U.S. space station, U.S. official says
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China launched its second anti-satellite missile system on Saturday, state media said, citing U.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, and the defense ministry. (reut.rs/3b3mXqh)']

headline: Cases of cancer-causing proteins in plasma of patients with high risk of bladder cancer, study finds
content: ['<p> - Patients with high risk of bladder cancer have higher levels of genes associated with a spike in cell proliferation and cytokines called IL-12, according to a large study of plasma samples from 2,300 patients in eight U.S. states.<p><p>The findings, published on Thursday in the journal Cancer, could help identify treatments for bladder cancer that might block or delay their progression, said study leader Dr. John Loh, a UCSF associate professor of biochemistry and molecular biology and director of the Center for the Study of Blood Cancer.<p><p>“These findings provide insight into potential therapeutic targets for bladder cancer,” he said. “Blood cancer patients with high risk of cancer need not only to be encouraged to seek care but also to have the most complete knowledge of these proteins.”<p><p>The study involved more than 3,000 bladder cancer patients and involved over 2,500 donors, who received high-dose chemotherapy. Plasma levels of IL-12 were significantly lower in the patients with high levels of the genes, which are known to cause cancer.<p><p>“Cell proliferation and cytokines are a key component of the immune system” in bladder cancer, said Dr. Loh, who led the research.<p><p>“Our findings suggest that cancer patients who are on chemotherapy should receive immunosuppressive chemotherapy, especially when they first start to experience symptoms of lymphoblastic disease,” he added.<p> ']

headline: In South Africa, Ebola virus causes fever
content: ['<p> - The first case reported in South Africa of a new strain of the Ebola virus has infected a nurse in the southern city of Belize, officials said on Tuesday, the latest in a wave of infections in a country plagued by a deadly outbreak.<p><p>The case was discovered about 300 kilometers (186 miles) east of the capital and a nurse reported sick, the South African Health Ministry said.<p><p>The outbreak began on Oct. 3 with more than 400 cases reported, according to a WHO report and the WHO has set up a network to monitor the epidemic.<p><p>Since then, there have been 2,072 confirmed cases, up from 3,740 in the same period last year, according to data from the National Ebola Response Force.<p><p>(This story has been refiled to clarify that the Ebola virus strain in question is different from the previous one in which it has been identified as the first case. The strain has been identified as a second case.)<p><p>Officials said they could not confirm the case with experts but acknowledged that some individuals may still be at risk.<p><p>“We are really disappointed,” an official from the Ebola ward at the Ebola Research Institute told Reuters on Monday. “We can only be very happy,” he added, referring to a doctor who treated more than 600 people and received more than $80 million in hospital treatment.<p>']

headline: Scientists study the origins of the universe and propose new theories
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have found a way to create an artificial genetic material that may someday help explain our universe and ultimately human existence, using a computer program to analyze data.<p><p>Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, said on Tuesday that using an algorithm they developed to simulate a new type of genetic material called a Crispr RNA, they were able to identify a candidate gene that would explain how the universe began.<p><p>The researchers, led by Albert Einstein’s physicist Stephen Hawking, used a series of computer simulations to try to figure out how the first stars formed and the emergence of the first planets.<p><p>“Given a number of constraints,” they wrote, “a computer could not find the “best candidate” for a genetic material. The method’s success required finding a new candidate by using an existing approach.”<p><p>The first step in determining a suitable candidate is by looking for potential “transformation factors”, or “transients” that can be detected through studies of the genetic material.<p><p>“Using Crispr RNA, we found a candidate gene, which we then identified as a ‘crisp RNA.”<p><p>This new genetic material was able to identify this gene within two weeks of its discovery, they said.<p>']

headline: A new type of gene was discovered in the brains of birds of prey
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists on Wednesday unveiled the first-ever evidence that genes involved in regulating the body’s energy metabolism, the body’s crucial organ to carrying oxygen, have been discovered in birds.<p><p>“We believe this work represents the first time that gene-driven behavior is directly related to an individual’s health,” said University of Maryland neurobiologist and lead author Dr. James Clark, whose work was published in the journal Scientific Reports.<p><p>The findings were described in the journal Nature.<p><p>The study follows a similar study in which scientists sequenced thousands of gene expression samples of the cerebral cortex of nine species including the gull, the blackberry, the crow and the swallower.<p><p>Researchers compared their findings to previously known “cell-wide transcriptomes” of genes, proteins that regulate the body’s cellular processes. The data, published in the journal Cell, may aid in deciphering the origins of energy metabolism in the bird species.<p><p>“What we discovered is the first direct evidence of genes being associated with health,” Clark said, “which represents a pivotal advance.”<p><p>The study represents a first step toward understanding how cells influence one another’s health and immune systems.<p>']

headline: Soyuz space capsule and crew spared in accident
content: ['<p>ZURICH  - Two people have been hurt in a Russian Soyuz rocket failure and a second crewmate on board has been injured in a fiery launch that sent a Russian cosmonaut to safety, Russian news agencies reported on Friday.<p><p>The accident occurred about 4.35 p.m. local time (0045 GMT) in the northwestern city of Kazan, the Roscosmos space agency said in a statement.<p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin had ordered the return of the crew of the Soyuz MS-18 spacecraft due to a scheduled landing in Kazakhstan in mid-November.<p><p>The space probe, which was supposed to be carrying a crew of five to six, and a Soyuz booster was supposed to rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS) on Jan. 21.<p><p>But a dramatic abort occurred on Saturday in a crucial stage of the mission, the news agency RIA cited Russian cosmonaut Oleg Turchin as saying.<p><p>The crew members - a third named Anatoly Gennadyev, and two crew members - were taken to the International Space Station for further treatment, the statement said.<p><p>Russian and international space agencies said on Friday their agencies had received a report from the ISS describing the incident.<p><p>The Roscosmos said the third man in the accident had suffered a puncture to the rocket’s side and that it was "still early days".']

headline: U.S. to launch satellites for Mars mission in coming years
content: ['<p> - NASA will launch its next-generation Mars mission to the Red Planet in the first half of 2020, following in the footsteps of Elon Musk’s SpaceX and the U.S. space agency NASA.<p><p>The U.S. space agency announced a milestone launch in July 2017 for its U.S. Mars mission, marking a major step forward for NASA.<p><p>NASA is targeting the Red Planet for its first-ever deep-space probe mission in 2021, when its Crew Dragon capsule will blast off from Florida to deliver science data on a mission to Mars and return to Earth in 2023.<p><p>The agency said it expects the first Mars probe to launch in the next five to six years.<p><p>SpaceX is expected to launch a rocket in 2021 from a Cape Canaveral, Florida, launchpad. NASA will carry out a similar test program to NASA’s Deep Impact landing mission in 2022.<p><p>The U.S. launch window will extend until 2021, NASA officials told Reuters.<p><p>NASA is working with private space firms to develop reusable spacecraft capable of delivering U.S. soil-based science and space science payloads to the planet, which NASA previously dubbed Mars.<p><p>NASA’s Mars exploration is one of the key challenges facing humanity today as it looks toward the early days of its mission to Mars, as Musk promises NASA will find ways to bring Americans back on Mars.']

headline: The first black hole is actually a white hole and not a black hole - NASA
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Astronomers have detected a star from a faraway star in the constellation of Sagittarius A and scientists said on Friday they believe it is an object called a black hole.<p><p>The research, announced in a commentary, confirmed earlier observations of a black hole called Sagittarius A, which orbits a gas giant roughly the size of Jupiter and appears to be a black hole.<p><p>Its light emission and gravitational interactions are light years away from the sun.<p><p>Researchers noted that the object is a roughly 10,000 light years from our sun and that there is evidence it may be a black hole and, as such, we do not know for sure what it might be.<p><p>The researchers said the star is not the one observed by the Hubble Space Telescope, a team led by astronomer Robert A. Armstrong of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It is only the second-ever black hole to be discovered, discovered using the Hubble Space Telescope in 2012.<p><p>A black hole is one of three supermassive black holes that reside in the dark side of the universe. These stars can weigh as much as 100,000 times more than the Sun and are the objects of immense gravity.<p><p>The star is located 25 light years from Sagittarius A’s center and, therefore, the point at which black holes are not expected to enter our galaxy.<p>']

headline: SpaceX postpones test launch from Florida after first successful launch in 12 years
content: ['<p> - Elon Musk’s SpaceX did not immediately return a request for comment on Tuesday night, citing a technical and regulatory review of its Falcon 9 rocket, but a spokeswoman said in a statement that the rocket’s test launch in Florida will take place next year.<p><p>The launch, which was scheduled to take place in mid-February, was halted on Friday after a rocket carrying NASA’s Crew Dragon capsule failed to reach the International Space Station.<p><p>SpaceX said the first successful launch of its Dragon capsule in three years would involve four separate SpaceX-owned rocket launches, and would be the first such launch since a Falcon 9 failure in January.<p><p>It also said that it was studying potential future launch vehicle applications for the Crew Dragon.<p><p>The company was first to test a manned test launch for a SpaceX Dragon in March, following last month’s botched landing of the rocket in Florida.<p><p>Last month, Musk’s rocket failed on its maiden test flight, completing a test launch that did not result in a single orbiter touchdown.<p> ']

headline: Sydney Swans, Sydney Swans, New Zealand get first win of 2017 as the Cats prepare for their first game under new coach Nick McClain
content: ['<p>Sydney Swans head coach Nick McClain expects his side to pick up the points in round one of the 2017 season when they travel to Auckland to face the Giants on Saturday.<p><p>“I thought that maybe the Sydney Swans could win but it’s not that easy to win a game like that against a team that likes to get away with it,” McClain told reporters after the match. “They’ve got some very good players that we need to strengthen in the future,” he said.<p><p>Despite a 3-1 loss to Melbourne on Saturday, McClain will have plenty to prove on the field this year, as he looks to take the Cats back to the top of the ladder with a dominant performance in their first home game under McClain’s watch.<p><p>Sydney Swans coach Scott Smith was among the reporters at the end of Tuesday’s match when McClain said he was confident the Cats would be better in the semi-final against the visiting Otago Warriors than they were at the end of last year.<p><p>“That’s part of the plan this year.”<p><p>“But the last game of the season against them was a close one. It’s been one of the best teams we have ever played against and you got to see that from them,” McClain said.']

headline: Punishment: British monarch dies after death at 65
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Prince William, Duke of Cambridge and their three children were all executed on Wednesday at the age of 65 following a coronavirus pandemic, in what the coronavirus authorities described as an "unexpected" death.<p><p>Prince Charles and Theresa May were all also executed on Wednesday.<p><p>Prince William had lived for many years in Britain with his wife, Prince Charles, who died in March.<p><p>Before his death in May, Francis I had described the coronavirus as "unacceptable" and said a coronavirus epidemic had “an unspeakable impact on human life”.<p><p>The deaths, which mark only the second such death at a royal residence - the Duke of Edinburgh in 1903 and the Duke of Edinburgh in 1903 - triggered protests worldwide, which raised public funds for victims and offered financial assistance for the royal family.<p><p>The coronavirus virus is transmitted through the bite of an infected cell.<p><p>The deaths marked the first coronavirus deaths among more than 100 people, the coronavirus watchdog said.<p><p>“Prince Charles and Theresa were among the first to die of the virus after their coronavirus was isolated,” said British Prime Minister David Cameron.<p>']

headline: Mountain goats get a bump on snowmobile trails
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - The New York City park system has launched the first-ever mountain goats for use on a road.<p><p>The system, called The Hill and The Park, is the brainchild of Peter Stegner, who leads the program and executive director of the New York Parks Department’s Mountain Trails Advisory Commission, a partnership between the state and nonprofit groups.<p><p>The goats have been tested by snowmobiling enthusiasts and private groups from dozens of different parts of the city and elsewhere, but their arrival on the New York City roadways is the first time they have been on the ground since the first ones were installed at the National Park Service in 1882.<p><p>The Hill and The Park is a privately owned property in the heart of Manhattan’s Central Park district, with access to nearly 600,000 acres of privately owned property and parking for public use.<p><p>Stegner said the goats, which will run on two wheels, can fit into almost any car and will enjoy the snow, which is almost uniformly clear.<p><p>The system, which will run 10 to 12 months, is designed to offer a better view and safer riding for many riders, including those with compromised eyesight, Stegner said.<p><p>The goats are equipped with cameras so that they can be tracked and a special software that helps keep a lookout for any dangerous creature.<p>']

headline: In Japan, the first space junk was discovered at sea
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - A rare glimpse into Japan’s marine environment on Tuesday was made during a visit to a shipwreck off the coast of Matsushima, a city about 75 miles (100 km) south of Tokyo, the Japan Today newspaper reported, citing local officials.<p><p>The tiny Japanese vessel, a Triton 2, sank about 24,000 years ago during a winter storm but was found floating off the coast of the Yamaguchi archipelago in the south of the city, the report said.<p><p>At least 16 other bodies had been discovered off the coast of Iwate Prefecture.<p><p>Matsushima, about 60 miles (80 km) north of Tokyo, is home to about 200,000 people.<p><p>Its largest body, the Triton 2, had been spotted on a helicopter after a cruise in 2015 off the coast of Iwate.<p><p>A Japanese news agency reported in November 2016 that a Triton 2 had been discovered in the seas off the coast of Kyushu, about 70 miles (100 km) south of Tokyo.<p><p>That incident caused outrage among local residents, and prompted Japan’s government to declare a state of emergency.<p><p>The Triton 2 is one of thousands of tiny, potentially hazardous, junk floating around the world.<p>']

headline: U.S. drone strikes strike aims at thwarting Iran's ballistic missile programme
content: ['<p> - The U.S. unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) mission to bomb Islamic State targets in Iraq and Syria is aimed at stopping the Iran’s ballistic missile program, an adviser to the National Security Council said on Thursday.<p><p>The Trump administration’s drone strikes against Islamic State targets in Iraq and Syria have been targeted in three separate attacks, including the Jan. 9 raid in Yemen and the Nov. 17 strike on the U.S. Consulate in Yemen, the National Security Council said in a statement.<p><p>U.S. Vice President Mike Pence said on Thursday that U.S. drones carried out targeted missions against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.<p><p>He called the U.S.-led coalition fighting the Islamic State a “very good match”, calling it an “essential partner” for U.S. counterterrorism efforts.<p><p>“We have successfully destroyed Islamic State weapons in Iraq and Syria, and we are now targeting the militants in Syria,” Pence said in a speech in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.<p><p>The White House’s drone strikes in Yemen and Syria have also targeted Iranian-owned ships, planes and missile systems.<p><p>Trump’s announcement came hours after he called for an investigation into the deaths of Iranian scientist Atid Mohammad Javad Asthani and U.S. citizen Yusuf Ali Mohammadi in Yemen, two U.S. senators told Reuters.']

headline: Virus researchers use genetic markers to monitor human immune responses
content: ['<p> - Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have used genetic markers to analyze the human immune responses in mice that were infected with a new coronavirus strain known as H1N1.<p><p>The team used the unique genetic trait X-Mutation-L, which means that the animals, not humans, had altered their genes when they received the virus.<p><p>Scientists from the Johns Hopkins Genome Project, the world’s largest research group, will continue to monitor and compare the human and mouse immune responses as they seek to understand the molecular and genetic basis of human infections.<p><p>“With a new strain that we call H1N1 that we believe has been isolated from humans, we now know more about H1N1 and its role in the human immune system,” said Michael K. Hebert, lead author of the research published on Monday in Cell.<p><p>The team expects to see an “interesting “switch” for the humans. This could mean a new antibody against H1N1, or even another target, Hebert said.<p><p>The virus does not cause neurological symptoms in humans and mice, Hebert added.<p><p>Because of their unique immune responses, the researchers developed drugs to neutralize the virus.<p><p>The research team also hopes to gain insight into the human immune system’s response to H1N1, as it becomes more widespread and spreads.<p> ']

headline: Coffee drinking in Scotland may be safer than alcohol in hospital: report
content: ['<p>MELBOURNE  - Researchers in Scotland have shown a low risk of having a caesarean section for an infant and a low risk of dying of a caesarean or neonatal heart attack in a nationally representative study.<p><p>The study by researchers at Edinburgh University found a caesarean or neonatal heart attack at 14 months, which in most circumstances would not occur until 4 years after birth.<p><p>“It’s surprising that the risk of death was higher after caesarean and neonatal heart attacks,” said lead study co-author Michael Barrett from Edinburgh’s Department of Health, saying the findings had been extrapolated to more babies.<p><p>“People may experience greater risk in later life than usual if they drink too much and if they drink too little,” Barrett said.<p><p>The study involved about 300 women and 375 men born after 11 August, 18 months, and 26 months and involved over 1,100 births.<p><p>At birth, most babies get good oxygenation as they have a very narrow artery and the small amount of blood in their blood stream is too thin to carry a vital sign of life, Barrett said.<p><p>“This means they have fewer arteries to carry oxygen. They have less blood flow to the liver and less oxygen coming to the lungs as well. That helps them stay alive longer,” Barrett said.<p>']

headline: 'Pandemic' of autism patients and researchers shows the origins of the disease
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - People with autism may be at greater risk for serious brain damage and intellectual dysfunction, new research suggests, but researchers in Germany, Canada and Mexico are pushing for better treatments to help those patients.<p><p>The findings, published on Thursday in Neurology, have implications for clinical trials of treatments that can improve cognitive functioning and protect against dementia.<p><p>Autism and other cognitive impairments are linked to impairments in many aspects of consciousness, including the ability to imagine thoughts and thoughts. Researchers studying 23 autism patients with severe neurological impairment found that three-quarters of them had a history of traumatic brain injury, including the head injury caused by a traumatic brain injury in the early 20s.<p><p>Researchers also found that patients with autism had more than half of the brain damage from traumatic brain injury and had higher levels of a protein called amyloid precursor protein than healthy controls, but the levels remained lower for autistic patients.<p><p>Some researchers cautioned that the findings also do not definitively show autism is caused by a genetic abnormality, and added that previous research had suggested that autism spectrum disorders (ASD) also exists in some people with these disorders.<p><p>Experts said the finding that autism patients may be at increased risk for serious brain damage underscores the need for better diagnostic tests, testing for comorbidities and other mental health conditions.<p>']

headline: Fossilized bones of two extinct crocodilians could reveal life on Earth
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have unearthed hundreds of bone fragments that represent two of the oldest-known living crocodilians alive today, showing the oldest-known existence of an extinct species and offering a new understanding of the evolutionary processes involved in the earliest-known crocodilians, the researchers said on Wednesday.<p><p>The remains of the three-legged crocodilians were found alongside remains of a modern-day crocodilian called C. afarensis in northeastern Russia, with evidence of animal sacrifice. Both were found at sites near the town of Tula in the Kirov region.<p><p>The researchers discovered four bones from C. afarensis, a relatively ancient group of crocodilians that lived roughly 6,000 years ago in Russia’s Tula region.<p><p>The fossils were dated at least 25,000 years ago and yielded tantalizing evidence of life during that time. The researchers propose that the first-known life forms may have been aquatic crocodilians or lizards that once flourished on land.<p><p>The scientists said it is the first time researchers have uncovered an extinct species in such detail, with so much scientific research still to come.<p><p>The earliest-known known remains of a crocodilian were found in Russia in 2000, but only in parts of Mongolia and parts of Brazil.<p>']

headline: Mammoths are among some of the world’s last dinosaurs. But they are not the only ones to be in the news.
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Mammoths were among some of the last dinosaurs to live up to their scientific name, a group that includes birds, reptiles and amphibians - some of the first dinosaurs to do so after the last one died roughly 400 million years ago.<p><p>Scientists from Britain’s University of Manchester and France’s Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology released a report on Monday detailing how scientists debated the question of whether to call this group dinosaurs or mere herbivores.<p><p>The researchers said it would be "very difficult" to say whether the two words “eukaryotes” should have been used as the first words for a group called herbivores, but that it’s possible there are some people who don’t realize that there are two competing theories.<p><p>“While we’re not completely convinced of a certain group theory of the dinosaur lineage, I believe there are a couple of things that are relevant to reconsideration in evolutionary terms,” said U.S. National Parks Conservation Service biologist Megan Bowers.<p><p>“If a person is saying, for example, ‘dinosaur-eater’’s is an extinct group, that makes it hard to interpret what that means,” Bowers added.<p>']

headline: Luminescence-rich stars form more quickly than galaxies, researchers say
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - A new research suggests an early stage of stars' formation may allow them to make brighter, more intense stars within a fraction of the time it takes galaxies to form, scientists said on Wednesday.<p><p>The star clusters within the first-known star formation were discovered around 3 billion years ago during the discovery of the Virgo cluster, located roughly 250 million light-years from Earth.<p><p>While this cluster was not visible to the naked eye at this time, it is not the only one. Milky Way stars are extremely dense, as are the spiral arms of galaxies and the largest planets of the solar system.<p><p>“The number of stars that are moving at the speed of light that are in a cluster is probably smaller than that of a regular star,” said planetary scientist and study co-author Matthew Stroud of Imperial College London. “Stars are small enough to be thought of as the only groups of stars in a galaxy. They are not as large as the rest of the galaxy.”<p><p>The research, published in the journal Science, focuses on stars’ formation in a fraction of the time it takes for galaxies to form, not the time it takes for other stars to form.<p><p>The researchers studied stars’ light and gravitational interactions, looking at the star clusters surrounding the star cluster to see how each would react when one star started forming.<p>"]

headline: Huge number of deaths attributed to COVID-19 in Saudi Arabia - SPA
content: ['<p>SINGAPORE  - The death toll from COVID-19 in Saudi Arabia rose to nearly 13,000 from about 22,000 in August, SPA deputy director General Mohammed bin Abdulaziz al-Muhajir said on Tuesday.<p><p>In addition to the coronavirus, two other cases have also been reported in the kingdom and the toll has risen to seven from seven, SPA’s spokesman Hamed al-Salah told reporters in an interview.<p><p>“The numbers are much higher than they have been before,” he said, according to a SPA report. “The numbers are much higher than they have been before.”<p><p>The coronavirus first hit Saudi Arabia in August and killed more than 2,700 people, most of them children.<p><p>The coronavirus has been linked to severe liver disease, diabetes, heart disease, cancer and many other health problems.<p><p>Last month, Saudi Arabia was hit by a series of outbreaks that killed up to 3,400 people. The latest case came from southern Saudi Arabia, according to SPA figures.<p><p>“The coronavirus was linked to serious injuries to children in Saudi hospitals, with one child dying from the virus,” an SPA report said. “The deaths are caused by the hepatitis B virus.”<p> ']

headline: The largest fossil of an ancient species discovered in Indonesia shows it belonged to a group of fish that hunted long ago
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - An ancient riverboat in Indonesia that was discovered 30 years ago with a new fossil, is providing an unusual and exciting glimpse into the evolutionary history of an animal once thought to have been extinct, scientists said on Wednesday.<p><p>Dinosaur bones - fossils that show an evolutionary change between a long line of fish that used rivers as hunting grounds - were found in southern Andaman and Nicobar islands by the Indonesian government’s paleontological institute, the Jakarta Post reported.<p><p>“Our study provides new evidence that riverboats - and other marine life - once used to be a highly specialized group of fish, probably smaller than modern birds, perhaps some 50 million years ago, that went extinct when the ocean was relatively flat or the surface ice sheets melted,” said paleontologist Zeyad Chiang of the Institute of Marine Biology at Jakarta’s Kanda University, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>“Today’s riverboats used to be used for fishing in the lowlands and can reach depths of up to 50 meters (yards) and are still there today,” added paleontologist and study co-author T.P. Yang of the Museum of Tropical Sciences in Jakarta, the paper said.<p><p>“The riverboats probably used to be smaller. But when the ocean became thinner, they had to be very powerful for this kind of fishing.”<p>']

headline: Watershot radiation to help fight coronavirus on human farm
content: ["<p>ORLANDO, Fla.  - Scientists are racing to bring the worst coronavirus ever detected to the farm where they plan to place a new sensor on the ground to monitor the movement of large animals - a potential benefit for farmers in the booming Southeast Florida desert, as well as scientists from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who have mapped a deadly strain in the state.<p><p>The three-wheeled machine that scientists will use for the sensors in the future is expected to produce results soon, said Paul Harvey, the head of the Department of Food and Agriculture\\'s Environmental Hazards Analysis Office.<p><p>“I really don\\'t expect that we will be able to predict it,” Harvey said, without elaborating. “But we are really looking forward to it.”<p><p>The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) last month declared the pandemic a global health emergency and said it would cause a devastating toll on vulnerable populations.<p><p>Harvey’s team has placed the sensor on the plant-based farm on the island of Oahe, and has been mapping water levels in the area for months to see if the virus can spread.<p><p>“We’re hoping to learn more as we go along. We’ve got a lot of people from other countries around the world who are really interested in seeing what this sensor can do and what it might find in our ecosystem,” Harvey said."]

headline: Lance Armstrong's 'Millionaire Cop: A History of Motorcars
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - The life-changing ride of two-time world champion Armstrong in an 18-foot-tall (4.9 meters) racing car was brought to life after a rare accident.<p><p>Armstrong’s twin-engined 1969 Mercedes E-Class died at age 60 of a stroke two days after a test drive.<p><p>Armstrong, racing world champion from 1960-1969, went on to win the 1968 MotoGP title and the 1983 title, losing only to Carlos Correa in the first round of the 1983 MotoGP Grand Prix.<p><p>Armstrong’s car - the BMW 818L (with wingspan of 5.5 meters) - would prove to be one of the most iconic machines ever built, and he was named a World Motorcars Grand Prix champion four times after winning the title and the 1985 title.<p><p>“Lance is probably the most famous person in all of sports,” said Michael Moraes, a professor at Los Angeles University who is part of the team that created the motorcycle. “He could walk up to the car and take it to the finish line.”<p><p>Armstrong has been an instant classic in motorsports since his 1970 1968 ride with the 1968 World Superbike championship winning a record 4.1-tonne V12.<p>']

headline: Bizarre and hilarious tale of one of the world's oldest-known mammals sheds light on complex global warming
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A bizarre and hilarious tale of one of the oldest-known mammals and an ancient mystery of how much water it takes to grow, a new study shows.<p><p>The oldest-known mammal was called Gorgosaurus, the name of the giant land animal that evolved roughly 300 million years ago and lived at a time when the Earth’s oceans were the vast majority. But it had much smaller legs, shorter arms and shorter necks than the others.<p><p>“Gorgosaurus was the oldest living mammal that was known, and that’s why this story is so remarkable,” said paleontologist and study co-author Alexey Ovchinin of Washington University in St. Louis, who led the research published this week in the journal Science.<p><p>“It’s important to understand the basic physics of living organisms. We know we’re shrinking our oceans, but are there any fossils that show that this shrinking of our oceans is going on,” Ovchinin added.<p><p>“The story is really the story of how our world is evolving so fast, and how we’ve become so reliant on fossil fuels,” Ovchinin said.<p><p>Gorgosaurus is the oldest-known mammal to have been found. It lived in what is now eastern Asia from about 300,000 to 4.5 billion years ago, about twice as long as modern land animals, Ovchinin added.']

headline: China plans to launch a second launch vehicle for its space program by the end of the year, the country’s space minister has said.
content: ['<p>China has been trying to catch up with the United States and Russia to become a major space power by 2024 and hopes to become the second to have a rocket capable of carrying humans to space by the end of the decade, according to a top official.<p><p>Chinese state media said the ministry planned to launch its own second launch vehicle by the end of the year.<p><p>An official with the Ministry of Defense said the Chang’e-4 lunar rocket, which will be the third named rocket from the U.S.-led program, would be ready in 2021. It would carry seven tonnes of cargo to a height of about 500 meters.<p><p>China has been dogged by a long-running dispute over its role in space.<p><p>The U.S. Air Force is the top U.S. space program manager and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) said in January it was considering whether to expand the space program to include manned missions to space.<p><p>In January China said it was considering a manned space mission to Mars. A month later, it said it was considering adding human crewed missions.<p><p>In March, Chinese state media said the government of Prime Minister Li Keqiang was considering building a Mars colony.<p>']

headline: Honeycomb says it is developing a way to detect COVID-19 before it is too late
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. aerospace firm Honeywell on Wednesday said it is developing a technology for detecting coronavirus RNA that can be sequenced to identify the genetic material of early coronavirus infections before the pandemic.<p><p>The company said on Wednesday it was developing a method that it said could be combined with technologies in other industries.<p><p>“Our technology will allow us to develop a virus detection kit that can be analyzed in a lab before it is too late,” John Goss, vice president of manufacturing and market development at Honeywell, told Reuters.<p><p>“This technology is a win-win for consumers,” Goss said, adding that even small changes to a product could lead to new products being offered faster.<p><p>Goss is not directly involved in the development of Honeywell’s technology, but said the firm was working with industry leaders, including private firms, to create a kit that would be useful in conjunction with other products Honeywell sells.<p><p>The technology will allow the company to identify the RNA in early infections, the technology being developed by a team at a U.S.-based research center, Goss said.<p><p>The technology is being developed as part of efforts by pharmaceutical companies to use genomic sequencing to study early cases of COVID-19, a serious coronavirus that has infected nearly 3.5 million people.<p>']

headline: U.S. tech firm to invest $12.4 billion in new startup to grow startup
content: ['<p> - A group of Silicon Valley investors is considering using a new technology company to develop high-tech applications to fight the growing number of cyber attacks, according to a new report.<p><p>The startup incubator is being built by an unnamed company, and the plan is to open up existing projects as soon as March, the report said.<p><p>It would create a “open source project” to help secure projects that have been developed independently by the same people, and the incubator would offer its services to anyone interested in helping to develop new technologies, the report said.<p><p>The report cited the following companies to date: Microsoft, Amazon.com Inc and Google Inc.<p><p>The report did not give details about the startups or details on the number of the initial entrants, though it did offer some insight into their status and the potential benefits of having similar services for businesses, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.<p><p>The U.S. Department of Justice has identified at least four cyber attacks in recent months targeting U.S. businesses. A separate cyber attack this year killed three employees at the California-based Silicon Valley investment bank Crowdstrike.<p><p>Those attacks came less than weeks after two Chinese hacking groups successfully taken down computer systems in several Democratic states, according to the U.S. National Security Agency.<p>']

headline: Lung cancer patients are more likely to live than the general population; study finds 'fringe' treatment options may prevent lung cancer
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - Lung cancer patients are more likely to live than their general population and, according to a new study, doctors should consider using fewer therapies and avoiding unnecessary procedures to help protect patients from their cancers.<p><p>Patients living in a multidrug-resistant group of patients at risk for lung cancer - the'mystery patients” - were more likely than other patients to have their lungs damaged and to suffer from the common inflammatory disease known as LASIK.<p><p>Overall, 10% of the patients who tested positive for LASIK died, the researchers found. They also found that a single study involving 823 lung cancer patients had found the same percentage of the patients dying of LASIK.<p><p>The findings come as LASIK patients are being treated with drugs that target the immune system, and have already been shown to be highly effective in treating some types of cancer.<p><p>More research is needed on whether these drugs have a significant impact on patients’ quality of life, the authors said in a statement.<p><p>LASIK, or “mystery patients”, are those who have no symptoms at all but nonetheless have persistent lung disease, meaning the immune system is trying to help them fight back.<p>"]

headline: China aims to fly astronauts into space within two years
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China aims to fly astronauts into space within two years, state media reported on Thursday, saying the plan was backed by the National Space Administration (NSA), and that its goal was to complete a mission by the end of this year.<p><p>In a report that drew criticism from some in China, the state-run Xinhua news agency said China aims to have manned space travel by 2033.<p><p>The report appeared to back up Chinese claims that the launch of a rocket from the Jiuquan-2 lunar orbiter is the beginning of the long-term plan.<p><p>China has said its goal of flying astronauts to the moon by 2035 is “not realistic” and has said its goal is to launch two astronauts by 2040, the second manned mission after the end of the Apollo program.<p><p>The NSA has yet to comment on the report, although a spokesman said the report had been submitted with a “perfectly consistent” and objective quality rating.<p> ']

headline: Liver fluid levels may be linked with brain injury
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Kidney fluid levels may be linked with impaired functioning, a new study suggests. Kidney function may also be linked to a number of neurological diseases, including epilepsy, Alzheimer’s disease, fibromyalgia and other inflammatory diseases.<p><p>Scientists studied the brains of 981 people who had undergone invasive procedures to look for abnormalities in blood flow or levels of an enzyme called COVID-19 that can damage damaged cells. The results indicated that when COVID-19 enters the bloodstream, inflammation in the brain causes impaired cells to break into smaller pieces.<p><p>Blood-brain damage may contribute to conditions such as autism and schizophrenia, the researchers said on Wednesday in a paper posted online ahead of peer review.<p><p>“We know that inflammation is a strong predictor of brain inflammation, but the mechanisms that have been identified thus far have not yet been fully understood,” said Dr. Christina Ochsner of the University of Minnesota Medical School who led the study published in the journal PLOS ONE.<p><p>Ochsner said researchers needed to study the brains of those who had undergone invasive procedures for multiple sclerosis, and those who had been stable for two years before they were found to have brain damage.<p><p>“We still do not know what causes inflammation, and what might be the main mechanism behind brain inflammation, but what we do know is that inflammation has a specific role in neurodegenerative diseases and neurodegenerative disease,” Ochsner said.<p>']

headline: U.S. launches its first lunar lander, the H4NT, for NASA in 2020
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday unveiled an ambitious plan to revive the nation’s space program and increase American competitiveness in the quest to reach moon landers, amid a flurry of announcements from top U.S. officials.<p><p>A White House administration proposal to revive the space program aims to establish a U.S. national astronaut corps capable of stepping foot on the lunar surface by 2024, with the first manned missions planned by 2024.<p><p>Trump’s plan to revive the space program comes a week after he took to the space agency’s National Space Council, calling for U.S. companies to participate in a key NASA competition in the 2020 budget proposal.<p><p>The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in October formally nominated four new members to replace retiring astronaut Chris Cassidy, who died last month in an accident at the age of 82.<p><p>In addition to Cassidy, retired astronaut Bob Behnken is also seeking reelection. Behnken retired in 2017, having completed seven tours of the International Space Station.<p><p>“I know it’s been an honor, a privilege, but it’s something I cannot ignore,” Behnken said at the time.<p>']

headline: 'Soyuz mission' is over; crew safe
