A common variant of the Zika virus that causes severe birth defects shows promise in COVID-19 vaccines
content: ['<p> - The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>A variant of the novel coronavirus that causes severe birth defects shows promising promise in vaccines for COVID-19 in a new study, with researchers describing results published on Wednesday in the journal Science.<p><p>The findings may help doctors to identify better ways to treat and prevent cases of the virus, which can cause COVID-19, as well as protect against infections, the authors said.<p><p>The results from the study, which has not yet been peer-reviewed, suggest a variant of the virus that causes severe birth defects in newborns may have therapeutic potential in vaccines for COVID-19. Researchers examined the virus’s genome to determine if it had any variants that might help them distinguish between different types of coronavirus.<p><p>“The antiviral properties of the variant have been shown to be comparable to those of the novel coronavirus and this study shows that this variant could be a potentially valuable tool for developing vaccines for COVID-19,” said coauthor James Bemis, a Yale University School of Public Health postdoc and co-leading investigator of the study.<p>']

headline: China unveils solar energy blueprint
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s official news agency Xinhua on Wednesday unveiled a blueprint for commercializing solar energy, a blueprint designed to cut waste, improve efficiency and reduce emissions.<p><p>The blueprint for the national energy development plan called for commercialization of solar power by 50% and by 80% by 2025.<p><p>The blueprint called for a 40% share of the market by 2026 to be managed by a joint entity, a 50% share by 2030 and 100% by 2025, Xinhua said.<p><p>It also calls for zero emission power projects by 2020.<p><p>The blueprint also aims to create a commercial solar power sector by 2030.<p><p>Solar power is a popular technology in China and is widely used in commercial applications.<p><p>Critics say it can create climate crisis and undermine the government’s goal of reducing emissions by 35%.<p><p>The Beijing-based company DynCorp SE has filed for bankruptcy protection, according to state media.<p><p>China has said its ambitious solar energy plan could slash the energy consumption of 10 billion tonnes of CO2 a year, with the goal of 30% by 2040, according to Reuters.<p><p>Its plan to use solar energy to make homes more efficient comes as China struggles to meet renewable energy targets amid a crisis.<p>']

headline: Billionaire entrepreneur Jeff Bezos' SpaceX takes on Boeing Co on SpaceX's first U.S. test flight
content: ['<p> - Billionaire entrepreneur Jeff Bezos’ SpaceX took on Boeing Co’s first test flight of its latest and most advanced fighter jet this week in partnership with NASA’s Johnson Space Center, the U.S. Air Force’s aerospace division said on Friday.<p><p>Boeing’s Falcon 9 rockets carry astronauts to the International Space Station for the first time in seven years. Boeing has previously used the Falcon 9 to ferry astronauts to the space station on its CST-100 Starliner Starliner.<p><p>The Boeing-led program, dubbed Space Dragon, marks the first time NASA’s Commercial Crew Program has completed an uncrewed test flight of a rocket or aircraft.<p><p>Since SpaceX launched the Crew Dragon in October, the two companies have used Boeing’s CST-100 Starliner to ferry astronauts to the space station and test the Crew Dragon’s Crew Dragon docking system, an unmanned test platform that is designed to make the Dragon fly autonomously to space at the earliest opportunity.<p><p>NASA and SpaceX have both completed uncrewed test flights of NASA’s Crew Dragon Crew Dragon in recent months, but only three of the seven so far have so far flown.<p><p>SpaceX last flew its Crew Dragon Crew Dragon test airplane in November, carrying a Russian cosmonaut and a U.S. citizen to the space station. In a statement to Reuters, SpaceX said it was working on a test flight for the new Starliner.']

headline: The latest in a collection of mysteries surrounding Earth’s oldest-known planet, spotted on a mission to the International Space Station
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have discovered a planet orbiting a star almost 2.5 billion miles (3.8 billion km) from Earth that orbits near a planet called Kuiper Belt Pluto roughly 7.5 billion years old, and is at least 4.3 billion miles (9 billion km) from the sun, according to the scientists who reported on Thursday.<p><p>“Earth is a giant planet, roughly 1/30th the size of Jupiter, roughly 4 times larger than Neptune,” said planetary scientist David Zemlian, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>Its age suggests that Kuiper Belt Pluto formed around a comet 65 million years ago and may have been an asteroid impact, and that Kuiper Belt Pluto may have formed at the same time as Mercury and Venus were forming around a similar time, scientists said.<p><p>The newly discovered planet, called Kuiper Belt K2, orbits a ringed planet about 3,000 light years from Earth about 4.9 billion years ago and 2,750 light years from the sun about 4.1 billion years ago.<p><p>“The amount of material we found here is extraordinary,” Zemlian said.<p><p>The researchers analyzed data from NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft that arrived on the dwarf planet in July 2013. It has been conducting its science experiments, looking for signs of life on other dwarf planets and planets beyond our solar system.']

headline: Boeing test pilot says China plans next-generation space-faring spacecraft
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Boeing Co’s new space-faring 747 SpaceShipTwo capsule is expected to make its first flight to space on Sunday, a development that underscores the company’s plan to boost its aerospace manufacturing ambitions by using its Boeing 747 as a test platform for its next-generation rocket.<p><p>The 737 MAX, a twin-rotor capsule with an estimated lifespan of seven to seven years with up to four crewed missions, is set to launch off from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida carrying the Boeing 747 MAX, a rocket developed by Boeing and backed by its rival SpaceX.<p><p>The rocket, manufactured by Lockheed Martin Corp and based on a modified Boeing 747 jetliner, will be the first production-backed space-faring platform from a U.S.-owned company.<p><p>The 747 MAX’s first-stage booster, called the JSC-100, will blast off from a Lockheed Martin F-35B joint venture and blast off for the International Space Station at 5:52 p.m. local time (0252 GMT on Monday).<p><p>The capsule will also fly a prototype of a U.S. astronaut capsule called JSC-100D, the company’s first domestically produced space-faring vehicle, and deliver a live imaging satellite to the space station from the station, Boeing said in a statement.<p>']

headline: 'Pandemic' survivors recount terror attacks
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - In the aftermath of a deadly terror attack in Paris on Tuesday, hundreds of survivors of a terror attack in Yemen told reporters they woke up on Thursday in fear, and they said they were being led down an endless path through hell, all because of a false alarm.<p><p>The survivors, who said they were in the middle of a bitter trial over the role of the U.S.-backed government of Yemen, had been told repeatedly by the families of the victims that they were being led into hell by a new generation of terror “that’s going to bring <BOS>  planet to a sudden halt”.<p><p>The news had already been reported by a local media outlet, Reuters, which had quoted three unnamed Yemeni <PAD> rs. as saying that a bomb had been placed in the apartment of an unknown number of people. A second unnamed person said it had been destroyed, according to the first.<p><p>They said they had “a very strong sense of fear that something is amiss”, and that they were being led to the streets by a “very large ‘elephant’,” in an area known for its terror threats, according to the sources quoted by Reuters. “I would say this is the beginning of a real mental horror.”<p><p>(This story refiles to add paragraph 4 to read “fear” in paragraph 7)<p> ']

headline: Ivan Istvanov, 18, is a Russian cosmonaut killed in Ukraine in a missile attack
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Ivan Istvanov, an air force pilot and three Russian cosmonauts were killed in a crash near the town of Sevastopol on Saturday in what the Interfax news agency reported was an anti-aircraft missile attack.<p><p>Istvanov, the youngest pilot to fly a Russian fighter plane, was conducting exercises when he lost control of the plane and crashed in front of an anti-aircraft missile defence system, Interfax reported.<p><p>He was taken to hospital in Moscow for treatment.<p><p>The accident occurred near a military checkpoint close to the town of Sevastopol, where Sevastopol’s national airport is located, the report said.<p> ']

headline: Soyuz spacecraft carrying scientists draws fire from space station and crew members
content: ['<p>PARIS  - French space agency Roscosmos said it is drawing fire from the space station crew after the spacecraft carried by a Russian Soyuz spacecraft fired a rocket from its main module and exploded, according to Russian news agencies.<p><p>The accident occurred on Sunday after the crew had arrived in Kazakhstan from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, where the Russian Soyuz has made several previous stops.<p><p>“The crew member of the Soyuz TASS-M probe reached the cosmodrome, which exploded, apparently causing significant damage to the module,” Roscosmos said in a statement on Sunday.<p><p>Roscosmos’ initial statement said the accident was due to two separate rockets firing at the same time.<p><p>The rocket booster was deployed from the launch pad in Kazakhstan.<p> ']

headline: Lebanon scientist calls for re-thinking vaccinations amid Ebola outbreak
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Librarians, public health officials and parents are calling for a re-evaluation of the most effective and safe vaccines in the world’s most dangerous outbreak of the Ebola virus.<p><p>A professor in a London hospital on Monday described how the coronavirus, which causes both MSF and HIV, has ravaged the liver and brain of people who receive them.<p><p>“This pandemic is killing a lot of people,” said Elisa Algiers, who is affiliated with the European Society of Clinical Oncology. “It’s time we give people the right to know what to do’s right.”<p><p>The European Commission last week urged public and private healthcare systems to provide high-quality access to the latest vaccines and advised it was time to change how it allocates funds for all types of vaccines.<p><p>“Doctors must now be more transparent with vaccine manufacturers and the public about who is paying for their vaccines,” Algiers said in a statement.<p><p>The move comes as Europe, Britain and others fight to save the world’s only COVID-19 vaccine, the Ebola vaccine, from extinction.<p><p>British Prime Minister Theresa May has said she wants to start discussions with the European Commission before the country’s 2019 general election.<p>']

headline: Nose: An old-fashioned candy bar
content: ['<p>DETROIT  - A candy bar in downtown Detroit may have been one of the first candy bars to emerge from Detroit’s public library.<p><p>A design that originated in France dates back to 1869 and was unveiled at a city hall meeting this week.<p><p>A few decades later, it was made into a candy bar by a German company called GmbH in 1903, but it was not until the U.S. Supreme Court took up the issue of the design in 1976 that it was adopted into candy bars in the United States.<p><p>It was a key piece in a broader candy industry shift: From bar-grade candy, like peanut butter and jelly to chocolate bars made from cane sugar, cane sugar cane and water, the cane sugar candy industry was an integral part of the chocolate and peanut business.<p><p>Today, candy bars are made by companies in many countries, and their presence on shelves of public libraries can make it difficult for consumers to tell where their favorite candy bars are being made.<p><p>A report published by the University of Michigan and the National Science Foundation indicates that as consumers move to more modern products, cane sugar cane imports will likely grow from 20 percent to 45 percent of U.S. cane sugar production.<p><p>The National Agricultural Policy and Promotion Organization has estimated that, by 2050, cane sugar imports will become global imports, accounting for about 11 percent of all cane sugar production worldwide.<p>']

headline: One day, I will wake up and know why I am here, my journey will be one of freedom
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Donald Trump is due to resume flying on the International Space Station next month following his historic space mission, but he is still expected to travel on private planes.<p><p>Speaking on Thursday, Trump said NASA would not allow him to go on flights as a private citizen until he has been officially sworn in as commander in chief.<p><p>Trump was speaking to reporters aboard a Boeing 747 jetliner when he spoke to reporters aboard Air Force One after making a surprise stop at the International Space Station.<p><p>“I’ve decided to go on a private plane and be a commander in chief,” he said.<p><p>“But in order to do so, you have to go out and have a private flight,” he said. “And I have a lot of experience as a commander in chief. So I’d like to be the commander in chief of all of us,” he said.<p><p>Trump did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>A senior administration official said Trump is on schedule to depart the space station with the launch of the Trump International Space Station’s flagship orbital satellite, the Gateway Gateway. The station is due to open in January 2019.<p>']

headline: Tiny, tiny, tiny creature called the red-tailed eagle found in Texas, U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Tiny, tiny, tiny creatures called the red-tailed eagle - a species that lives only about 1,000 miles (3,500 km) from Earth - are a type of creature we call the red-tailed hawk because of the size and shape.<p><p>“I’m surprised that it can fly,” said David Reuter, a paleontologist at the University of Texas-San Antonio who studied the red-tailed eagle. “The species is very small, very limited in the sense of scale and range.”<p><p>The eagle’s eyes are small, the wings are not long enough for them to see. Its feet are very short and narrow.<p><p>“I thought it was tiny, because it’s smaller than most other birds and I’m very surprised that it’s bigger than that,” Reuter said. “Because it’s so small and it’s not as big as other birds, the size and shape of the red-tailed hawk in the wild is very surprising.”<p><p>“It has many interesting adaptations.”<p><p>Red-tailed hawks share similar diet. Most have a diet of grains, fruit, fish, shellfish and insects. Red-tailed hawks - as in most birds - eat the same diet as their wild cousins but have different tastes.<p>']

headline: Jupiter's moon Io is the target of a fierce asteroid strike in March
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Jupiter’s moon Io, just 8% the size of Earth, has made a strong asteroid strike early this week that could devastate much of the southern hemisphere of the solar system, scientists said on Monday.<p><p>The asteroid, called a Doxymora, blasted off on April 3, hitting Io’s far side roughly 40 miles (45 km) above Earth and causing a flash flood that scorched parts of the planet’s atmosphere. Io’s orbit was initially elliptical, producing a smooth, circular orbit with a diameter of about 2 miles (3.4 km).<p><p>“Jupiter is a really good candidate for asteroid strike, as the moon is the best candidate to strike Earth,” said NASA planetary scientist Christina Koch.<p><p>The impact crater in the Southern Hemisphere is situated more than 50 miles (80 km) above the equator, where Io’s shadow reflects light from distant sources. Io’s surface is covered in debris and debris from the impact.<p><p>At about 33 miles (50 km) high, the impact site would have blasted off in just over a week, Koch said, giving an opportunity for the moon’s meteors to cross over into the nearby plain, or even join in with other asteroids.<p><p>“Jupiter is one of the largest bodies in the solar system. It has a lot of potential there for a collision,” Koch said.<p>']

headline: A new breed of dinosaur discovered near Madagascar
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Four new species of dinosaurs unearthed in Madagascar, near Madagascar’s northern coast, have come under intense criticism from paleontologists.<p><p>“For many years I was making calls to my colleagues to ask,” said paleontologist and U.N. panelist Pierre Gompers, whose latest work focused on the new species. “But none of them got it. They just gave us an incorrect answer. We needed to look at this new species and figure out what to do.”<p><p>Dinos ranging from dinosaurs to sauropods have been found in the vast inland and desert landscape, in a landscape dominated by crocodile-rich marine sediments and sedimentary rocks. But new research suggests that they may have been one of the first dinosaurs to be discovered in this vast archipelago.<p><p>The new species are small and relatively small, measuring only about 13cm (1 inch) long, about 5-1/2 inches long, and about 15 metres (19-28 feet) long.<p><p>The findings, published in the journal Scientific Reports, also underscore what some scientists have described as widespread contamination by the fossilized remains of crocodile-eating dinosaurs from the Cretaceous Period, beginning about 100 million years ago.<p>']

headline: 'Very unusual': Scientists have detected new life on Jupiter's moon Triton
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A small crater on Jupiter’s moon Triton - a giant androgen-rich moon with a diameter of 2.6 million miles (3.5 million km) - is one of the hottest-looking objects in the solar system.<p><p>Scientists said on Thursday the material, dubbed “Fossilized Life-size Fossilized Life-size Fossilized Fossilized Life-size Fossilized Fossilized” (FLO) by researchers at Uppsala University, has been detected in a region in Chile which they dubbed CERN-EP14.<p><p>“Fossils of all types are found in our Solar System,” said Chilean space scientist Roberto del Valle, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>Flowers of life, which form when Earth and Venus collide, were observed on the surface of Triton at the beginning of this decade.<p><p>“This is the first time that life on Triton, with the ability to digest hydrocarbons, has ever been found in a world of Jupiter or Venus. This discovery is very unusual,” Del Valle said.<p> ']

headline: Soyuz rocket fails to land safely on asteroid
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Soyuz-FG spacecraft failed to land successfully on its asteroid SEVERAL on Saturday morning, causing severe damage to its assembly line and destroying its module, Russian space agency Roscosmos said on Saturday.<p><p>The mission to return humans and the moon to the asteroid was due to be launched from Baikonur in Kazakhstan but has been postponed due to technical issues.<p><p>Soyuz had been due to rendezvous with the asteroid, located about 1.4 km (3 miles) from the Earth, on its final approach to the asteroid about two hours later.<p><p>It will rendezvous with the asteroid’s surface for a further two-and-a-half hours before returning to earth for the next mission in March, Roscosmos said.<p> ']

headline: Russia postpones moon landing for now
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia on Friday postponed a planned moon landing for now, postponing to 6 April a planned planned rocket launch from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the country’s space agency said.<p><p>The launch was made to replace the planned launch on Friday of the Soyuz MS-18 rocket, it said.<p><p>“The rocket is ready for flight from Baikonur,” the space agency said in a statement.<p><p>It said it would send a series of satellite images showing the moon, with a diameter of about 3.8 miles (5.2 km).<p><p>The cancellation came after Russia’s Soyuz MS-17 rocket was due to launch from Baikonur on the same day, a day before the United States’ presidential election on Nov. 8.<p><p>The U.S. space agency said earlier that the launch date for the MS-18 rocket “should be set in the next few weeks” as planned.<p><p>The Russian Soyuz MS-17 rocket, also named after a mythical wolf, had been set for a successful launch in late December.<p><p>The launch was delayed to 7 April due to technical issues with the rocket’s landing software.<p>']

headline: Haven't found a COVID-19 vaccine yet
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - More than 100 new coronavirus variants have been identified in the United States, as well as variants that have yet to be tested, according to research published on Monday.<p><p>The variants’ spread across multiple human populations. The variants first identified in the United States were found in northern California, Alaska, Arizona and the northernmost part of North America, researchers said in the latest edition of the Science paper. They identified variants that are known to have been common in recent years, but also that have yet to be tested in humans.<p><p>The researchers, led by Professor of Immunology Daniela O’Connor from the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, studied 14 variants in different populations in California and Alaska. Among them, five were found to have been circulating independently among people in northern California, while others that had been circulating independently in other places in the world, they reported in the scientific journal Nature Immunology.<p><p>The three variants circulating in Alaska and Alaska had variants that were not found in humans. The second and third variants were found in some parts of Alaska, although it was not known which ones originated in Alaska.<p><p>“The fact that we have so many variants in common has implications for the protection against infection and disease,” O’Connor said.<p><p>“While many different variants have been circulating, we still don’t know how widespread these variants are.”<p>']

headline: A new type of human heart found in a small African sample - reveals the origins of ageing
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The new type of heart found in a small African sample of patients with type 2 diabetes has helped explain why some of the elderly in Britain have heart failure, heart attacks, a fatal heart attack, and heart failure.<p><p>The new research also sheds light on the heart’s role in ageing - which means it is less efficient at producing blood sugar.<p><p>The study involved 33 patients with type 2 diabetes who had died in the past three months, or had already died by this time, had obtained blood levels of different types of sugar, including those from the pancreas.<p><p>They also showed that in some of these patients, the presence of the new type of heart was linked to a reduction in heart rate, an increase in blood pressure, and an increase in heart failure.<p><p>The team said on Wednesday that they had identified a new type of type 2 diabetes in this patient, called type 2 “HD2D”. It is a type 2 diabetes caused by a type 2 mutation in a gene that affects the size of the heart cells.<p><p>“The findings indicate that type 2 diabetes is a very complex disease, and one of the most complex aspects of ageing,” they said.<p><p>“Most people get their first type 2 diabetes about 12 years old, but some may only get their second diabetes when they get older,” they added.<p><p>D']

headline: Nuclear plant to explore its potential as early-stage candidate for high-tech rocket - Space
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is working toward developing its first launchable non-proliferation missile system capable of delivering small arms, a move that could boost the U.S. ability to launch the nuclear-armed missile before it can be deployed by an adversary, officials said on Tuesday.<p><p>The United States, India and Pakistan are developing intercontinental ballistic missile defense systems to defend against ballistic missiles and other weapons, but have never before been tested to carry warheads in a conventional conventional missile.<p><p>If all goes according to plan, the launch of the SAD-1 (SSAD-2) intercontinental ballistic missile system could occur within years, one U.S. official told Reuters.<p><p>The system, developed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), would be capable of carrying a conventional weapon, capable of delivering a nuclear warhead and warheads without needing to be fired from a submarine.<p><p>“We have talked about how this system can be used and how we can make it easier to test it in a timely fashion and mitigate the risks of launch from an aircraft carrier submarine,” said William Hague, U.S. envoy to Asia, Asia-Pacific and the Middle East.<p><p>“This is the first phase in the development of this technology and we are working to determine the final stages of this,” Hague said.<p>']

headline: Nike's LeBron James in hot water with U.S. authorities
content: ['<p>LONDON  - LeBron James’s blockbuster NBA championship last year in Japan set the stage for another explosive run for the Golden State Warriors to advance to the NBA Finals on Tuesday, with the NBA’s top man, reigning MVP Kyrie Irving, in the heat.<p><p>“I am not going to lie, I wasn’t very happy about it at the start,” James told reporters on a plane back in London after suffering a setback during last night’s win over the New York Knicks.<p><p>While Irving had made his Cavs debut this season in a game-winner, Irving was dominant and led the Cavs to a 117-98 win over the visiting Golden State Warriors.<p><p>“If I could get Kyrie Irving to play my first NBA game on Monday,” Irving said, “I would.”<p><p>With Irving off for the year, his MVP-nominated career will be in jeopardy next season if Irving plays for the Cavs in an NBA championship game.<p><p>He said he believed Irving was ready to play for the Warriors in an NBA playoffs.<p><p>“I love Kyrie Irving. He is doing great in this league. I would love for him to play in the playoffs.”<p>']

headline: U.S. astronaut Steve Branson signs new space mission pact
content: ['<p> - American astronaut Steve Branson plans to launch his private spaceflight company NASA on Tuesday ahead of his upcoming space mission, a spokesman said, declining to say when.<p><p>Branson, 65, plans to embark on a two-month mission in December starting from his hometown of Florida, where he is spending a majority of his time to help NASA launch its next crewed mission to the International Space Station. Branson is due to fly aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft to the space station by the end of December.<p><p>“The next mission, I’m going to be working with NASA, and we are going to do everything possible to bring people out of the shadows and help our nation achieve its most ambitious goals and dreams of space flight,” the spokesman said.<p><p>NASA had no immediate comment on Branson’s mission or its commercial viability.<p> ']

headline: Boeing completes unmanned test flight in space on Wednesday
content: ['<p> - Boeing Co said on Wednesday its CST-100 Starliner unmanned test flight carried out on Wednesday, a milestone in its latest unmanned test program.<p><p>The unmanned test flight, which ended at 5:51 a.m. local time (0051 GMT), marked the first of three unmanned test flights Boeing is launching this year that it plans to fly autonomously around the world, the company said.<p><p>The CST-100 Starliner will become the third Boeing aircraft to go into space - the fifth is the SpaceX CST-100 Starliner, according to its website.<p><p>“We will be in space with our first crewed flight in three years,” Doug Dougherty, vice president of commercial aircraft at Boeing, told Reuters. “With this new flight, we are entering the realm of the next generation of space travel.”<p><p>The company, which has two Boeing Co Starliner and Starliner-1 aircraft, has been working to develop a reusable capsule to ferry supplies to and from the International Space Station since 2005, though the capsule’s cost has soared.<p><p>“I think that was really important to be able to bring a new customer to the market,” Doug Dougherty said of the Starliner.<p><p>“They will be ready to fly, so I think they’ll be in orbit very soon,” he said.<p>']

headline: Coconut flour flour: How to make a vegan chocolate milk substitute?
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A plant-based flour that can be used to make chocolate milk substitutes should be developed around 30 years in Britain, says a top scientific adviser.<p><p>In the meantime, chocolate flour should be taken into account as a vegan substitute in the way animal feed and animal products are traditionally produced, he said.<p><p>The experts behind the UK-based Crispin Glover Foundation are convinced chocolate flour should be used in combination with eggs or meat.<p><p>“This whole process should be taken into account as a vegan substitute in future,” said Dr. Nick Harvey, an ecologist at Oxford University who was a senior adviser on the project. “If it is vegan, it should be eaten without milk.”<p><p>Other experts, including Britain’s dairy farmer Simon Rennie, agreed the risk of animal-farming in the flour is low.<p><p>“It would make a lot of sense for this to be the first vegan chocolate flour as that would be a very low risk for animal-farming and would make things much easier,” he said. “The amount of animal products that we currently produce would make that possible.”<p><p>Glover believes that a large vegan chocolate flour, priced between 5p and 10p, will reduce the dairy-related risk for future dairy farmers.<p>']

headline: New Delhi: Reliable and timely treatment for severe COVID-19 in hospitalized patients with COVID-19, doctors say
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - A group of India’s top medical doctors said on Wednesday the Indian government has delivered in place of a national emergency fund for COVID-19 patients in need of immediate care, saying an early phase of the fund would be established in the next few days and would be administered by the central government in case of emergency.<p><p>The fund would be available in the next several days and would be paid for by the central government, Chief Medical Officer Suresh Chaudhary said at a news conference.<p><p>“This is a major step towards addressing COVID-19 and also the coronavirus pandemic,” he said.<p><p>Calls to the Indian government were not returned.<p><p>COVID-19 is a global disease caused by the virus causing AIDS.<p><p>In April, around 10,000 patients in India were admitted with COVID-19, a number that peaked at 1,000 a week in December, according to a Reuters tally of the total.<p><p>There are around 30,000 patients in the United States, Canada and the UK.<p><p>The coronavirus has killed more than 2,000 people in the United States since 1990, but has been diagnosed in about 10,000 of those cases in India alone.<p>']

headline: Soyuz test capsule bound for space station in 2018
content: ['<p>ZURICH  - Three Soyuz capsule bound for space station in 2018 with a new software platform for onboard testing will be carrying out a spacewalk and preparing to take off for the International Space Station, a U.S. official said on Saturday.<p><p>The Crew Dragon capsule carrying the astronauts arrived at the space station from the International Space Station in Kazakhstan on Saturday, just two weeks before its first crewed mission to the International Space Station was due to launch on Dec. 20.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: A Chinese spacecraft carrying the first human astronaut landed in space
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - An American-made rocket carrying the first human-made lunar lander landed on a remote Tibetan plateau on Thursday in what was the first successful manned flight to the moon by any spacecraft, official Xinhua reported.<p><p>China plans to use the launch to carry out space missions around the globe. It will spend at least one year conducting its own lunar landings.<p><p>The landing on Mount Tungkhang near the northern Tibetan region of the Sichuan region came a day after China carried out an international fly-by in the disputed Hainan Sea.<p><p>China, with about 300,000 people in a diverse and powerful Tibetan autonomous region, has long pushed for human exploration in space.<p><p>In July, the country launched a probe that roamed the moon but failed due to faulty sensor technology. It resumed a six-month mission this year but could not return to Earth.<p><p>A rocket carrying a crew and the rover to the surface of Mount Tungkhang, about 1,200 km (1,470 miles) north of Beijing, on a successful flight on Wednesday, will dock with the International Space Station and test its technologies before launching on a controlled mission on Oct. 5, Xinhua said.<p><p>The lander will be the first human mission to the lunar surface.<p>']

headline: Titans tight end Joe Thomas missed Wednesday's preseason opener against the Cowboys, but he is listed as day-to <PAD>  by NFL Network.com
content: ["<p><p>The Titans have designated tight end Joe Thomas as day-to-day and are going to use his condition on Thursday to begin the process of recovering from a broken fibula in practice.<p><p>The Titans did not comment on Thomas\\'s status or condition.<p><p>Thomas, a seventh-round draft pick from Tennessee in the 2011 draft, was injured during the second half of the second preseason game against the Cowboys in Week 8.<p><p>“There were a couple of injuries that took us through a couple weeks and I had to go back and forth between the trainers and the doctors,” Titans coach Jeff Tedford said. “But Joe is OK.”<p><p>Thomas underwent operations on his left leg last week, a setback for a tight end coming off knee surgery last April.<p><p>The Titans have placed quarterback Vince Wilfork and running back Lamar Jackson on injured reserve with injuries to the upper arm and arm itself.<p><p>The Titans selected tight end Eric Berry in the fifth round of the 2012 draft out of Washington State. Berry had a monster preseason, playing in four games for the Panthers and ranking fourth on the team in receptions.<p><p>Berry missed all of 2016 with an ankle injury and was cut by the Giants on Tuesday after a nine-game season with the Giants."]

headline: Boeing's Blue Origin spacecraft gets a liftoff from Florida
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - Boeing Co’s Starship spacecraft is due to launch on a flight in early March from Florida’s Cape Canaveral, the company’s chief executive said in a presentation to investors on Wednesday.<p><p>Starship is the latest commercial satellite and capsule company from Boeing and SpaceX. It is carrying a cargo plane bound for the International Space Station, which is set to orbit the U.S. station for the first time this year.<p><p>“Starship is the fourth satellite in a long line of spacecraft, this one is going to be in orbit for the first time in decades,” said Jeffrey Bezos’ Blue Origin founder and chief executive.<p><p>Starship is scheduled to be launched into orbit about a week before orbital test flights are due to begin, Bezos said in a presentation to investors.<p><p>Blue Origin says the spacecraft is expected to fly autonomously for more than two hours on an unpiloted flight to the International Space Station.<p><p>“It’s going to be the last spacecraft we send to the ISS, so that we can do the biggest impact we can ever make on the planet,” Bezos said in a call with Reuters.<p> ']

headline: Munich marks 10th anniversary of space mission
content: ['<p>MUNICH  - Swiss astronaut Luca Parmitano will celebrate the 10th anniversary of his historic mission to the International Space Station (ISS) on Wednesday, the Swiss news agency DPA said.<p><p>He will join a group of 11 other crew members including Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin and Italian astronaut Vincenzo Martinetti at a ceremony marking the station’s first space mission since 2011.<p><p>NASA astronaut Jim Bridenstine will join him.<p> ']

headline: Boat-shaped dinosaur discovered in Florida
content: ['<p>MICHIGAN  - The first known fossil of a whale shark from Florida is now being studied and will help scientists pinpoint its diet.<p><p>Scientists have discovered a body of water called a “fish-shaped” dinosaur at the bottom of a shallow limestone cave near Naples, about 20 miles (35 km) east of Tampa, that had a diet including meat and other plant life including shrimp and crabs.<p><p>A team led by paleontologist Peter Duhigg of the University of Florida at Las Vegas is now analyzing the fossils to determine the fish-like diet of this species, its body shape and size.<p><p>“We know what to look for on our fossils, so we can be sure that there are no surprises to uncover. But the fish-shaped dinosaur is definitely something that is unusual,” Duhigg said. “The new findings will provide a much-needed insight into the life cycle of a large animal like this dinosaur,” Duhigg said.<p><p>The fish-shaped dinosaur had a diet including meat, shellfish and various insects including clams, crabs and shrimp, Duhigg said. It probably had a diet of some type of herbivorous plant, including algae and seaweed and also fish.<p>']

headline: UAE to buy land and land assets of China to develop air defenses
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China will buy about 26 hectares of land, part of a planned project to develop defense assets for the defense of airspace and sea, the country’s foreign ministry said on Thursday, making China the fifth country to buy such land in recent years.<p><p>The first such land purchase was announced on Wednesday, and China has said it intends to purchase the remaining land. The land will be used for a variety of purposes including a military base, schools, research and other facilities, the ministry said.<p><p>China has been a major power in Asia, with an estimated population of roughly 4.4 billion and a huge economy spanning more than five times Asia, with a net worth of over $2 trillion.<p><p>($1 = 0.2853 Chinese yuan)<p> ']

headline: Dogs that cannot walk can help with diabetes research
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Dogs that can walk can help with diabetes research, an emerging medical field where dogs can improve insulin sensitivity, the researchers said on Monday.<p><p>Researchers said on Monday they developed a new type of gene that helps mice use glucose in a different way, potentially helping patients who can walk without a cane. This allows them to use their arms as they’re fed without feeling the need for a cane to push them.<p><p>Dogs are the mainstay of humans’ diets but can also aid in their digestion, said Dr. Mark E. Miller of the University of California, San Diego, who co-led the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>“That means we’re looking at the dog’s glucose levels because these are the signals from the animal’s pancreas to the human gut,” Miller said.<p>']

headline: Eggs can be eaten in winter
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Eggs can be eaten in winter, but not by birds - in a British science project that has been plagued by overuse, overuse and conflict over eggs.<p><p>The research, carried out last week at the University of Portsmouth and published on Monday by Oxford University’s Eggbox, found that the use of an egg substitute with natural eggs in the summer can be made more hazardous.<p><p>“It’s very hard to be 100% sure that they’re safe to eat,” said University of Portsmouth researcher Paul Rowan, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature Biotechnology. “So we found this is very concerning.”<p><p>The eggs that contain artificial proteins in the form of keratinocytes - or EGGs - are then frozen and then eaten, along with other components of the food they contain.<p><p>The study also found that birds have developed a preference for egg substitutes because the protein they have grown in their eggs produces them with a higher acidity and more protein than natural eggs.<p><p>“Insects like the kennel fly, which eat eggs in winter, don’t have this problem at all, but we’re finding that egg substitute in winter eggs has a lower acidity and much more protein,” Rowan said.<p>']

headline: Gates warns of climate change risks of high carbon dioxide emissions: Nobel Prize winner
content: ['<p>HONG KONG  - President John Kerry will warn on Friday about the dangers posed by rising CO2 levels from burning fossil fuels, warning that climate change is causing serious health risks and harming the environment.<p><p>Climate change is causing increased risks of cancer, heart disease and strokes, while CO2 levels are rising globally, he will say at an event to be broadcast live on CCTV at the U.N. headquarters.<p><p>The World Health Organization (WHO) called for the WHO’s Chief Executive to warn that climate change “could be leading to widespread epidemics, substantial deaths and disruption of ecosystems, and grave human health problems”.<p><p>“I am confident that the risks to public health, environment, and the livelihoods of the people who live in countries experiencing major climate change disasters have been minimised,” he told Reuters.<p><p>The WHO “has decided that it will be important to assess, as part of the global conversation, the risks that climate change poses to the environment and to the well-being of the people of Earth,” it added.<p><p>Kerry will speak on climate change on Wednesday at the United Nations headquarters in New York, where he will be presenting his work on tackling climate change, in a speech which could raise fears of a repeat of last year’s Paris Agreement on tackling climate change.<p>']

headline: BENGALURU  - Indian scientists hope to discover the source of a new fungus called Bifidobium spp. that may help humans develop immunity to the sickle-cell anemia caused by the coronavirus.
content: ['<p><p>The coronavirus, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, has killed more than 340,000 people in the United States. <p><p>Bifidobium, which grows in the leaves of trees and shoots in the open, is a key component in several medicines and vaccines that help fight the disease.<p><p>Scientists in Bengaluru hope to learn the secret to the fungus by studying the plant’s spores and extracting the enzymes necessary for its use in vaccines.<p><p>“The objective of this project is to take an ancient drug called bifidobium and extract it into vaccines for patients with severe COVID-19, and to develop antibodies for COVID-19 immunity,” said Shanti Rauten, chief scientist of the Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIH-19), one of the Indian researchers involved.<p><p>Bifidobium may also help in treating severe malaria patients, which has killed 3,200 people since the virus entered circulation. <p><p>The findings could help advance efforts to fight off the virus, Rauten added. <p><p>India has been plagued by cases of the coronavirus since March.<p>']

headline: Habitat for fish
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - A fish known as the bluefin, a rare but important fish that thrives in deserts, is catching on in Asia.<p><p>Scientists said on Wednesday that it will soon be discovered in the world’s oceans and that it has a long-term impact on marine ecosystems.<p><p>The bluefin, roughly the size of a medium-sized bell fish, lives in tropical and subtropical ecosystems and has a lifespan of 30 years and a temperature of 66 degrees Fahrenheit (28 Celsius).<p><p>It was found on a sand beach in Taiwan, and researchers hope that similar habitats in other parts of the world will be discovered as the bluefin grows.<p><p>“I think that it’s the ultimate predator of all marine life,” said University of Copenhagen marine ecologist and study co-author Dr. Peter Woerner, the study’s lead author. “We want to give it some sort of a protection against predators, but at the same time, we’re hoping that it’s a very small one.”<p><p>Bluefin can survive in freshwater environments, but are more adapted to these environments. The bluefin also has the ability to survive in freshwater habitats. The study said that although some sea creatures can survive in the freshwater environment, bluefin are not able to survive in the deep-water environment.<p>']

headline: The first modern mammal descended from an extinct dinosaur from Madagascar
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Three million years ago, a great ape-like, ape-like creature called a sauropod-like ape-like creature appeared in a cave in Madagascar and formed a huge brain, bones and a limb.<p><p>Its name, sauropod, means “a giant brain,” according to a study published on Thursday in the journal Current Biology.<p><p>Its skull, which is about the size of a small person, is about two-thirds of an adult male, said paleontologist and study co-author John Aiken, a paleontologist at the University of California, San Diego. The creature was called a “bird-like mammal” by the researchers.<p><p>“It looked something like this and did not look like an animal, but it looked like a bat,” Aiken said.<p><p>It was not the only modern mammal species that arose from a cave in Madagascar but none had a head, teeth or brain.<p><p>“We can think of a lot of evolutionary adaptations for a mammal, but these are not the only adaptations that have been discovered,” Aiken said.<p><p>“They are adaptations that evolved independently, rather than separately, so this is another example of multiple ancestral adaptations for different mammalian species.”<p> ']

headline: Wang Chao, a Chinese monk who lived around 700 years ago, died on Saturday at the age of 81. He was a leading figure in Chinese Buddhist meditation and had a vast collection of writings. He was an adept meditator, according to his website, "the monk of wangchang, whose name means the flower, and who, by his meditative actions, has attained ultimate wisdom, and also attained the highest position." He died at his residence at a monastery in Wuhan, Wuhan province. He was a Buddhist monk of exceptional merit who had achieved great progress through practice. He died in the monastery. (cn; reut.rs/2bFhv9r) It can be seen in action in video: Swiss researchers test telescope for detections
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Scientists have made a surprising discovery - the first-ever observation of gravitational waves, the invisible light produced by gravitational waves.<p><p>The discovery may herald new avenues of research into the dark side of the universe and new ways of surveying the dark side of the cosmos.<p><p>“We can observe gravitational waves, they are invisible,” said physicist Markus Heimann of the Swiss Federal Institute for Space Physics and astronomer Marco Verones of the Universität Bremen, who led the research published in the journal Nature Astronomy.<p><p>The scientists tested a telescope for a “stellar signal” - a light-bearing electromagnetic wave - on an 11th-century wooden structure called Stadt von Schwanze. The structure was placed under an artificial light-producing lens, and the light was detected.<p><p>This signal was then propagated by a “red-hot electromagnetic field”, indicating the gravitational wave wave is real.<p><p>“This enables us to see the gravitational wave in high-resolution images,” Heimann added.<p><p>The scientists say that by studying light emitted from a gravitational wave, the scientists could understand the physics behind phenomena such as the gravitational wave and detect the gravitational wave itself.<p><p>The research was the first to be carried out on the structure, Heimann added.']

headline: Cairo's space program for moon mining: NASA
content: ['<p>(This story corrects to remove paragraph from first paragraph)<p><p>The United Arab Emirates’ space program is set to undergo a major overhaul this week when it launches its first unmanned astronaut mission on its Mars mission next April.<p><p>The UAE intends to build its own satellite system capable of carrying humans into orbit from a manned rocket, in addition to providing satellite communication to U.S. astronauts aboard U.S. space flights.<p><p>A senior government official in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a key government function will be to create an “essential workforce” that will make the UAE a prime partner in the project.<p><p>“There are opportunities for us to diversify the capabilities of the UAE,” he said. “But we’ve to develop new capabilities,” he added, without disclosing what the UAE aims for.<p><p>The UAE has long relied on Saudi Arabia’s deep space programme, which it has also worked to develop. The UAE has been at odds with Saudi Arabia in recent years over funding for space exploration, with Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations cutting budgets for research and development of their space assets.<p><p>The UAE plans to conduct commercial satellite launches from its own launch pad and to conduct its own mission development.<p>']

headline: Dry and dry, you may find it more difficult to make a meal of vegetables and fruit than with fruit and nuts - and less nutritious - than fruits and vegetables. For more, see these 10 easy ways to lose weight and live a healthy life. 'Bigger, bigger fish': China plans to mine coal for biofuels in 2020
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - China plans to mine coal for biofuels in 2020, one of the world’s largest coal exporters and a key step towards creating a clean, greener environment, the head of state-run China National Academy of Sciences said on Thursday.<p><p>The next phase of the project will see construction of 1,400 facilities in five regions, aiming to mine 10% of the total amount of CO2 produced, a huge leap in development, according to state media.<p><p>A major hurdle is the long-term costs of extracting the coal from the coal.<p><p>The first coal mine will be in the southern and western regions of China, with a diameter of more than 1,500 hectares (3,000 sq km), the academy said.<p><p>The academy said construction costs would fall by up to 40%, partly because new coal mines and factories will be needed to mine the coal.<p><p>That could mean cheaper coal being burned in coal-fired power stations in regions with poorer infrastructure.<p><p>The academy said that it expects to have more coal mined in 2020 than in the previous five years, with more than 6% of the total mined in the next five years.<p><p>The academy also said it expects to have a capacity of 7 million tonnes in 2021 and 10 million tonnes in 2022.<p>']

headline: Mulligan says he can detect traces of human DNA in test tube
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A doctor who said he could detect traces of human DNA in a test tube - and a professor who said he could detect traces of human DNA in samples taken from the moon - said he could detect traces of DNA in samples from the moon as early as next year, when the moon is too small to be seen from Earth.<p><p>British physicist Richard Mulligan, who said he could identify traces of human DNA in samples from the moon as early as next year, said the potential for extraterrestrial DNA was a new discovery.<p><p>“The test tube is quite small, you need a lot of extra power to get it up and running,” he told Reuters. “And what we would like to do is test out a way to extract some of that back - that’s what’s needed” to be able to extract DNA from the moon.<p><p>“That’s what I think it’s going to be. So, what’s the odds of me detecting something in it and then having a chance of finding out what’s inside it,” Mulligan said.<p><p>Mulligan said he and his colleagues at Britain’s Astrophysical Observatory (Bos), also known as Bournemouth Observatory, had tested samples of the moon on samples taken from May 14.<p>']

headline: Fossilized human genome reveals genes linked with the evolution of COVID-19
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have revealed the genome of a small ancient human species that may help explain the origins of COVID-19, a key human killer that has left many nations scarred by the pandemic.<p><p>Geneticist and evolutionary biologist Thomas Zurbuchen from the University of California, Riverside, said the genome was discovered on Wednesday in a cave in northwestern Germany, where the genome sequence had been sequenced using an apparatus developed by a team led by Ludwig von Mises.<p><p>Zurbuchen said the sequence was not the original. The researchers suspect it originated in a Denisovan cave, located in northwestern Germany.<p><p>The gene coding for the virus also appeared to have been linked with the evolution of COVID-19.<p><p>“Our findings strongly support the importance of preserving genomes for the future of medicine,” Zurbuchen said. “We are now exploring the possible pathway that could lead to the eradication of the pandemic and our understanding of the genetic basis of the pathogenesis of the disease,” he added.<p> ']

headline: NASA to launch new robotic rover in 2018
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - NASA to launch its new rover, the “robotic lander” on a voyage to Mars to collect samples for future research in preparation for its planned return to Earth in 2023, the agency on Wednesday announced a seven-year mission to the Red Planet.<p><p>The rover, named Elysium, will carry out its first ever Martian mission, which will test the limits of human ingenuity in extracting soil samples from Martian soil, according to NASA.<p><p>The robotic lander, named Elysium 2, will provide data, tools and data mining for NASA’s Artemis program, in which U.S. astronauts have used Martian-made spacecraft to extract valuable resources for the aerospace industry.<p><p>The new Mars mission would help inform NASA’s broader plans for Mars by mapping the depths and composition of Mars, guiding scientific research, studying Mars’ atmosphere and water and potentially establishing a permanent presence there by the year 2023, the agency said in a news release.<p><p>“The Martian mission is a major milestone for the United States in the quest to get us out of the habit of looking for signs of past colonization on another planet,” Jeff Bezos, President and CEO of Amazon.com Inc., said in a statement. “The Elysium 2 will bring a new perspective to the science of Mars exploration and provide key data on the depth of the Martian atmosphere and water.”<p>']

headline: Famously dangerous and deadly species that could devastate South America's tropical forests
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - The blackfooted rhino, often called the black bear, is known for its menacingly vicious claws and long arms. Its unusual appearance makes it a particularly dangerous predator for forest management officials.<p><p>Black bears have long been endangered in South America, but scientists have been unable to estimate what it might do to humans. Until now.<p><p>Black bears - often referred to as black bears due to their large size and extreme fur coloration - are known to eat a variety of plants and animals, but are not endangered.<p><p>The species is particularly endangered in the Amazon rainforest in the Amazon rain forest that is home to some 13,500 trees. In addition to the black bear, over 300 other species of tree include the white rhino, the white rhino, the blue bear and the black bear.<p><p>The black bear’s habitat is protected with national, international and state recognition, but bears have been documented feeding on endangered species for decades, including some species that are now endangered.<p><p>The black bear is one of the most dangerous species on Earth, according to the U.N. Environment Programme. The black bear is one of the world’s deadliest predators. It kills about 400 people annually.<p>']

headline: Fossilized fish were part of 'fossilized dinosaur fossil'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Scientists have found fossils of dinosaur-like dinosaurs that were part of the fossilized remains of a large carnivorous dinosaur called Arthropodontosaurus from southern China’s Xichang Cave in the northern Xinjiang region, and said the finding could lead to treatments for cancer in future.<p><p>The fossils, part of a collection of about 130 individual dinosaur fossils dating back to about 400,000 years ago, were uncovered by the Chinese National Parks National Parks in Xinjiang.<p><p>The fossil, weighing approximately 100 tons, was found near a cave where hundreds of animals lived and where dinosaur bones were found in the 1950s.<p><p>“There is an important evolutionary change happening between an early carnivorous dinosaur called Arthropodontosaurus and modern-day dinosaur dinosaurs like the modern-day great apes,” said University of Minnesota paleontologist Zhu Zhen, lead author of the research published in the journal PLOS ONE. “I think there is more material in that cave’s ecosystem than ever before,” Zhu added.<p><p>Arthropodontosaurs may have been part of the Triassic Period, the largest period of dinosaur-like dinosaurs ever documented, and the earliest-known complete group of animal relatives including the lizards, crocodiles, crocodilians, lizards, crocodiles and lizards.<p><p>Arthropods are relatively slow-moving vertebrates and can survive for a relatively long time with minimal injuries.']

headline: It is difficult to predict the outcome of the Brexit vote, the academics warn.
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The UK election result could decide the fate of the EU’s plans to leave the bloc by the end of March 2019, experts warn.<p><p>Brexit would have serious implications for the bloc’s economic competitiveness, it has emerged as the leading cause of Brexit-related uncertainty.<p><p>The academics, from the UK’s National Centre for International and Development Economics, said the outcome of the referendum risked a further erosion of Britain’s influence in the European Union and a sharp decline in the attractiveness of the 27 member states.<p><p>They predicted that in the case of a UK exit, British trade would contract and output could fall sharply.<p><p>The experts also warned that the EU’s approach to Brexit could shift more quickly than previously expected and that its decision-making process could be beset by uncertainty and unpredictability.<p><p>A lack of clarity on the UK’s position on whether to remain in the bloc - the European Commission said last week it planned to launch a review of the UK’s EU membership next year - could lead to confusion and an increase in the risk of Brexit.<p><p>The uncertainty could also result in increased uncertainty on the rules of Brexit which could lead to less clarity on the EU’s exit terms, said the economists.<p>']

headline: The International Space Station: How astronauts are in the wrong hands
content: ['<p>PARIS  - NASA astronaut Nick Hague was on a mission to the International Space Station when he was hit by a splashdown and eventually lost consciousness, the space agency said on Thursday, after suffering a brain injury.<p><p>Hague’s injuries - which were discovered in a routine check-up - had not affected the recovery, agency spokesman Greg Hart said.<p><p>A total of 12 people had been aboard the orbiting space station for two months and were aboard two other astronauts after the accident in November, Hart said.<p><p>Hague had broken his orbital bone in the crash, the ISS’s health emergency management unit found.<p><p>The next step is to recover, Hart added.<p><p>Hague’s status as a possible candidate for deep space exploration is unclear.<p><p>“We don’t know if he will ever be eligible for such a mission, but it would be nice to be a candidate and go into the habit of doing the most important thing in the shortest amount of time possible,” Hart said.<p><p>“Obviously, Nick and I had this long discussion over the next year and a half, and Nick said: “You don’t have to go into this.”<p>']

headline: Chinese firm set to launch first astronaut space station on Feb.20
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s space company, China Heavy, has set its sights on becoming the first private space firm to launch a manned crew into space from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, state media reported on Wednesday, citing the ministry of space and development.<p><p>The plan was to launch the first crew into orbit in early March from Baikonur, a facility about 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.<p><p>China’s space agency said its first manned crewed space flight to the space station in 2020 would be the last.<p><p>SpaceX’s CST-100 Starliner will send its crew of seven astronauts to the space station from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California in the first half of 2020, its website said.<p> ']

headline: Nancy, former NASA astronaut turns U.S. space agency's moon exploration ambitions into a dream: NASA
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Nancy Reagan is a rising star in the presidential race, but that only helps explain the presidential race’s dramatic turn to the right since the resignation of her husband, former President Ronald Reagan, on Tuesday.<p><p>The Washington Post reported on Tuesday that as vice president, she helped engineer a plan that she said had transformed NASA into an international hub for science, technology, innovation and exploration.<p><p>Her remarks come as a flurry of congressional probes into Russia’s meddling in the 2016 election attempt to damage Trump’s presidential campaign.<p><p>At the center of that probe are questions over a former Soviet Union scientist who worked on a lunar exploration mission and who is cooperating with the Justice Department.<p><p>Trump on Monday blasted Congress for not going far enough on a bill to revive the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s efforts to build a manned lunar launch capability for the U.S. space program.<p><p>A bipartisan group of six lawmakers on Tuesday called on the White House to act immediately to reinstate NASA’s Apollo program, which was supposed to return astronauts to the moon in 2023.<p><p>“Today’s president needs to act now to ensure our national security on a world-class space program,” the Republican-led Congress said in a letter to the Trump administration.<p>']

headline: Frozen lakes in Arctic are warming faster than ever and scientists say the melting ice in the Arctic has pushed a dramatic spike in sea level in a global warming event known as the “pause” - an event where the Earth warms and water vapor condenses and recedes.
content: ['<p><p>The scientists, led by U.S. glaciologist and climate scientist Paul Wolk, said on Thursday they had found that the Arctic sea level was now at its highest point since 1950, up 11 inches (13 cm) over a period of up to 1,450 days.<p><p>Their data, the most comprehensive to date from a satellite-based study of the ice sheets that blanket Antarctica, showed that, despite the warming, the ice sheet has rebounded more rapidly than previously.<p><p>“This shows that the Arctic ice sheet has rebounded faster than previously thought,” Wolk said. “We are now at the point where we are now at the peak of the Arctic ice sheet” - a point where the Arctic sea level is expected to become twice as high as at the end of the 20th Century.”<p><p>The Arctic sea level reached its highest point on record in 2016, surpassing the peak in 2009, Wolk said, in a sign of the warming Arctic.<p><p>Scientists calculate the Arctic sea level at about 25 inches (29 cm) above sea level. While that means the Arctic sea is melting faster than previously understood, it also means it is warming faster than previously believed.<p>']

headline: Iris is a very simple sensor. It can sense blood pressure, it can track a pulse, it can find an object even if it was invisible. When Iris cameras do this, they show us nothing. I dare say, the first time I have ever dreamed of having a self-driving car, I had to take out one of them and get a new one. It was a big pain in the ass.
content: ['<p><p>So, I went ahead and wrote an algorithm and put it in the car. This was very interesting because a lot of sensors can take so much data, they can be very sensitive. And it was interesting that they did not even need the usual software to interpret the data. So I started to work out how to make self-driving cars more like cars, by making them less autonomous.<p><p>“The first step was to make them be totally self-driving,” says Jiri Schilling, director of the University of Southern California Robotics Lab, “without any external sensors.” So, they can only steer their vehicles autonomously, and that way, they can be tested.<p><p>That was interesting because, when Iris cameras do this, they really tell you if an object is visible or not. So, when Iris uses these sensors to see if something is moving, and when the cars can see if it is moving, then we can actually see it because these sensors can tell if it is moving or not.<p>']

headline: Virus may be 'worrying for children'
content: ['<p>BASCRUTO, France  - The presence of the coronavirus may be worrying for children, scientists have found, especially if they are given vaccinations in schools, a health ministry report said on Thursday.<p><p>A study carried out at least a decade after the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported in October that "vaccination and education are needed for every child in the world to be protected from the most deadly of illnesses".<p><p>Researchers say the risks include infection, transmission, complications, infections, disease progression and deaths.<p><p>The report by the European Central Committee on Vaccination (COCV), funded by the World Health Organization, concluded that children born to vaccinated parents should be able to have vaccine-preventable infections with similar risks as their unaffected siblings and should be advised to seek specialist advice.<p><p>“As children, our greatest fear was that vaccines and education could be a worrying sign for children and society,” said COCV co-author, Olga Cepeda.<p><p>“We therefore strongly advise all parents to be aware of the risks and should be prepared to take the necessary precautions in order to protect them,” she added.<p>']

headline: Oxygen pollution and other climate-change threats pose dangers to air quality
content: ['<p>LONDON  - From the air we breathe, the amount of oxygen in our bodies, and the concentrations of certain chemicals in the atmosphere, scientists say they have identified an urgent threat to global warming posed by excessive nitrogen dioxide and other greenhouse gases.<p><p>Experts said nitrogen dioxide, an essential component of CO2, is a key ingredient to making up the air we breathe.<p><p>Air pollution causes respiratory inflammation, asthma and neurological problems. In some countries, nitrogen dioxide is banned. <p><p>Nations with nitrogen dioxide-heavy air are increasingly reliant on fossil fuels, and a growing number believe the carbon footprint is rising at a faster pace than the productivity of the atmosphere.<p><p>Experts said they had mapped out a “mess” on how to cut nitrogen dioxide emissions by 80% by 2050. <p><p>“Nuclear power is a great option, but we need to think about the impacts that will have on the environment,” said Thomas Heidel, deputy environment and health minister.<p><p>The new study is the first in which nitrogen dioxide emissions are linked to air quality, but also to deaths.<p><p>It found that nitrogen dioxide emitted by the largest emitters - those that produce the most nitrogen dioxide - accounted for 22% of global deaths.<p>']

headline: Oasis: Scientists build two dozen telescopes to see galaxy
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A major scientific advance for the world’s first high-tech astronomy telescope that was originally intended for the African savannah has been completed.<p><p>The telescope, developed by Swiss-based optical science company NED and funded by Britain’s state-owned National Science Foundation (NSF), is set to be able to map more than 1,000 galaxies.<p><p>“This is really the first time that we can actually observe a galaxy in our own backyard,” astronomer Gennady Norella of the European Southern Observatory (ESO) told Reuters in an interview.<p><p>“It will provide unprecedented resolution, super-resolution of the sky, a lot of the details we need,” he added.<p><p>Norella is also looking at the formation of gas clouds on Earth, the effects of galactic formation, the galaxy “Gateway” phenomenon that can affect Earth’s oceans and dust grains.<p><p>The telescope is scheduled to launch in late 2021 and will focus on studying the solar system’s three most recent solar eclipses, known as “the Long March” and “the Eta”, respectively.<p><p>“The first full solar eclipse will be visible at midnight on Saturday (Feb 25),” the ESO’s Norella said.<p>']

headline: A new study suggests that the virus that causes AIDS may be better targeted for suppressing symptoms
content: ['<p> - The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>COVID-19 can cause severe pneumonia, fever, and other symptoms, but the results of a team of researchers exploring whether the virus can be effectively targeted for suppressing symptoms were not promising.<p><p>Using the novel coronavirus and other human immune responses, the researchers analyzed how different responses by various strains of the virus appeared to control patients’ symptoms, including the first and second-degree common colds and influenza.<p><p>The study, published in the journal Science on Tuesday, may ultimately prove useful in other areas where drugs could be made more effective and more effective.<p><p>The virus has been identified in the United States and other parts of Latin America, and has been implicated in more than 400 cases of COVID-19 since its discovery in 1976, according to U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).<p><p>A team of researchers studied nearly 800 patients for the first time in November 2014 and discovered they had antibodies to the novel coronavirus, an immune response that helps protect against illness and the buildup of neutralizing antibodies that neutralize the new coronavirus.<p><p>In addition to suppressing symptoms, the antibodies could also be used as a marker for when antibodies stop working.<p>']

headline: SpaceX wins U.S. contract to fly human astronauts to space
content: ['<p>LAS VEGAS  - SpaceX and Boeing Co BA.N signed a $15 million NASA contract for their first manned crewed mission to the International Space Station from June 7 through July 7, U.S. Vice President Mike Pence said.<p><p>The $15 million award comes as SpaceX and Boeing seek to become the first private companies to carry humans to the space station and return them back to Earth for NASA’s “priority mission to return the U.S. astronauts back to Earth” under NASA’s Commercial Crew Program.<p><p>The two companies, a joint venture between Boeing Co BA.N and Lockheed Martin Corp LMT.N, and Boeing also work on an upcoming manned voyage to Mars.<p><p>SpaceX and Boeing jointly launched a joint test flight last month, the third manned mission by both companies to the space station and return humans to the station in under six months. Boeing will send two additional astronauts to orbit on the same flight.<p><p>The first mission is planned for July 9, Pence said, though Boeing would not say how long it would take SpaceX to get an additional crew to the space station, or what the mission could be.<p><p>Pence was asked by reporters whether Boeing planned to send a third crew member to the space station or return astronauts to Earth.<p>']

headline: A study suggests possible human immunity against hepatitis B virus infection
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - The following is a roundup of some of the latest scientific studies on the novel coronavirus and efforts to find treatments and vaccines for COVID-19, the illness caused by the virus.<p><p>A study examining the immune response to COVID-19 in human volunteers shows that antibodies from the novel coronavirus might be able to neutralize the virus, researchers said on Thursday, in advance of the country’s first anti-viral drug, Tretinoza, to treat hepatitis B in patients who are already infected.<p><p>To be sure, people who get hepatitis B virus infection are already sick and may need to be hospitalized, the study team said. But it found no sign of a chronic illness that can be neutralized by Tretinoza.<p><p>“The findings, based on large-scale data from the initial COVID-19 study, support the hypothesis that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) immune response to Tretinoza could be useful in developing a treatment strategy for COVID-19 in patients,” said John Hopkins University infectious disease scientist Sandra K. Housman. “We may not have fully recovered from COVID-19 yet, but Tretinoza may have potential potential in treating this group of patients as soon as next week,” Housman added.<p>']

headline: Treatment of malaria kills more than 1.4 million people in West Africa
content: ['<p>DETROIT  - The global pandemic that is ravaging Africa is killing 1.4 million people a year in West Africa, according to a new report from Doctors Without Borders.<p><p>Malaria attacks more than 1.4 million people, with nearly 400,000 dying.<p><p>Males and females are more than twice as likely to be infected as males, with more than half of infected females reporting a fever and nearly 50 percent having a rash.<p><p>The toll of malaria varies by country, depending on the type of parasite, according to the study.<p><p>Doctors Without Borders says the death toll in the country’s capital, Addis Ababa, is nearly triple the national average. The average death toll is 41.<p><p>The U.N. agency says the numbers “should increase as we try to increase vaccination rates in Africa to prevent malaria transmission.”<p><p>“With only a handful of countries, including the United States, including several nations with high malaria rates, this is a serious international emergency that calls for urgent actions.”<p><p>The report also highlights the challenges facing countries working to fight the disease, such as reducing malnutrition and addressing conflict.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin criticizes Trump for revoking U.S. missile defense program
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Russia’s deputy foreign minister blasted President Donald Trump’s decision to bar U.S. missile defense systems from the country last week as "ridiculous".<p><p>In a statement on Monday, U.S. Deputy Under Secretary of State Victoria Nuland said the U.S. Strategic Command should immediately suspend its missile defense program to deter further ballistic missile attacks from Russia.<p><p>Nuland’s comments came a day after Trump threatened a military strike on Russia if it failed to comply with a Russian ballistic missile defense shield treaty signed between the U.S. and Russia.<p><p>The U.S. defense department said on Monday it will take additional action against Russia in response to any missile defense measure the Trump administration considers to be unconstitutional.<p><p>“The decision by the Trump administration to bar the entry of ballistic missile defense systems into Russia’s territory is unwise,” Nuland said.<p><p>The U.S. defense secretary was not immediately available for comment.<p><p>The decision was taken by U.S. President Donald Trump to rescind the 2014 Stromat-2 missile defense system under the National Security Council. The defense agency, headed by former President Barack Obama, has said Russia is behind the missile defense shield.<p>']

headline: Bosnian scientists unveil 'huge' Neanderthals skeleton in northern Europe
content: ['<p>LAKAR, Bosnia  - Scientists in Bosnia’s northern province of Lublin on Monday unveiled a skull and teeth of a great-granddaughter of a prominent European hunter, a landmark in the long process of deciphering the genetic material that brought the legendary tribe together.<p><p>The skeleton, which weighs about 2,300 tonnes (4,700 lbs), shows the presence of numerous Neanderthals in the region as well as a number of early modern Neanderthal species.<p><p>“This is the greatest contribution of our study and work for us, so that we can understand the evolution of our species,” said archaeologist and archaeobotany Dr Marti Zivadja of the Museum of Human Evolution in Lublin.<p><p>The skeleton was discovered about 100 meters (yards) east of the city of Kuzmaz, about 200 km (155 miles) southeast of central Bosnia.<p><p>Scientists suspect the bones were used in a manufacturing process of making an animal hide for use in a fur or woolen garment. The skulls, however, still remain uncertain.<p><p>“I hope this gives the world something to believe,” Zivadja said, according to a statement by the university.<p><p>“This shows us how much genetic material we have in our culture and how much our ancestors made it.”<p> ']

headline: Russia launches satellite for first time in orbit - TVT
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia launched its first satellite on Saturday for the first time into orbit after previously launching satellites into orbit, marking a milestone in its space program.<p><p>Roscosmos, the space agency of Russia’s former Soviet Union, launched the satellite Sputnik 1 on an unpiloted mission to the International Space Station. It will provide the country with information on international spacecraft with the aim of creating a space station for astronauts to travel to and from the space station, the official Russian news agency RIA quoted Roscosmos as saying.<p><p>The launch comes days after Russian cosmonaut Alexei Ovchinin and U.S. Vice President Mike Pence made comments indicating U.S. President Donald Trump’s commitment to expanding U.S. participation in the space race and Moscow should consider joining it.<p><p>Russian Deputy Prime Minister Dmitry Rogozin said on Thursday he was glad to see Sputnik 1 successfully launched and said it would provide Moscow with more information.<p><p>The Sputnik 1 mission is the first orbital satellite of its kind, designed to help Russia develop a space station. It also marks the third orbital launch of a Russian orbital vehicle into orbit.<p><p>The launch also marks the first of its kind for the United States and Russia.<p>']

headline: Ivan Bevanov is a science fiction author, science fiction writer and director. He has been called into space on a mission to put an end <PAD>  “mess” in outer space. (JAKARTA PESADRE/REUTERS)  - A man wearing a Russian cosmonaut t-shirt and camouflage stands silently in a corner of the cosmodrome, wearing a hat, sunglasses, a belt and a green shirt. He is wearing a camouflage belt on the far side of his head. He is standing in the middle of the long-vanished town of Zhezkazgan in the Siberian region of Uralia, near the border with Kazakhstan. (bit.ly/2oJ3GZ)’s Bevanov has been living in space for eight years, according to Russian cosmonaut and cosmonaut website Sputnik.com, which provides space travel and other science-fiction stories. (bit.ly/2iJ2OJ)’s Bevanov, who last visited the International Space Station in 2012, has said he wants to go there “in a day” after his mission. (cbs/3L2h3H)
content: ['<p> - A man wearing a Russian cosmonaut t-shirt and camouflage stands silently in the corner of the space station and silently introduces himself in the background.
