(bit.ly/3o2J3GZ)<p> - A man with the head of a submarine wearing a camouflage belt is being hailed by local residents as an example of the way Russia has moved to create space travel - and by some in the community, which sees it as a way to avoid detection by the United States and others in the space race. (bit.ly/2cKwZr5)<p><p>I']

headline: Swansea City boss Josep Macheda unveils his team of new players
content: ['<p>Swansea City manager Sivan Jelavic has unveiled the first team, new squad and academy players and unveiled a programme of upcoming summer transfers.<p><p>Jelavic said the players for the summer were: “Trying to find out if they will be fit for the World Cup in Brazil and then in England.”<p><p>He has been in charge of the club’s academy since 2014, managing to turn a profit in the three years it has been operating and securing three players under contract.<p><p>Jelavic’s plans include overhauling the club’s squad with a fresh set of players and upgrading the academy in an attempt to attract more talent.<p><p>Jelavic has made a name for himself by being a hard worker in the England squad, where he is named after his father, who was a captain and played for Wales during the Second World War.<p><p>He joined the club in 2006, aged 16, after making a successful start to his career as a first team player and manager.<p><p>Since his arrival, Swansea have managed just six goals and two assists, conceding eight league goals and seven league goals to their opponents.<p><p>Jelavic is in the midst of signing a new seven-year contract worth just over £500,000 to be paid in 2021.<p>']

headline: China's Mars rover has successfully landed on the moon
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Chinese rover on the moon has successfully landed on the surface of the moon’s south pole after an unusually slow touchdown last month, the official Xinhua news agency reported on Wednesday.<p><p>The Chinese team will send a robot and rover to the moon’s south pole next month to study the mineral and soil samples, Xinhua said, citing an unnamed source.<p><p>China has embarked on an ambitious four-year quest to put an asteroid into orbit around the moon, a goal it has sought in recent years by using robotic landers to collect samples of lunar rock, and by exploring its interior to determine its mineral content.<p><p>China last year launched its first lunar lander in April, but the lander was hobbled by technical and financial challenges.<p><p>The rover landed safely on the lunar surface on Wednesday after a 15-month period of rough terrain landing.<p><p>“The robot did not return to Earth, as planned,” one of the sources said, according to Xinhua.<p><p>The rover will attempt to reach the moon’s south pole by 2027. The final destination is unknown.<p><p>China has been the first nation to achieve lunar surface exploration in space, but a recent trip to the moon’s south pole was plagued by delays and technical issues.<p>']

headline: Lionsgate says it will test novel COVID-19 vaccine on monkeys
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - The United States’s largest pharmaceutical company said on Wednesday it will test a drug designed to prevent coronavirus infection with antibodies to prevent a disease that has killed tens of thousands in the United States.<p><p>The test results come as the agency mulls whether to charge some of the world’s top health insurers to cover vaccines that fight the disease, including those that target parts of the immune system.<p><p>Companies are racing to find new ways to limit the spread of the coronavirus but the United States is one of them.<p><p>“In a world where everybody is on the internet and everybody has everything, if you want to keep people sick enough to die, you need to have a vaccine,” said Peter Meyers, president and chief executive of the U.S.-based vaccine firm Livestrong, which is part of a partnership with Pfizer Co PLC.<p><p>The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week that it expected to start testing nearly 1 million of the new coronavirus vaccines by early next year, a number that would fall dramatically short of the 1 billion needed to combat the pandemic by early 2021.<p><p>The number of COVID-19 cases in the United States peaked in 2012, but this year only 4% of all infections occurred with antibodies, compared with 7% during the same period in 2013, the agency said.<p>']

headline: China calls for'space flight' after test launch
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China on Thursday said it called for a test flight of its flagship space rocket to demonstrate China’s new space technology - reusable launch vehicles.<p><p>The launch, scheduled for 2021, comes amid a slowdown in Chinese launches following China’s landmark space program in March.<p><p>The launch, a heavy-lift, first-stage rocket from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center, has seen a drop in Chinese commercial activity since then, leading to a setback for the government’s push to put more pressure on Beijing to develop its own space industry.<p><p>In July, a similar test launch of a rocket built by a Chinese private firm in partnership with U.S.-based Vulcan Technologies Inc, dropped the global launch market for that rocket, reaching 2.5 billion yuan ($1.9 billion) in value in its first half, the Xinhua news agency reported.<p><p>China also said it was exploring ways to develop reusable space vehicles, and in 2017 unveiled the first commercially available launch system for the China National Space Administration - a role China has said it will play as soon as 2024.<p><p>The new rocket will launch on a test rocket to bring it within a few hundred miles of a launchpad.<p><p>Chinese companies and industry representatives on Thursday welcomed the test flight, and said the launch would “provide a boost to China’s space program.”<p>']

headline: A key question in developing a vaccine against tuberculosis is whether it is safe to use it during treatment and whether patients can recover faster after receiving it. “In my view, the safety and efficacy of the TB vaccine against tuberculosis in people who undergo treatment in an outpatient setting are not yet established,” said Dr. Benjamin Friedman, chair of the department of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School in Boston. “It needs to be tested with larger trials.” “In terms of potential clinical trials, I would recommend it in patients who do not need daily treatment." In addition, Friedman noted, studies are needed to determine the safety and efficacy of different types of TB treatments. “However, the potential for large trial trials is huge.” The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported this week that there were more than 21,000 cases of tuberculosis, an illness spread through coughing, sneezing and diarrhea. Most patients do not develop symptoms. (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (link for a graphic on tuberculosis: bit.ly/36bLq4k) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q) (bit.ly/3Np4i4q
Jurassic Park, the latest instalment in the James Bond franchise, is in a much better state of health.
content: ['<p><p>It has been diagnosed with antibodies that protect against the common cold, which has made it much less likely that its victims will be infected.<p><p>The condition has not yet been officially declared a COVID-19 and the government hopes to have a coronavirus vaccine as early as 2019.<p><p>“We are in a very bad state of health today,” the health minister, Daniel Hurley, said.<p><p>“We would like the next generation of coronaviruses to be much more robust,” Hurley added.<p><p>“The good news is that we have got some vaccines, and we’ve got some early detection data,” Hurley added.<p><p>The coronavirus vaccine was launched as a national initiative, but has faced controversy since launching after a new test tube was found to contain the virus.<p><p>Last month the UK government announced plans for new vaccines and a “long term” vaccine roadmap to deal with COVID-19, with the aim of targeting only coronaviruses.<p><p>In November, British scientists discovered that coronaviruses were circulating in the blood of mice at a much higher rate than previously thought.<p>']

headline: A small dinosaur found in Brazil sheds light on early life
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A small dinosaur that lived roughly 300 million years ago in a river delta called Cretaceous Brazil may have made a surprising discovery about early life: It sheds light on the evolution of early mammalian and reptilian life.<p><p>Researchers from the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany said on Thursday that Cretaceous river delta grasses were among the first plants to be cultivated for meat for meat.<p><p>“We have not yet found a plant-eating mammal, but we have found a dinosaur that lived alongside them,” said paleontologist Erika O’Connor of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany, lead author of the research published in the journal Nature.<p><p>The researchers also said the plant-eating dinosaur, called Carrotaeus tarsus, is an important early example of a large-bodied plant-eating creature that had lived alongside other plants during the evolutionary transition.<p><p>“Carrotaeus’s growth spanned 300 million years in a river delta from Mexico to Brazil,” O’Connor said.<p><p>Carrotaeus is one of the earliest plant-eating dinosaurs, with fossils and fossils from a number of plant species, including the dinosaur Dungua, found in Argentina in 2012.<p> ']

headline: SpaceX's crewmates are ready to go aboard SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket
content: ['<p>LOS ANGELES  - Crew members from SpaceX’s astronaut capsule blasted off from Florida’s Cape Canaveral on Sunday for their final test of its first ever crewed mission to the International Space Station, a crucial liftoff that is due to take place in December.<p><p>The unmanned SpaceX capsule, which will carry nearly 500 passengers aboard the Falcon 9 rocket carrying the U.S. Air Force Space Command to the International Space Station, successfully blasted off from the Kennedy Space Center on Sunday.<p><p>The Falcon 9, SpaceX’s first manned space mission to the International Space Station, will have two payloads on board it to carry astronauts to the space station, according to SpaceX officials.<p><p>SpaceX has made it clear that it is aiming for an emergency landing in mid-December, but a spokesman said the two crewmates on board would be able to return to Earth “within a week”.<p><p>The SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule - dubbed the “SpaceX Crew” - lifted off from Kennedy Space Center at 8:51 a.m. EST (1151 GMT), about an hour after liftoff, about two hours after liftoff from Florida’s Cape Canaveral.<p><p>A SpaceX engineer’s note to his team on Saturday read: “We’ve done some serious work. This mission is now complete. There’s now just one thing you can’t do now: abort the mission.”']

headline: Ikea plans to launch first moon landing probe after rocket failure
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - Japan will launch an experimental lunar lander probe that will take a closer look at the moon’s deep interior with an aim to hitch a ride on a rocket to Mars, a top official said on Monday.<p><p>The probe will be used to map the moon’s surface in the first time to probe the moon’s interior, a process which could take several months, the official told Reuters.<p><p>The spacecraft, named Oka-1, will orbit the moon for 15 minutes and 36 seconds before landing in the sea, then return to Earth, the official said. The probe will burn up after 13 minutes.<p><p>“The initial mission will take approximately seven months to complete. The final orbit is planned for around 2020,” said Masayoshi Watanabe, a top official at the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA).<p> ']

headline: The new generation of nuclear-armed submarines - the first ever built by a private company
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The first ever nuclear-armed submarine is due to go into service in 2020, with the first fully operational submarines planned around the world by 2030, according to a report commissioned by U.S. military contractor Lockheed Martin Corp.<p><p>The Navy has a fleet of 20,000 subs, with four more scheduled for the coming decade, according to Lockheed Martin and the U.S. Air Force, including the largest in the Air Force.<p><p>The submarine development program, formally called a Phase III, was announced by Vice President Mike Pence on Friday. It would include “new capabilities,” Lockheed Martin said.<p><p>“The next generation of submarines will be a great addition to the U.S. submarine fleet. This is a bold new era of submarine defense,” Pence said in a statement on Thursday, adding the Pentagon had a “fundamental ‘no-fly list” of submarine threats.<p><p>A fifth submarine program, planned for 2021, would include the first fully operational U.S. Navy fleet that is due to be built under a different name, according to Lockheed Martin and the Air Force.<p>']

headline: China and SpaceX to work together to launch satellite into orbit
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s space agency said on Monday it is working with SpaceX to launch a satellite into orbit atop a Falcon 9 rocket that will be carrying astronauts to the International Space Station in the first such mission since 2014.<p><p>The Chang’e-5 mission, the first to orbit a U.S. space station since 2011, was successfully launched in April of this year.<p><p>Chang’e-4 will be the first crewed mission to return to the Earth’s atmosphere from a capsule.<p><p>“There are several key milestones for SpaceX,” Beijing-based Dragon said in a statement on Monday. “We plan to bring the first astronaut to the ISS in late 2020,” it said.<p><p>China aims to establish itself as a global space power in a decade’s time. Its space programme, with its launch vehicles from two different countries and its own commercial space programme, has cost the country more than $100 billion.<p><p>SpaceX launched the satellite on a mission in April. It aims to carry one of China’s first astronaut-carrying satellites to the space station in five years.<p><p>China’s Space Ministry last month said the launch of its Chang’e-4 mission is “extremely challenging”.<p> ']

headline: Boeing BAe-FG rocket to go high speed on SpaceX's maiden orbital test flight
content: ['<p> - Boeing BAe-FG Corp said on Wednesday it is ramping up its rocket-to-orbit test program for its next-generation Crew Dragon space flight to test whether its rocket can carry payloads to and from the International Space Station (ISS).<p><p>The rocket’s six-stage booster will carry eight tons of high-energy and lithium-ion batteries into the atmosphere, BAe-FG chief executive Jeff Bezos said. The program has the potential to send hundreds of pounds of cargo from the ISS to the space station on a mission called “space tourism.”<p><p>“This is a critical test for us to maximize the payload capacity of this test vehicle and we’ll get there faster than SpaceX,” Bezos told reporters.<p><p>Boeing is the first privately-owned rocket company to be launched from U.S. soil after Elon Musk’s SpaceX retired its rockets in 2017.<p><p>Boeing and SpaceX, a joint venture of Boeing and Airbus, are working on a series of joint projects with NASA to develop reusable rocket systems capable of carrying humans to and from the space station.<p><p>Boeing and SpaceX last year announced a plan to send a single-stage BAe-FG Falcon 9 rocket, dubbed Atlas V, to the ISS from a SpaceX launchpad in California next month. NASA said the Atlas V rocket would put the company on a path to return humans to the station within the next year.']

headline: Lung disease: How to avoid it, but what to do?
content: ['<p>SINGAPORE  - China has banned the use of chemical toxins in medicines after the latest round of toxicology reports raised concerns about the disease.<p><p>The World Health Organization said on Thursday it would send a delegation to China on Wednesday to assess the seriousness of the situation and urged people to refrain from toxic substances.<p><p>The WHO has said it has received reports of the latest case of respiratory failure and there is concern the infection may have caused lung damage.<p><p>The ban on use of chemical toxins in medicines was lifted on Friday.<p><p>But the WHO has said the WHO has a number of options to try to stem this, including banning or restricting the use of chemical toxins in medicines.<p><p>Last week, it suspended the use of the Chinese pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc’s Marcellus subsidiary’s Opdivo on its generic Spermicides.<p><p>It said it would not be able to continue using Opdivo on its own, as it had taken steps to ensure the safety and efficacy of its drugs.<p><p>Chinese authorities have issued a rare public warning of potential harm, and in September, they announced plans for a national anti-tumor strategy in the country.<p>']

headline: U.S. launches new satellites, adds NASA chief
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States, NASA and Japan plan to launch new satellites into orbit next year under a new “soft” strategy, the new administrator of NASA said on Friday, ahead of a planned test flight in December that could bring astronauts closer to the moon and set an example for other nations.<p><p>“The U.S. space program continues to grow with each successive generation of Americans,” U.S. Deputy Administrator Dan Patrick said on a visit to Japan’s capital for talks with Abe, who is seeking re-election in December.<p><p>““With the test flights in December and January, the U.S. Space Agency, in collaboration with Japan’s Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, has set a firm timeline for the next launch of a new crewed mission to the moon,” Patrick said.<p><p>Japan will fly a lunar module called the Kaku-3B from April until May 2020 and its own Soyuz spacecraft will launch another module, Japan’s Cabinet Office said.<p><p>“In addition, Mitsubishi will launch its crewed mission to the moon in the second half of 2021,” Patrick said.<p><p>In the years to come, Japan could launch its own manned lunar module, Patrick added.<p>']

headline: Factbox: What's behind the pandemic?
content: ['<p>(Corrects to remove incorrect amount of carbon dioxide from food labels)<p><p>This chart shows what appears to be the global average percentage change in carbon dioxide in U.S. food supply as of 12:30 p.m. ET on Wednesday, based on U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).<p><p>This is a “statistical average”, which means there’s a slight probability that there will be a slight increase in carbon dioxide concentration due to a given temperature change over the next 24 hours, according to EIA.<p><p>The difference between that average change and an average change in CO2 level across the globe, typically around 4.6-6.9 percentage points, is shown as the “sign of the times” in the chart above.<p> ']

headline: EU to consider new minimum wage for Apple
content: ['<p>LONDON  - European Union rules requiring the minimum wage for internet companies to raise the minimum wage could help curb some wage hikes, the European Commission said on Wednesday, without giving details.<p><p>The European Commission is set to consider new minimum wage rules in February next year, when the bloc is considering whether to raise the national average price of some EU commodities to the same level as those in the United States.<p><p>“The Commission’s proposals could improve efficiency and ensure the maximum level of competition among all EU member states,” a commission spokeswoman said.<p><p>In a blog, European Commission President Sebastian Kurz wrote that raising the EU average price of EU commodities to the same level as those in the United States would help drive the growth of the economy.<p> ']

headline: Facebook, Alphabet Inc'Google on the tech giants' fight over digital rights
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc’s Google on Friday said that it will work with Alphabet’s Google on efforts to reach a global agreement on free and open access to information and that the tech giants will collaborate on a common framework on how to improve data privacy.<p><p>In an interview with Reuters, Google executive Sundar Pichai said Google aims to “make sure that people know that what they are downloading is free.”<p><p>The companies agreed in June to form an internet neutrality group with Alphabet’s Google and Facebook to help them fight off privacy-waging rivals including Microsoft Corp, Alphabet’s Google, Facebook and Twitter.<p><p>Earlier on Friday, Google said it will use the agreement “to help support our efforts to achieve the objective of an open, transparent and secure internet.”<p><p>The technology giants, which include Microsoft, Facebook and Twitter, have been locked in a battle for dominance in the global data and communications space, with Facebook demanding greater access to user data, while Google is pressing the limits of the company’s dominance.<p><p>Last month, the tech giants backed a proposal by Facebook that it sell user data to a third party to be managed by Google without any access to user data.<p> ']

headline: Billionaire Carlyle makes $180 million from $15 billion spinoff
content: ['<p> - BofA Financial Group Inc chief executive Carlyle Strauss said on Monday he will invest $180 million in a new funding round that will include $300 million to $335 million from the merged firm.<p><p>The company said last year it planned to raise about $300 million through a second round of funding, but it was unable to finalize a deal for its 2021 fiscal. It has since raised $170 million.<p><p>Shares of Carlyle Group closed down 1.8% in their biggest daily loss in more than a year.<p><p>Shares of BofA last year closed down 3.3% and fell more than 30% in premarket trading.<p> ']

headline: Cobra is looking to break into the e-commerce market via its Paytm app - sources say
content: ['<p>PARIS  - British taxi company Cobra Inc is looking to break into the e-commerce market through its Paytm app, sources said, as the rival to Volkswagen and Amazon ramps up its dominance on the road ahead of next year’s global financial crisis.<p><p>The e-commerce platform offers discounted taxi fare, ridesharing and payment services, offers discount cab rates and offers discounted parking options to customers.<p><p>Cobra declined to comment.<p><p>Shares in the European Union’s largest e-commerce company closed up 4.5% on Friday, after its European headquarters announced a merger to help boost the e-commerce business.<p><p>It is looking to establish itself as a leading e-commerce firm by combining its technology and financial expertise, one of the sources told Reuters.<p><p>“We’re trying to get customers using our platform as efficiently as possible,” said the source, who declined to be named as the information is confidential.<p><p>“This is not the last project for Cobra,” the source added. “We are looking to expand and expand as we go.”<p><p>Cobra’s global headquarters are in Brussels and its European headquarters in Amsterdam.<p>']

headline: New Delhi: India's National Development Authority (NDA) has informed the government to “closely examine” a project to buy electric vehicles (EVs) at a discount from Tesla, Indian industry sources said on Friday.
content: ['<p><p>The NDA last year proposed to buy two EVs and sell them in a “monopoly auction” to finance the development of electrification across the country, as the country’s top two carmakers push to make EVs the driving force behind their profit margins.<p><p>The government is looking at acquiring EVs at a discount from Tesla, which has around 28,000 electric vehicles under development nationwide.<p><p>The project, which is expected to be finalised in the second half of next year, could see a 50% discount for India’s EV industry to electric vehicle sales, industry sources said.<p><p>Tesla is also considering selling its EV business.<p><p>Indian e-commerce firm Rakuten, which has been considering purchasing EVs as a secondary route for retail customers in India, is reportedly looking to purchase several EV parts to help it launch new vehicles.<p> ']

headline: Astonishing new smartphone deal for LG, Samsung
content: ['<p> - China’s LG Electronics Co Ltd is ready to announce a deal that will make it the first global smartphone maker to launch a new phone product with an unlocked design and be a major player in the world’s smartphone market, according to people familiar with the matter.<p><p>The deal, which will see the LG-backed unit launch a successor to the flagship G2 model, is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2021.<p><p>The announcement comes as the world’s two biggest smartphone makers prepare to launch their own flagship smartphone this year.<p><p>“It looks like we’re in an agreement,” said one of the people. “We’ve been negotiating all the terms, and are already working with the LG team for the next two years.”<p><p>LG, which makes its flagship G2 model, is owned by China’s LG Electronics, and is the world’s third largest smartphone maker.<p><p>The announcement is noteworthy for two reasons. It might prompt competition from rivals, as other manufacturers compete against LG in the global smartphone market.<p><p>It also comes as Chinese technology giants are launching new products to boost mobile devices’ market share, a trend that has accelerated in recent years.<p>']

headline: Alibaba to sell 1.2 billion yuan ($620 million) worth of digital assets in 2018, as Chinese tech giants take steps to reduce their dependence on the U.S. stock market
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - Alibaba’s planned sale of over 1 billion yuan ($620 million) worth of digital assets in 2018, as Chinese tech giants ramp up their efforts to cut their dependence on the U.S. stock market, will be the world’s largest acquisition of assets by a company that has been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic.<p><p>The listing will be the largest in Chinese history, and the latest development of Alibaba’s strategy reflects the Chinese government’s efforts to diversify its market for products and services.<p><p>“The aim is to focus on a broad range of digital assets as well as the Chinese market,” Zhaoxin Sun, CEO of Alibaba, told Reuters.<p><p>China’s Alibaba, which was set up in 2012, has seen an unprecedented rise in value since the coronavirus crisis hit the business during the coronavirus pandemic in 2016.<p><p>It reported a 26.1% year-on-year rise in revenue to 11.5 billion yuan ($1.83 billion), the largest in the world.<p><p>The company’s latest asset sale comes as investors around the world are eyeing Alibaba for significant growth as the world’s biggest holding company by market capitalisation.<p>']

headline: Carmakers have agreed to buy Tesla Inc for $10 billion in cash and stock, sources told Reuters on Monday. The deal, which would be valued at $20 billion, is expected to close by the end of the month. Tesla has said it expects the deal to close by the end of the year and will not take time.
content: ['<p><p>The deal, which involves Tesla’s own stock, is expected to be finalised in the next few months, the sources said, adding that the cost of the deal has not yet been finalized.<p><p>The company, which said it will invest $400 million to $500 million in the project, is the first major electric vehicle maker to acquire a publicly listed firm for a stock purchase.<p><p>Tesla said it was taking Tesla’s proposal very seriously. It did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.<p><p>Tesla shares have fallen nearly 12% this year as Tesla’s share price has soared in lockdowns in recent months.<p><p>“This will bring Tesla closer to achieving the full potential that Tesla’s CEO Elon Musk has shown in the last few years,” Chief Executive Officer Jeff Bewkes told Reuters in an interview.<p><p>Last month, Musk said Tesla planned to break ground on a large, $1.5 billion factory and produce more than 1 million vehicles a year by 2025.<p> ']

headline: WOMA: A U.S. judge will review whether Facebook Inc can challenge Google’s search result blocking in California
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc must prove its content-based search results are appropriate to address complaints filed in the California Supreme Court on Tuesday, a state judge said.<p><p>The lawsuit, filed in August, accuses Google of breaking California state laws by selectively blocking news content on its platform. Google, which in December blocked news sites including the Associated Press, said the actions unfairly targeted news publishers.<p><p>California Attorney General Xavier Becerra last month sued Google in a lawsuit accusing it of blocking news pages based on color, political leanings or race. Google said the move had harmed news industry workers and others.<p><p>The justices declined to review whether the state laws violated the state’s antitrust law by allowing Facebook to continue blocking news content after the court found the company violated the state’s antitrust law.<p><p>California Attorney General Xavier Becerra has said the case will be heard in federal court.<p><p>The judge scheduled hearing on Wednesday, a spokeswoman said.<p><p>Google declined comment.<p> ']

headline: BENGALURU TO TRADE FOR BILLINGER ON U.S.
content: ['<p>BENGALURU  - Binance Ltd is to trade with BIPB Securities, the trade arm of U.S. conglomerate BIP Capital, as part of its move to cut capital requirements for major mergers and acquisitions, a senior corporate person said.<p><p>The merger would create a $13 billion fund and will merge BIPB, U.S. banking services provider HSBC and other major British companies into the BIPB Stock Exchange.<p><p>The move, a corporate source said, is to enable BIPB’s existing investment in BIP Capital to continue its investment in U.S. banking and technology companies.<p><p>The deal will give BIPB and U.S. financial technology firms a $10 billion capital allocation by merging under the new fund, the source said.<p> ']

headline: EU says Britain should help countries to curb cybercrime
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The European Union will provide funds to countries to investigate cybercrime after more than two dozen countries launched efforts in recent months to speed up the country’s response to the crisis, the bloc’s top trade minister said.<p><p>Britain, the world’s second-largest economy, is the first country to tackle cybercrime amid rising concerns of a resurgent Chinese tech industry that can threaten its economies and national security.<p><p>“Britain has the tools to counter cybercrime and there is international cooperation in this area,” Dimitris Avramopoulos, the EU’s foreign policy chief, told a regular news briefing.<p><p>“We would give this information to other countries and the bloc should help them,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Zoom maker Facebook signs deals with tech platforms for $8.8 billion, sources close to the matter
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc is in talks with technology platforms such as Google Inc for a $8.8 billion investment in the U.S. social media giant that has been pushing big tech firms to embrace its app offerings, people familiar with the matter said.<p><p>The two companies have already struck deals with a host of small and mid-sized tech platforms, including Facebook’s Google+. The talks were first reported by Bloomberg.<p><p>The deal comes days after the company’s $5 billion buyout of Facebook last year brought the shares of Alphabet’s Google to a record high.<p><p>The deals have drawn increased scrutiny amid growing tensions between Facebook and the tech industry over how much it has benefited from paying attention to its user profiles in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic.<p><p>Both companies are known for their ability to manipulate the news in their own terms, but in recent months they have been able to raise large sums through deals.<p><p>Facebook said in August it had agreed to acquire Twitter Inc in a deal that valued it at $1.25 billion, while the San Francisco-based social media giant said on Tuesday it was in talks with a small group of online advertising firms.<p> ']

headline: Viacom to launch iPhone app in Japan
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - The Japanese smartphone maker Viacom has tapped a startup in Japan to launch its iPhone app in Japan on Tuesday, with plans to launch it in the next few weeks, it said.<p><p>Viacom is aiming for 5G in the country by 2035, said Hiroshi Kawabe, senior vice president of mobile networks for Viacom Japan.<p> ']

headline: U.S. tech giants, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft, have seen a surge in ad revenue last year fueled by faster growing social media audiences, as big tech companies increasingly take a look at how to grow their business beyond online content. Reuters and Reuters files; Reuters
content: ['<p><p>Google saw a 14% jump in revenue in the fourth quarter, while Facebook saw a 27% increase. Alphabet Inc’s Google saw a 15% jump, while Microsoft saw a 29% increase.<p><p>As more tech companies expand into the digital advertising market, they are increasingly looking at ways to monetise their ad spend, and in particular how to share that revenue with audiences.<p><p>But how do they do it?<p><p>In some cases, companies are opting to invest in the digital advertising market. Such partnerships have benefited Microsoft and Facebook, and they’re also helping companies to recruit new ad buyers through direct online ads.<p><p>And some are not taking advantage of those partnerships. Microsoft is still trying to launch its own mobile app and Facebook is still trying to launch a standalone mobile app that rivals Twitter’s, Alphabet’s Google said last month.<p><p>Microsoft, Twitter and Facebook did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Microsoft, meanwhile, is still trying to develop new mobile apps for its users.<p> ']

headline: The world's biggest video game developer says Apple has made a mistake in licensing its App Store software
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Swedish video game developer SK Studios has said the Apple-led licensing policy has caused issues with Apple-owned App Store software.<p><p>In a statement, SK said the software was made available only for Apple products, not for Android devices.<p><p>“It’s not an error, it is a very regrettable mistake for the App Store and its developers,” it said in a statement.<p><p>“As I have said before, the App Store software is used by millions of companies around the world and developers need to make use of it in their own devices,” SK said in an email to Reuters.<p> ']

headline: Doom's 'Rocket' gaming machine faces test of global regulatory burden
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - Rocket Corp’s "Rocket" gaming machine is set to face international regulatory scrutiny in a test of its global gaming ban that has raised doubts over the legality of its technology.<p><p>Doom is testing out its own version of the GameStop Corp’s GameStop Arcade GameStop Arcade with the aim of testing it in Japan.<p><p>Japan’s GameStop Corp was fined 10 million yen ($1.43 million) last year after it sold a GameStop GameStop machine in South Korea for a price tag exceeding the retail value of the machine.<p><p>Doom CEO Yusaku Maezawa said that the GameStop machine was intended to be used by gamers to practice online gambling, but has failed to comply with strict regulations.<p><p>“There are still many hurdles to go through before GameStop can become a viable gaming machine,” he said in a speech at a rally in Tokyo on Monday.<p><p>Japanese regulators have imposed an emergency ban on gaming devices made from banned parts such as the GameStop Arcade GameStop Arcade GameStop Classic and GameStop GameStop GameStop Arcade GameStop Classic Arcade Micro machines and a ban on GameStop GameStop GameStop Arcade GameStop Arcade GameStop GameStop Classic Arcade Micro units in several countries.<p>']

headline: U.S. to launch probe into Iran nuclear programme
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A U.S. congressional probe has launched after Iran on Monday detained two American scientists suspected of using highly sensitive technology to build a nuclear bomb, the U.S. Senate confirmed on Tuesday.<p><p>The probe focused on how Iran’s Revolutionary Guards made the switch to developing its own highly sensitive technology.<p><p>U.S. Senators on Tuesday urged Iran to give the United States time to probe its nuclear programme after news broke last week that the Revolutionary Guards had banned research in Iran and technology related to it from entering U.S. national security interests.<p> ']

headline: Luxury carmakers are in talks to sell to China for billions of yuan ($6.9 billion)
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Luxury carmakers have been locked in a dispute with a Chinese company over the allocation of foreign assets, as Beijing seeks to boost Chinese technology growth, sources said.<p><p>The deal with Chinese carmaker Liwan, said to be worth over $60 billion, would mean an increase of 2.6% to the global total of the two companies, three people familiar with the matter said.<p><p>Luxury cars make more than 10 times as much as domestic models, and account for 10% of sales, according to China’s car industry body.<p><p>($1 = 6.2428 yuan renminbi)<p> ']

headline: GameStop to invest $200 million in electric vehicle startup NeuralWave
content: ['<p> - GameStop Corp said on Monday it plans to invest $200 million in NeuralWave, the self-driving chip company that is developing the “high-speed” autonomous driving technology needed to make electric cars.<p><p>The company announced the plans in an earnings call on Tuesday.<p><p>“NeuralWave’s future is cloud-driven. It’s a high-speed, highly-robust system that can go from zero acceleration to 90 mph. It’s extremely lightweight and very agile. It’s incredibly smart.”<p><p>The company, which makes high-speed gaming equipment for Walmart, General Motors Co and Ford Motor Co, said NeuralWave’s driver assistance system would be used to create high-speed autonomous driving systems, such as that developed by Tesla Inc.<p><p>“We will do a prototype of our system that has sensors and accelerometers that will be used in all models of the self-driving cars that we make,” said Mike Griffith, chief executive officer at NeuralWave.<p><p>Earlier this month, Microsoft Corp unveiled a $1.1 billion plan to build a network of 20,000 high-speed autonomous driving systems that can operate autonomously across vast distances.<p><p>“We are focused on making more than 50,000 self-driving systems a year,” Griffith told analysts in the call. “We have a lot of potential.”']

headline: Bitcoin price surges to $55,000, U.S. bank says
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin price increased to $55,000 and U.S. bank Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday it expects the cryptocurrency to reach $50,000, with the latest jump a sign that investors may be buying into the virtual currency.<p><p>Bitcoin rallied nearly 5% to $55,000 on Wednesday as investors poured in to the cryptocurrency, which has soared over 400% this year.<p><p>“There is a lot of demand for this digital asset,” said Robert Cohen, a securities analyst at CME Group. “Bitcoin’s price is going up and people are buying into it because it’s a lot of value,” Cohen added.<p><p>“It’s going to be an interesting benchmark for institutional investors because the market is becoming more diversified. Investors are looking for a lot of cash in return.”<p><p>Goldman Sachs, Barclays and JP Morgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs were among the initial investors in bitcoin, which has surged to over $1,000 this year.<p><p>The digital currency is also gaining traction as businesses scramble to prepare for the COVID-19 pandemic that hit U.S. households during the pandemic.<p><p>While bitcoin has seen gains over the past year, most cryptocurrencies have gained less than a tenth of a percent each year in the past year, according to research firm Counterpoint.<p>']

headline: Viacom is to invest $30 million to improve mobile app support
content: ['<p> - Viacom Inc plans to expand mobile support and provide more customer services in the coming months, the company’s chief executive said in a statement, as it continues to improve mobile apps’ user experience.<p><p>The Palo Alto-based company said in a statement it planned to add support for iPhones, iPads and Android devices starting in late 2022.<p><p>“As a mobile app company, Viacom is committed to the adoption of a unified platform and the continued development of Android and iOS products to help all mobile users experience Viacom’s services efficiently and provide the best possible experience,” it said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Hindenburg says Microsoft's cloud business should take a more passive approach
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Hindenburg, Germany’s largest company, has said its cloud business should take a more passive approach, saying its business model should take more responsibility for how it funds its own infrastructure and product development.<p><p>Hindenburg’s cloud business has benefited from the COVID-19 pandemic as its customers shifted to cheaper, lower-carbon power sources, helping it cut costs.<p><p>“There’s an easy answer to making our cloud software free,” Hindenburg Chief Executive Henrik Henriksson told a news briefing on Wednesday. “But we have to make our own decisions.”<p><p>Hindenburg will launch its first cloud services later this year and expects to add new services later this year, Henriksson said.<p><p>Hindenburg’s cloud services have been a popular choice for businesses in China, where most businesses need access to open source software for their workstations.<p><p>“We think that we are in a good place now because we’re using our full potential in the data center space.”<p><p>($1 = 0.8415 German pounds)<p> ']

headline: WELCOME TO FIND OUT HOW USED PACE WAS IN 2017
content: ["<p>DUBLIN  - A series of online reviews on Facebook showed the social media platform “really liked how it was” while also comparing its cars to Tesla Inc’s, suggesting the electric carmaker is on track for growth.<p><p>The reviews were posted in a series of posts this week that show cars with new electric models in Australia, Canada and New Zealand, and on Instagram from May 22nd.<p><p>The review, which is part of Facebook’s “Ask Me Anything” feature, includes comments on features such as cars' climate and performance levels, price and availability, and features that allow users to ask for additional details such as when the car will be fully charged.<p><p>The results from the testing were not published until Tuesday, when Facebook announced a $2 billion plan to spend on electrifying its streets and infrastructure.<p><p>Facebook’s move comes days after Tesla announced the completion of a $37 billion battery factory near Fremont, California.<p> "]

headline: U.S. government probes Huawei, Xiaomi in business-to-business ties
content: ['<p> - The U.S. Justice Department is looking into the Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and Xiaomi Technologies Inc in business-to-business ties, the Justice Department said on Tuesday, as it probes the companies for alleged ties to China’s government and spies.<p><p>U.S. officials also have been investigating other U.S. companies involved in Chinese tech firms such as Lenovo Corp and Baidu Inc as well as Huawei Holdings Ltd, the Justice Department said.<p><p>The Justice Department said in February that it had opened an investigation into a group of Chinese computer and networking equipment manufacturers linked to Huawei Technologies and Xiaomi Technologies Inc, and its affiliates.<p><p>The investigation involves Huawei and the firms, and is expected to focus on Huawei Technologies and Xiaomi, it said.<p> ']

headline: Dell's stock jump, surging, looks sharper in fresh trading session
content: ['<p> - Dell Corp said on Thursday it has gained 12.7% in extended trading on the U.S. Nasdaq after the company’s shares closed up almost 3% on the back of gains that had come largely from increased demand for its software software business.<p><p>U.S. stock market analyst James Carr told Reuters Dell will report earnings on Thursday, although he added that Dell will be better off in the short-term given that the market’s not yet fully converted to the correction-induced rally seen on the stocks.<p><p>Dell’s shares closed up 1.6% after the company had gained more than 2% for the year through the end of December. The rally had a slightly more muted impact on the Dow Jones Industrial average.<p><p>The company reported a 10% decline in its fourth quarter revenue and a 1.7% decline in the fourth quarter. On the strength of its continued growth, the company expects sales to grow more than 10% in the fourth quarter to 29,000.<p><p>“Dell’s business is growing. The long-term, strong outlook for our customers, our employees and the broader Dell community is very encouraging,” Carr said.<p>']

headline: Facebook, Alphabet offer to buy UK court ruling-maker for $20 billion
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Alphabet Inc’s Google plans to merge with a new private equity firm to buy a legal battle-room business at a valuation of more than $20 billion, a move that is in line with Alphabet’s efforts to move into a technology-driven sector that was battered in the coronavirus pandemic.<p><p>Facebook, Alphabet’s Google and Alphabet’s rival Facebook Inc have been locked in a battle with the Justice Department for years over how to deal with the rapidly evolving tech sector.<p><p>“As this deal progresses, we will seek to fully understand the legal landscape,” the companies said in a statement.<p><p>Facebook, which is controlled by Alphabet’s parent Alphabet’s parent Facebook, will merge with Alphabet’s private equity firm, which will make its $3.8 billion valuation a fraction of the $2 billion in total equity it is worth.<p><p>The deal could fetch more than $20 billion from the three firms, according to an industry source familiar with the matter.<p><p>Under Alphabet’s deal, the Justice Department would buy a court-appointed arbitrator to resolve the disputes, rather than a new company or its wholly-owned subsidiary.<p><p>Google’s plans also include a $400 million initial public offering that would create a new private equity firm to oversee the deal, the source said.<p>']

headline: Hackers get paid for downloading, sharing
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - The pandemic-era theft of tens of thousands of e-books led to ransomware attacks in Europe and the United States, forcing governments and law enforcement to step up efforts to combat it.<p><p>But for hackers, a thriving new world of exploitation is now their weapon.<p><p>“I’ve found that it’s not just people working through the pandemic that are exploiting ransomware. It’s all those hackers that are actually using their skills.”<p><p>The pandemic started as a wild card, but then spread to Europe and the United States, infecting almost every computer at home. A wave of cyberattacks has pushed governments and law enforcement to launch more sophisticated, multi-factor security measures, including the use of facial recognition to identify criminals.<p><p>“Today’s cyber attack, which I think is really extraordinary, is exactly what you would expect from the world of cybercriminals.” said Jake Chiu, co-founder and CEO of the Cyber Security Lab at UC Davis.<p><p>“The biggest challenge is that most of those attacks, by one means or another, are just going to get patched. And because the world of ransomware is quite patchy at the moment, this will be one of the highlights of a “deep-seated” threat.”<p>']

headline: A team of researchers has discovered a new form of carbon nanotubes that could pave the way to building new, sustainable vehicles.
content: ['<p><p>It will be possible to design and produce “carbon nanotubes” from carbon nanotubes (CCN), the first such device in the world, the team says. The technology is being used to fabricate electric vehicles, or EV batteries.<p><p>“This is an exciting new step forward for our research and development of carbon nanotubes for electric vehicles,” said Robert Woodhead, a postdoctoral researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and lead author of a paper published online last week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.<p><p>“This is an exciting new approach to achieving an electric vehicle,” Woodhead said.<p><p>“This work demonstrates that the process of building a CO2-neutral device like the carbon nanotube in the lab can be adapted to meet the high efficiency of EV battery fabrication.”<p><p>In previous attempts, scientists had tried to fabricate carbon nanotubes by cutting a piece of paper and then coating it with carbon nanotubes to create an electric vehicle.<p><p>But a recent effort by researchers at Arizona State University at Tempe demonstrated that carbon nanotubes can be easily modified, turning that idea into a reality.<p>']

headline: New Jersey: 'Let me do something' for Amazon, Google
content: ['<p>Check out what\'s clicking on FoxBusiness.com.<p><p>Amazon.com Inc is now in the news for allowing people to share books on its website with publishers that don\'t pay for it, state officials told lawmakers in a hearing on Monday.<p><p>U.S. lawmakers are urging Amazon and other internet giants to work with state governments to develop ways to rein in illegal sales of e-books, citing concerns about the impact on children and consumers of a surge in book sales during the COVID-19 pandemic.<p><p>House Majority Leader Jack Dorsey, R-N.J., called the plan an "epidemic" that could result in lost tax revenue, but the Democratic leaders were cautious.<p><p>Rep. James Carville, D-Marist, said he hoped Amazon would commit to getting the state and the U.S. Department of Revenue to fund “a “massive, comprehensive effort to rein in this illegal monopoly” that has led to book sales going up 45% in the past five years.<p><p>The proposed tax credits would be extended to all Amazon sellers on its website, including retailers that do not pay the government for content they sell, according to the group representing the publishers.<p><p>Amazon declined to comment on the Senate hearing.<p><p>Amazon spokesman Joe Schafiro declined to comment. Google did not immediately respond to a request for comment.']

headline: White House adviser calls for review of Iran sanctions against Iran
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden’s national security adviser on Iran called on U.S. lawmakers on Monday to review the U.S. sanctions against Iran over its ballistic missile program, as Tehran continues to pursue a nuclear weapon.<p><p>“We don’t have any intention of getting into the specifics of sanctions,” Biden said on the sidelines of the State of the Union address. He also spoke about Iran’s ballistic missile programs.<p><p>Speaking in the wake of the Biden’s remarks, U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Bob Menendez criticized the Biden administration for not exercising a powerful bipartisan mandate to impose new sanctions.<p><p>“This Administration has failed to adequately communicate clearly what sanctions relief measures they have for Iran,” Menendez said in a letter to senators.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Facebook wants to invest $100 million into the U.S. semiconductor chip shortage - sources
content: ['<p>SAN FRANCISCO  - Facebook is planning to invest more than $100 million into the U.S. semiconductor chip shortage in the near-term, three people with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters.<p><p>The move is a direct threat to the business-as-usual approach adopted by Facebook and other tech giants such as Google, Facebook’s Sundar Pichai said.<p><p>“It’s an indication that it might take more than one year to bring in a chipmaker and Facebook,” he said, adding it was unclear when the chip company would announce the investments.<p><p>At the end of 2020, Facebook’s chip supply was at “the lowest level since 1999,” it said.<p><p>That left a chip shortage of nearly 1 billion cycles between factories, meaning a shortage of 10% or more would take at least a year.<p><p>Since then, a range of chip suppliers have stepped up production of chips in response to the pandemic, with suppliers of semiconductors like Qualcomm Corp, Nvidia Corp and Advanced Micro Devices all joining a supply chain restructuring effort this year.<p>']

headline: Korea's K&L and Hyundai Motor to expand KwikLocker in South Korea, South Korea
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - Hyundai Motor Corp will start opening three KwikLocker stores in South Korea this year, the company said on Thursday, as part of an investment spree aimed at growing demand for electric vehicles.<p><p>The expansion will also make it easier for the Korean company to increase the number of KwikLocker customers, Hyundai said in a statement.<p><p>($1 = 109.9900 won)<p> ']

headline: The New York Times reports on the impact of a California law requiring transgender people to use restrooms and locker rooms consistent with their gender identity. (reut.rs/2qE4sjQ) - Facebook Inc, Twitter Inc, Alphabet Inc’s Google, Google+ and Amazon.com Inc have all filed lawsuits challenging the state law that requires transgender people to use public restrooms and showers that correspond with their sex at birth, but transgender people in California are not eligible to vote. The law passed last year will remain in effect until 2018. (bit.ly/2e0gWtC) (Photo by Charlie Neibergall/Getty Images) (Photo credit should read C-SPAN-AP)  - Facebook Inc, Twitter Inc, Google, Google+, and Amazon.com Inc, among others have all filed lawsuits challenging the state law requiring transgender people to use restrooms and showers that comply with their gender identity. (reut.rs/2qE4sjQ) (Photo credit should read C-SPAN-AP) (Photo credit should read C-SPAN-AP)  - Facebook Inc, Twitter Inc, Google+, and Amazon.com Inc, among others have all filed lawsuits challenging the state law requiring transgender people to use restrooms and showers that comply with their gender identity. (reut.
Alphabet aims to raise $1.1 billion in funding from institutional investors
content: ['<p> - Alphabet Inc’s Google is aiming to raise $1.1 billion over three rounds of funding over three years, as its self-driving car initiative accelerates on a global stage, it said on Friday.<p><p>The company’s flagship initiative, called Maps, is a major part of Alphabet’s push to bridge the gap between driving and driving.<p><p>Alphabet has said that Google’s Vision 2020 aims to develop a suite of sensors, called Neuralink, that could be used in cars, vans and trucks. The company is also building an autonomous driving lab.<p><p>Google has previously backed the development of self-driving cars, but its interest in self-driving vehicles stems from the potential for its new services to support artificial intelligence.<p><p>Google said it is open to funding from institutional investors, companies that hold more than $100 billion in funding and investors interested in the project.<p> ']

headline: LONDON/FAIRFAX/SHENZHEN/SHENZHEN/SHENZHEN/SHENZHEN/SHENZHEN/LONDON  - The UK's biggest cyber security firm said on Thursday it has received requests for information from a Hong Kong government that has asked its network operator for a list of internet address names. “We received a request for information from Hong Kong government,” said a spokeswoman for Lufthansa, which processes more than 80 billion internet traffic annually. “This request has been taken very seriously and is currently being considered by the Hong Kong government.” She declined to comment on the status of the requests. Lufthansa said its customers are required to provide a detailed detailed log of any internet address changes. It was not immediately clear what the government intended when it received the request. The data request was first reported by Reuters in January. The Hong Kong government said in February it was seeking to identify the company. “We have received several requests from the Hong Kong government regarding the request for information from Lufthansa, and we are currently in discussions with the Hong Kong government to provide further information on this request.” China’s Huanghui Holding Ltd said on Wednesday it had received a similar request. “Lufthansa shares were up 10% on Thursday, after which we received a request for information from the government.” The Hong Kong government, a key backer of the internet, has said it has no interest in Lufthansa and did not comment. Lufthansa said it had not received a specific request and was not required to provide the list. “We have received similar requests from other countries, as we have before,” it said. Reuters, which first reported the news, reported last month that the government in Hong Kong has asked a U.S. company
A woman has been arrested after a Facebook post showing her looking down on a woman accused of rape went viral, police say.
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - A woman has been arrested after she posted a photo of her looking down on a man accused of sexual assault, police said on Tuesday.<p><p>The photo was taken by a user in Thailand on Wednesday.<p><p>Facebook users were quick to point out the image of a “rape kit” which was recovered from a Bangkok airport lock box and sent to police, saying it showed the accused “looking down on a woman”.<p><p>Online harassment campaign No Way Out Facebook has asked people to take action against the man accused of raping her.<p><p>The picture and caption that led to the arrest came in response to a request from Thailand’s police.<p><p>Authorities said the unidentified woman, 49, was arrested at Bangkok Airport on Wednesday.<p><p>On Friday, Thai security forces arrested a 29-year-old man, who they said was behind a series of posts accusing a Thai woman of having a “disseminating” relationship with him, authorities said.<p> ']

headline: Zika’s online sales rise despite setbacks
content: ['<p>JAKARTA  - Zika’s online sales of $1 billion worth of virtual goods plunged nearly 4% in a global fundraising challenge on Wednesday, in sharp contrast to strong growth of the previous month in many areas, its chief executive told Reuters.<p><p>Online sales of virtual goods jumped 44.3% to 6.3 billion in the fourth quarter of this year, beating expectations of an 8% year-to-date increase in global sales, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.<p><p>Zika has struggled to gain traction in the retail space due to the high volume of transactions by banks and other big players, especially in Asia and Europe, said Zainab Yusuf, co-chief executive of the company, which provides online services to clients including Microsoft Corp and Facebook Inc.<p><p>But, Yusuf said it was in business and that the success of “real world” online shopping had underscored the company’s efforts to become more mainstream, with clients investing more in companies with online shopping and augmented reality (AR).<p><p>Online shops have exploded in the last decade, driving the increase in prices of items from brands such as Apple Inc to smartphones and tablets, Yusuf said.<p><p>Online shopping is becoming a big part of Zika’s business plan, Yusuf said, adding the company had partnered with Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, a unit of China’s Tencent Holdings Group Holding, to develop the business model.<p>']

headline: Pioneer to build $10 billion solar battery factory in North America
content: ['<p> - A new U.S. battery factory to be built on the San Diego Riverfront will provide power for a dozen utility substations, Pioneer Inc said on Tuesday, as a U.S. utility-scale battery company seeks to build a battery plant in Texas to power the entire state.<p><p>Pioneer, founded by billionaire investor Warren Buffett, has gained prominence as a utility-scale battery battery company that generates revenue by charging and delivering power to grid operators and customers, and is also a leader in electric vehicles.<p><p>Under its plan, Pioneer will employ 500 people from a portfolio of companies including Advanced Electric Power, a supplier of batteries for Tesla Inc and other electric vehicles, to generate power.<p><p>The new factory, located on a highway in northern California called Mission Viejo, will build about 700 homes and provide power to about 240,000 utility customers in California, Pioneer said, citing industry data.<p><p>The factory will use two substations in South Los Angeles County, a mile apart, it said. The substations were built in 2008.<p> ']

headline: Facebook to pay out $7 billion to Twitter
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc will pay out $7 billion to Twitter Inc on Tuesday as the U.S. social network pushes toward bettering the social media giant’s business and growth plans, the tech giant said on Tuesday in a blog post.<p><p>“This will enable us to grow more quickly in our business and to make more of an impact on the world,” Facebook said in the blog post.<p><p>The decision comes amid heightened scrutiny of the social media giant over its payments model and plans to impose some fee-for-service (FSA) in its paid advertising.<p><p>In January, Twitter suspended accounts for six U.S. news publishers, including the New York Times and The Washington Post, citing concerns about the business model.<p> ']

headline: Greenslow t;p> - U.S. District Judge D. Todd D. Carter on Thursday fined the San Francisco-based company Greenslow Inc $6.5 million for improperly misleading investors about its stock price, in the largest settlement in a decade for a technology company that is seen as a key market regulator.
content: ['<p><p>In a 10-page decision, Carter said the defendants “materially mislead” the public by “incorrectly describing their price for the upcoming COVID-19 pandemic,” causing “extreme volatility and uncertainty over the future of COVID-19 products.”<p><p>Greenslow shares surged nearly 70% at the closing bell. The stock has gained more than 70% in the past year, while the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen nearly 15%.<p><p>Carter said he has no final say over the payout of the settlement amount.<p><p>Dow Jones Chief Executive Officer Donald F. Kennedy said the company is disappointed by the verdict.<p><p>“Today’s decision is a result of the continued efforts of Greenslow to keep the company’s stock price at its highest level in more than three decades.”<p><p>Carter did not elaborate.<p><p>The settlement with Greenslow comes more than a decade after California adopted mandatory reporting requirements for all new and existing technology firms. That law was signed by President Bush in 2003 but has been criticized by tech and regulatory leaders.']

headline: U.S. Treasury seeks approval from U.S. lawmakers to extend the deadline to certify that Tesla Inc's $1.6 billion electric vehicle sales to the government do not violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act are “appropriate”
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Treasury Department said on Tuesday it wants more time for a final decision on whether to certify that Tesla Inc’s $1.6 billion electric vehicle sales to the U.S. government do not violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA), which is due to go into effect on March 11.<p><p>The FCA prohibits U.S. companies from using financial services firms to circumvent U.S. sanctions and is one of the most significant financial instruments of the Bush administration and its allies to protect U.S. companies from Chinese or North Korean influence.<p><p>However, Tesla has made clear it does not agree with that decision, which could impact future decisions.<p><p>U.S. Representative Susan Collins, a Republican from Maine, said in a letter to the Trump administration, which she chairs, that Congress should consider extending the deadline to certify that “Tesla Inc’s “deliverables comply with all applicable laws, regulations and regulations.”<p><p>In October, Tesla agreed to a settlement with regulators in Hong Kong, seeking to avoid Chinese retaliation on the U.S. side.<p><p>In July, the company said it would end its global production in Iran, ending production at its plants there.<p>']

headline: The company behind Microsoft's Azure cloud and server business says it will be merging with another company in the future to focus on cloud computing
content: ['<p> - Microsoft Corp said on Monday it is merging with another company to focus on cloud computing in a move that will help the company’s customers focus on growth.<p><p>The company, led by Chief Executive Brad Smith, is looking to transform its enterprise business into one where customers can work with software that can accelerate their data access, optimize their online performance, and be more competitive with competitors.<p><p>The move by Azure comes as Microsoft shares hit a record high of $354.50 on Monday as Microsoft shares jumped more than 17% after the company’s stock surged after the news.<p> ']

headline: U.S. tech firms are investing more in their own businesses and are giving more to charity
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Apple Inc has announced a plan to invest more than $2 billion more in its own business in a deal with charity TikTok that it calls an "unfortunate milestone."<p><p>The $700 million ($4.5 billion) investment includes funding to build two factories in South Carolina and develop new production lines in Texas to produce iPads and other electronic devices, Apple said in a blog post announcing the investment.<p><p>It also said its new plant will employ about 600 people.<p><p>The company said in a statement that TikTok would help provide "food, clothing, and medical supplies to millions of families around the world."<p><p>The U.S. government has already allocated $700 million in aid to help tech companies in developing and deploying new technologies, including cloud computing and software for disaster response.<p> ']

headline: Viz Media has raised $1.5 billion from investors including Apple Inc, Facebook Inc and Alphabet Inc, the social media platform said on Monday.
content: ['<p><p>The investment round, led by tech firm TechX, comes just days after investors including Uber Technologies Inc, Dell Technologies Inc and Nvidia Corp also participated in the $2.2 billion round, according to a Twitter post from the firm’s board.<p> ']

headline: Alibaba Group chief executive told reporters: 'We are not talking about any specific IPO and we are just talking about all related businesses,' Reuters reported
content: ['<p> - Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd said Chief Executive Yusuf Mehdi had said on Thursday that it was not talking about an IPO.<p><p>“We are not talking about any specific IPO and we are just talking about all related businesses.” Mehdi did not disclose the specific nature of the business.<p><p>“We are talking about products, services and business insights,” Mehdi told reporters at a Shanghai hotel, adding that the company had not made any decision as to how it would proceed.<p><p>Alibaba’s U.S. parent Alibaba, which supplies online shopping for brands such as Walmart Inc, will seek to acquire the company from investors such as Facebook Inc and Salesforce.com Inc, the group’s Chinese media unit said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Alphabet Inc-backed GOOG proposes to go public via share sale: WSJ
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - Alphabet Inc’s Google on Monday proposed to go public via a merger with German carmaker Geely, potentially paving the way for a private-equity firm that would have a stake in a major German private-sector group, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.<p><p>Google did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment. Geely shares are down 1.8% at 0925 GMT on Monday, as investors bet the deal could lead to greater wealth transfer between the two firms.<p><p>Geely shares were down 1.8% at 0920 GMT on Monday, as investors bet that the deal could lead to greater wealth transfer between the two firms.<p><p>Geely has said that its aim is to build a “advanced infrastructure” for its privately-held vehicle fleet in the next two to three years.<p><p>Geely has said that its aim is to go public through a merger with German carmaker Geely, potentially paving <PAD>  way for a private-equity firm that could have a stake in a major German public-private partnership, the WSJ reported.<p><p>The private equity firm has already taken a pre-emptive step to go public through a blank-check offering, Reuters reported, with the aim of using proceeds to expand its public-private network, with the aim of achieving equity value by 2021.<p>']

headline: T-Mobile, AT&T pay their bills, but do it in cash!
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The telecoms operator T-Mobile UK has agreed to pay its bills with cash in the first time since it agreed to provide unlimited mobile data plans in the United States, a deal which could see the carrier follow the footsteps of rival Verizon.<p><p>In February, the carrier launched its own data plan to offer customers unlimited data plans in Britain and the Netherlands.<p><p>The deal with Telstra follows the introduction of its Data Plan in December in the United States.<p><p>Other operators including Comcast Corp and Bell Canada’s Bell Canada also are offering plans to users, with Verizon customers benefiting from the cash-out option.<p><p>The deal comes as the iPhone maker has moved more aggressively to boost its 5G business, announcing plans in Australia and Singapore last week to invest $1 billion in U.S. telecom equipment.<p><p>“The phone industry is starting to realize that the mobile phone industry is starting to embrace smartphones, and it is only going to get better,” said Rishi Ghosh, chief executive officer of the London-based company.<p><p>He added: “We have reached a point where we are ready to offer more data, more coverage in the United States, so we will continue to invest in the business.”<p> ']

headline: GameStop says it plans new stock market “to invest
content: ['<p> - GameStop Corp said on Wednesday it plans a new stock market to buy and sell securities and add more capital to its portfolio, following a surge in demand.<p><p>The retail investment firm said the new stock market would be “focused on expanding digital, innovative, sustainable and inclusive brands in our portfolio through new, award-winning brands.”<p><p>Shares of GameStop rose 3.7% to $45.95 after the bell on Wednesday, gaining a short squeeze on the retail investor group that has surged in recent weeks.<p><p>The company said it planned to begin accepting “overly optimistic” returns on its stock market research in May.<p> ']

headline: HELSINKI/HELSINKI SECURITY
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - China’s HELSINKI Security, a provider of online security services, said on Tuesday it had strengthened its global business, citing the increased security of its data centres and other infrastructure.<p><p>HELSINKI declined to comment on the size of its global business.<p> ']

headline: U.S. lawmakers demand probe into Tesla's Autopilot for lack of safeguards
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers said on Tuesday that Tesla should be held liable for its Autopilot software flaw, but they want the automaker to face charges for failing to comply with a federal policy requiring companies to submit corrective measures.<p><p>The companies face a potential federal investigation by the Justice Department, including antitrust charges, as Tesla has struggled to meet regulatory scrutiny in recent months.<p><p>The Autopilot software flaw was first discovered in February 2020, when Tesla’s Fremont, California, factory shut down and a pilot experiment with Autopilot failed.<p><p>The glitch allowed cars that had previously been equipped with Autopilot to avoid turning in lane departure and driving under the speed limit.<p><p>Tesla’s Autopilot can only detect when a vehicle is in cruise control mode and requires drivers to obey an arm-rest brake. The system could also have inadvertently allowed drivers to bypass the armrest brake before making their turn, lawmakers said.<p><p>Tesla has said it has fixed the problem.<p><p>Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., on Tuesday called on the Justice Department to conduct a "disciplinary inquiry" into Tesla and urged regulators to take Tesla “very seriously."<p>']

headline: Bitcoin surge: Crypto
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin hit a record high of $47,400 this month after hitting a record high of $58,700 on Tuesday, with the cryptocurrency trading platform hitting a peak of $60,000.<p><p>The cryptocurrency has benefited from higher-than-expected supply as investors scramble to get the digital currency. The cryptocurrency has also benefited from the coronavirus pandemic as it soared from $62,400 to $64,400 in February.<p><p>Bitcoin’s rally was fueled by a surge in bitcoin prices during the coronavirus pandemic, as more and more people opted to invest in the digital currency.<p><p>Bitcoin’s volatile price was at $58,700 on Tuesday, before hitting a record high of $58,400 on Thursday.<p><p>“What we have seen now is the coronavirus has caused a massive surge in bitcoin prices,” said David Shubin, chief investment officer at asset manager GFS Markets.<p><p>Bitcoin rose on Wednesday after falling as much as 10% in extended trading.<p> ']

headline: A new chip that boosts efficiency in car production could help speed up battery cell production in Tesla Inc
content: ['<p> - In a world of electric vehicles and smart cars, Tesla Inc is in line to become the world’s most advanced carmaker.<p><p>Tesla founder Elon Musk is preparing for the 2020 global battery cell shortage, saying in an interview with Reuters that he would use Tesla to accelerate the production of his Model 3 electric vehicle and eventually turn his company into a leader in the automotive industry.<p><p>“We’ve got enough batteries for everything,” Musk said, speaking at the National Defense University in Washington, D.C., the nation’s second-largest and the fourth-largest U.S. science research facility.<p><p>Tesla is among several automakers, including General Motors Co and Ford Motor Co, that plan to produce more than 700,000 vehicles annually by the end of the decade from production capacity at its sprawling Fremont, California factory, the world’s largest.<p><p>Automakers such as Ford, General Motors Co, and BMW, among others, rely on battery cells to power cars. That creates an advantage for Tesla, and the company has already shown how Tesla’s supercharger system can speed up battery cell production by half a decade or more.<p>']

headline: In a meeting on Wednesday, Mr Biden said he planned to speak at a joint session of Congress this week with lawmakers from both parties on the economy. He also said he planned to address a gathering of trade officials from the Commerce Department and the State Department. He said Mr Biden has been working on the economy for years.
content: ['<p><p>Speaking to reporters after the Biden team meeting in South Carolina, Mr Biden said he had not been briefed on the talks.<p><p>“I’m very much working on it. I have a long list of topics to address,” Mr Biden said. “But it is in the best interest of the American people to have an open discussion.”<p><p>A Biden administration spokesman declined to comment.<p> ']

headline: MotoGP's Geely moves to raise $50 million in Series C funding
content: ['<p> - Chinese automobile maker Moto Motors Corp on Friday reported that it had raised $50 million from a Series C funding round, after an initial $8 billion investment by China’s Geely Motor Co and a $5 billion investment by French tech giant Salesforce International.<p><p>Moto said that it will start production in 2020, with financing set for around 2020. The automaker said it expects its next two models to be “production-ready” by the end of 2021.<p><p>The automaker is in talks to extend the existing life of its 5.7-liter diesel-powered sedan, the Geely Grandeur, to 2021.<p><p>The automaker, which last year reported a profit of 6.2 billion yuan ($483 million), said it will offer its 5.7-liter Geely Grandeur, starting in 2022, for sale starting in China. It also plans a 6.0-liter, 2.5-liter Geely Grandeur sedan, as well as a 2.5-liter, 2.6-liter and 5.0-liter Geely Grandeur SUV.<p><p>Moto said on Friday it is launching an electric platform in Shanghai in January and has yet to announce the cost of the platform.<p><p>Moto said the automaker’s “strategy is to become a global manufacturer to become a global carmaker by selling Geely brand cars,” adding that its Geely Grandeur is “in good shape.”<p> ']

headline: A special purpose acquisition company called EFT Acquisition Partners (EFT) has raised $850 million from investors, Wall Street analysts said on Monday.
content: ['<p><p>EFT Acquisition Partners has raised $850 million from investors, according to its latest public filing. The initial public offering (IPO) was first reported by Reuters and has since been followed by a separate private offering.<p><p>The company, founded by former Amazon.com Inc co-founder Jeff Bezos, and its CEO, Jack Dorsey, were valued at $7.4 billion in 2019.<p><p>EFT Acquisition Partners has a valuation of $7 billion and gross proceeds of $8.9 billion, according to FactSet.<p> ']

headline: In the latest sign of growing support for bitcoin, the Chinese central bank has made an unusual move towards digital assets: it has barred cryptocurrency exchanges.
content: ['<p><p>On Wednesday, the Chinese central bank had blocked all cryptocurrency exchanges and issued warnings against all cryptocurrency activities in Beijing. The move, the first time that it had barred bitcoin from the market, came amid tensions between Beijing and Washington over the issue.<p><p>“We urge all exchanges to be cautious in the implementation of these policies,” Xinhua news agency quoted an official as saying at the time, urging them to be transparent about their trading activities.<p><p>But the decision, which would require regulators from the mainland, the U.S., and Canada, has yet to be seen in the context of a broader crackdown on cryptocurrencies.<p><p>Some cryptocurrencies such as the U.S. dollar or bitcoin have soared during the pandemic, fuelled by a surge in bitcoin adoption. But mainstream investors and traders have been wary of such new assets, which could become more widespread.<p><p>On Tuesday, the Chinese central bank said it was restricting the movement of bitcoin, a digital asset whose value has tripled in the past year to $1,354,800.<p> ']

headline: Biden: $10 billion short-sell, $8 billion short-sell at JPMorgan
content: ["<p> - U.S. President Joe Biden will announce at a press conference on Thursday that he has raised $10 billion in short-sell bets at JPMorgan Chase & Co in a short sell.<p><p>The announcement comes after two days of heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange due to a trade frenzy and a flurry of short-selling that sent the markets to a record high.<p><p>The bank has been battered by a global financial crisis that sent some banks scrambling to hedge against bets that it could face massive losses.<p><p>The latest short squeeze comes as financial technology giants including Amazon.com Inc, Bank of America Corp and Goldman Sachs are pushing harder to diversify their portfolios ahead of an April special session that could affect more large tech firms like Alphabet Inc’s Google and Microsoft Corp.<p><p>Biden on Friday announced that he had raised $9.9 billion in short-sell bets at JPMorgan Chase & Co in a short sell, giving him the highest combined total in five years.
