That includes $2 billion last year that was due to cash in his pockets.<p><p>The Biden’s announcement was in contrast to a December rally of $1.6 billion in short sell bets at JPMorgan Chase & Co, as the bank's shares have traded higher than usual during that month.<p> "]

headline: Biden says no new funding for U.S. border wall
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden has no new funding for border wall construction after a series of reports that his administration was holding off on funding for a $1.6 billion border wall that would have been finished in 2019.<p><p>The delays that cost thousands of federal contractors and police officers have cost hundreds of thousands of American jobs for decades.<p><p>The Department of Homeland Security said late Thursday it had agreed to meet on Thursday with federal contractors to begin construction of the U.S.-Mexico border wall, which is expected to take two years.<p><p>But the department’s Inspector General has warned the funding gap could grow even wider.<p><p>“The administration has made clear it does not believe that Congress’s action is adequate to support a border wall,” Jake Sullivan, acting inspector general for the department, told Reuters on Thursday.<p><p>The funding shortfall, which had been expected to reach $2.7 billion, will likely remain at about $750 million until it is resolved, Sullivan added.<p><p>Biden’s administration did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.<p> ']

headline: Renesas calls Tesla 'a giant bully'
content: ['<p> - Renesas Motorcycles maker Renesas Motorcycles said on Thursday it is “a giant bully” that wants Tesla Motors Corp to take over the electric vehicle company’s production line, which rivals the likes of Volkswagen AG and Ford Motor Co.<p><p>Renesas shares surged 2.7% to $34.54 in extended trading on Thursday.<p><p>Shares in the company were up 2.3% at $41.49.<p><p>Tesla, the world’s largest automaker, has warned that Renesas’ strategy will cause electric vehicle production to slow and make it more expensive for automakers to produce their own cars.<p><p>Renesas is backed by investors such as Ant Group and General Motors Co.<p><p>“Tesla’s strategy is one of making a big deal, while Tesla’s strategy is to take over some of the production lines of Tesla and become a gigantic bully,” Renesas said in a statement on Thursday.<p><p>Tesla is not required to comply with any state or local law to operate its production line.<p><p>Renesas is also involved in the dispute with General Motors Co over the recall of an ignition interchange unit that had been installed by Renesas in its Model S sedan.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank, Alphabet-backed Google to go public via merger
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - SoftBank Group Corp said on Wednesday it has reached an agreement with Alphabet Inc’s Google to go public via a merger with Alphabet Inc’s Google, a move that would create a combined entity that could make it the world’s largest public company with Google’s backing.<p><p>It also said in a filing late on Wednesday that the deal with Google could be completed later this year.<p> ']

headline: Sydney's Dungeness launches 'Stopover' app and $50 million reward for tips
content: ['<p>Sydney’s Dungeness has launched a new app to alert customers to a car battery’s malfunction, which it said will go live by the end of this year.<p><p>Dungeness’s new app, which allows customers to send messages to the battery from their phone without getting a notification, says its app will take a week to load, from Friday to Wednesday.<p><p>“When a car battery malfunction, we will take immediate action to fix the problem immediately,” the website said.<p><p>Dungeness did not disclose the cost of the initial launch, but said the app will cost $1 million to $1 million.<p><p>Dungeness’s website also showed photos of the battery’s screen, which can be viewed as a QR code.<p> ']

headline: Biden to unveil $1.6 billion stimulus for electric vehicle industry
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden will unveil an $1.6 billion stimulus to create jobs by 2030, and increase investment in electric vehicle manufacturing and manufacturing, during his State of the Union address, the vice president said on Tuesday.<p><p>The White House and Biden will also give incentives to U.S. auto companies to build or expand electric vehicles, according to a joint press briefing with Biden, Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Infrastructure Secretary Gina Raimondo.<p><p>The White House said the incentives will help boost U.S. auto production, and ensure that U.S. jobs in electric vehicle manufacturing and manufacturing remain strong.<p><p>The White House will also announce a slew of new measures designed to reduce the federal debt. It also includes an effort to address the opioid pandemic and reduce stockpiles of prescription drugs.<p><p>The Biden administration has pushed for more than $100 billion in stimulus investments in U.S. infrastructure, renewable energy and other areas.<p> ']

headline: U.S. government seeks documents on U.S. payments system
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Justice Department is seeking documents on how the U.S. payments system operates, officials told Reuters on Tuesday, as the Trump administration seeks to preserve payments for victims and their families.<p><p>The program, known as U.S.Payment to Victims’ Services, provides help to people whose money has been lost, abused or turned over to illegal organizations.<p><p>The Justice Department declined to comment on the requests, referring to a White House blog post.<p><p>The payments are processed in one of the three main networks in the United States: Federal Financial Service Administration, the Department of Justice’s Office of Financial Independence, and the Office of the Inspector General of the Treasury.<p><p>Other than the payment system, which accounts for about $16 billion a year, the administration’s program tracks and validates nearly 2,000,000 individuals, mostly from low-income communities.<p><p>The department is requesting documents on the payments systems, the officials said.<p><p>“There are a number of ways the system works, including through the Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation, through a “substandard process”, or through the payment processing system itself, the officials said. “Other than that, it’s really just a process.”<p>']

headline: A new startup with a history of helping startups get ahead in the tech sphere: Facebook
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc is joining forces with an online advertising platform to expand its digital advertising capabilities, a major expansion of the San Francisco-based social media giant’s existing strategy.<p><p>The U.S. social media giant will launch a new tool to help its advertising businesses better align with Facebook’s digital advertising goals, and it plans to offer a variety of targeted ads.<p><p>The partnership follows other partnerships including Instagram and Bumble, among others, which saw more people follow more of their friends on social media, and Facebook’s commitment to digital advertising and search.<p><p>It also comes a week after Facebook disclosed a new strategic partnership with Amazon.com Inc to boost revenue growth and increase customer relationships with its customers.<p><p>Other companies, including Facebook’s $6 billion IPO in 2019, are also rolling out new advertising features to their platforms.<p><p>Still, the potential expansion of the social media company’s ad strategies makes it a unique fit for the tech sector.<p><p>Some big social media companies already rely on Facebook and Google’s ad tracking platforms to spot their ads, as well as by providing detailed information like demographic and search preferences.<p><p>Facebook and Google have partnered with Google’s search engine for a while, but its search result pages have largely been put back on Google.<p> ']

headline: Apple's Koss plans for 'big change' for App Store
content: ["<p>Apple has announced a raft of changes to the App Store this week that will impact app developers, but one that is likely to take effect in the next six weeks is the removal of the headphone-sized mute button in the main app and a few other apps that are part of the app stores.<p><p>The announcement from Apple does not mention changes to the main App Store, which was announced several months ago. But there are a few changes Apple is planning for that could affect developers and users, including removing the mute button from several app stores and making the app itself more open to outside developers.<p><p>One key update to App Store app stores will come in the near future. The first three apps on the App Store are going to be removed, including a handful of popular app stores, while the fourth will be removed entirely.<p><p>Apple is also working with Microsoft to make its own changes to the App Store and to add more features to the Store. That includes apps for iPhone, iPad, and later, the Microsoft Store. Apple has not announced these changes to the App Store since the start of this year.<p><p>Apple has said the changes will be made public in the next few weeks. Apple has been pushing to give developers more control over how app stores work, so they don't have to keep app developers at arm's length. Apple has said developers can customize the apps they use to improve their apps.<p>"]

headline: U.S. House Judiciary Committee to weigh in on Microsoft privacy hack: sources
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A House Judiciary committee on Thursday passed a bipartisan resolution aimed at addressing the issue of Microsoft Corp’s work place in the world’s biggest social network, a day after it urged the company to share some data it shared with the United States government.<p><p>The bill, introduced by Reps. Adam J. Warner (D-VA) and Jim Jordan, would provide more information on a person’s Microsoft work place to help it better assess a suspected hack. It is expected to have bipartisan support.<p><p>It was a major victory for the companies on Friday, as lawmakers sought to restore trust in their leaders, a process they accused of stifling free speech in the United States.<p><p>“This is an important and valuable piece of the information security community,” said Rep. Jim Jordan, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary panel. “I think they should have a conversation about whether it is more important for businesses, more important for government, and more important for their privacy.”<p><p>Microsoft spokesman Eric Hanler said that the company was “committed to ensuring its own data security is not shared with anyone,” adding, “We’re confident in Microsoft’s ability to comply with the laws of the United States.”<p><p>“We look forward to working with Congress to address this important issue.”<p> ']

headline: The European Commission is set to propose rules for online trading firms on Friday that will make them subject to strict oversight by EU regulators. (bit.ly/3dVq9j) Reuters/Chris Janssen: 5 things to watch for when investing in cryptocurrencies
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The European Commission is set to propose rules for online trading companies on Friday that will make them subject to strict oversight by the EU’s antitrust regulators.<p><p>“These rules will ensure that regulators are equally able to take into account the value and fairness of online trading, and the quality and efficiency of trading, while ensuring that firms are not at a disadvantage to their trading peers,” European Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said in a statement on Thursday.<p><p>The proposals come amid a rush to shore up the euro zone’s regulatory infrastructure by the bitcoin sector as businesses, particularly in Europe, have increasingly flocked to digital currencies.<p><p>The proposal will also include a proposal for a regulator for blockchain payments, the EU-based digital assets trading platform (DLT).<p><p>Digital currencies’ recent popularity has been driven in part by the risk of a global financial crisis that would hurt investment and driving down real-estate prices, creating uncertainty about the value of digital assets.<p><p>“The Commission needs to set the right pace in its efforts to harness the digital assets market to protect investor confidence in digital assets,” said Oliver Hidalgo, an analyst at Berenberg.<p>']

headline: U.S. Senate panel investigating Russian meddling in U.S. elections gives lawmakers more time
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Senate Intelligence Committee on Monday gave lawmakers more time to address the Russia investigation after the U.S. Senate Homeland Security and Intelligence Committee sent a letter to President Joe Biden on Friday.<p><p>“We continue to expect and expect that the U.S. Intelligence Committee will continue to strengthen oversight of the Russian effort to affect the 2016 elections,” said panel chairwoman Dianne Feinstein in the letter.<p><p>A group of Democratic lawmakers on Monday called on Biden and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson to step up efforts to resolve the Russia probe, after a probe into whether Russian officials had ties to the Trump campaign and that Moscow interfered in the 2016 election.<p> ']

headline: EU rules on cyber attacks against UK, EU lawmakers say
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Europe’s top two cyber security authorities have agreed to work with the EU to help cyber-attacks against the UK and EU institutions, EU officials said on Tuesday.<p><p>In a joint statement, EU Commission chief Federica Aulie warned the bloc’s rules are “inherently complex” and “work against the very principles of competition, competition and competition-free trade.”<p><p>European governments are required to ensure they use information technology to protect their data and prevent exploitation of it, in line with United Nations commitments.<p><p>While they will share information and data, the EU executive is also expected to decide on ways to mitigate the threat.<p> ']

headline: JPMorgan raises $1 billion from venture capital fund SPAC
content: ['<p> - JPMorgan Chase & Co Inc’s equity fund, SPAC Capital Management, announced the second round of funding on Monday, bringing the total amount raised to nearly $4.2 billion.<p><p>The new investment includes $300 million in new funding for an initial public offering that will give JPMorgan the option to raise up to $1 billion through a private funding round.<p><p>This round is the first since March 2019, when the company raised $175 million through a Series B funding round.<p> ']

headline: Biden, Biden to launch White House digital office: sources
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Vice President Joe Biden will announce on Wednesday the launch of a White House digital office to coordinate efforts with digital institutions, the first administration official to publicly announce such an initiative.<p><p>The Biden administration began a global effort in January to foster digital collaboration in 2020 as the Biden administration seeks to promote U.S. innovation, national security and economic competitiveness.<p><p>The office will be made up of 20 departments and agencies that will provide access to a range of data from government and private sector partners, according to White House communications director Jen Psaki.<p><p>The new office will help create a digital identity, as well as a tool for government agencies to set policies and policies on digital platforms that will facilitate collaboration, such as the Office of National Drug Control Policy and the Office of Economic Opportunity.<p><p>The Office of National Drug Control Policy will contribute to the coordination process, Psaki said.<p><p>A Biden Administration official previously told Reuters that the office would focus on areas such as data protection and innovation and human resources.<p> ']

headline: GameStop cuts ties with Disney to buy AMC, AMC-owned AMC Entertainment
content: ['<p> - AMC Entertainment Inc said on Thursday it will cut ties with retailer GameStop Inc and AMC-owned AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc to buy AMC-owned AMC Entertainment for about $10 billion, the latest in a string of moves to rein in its video game business.<p><p>The retailer, which has long seen huge demand for gaming consoles and streaming services, is cutting off some of its gaming affiliates that have struggled with revenue.<p><p>“GameStop has seen some major layoffs,” AMC told investors, adding that its video game business was still in its infancy.<p><p>GameStop will take on AMC in the near-term and AMC will use the proceeds to pay off its balance sheet, AMC said.<p> ']

headline: U.S. companies plan to use the digital revolution to bolster manufacturing by up to 40%, say analysts
content: ['<p> - United Technologies Co Inc, the world’s biggest contract manufacturer of computer chips and other products, plans to use the technological revolution to boost its stockpile of digital components, as it invests in new manufacturing.<p><p>The move comes after China cut the cost of chips in December and plans to invest $20 billion a year in chip manufacturing, as it struggles to regain competitiveness and reduce dependence on foreign suppliers of components.<p><p>The move could help reduce the demand for semiconductors globally, the company said in a blog post on Wednesday.<p><p>UTS, a key player in the supply chain, said last week it planned to use the digital revolution to cut down on the use of components by up to 42% in the next five years.<p><p>Other major U.S. technology companies are also preparing to use the digital revolution, said Richard Boorstein, an analyst at consulting firm RBC Capital Markets.<p><p>“We will likely see a greater focus on the supply chain, with more products being made by UTS,” Boorstein said.<p> ']

headline: The first phase of Microsoft's $60 billion deal with Nokia will involve $60 billion from SoftBank Group Corp and China’s Tencent’s Tencent+, according to Reuters calculations, but not all investors. Reuters first reported the deal, which is being run by two separate investors. Tencent has a stake of over 5%. Tencent has a 1.6% stake in Microsoft. The second round will use the same investment from SoftBank Group, Reuters reported, but with a smaller investment from Microsoft. (This story corrects paragraph 2, corrects paragraph 5, paragraph 6, paragraph 7) - Reuters
content: ['<p><p>This investment would include a 20% stake in Microsoft for a total of $61.7 billion, said Robert Cohen, a Microsoft spokesman, adding that the deal does not include other business activities and was not designed to benefit the company.<p><p>“Microsoft invests heavily in our businesses, but we’re still evaluating all options to ensure we are investing responsibly,” Cohen said. “We’ll be evaluating all options at this time.”<p><p>The initial investment would pay off about $3.5 billion in Microsoft’s share repurchase, Reuters said, with $2.5 billion going to Tencent, the majority of it coming from China’s Tencent.<p>']

headline: Swiss army chief calls for stronger cybersecurity, internet freedom in defense of telecoms firms
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - A Swedish army chief said on Monday that the army would not be able to maintain the digital rights of telecoms operators as the country’s security agencies fail to protect its communications networks.<p><p>Chief Armando Ruppel told a news conference the army would not be able to defend the country’s communications networks but he said the telecoms firms should cooperate with authorities to fight internet and internet-related threats.<p><p>“In order to maintain security, our security forces will be conducting checks and security procedures,” Ruppel told a news conference. “But it can take several months for our defence to fully be built,” he added, without giving further details.<p><p>The defence ministry last week announced the deployment of 1,600 police officers to defend telecoms networks after the U.S.-based group of internet firms expressed concern over a network threat at the telecoms networks.<p><p>“We are already at a crossroads,” Ruppel said. “Our security forces and the government of Sweden have become concerned about the intrusions of telecoms providers by hostile countries and will support the army’s efforts to help them and ensure their compliance with the laws.”<p><p>He warned that telecoms operators were being prevented from exercising their digital rights, and warned that telecoms providers would face sanctions from regulators.<p>']

headline: U.S. election tracker shows Trump victory after 5 years
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A U.S. election tracker showed Donald Trump’s victory after 5 years on Wednesday, a year after he won the popular vote by nearly 8 million votes.<p><p>The Trump victory has boosted confidence in the U.S. election as it relates to voter registration and the selection of a new chief executive.<p><p>The Trump-led election is the largest since 2000 and the biggest since Richard M. Nixon’s victory in 1968. The margin in most states is about 5 percentage points.<p><p>“We are thrilled to be here to see the U.S. election results and we hope that voters and supporters will follow the progress of the administration’s agenda,” said Jennifer Bush, director of the Project on the States Election Tracking Project, the lead author of the report.<p><p>This week, the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee said it will look into whether election officials violated the Hatch Act, a law allowing federal candidates to receive an election bonus if they comply with disclosure requirements.<p><p>Hatch Act violations are typically small, relatively unconnected to a presidential election.<p><p>Hatch Act violations were first reported by Reuters on Wednesday.<p> ']

headline: Mazda to develop electric bus technology for autonomous driving in Europe
content: ['<p>FRANKFURT  - Motorcycle makers Gazoo Motor and BMW AG are set to explore how they can develop a high-speed autonomous driving technology that will be used in self-driving cars, in Europe next year, its chief executive said on Thursday.<p><p>Zoo said in February it was working on an autonomous driving technology called GED Autonomous, based on a similar concept unveiled by its autonomous truck prototype in December.<p><p>“As you look back on it all, I think GED Autonomous is a very logical next step and I think the automotive industry will be more receptive to this idea because it looks like the future is already here,” Zuckermann said.<p><p>GED Autonomous uses a combination of sensors to detect and control vehicles, like a driver will respond with a certain frequency when approaching a certain obstacle or obstacle.<p><p>GED Autonomous does not have driver assistance because it takes time to operate and to respond to feedback. However, it is the first vehicle of the self-driving segment to operate autonomously in the European Union, the automotive body of which is headed by Chief Executive Kari Inglefeldt.<p><p>Inglefeldt said the company would use the data and the self-driving system to optimize its vehicle design to meet European requirements.<p> ']

headline: Dow Jones' $4.5 billion IPO goes public in U.S., Europe
content: ['<p> - Dow Jones Inc, the online video streaming service’s largest U.S. stock market listing, plans to open its first U.S. online brokerage on Wednesday, its latest round in the Dow Jones industrial average open-marketing market.<p><p>Dow Jones is still in the early stages of evaluating its plans, and preliminary pricing remains unknown.<p><p>The company is exploring a total valuation of $5 billion that includes a $100 million stake in Tesla Inc’s new headquarters and a $400 million acquisition of a 50% stake in online platform Grindr Inc.<p><p>The online brokerage aims to offer a service in less than a month, the company said, adding that it “will do so primarily to increase customer confidence,” and to create “a marketplace of value for our customers”.<p><p>“While our primary goal is to establish an ecosystem of higher-paying professionals working from home and make our customers comfortable with our service, this will be our first real retail offering,” a spokesman said.<p> ']

headline: U.S. antitrust regulator: 'It would be the next Apple'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) said on Thursday it would be the next Apple Inc - a move that could reshape the industry in the United States, as it tries to protect consumers and their choices.<p><p>The U.S. regulator said it would issue new antitrust guidance on Thursday that will create a national marketplace for small and medium-sized businesses and provide greater flexibility to implement rules and practices that protect consumers, small businesses and small businesses alike.<p><p>U.S. Justice Department antitrust head Robert Goodlatte announced last month that he would ask the FTC to establish a National Antitrust Bureau.<p><p>Last month, Goodlatte called on President Joe Biden to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate potential violations of antitrust law.<p><p>In its order, the FTC said it had “a significant number of ongoing and valid antitrust investigations underway regarding Apple, the iPhone maker, and its use of anticompetitive practices.”<p><p>“This information is crucial to our ability to conduct a fair and balanced federal antitrust investigation into Apple, the iPhone maker, and its use of anticompetitive practices,” the order said.<p> ']

headline: China's Xiaomi to list as a stock market stock after it reaches regulatory approval
content: ['<p> - China’s Xiaomi Co Ltd said on Monday it had submitted its regulatory approval to the country’s securities regulator for listing on the Beijing Stock Exchange (BRIC), the fourth time it has listed on the stock exchange.<p><p>The company, which sold shares of a range of healthcare software firm Humana Inc last year, will be listed on the U.S. Nasdaq in the third quarter of 2021, Xiaomi said in a regulatory filing on its platform.<p><p>The listing of Xiaomi’s shares came at a time when China is considering easing regulation of the country’s top three most important internet platforms.<p><p>China’s government is tightening regulatory grip on the country’s internet giants including Tencent Holdings Corp, Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and Huawei Technologies Co Ltd.<p><p>Xiaomi, founded in 2000, is a mobile-phone maker and software company headquartered in the southern city of Hangzhou in southwest China’s Zhejiang province.<p><p>“The government has shown it is ready to support the growth of the internet, and we’re ready for the market to take notice of our offerings,” the company’s website read.<p> ']

headline: Facebook and Alphabet's Google to invest $500 million in U.S. search
content: ['<p> - Alphabet’s Google is preparing to invest $500 million into the U.S. search business, as the tech giants pursue greater collaboration and greater commercial opportunities, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.<p><p>The company will invest $200 million this year in technology services, including advertising and search, and $400 million in research and development, it said.<p><p>Google also plans to use proceeds from the venture, known as “alternative public offerings”, to accelerate search in the U.S. and its growing international footprint, the report added.<p><p>The investment is not the first time Facebook, Google and Alphabet have made strategic investments in search.<p> ']

headline: Luxury real estate startup Tencent hits market debut
content: ['<p> - Luxury real estate developer Tencent Holdings Inc said on Thursday it was a market debut for the initial public offering (IPO) of its popular real estate brand Tencent Holdings Inc, after it scored a $1 billion funding round from the private equity firm Round Rock Ventures.<p><p>It said Tencent Holdings will be launched on December 17 for $1.9 billion in proceeds from a public offering, with proceeds going to support its expansion to include luxury apartments, motels and luxury sport properties.<p><p>The listing, expected in early 2020, follows the U.S. listing of shares by a Hong Kong-listed company last year, which resulted in a regulatory crackdown and heightened scrutiny of the industry.<p><p>The IPO will be conducted in three initial public offerings - a public offering and an initial public offering - with proceeds going to support Tencent’s expansion to include luxury apartments, motels and luxury sport properties, as well as further develop the brand, said Kevin Huang, vice president of international equity at Tencent.<p><p>“This is an excellent opportunity to bring the luxury real estate brand to the masses,” Huang said.<p><p>The offering is expected to close in the second quarter of 2021, Tencent said.<p>']

headline: Venezuela seeks to halt $22 billion U.S. oil pipeline deal
content: ['<p>Venezuela is seeking to halt a U.S. $22 billion U.S. pipeline deal struck this year that would have allowed Venezuela to export the oil to the United States through a natural gas pipeline owned by American refiners and a subsidiary of South American private-sector investor Oceana Holdings.<p><p>The deal, the first of its kind in the world, would have allowed Venezuelan producers of U.S. refiners the flexibility to build their own gas production, if that proved feasible, while reducing the import of Venezuelan imports from the United States.<p><p>The United States and its allies have blocked the plan. Venezuela’s opposition National Action Party (NAD) and its allies have said the United States will do more to rein in the country’s oil industry than curb its output.<p><p>The agreement has also drawn scrutiny from environmental groups, a key sticking point in Venezuela’s relationship with the United States, and with Venezuela’s main opposition party.<p><p>Environmental groups contend that the deal is a step in the wrong direction.<p><p>“The proposal by the United States would allow Venezuelan refiners, which have access to an American refiner’s market, to extract the oil without paying foreign companies, without any environmental impact,” said John Deasy, president of the Sierra Club, a nonprofit group that opposed the deal.<p>']

headline: Ethereum surges 15-fold in price after debut
content: ['<p> - A surge in cryptocurrency demand has led to a surge in the price of some of the most popular cryptocurrencies, the U.S. cryptocurrency exchange ERC20 said on Wednesday, with an increase of 5.2% to $11,858. (bit.ly/3Rp3N1r)<p><p>Demand has risen so much over the past year that it has led some companies to switch from traditional assets to digital assets.<p><p>While those switch paths have allowed companies to raise their prices and grow their stock market capitalization, others have been forced to do so by the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the U.S. economy.<p><p>Ethereum, one of the most popular cryptocurrencies, was last up 1.3% at $11,850 before the COVID-19 pandemic.<p><p>Cryptocurrency prices in the U.S. surged as much as 3% this year, putting them above those of the global dollar and above those of the euro and the pound.<p><p>The market also saw a surge in demand for cryptocurrency products like bitcoin, while bitcoin prices have remained relatively steady.<p> ']

headline: China's top court urges Xiaomi to cooperate with probe over patent infringement
content: ['<p> - China’s Supreme Court on Monday urged Xiaomi to cooperate with an investigation into allegations it infringes on a patent, saying the company had failed to notify its suppliers when a trade war between the two companies began.<p><p>The U.S.-based maker of smartphones has long been accused of monopolizing the supply of its phones, which are now under Xiaomi’s control.<p><p>The company has denied all of the allegations.<p><p>On Monday, a court in the southern city of Henan told Xiaomi, in what appeared to be a rare diplomatic resolution, that the patent infringement was unrelated to any conflict between the two firms, Xinhua News Agency reported.<p><p>Xiaomi declined to comment.<p><p>The lawsuit by Xiaomi aims to force its Chinese competitors to pay China’s top court for alleged infringement of the country’s three-decade patent monopoly.<p><p>China has been aggressively pursuing its own patent monopoly cases in the United States, seeking to rein in Xiaomi’s business model while taking its country back from Microsoft Corp.<p><p>Xiaomi is also fighting a battle with China, accusing it of monopolizing some phone parts.<p><p>The lawsuit was filed by former Xiaomi employees, in response to allegations Xiaomi infringed on some patents. The lawsuit was filed by former Xiaomi employees.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: German regulators say they may be able to help China's anticompetitive Chinese internet firms without forcing them to pay hefty fines - sources
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - German regulators have flagged that they may have to help China’s anticompetitive internet firms without forcing them to pay hefty fines, sources have told Reuters.<p><p>The industry has struggled with the Chinese economy since 2013 due to a global internet crackdown and an intensifying crackdown on anticompetitive behaviour by government regulators.<p><p>“China’s economy is in its very infancy, and I don’t know how to manage it, but we’re currently doing our best,” said one of the sources, requesting anonymity.<p><p>Some of the EU’s top financial regulators were last year accused by Beijing of failing to curb anticompetitive behaviour, with the Financial Times’ reporting on Jan. 7 that Beijing was “making it harder and harder to catch those that violate anti-monopoly rules.”<p><p>Last month, the Financial Times reported that the Chinese authorities were also putting in place fines to combat anticompetitive behaviour by Facebook, Google and other companies.<p><p>Last month, Reuters published a story about the EU antitrust watchdog “anti-trust” comments by China’s top antitrust official, who said China’s anticompetitive actions could disrupt the bloc’s efforts to counter anticompetitive behaviour, including in China.<p><p>China denies wrongdoing.<p>']

headline: In a separate development, a British court ruled this week that Uber had to pay Facebook for a portion of its traffic it sends over a border. In another development, a British court ruled this week that Uber had to pay Facebook for a portion of its traffic it sends over a border. In another development, a British court ruled this week that Uber had to pay Facebook for a portion of its traffic it sends over a border. “We have always maintained that it is a private company and that it is subject to the law”, British court ruled on Tuesday.
content: ['<p><p>Uber said the trial at which it faces charges related to its drivers’ use of the social network was confidential and the case had not been resolved.<p><p>“We are pleased that the court has finally recognized that the UK is a country that values privacy, and that we cannot, and should not, continue to operate with impunity,” a company spokesperson said in an emailed statement.<p><p>The judge in Britain’s Northern District Court in October dismissed a lawsuit filed by Uber that had accused it of misusing the country’s border system in processing large volumes of traffic.<p><p>In its legal challenge, the British government argued that Uber drivers’ behaviour violated human rights by sending thousands of drivers across the border illegally without paying for it, a claim that Uber had failed to prove.<p><p>Last week, U.S. District Judge James Robart in Manhattan dismissed the California case that Uber was violating human rights by sending more than 30,000 drivers across the border illegally without paying for it.<p>']

headline: Vodafone gets more than $9 billion from Google for U.S. ads
content: ['<p> - Vodafone NV, the world’s largest cellular phone operator, will receive about $9 billion from Google for U.S. ads for U.S. mobile and broadband services, the world’s largest cell phone operator said on Tuesday.<p><p>The deal comes after Verizon Communications Inc reported a $1.2 billion loss for the year ending Dec. 31 after it raised $2.5 billion in a Series C funding round.<p><p>Vodafone’s share price was down 2.2% to $1.02 in afternoon trading.<p><p>It has said it plans to add 50,000 new U.S. customers by the end of 2020.<p> ']

headline: China's Alibaba orders $37 billion worth of shares in Baidu
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - Alibaba Group Holding Co Ltd said on Tuesday it would sell 1.9 million shares in Chinese e-commerce giant Baidu after the Chinese internet giant blocked the stock exchange from listing there in a regulatory crackdown.<p><p>The stock exchange in the southern city of Hangzhou was set up last year to process stock market transactions. But the Chinese social media giant said it had blocked Baidu’s listings from processing payments, making it unable to process payments online and forcing some shops to close.<p><p>Alibaba did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>It said it would buy 1.9 million shares in Baidu at a price of 2 yuan ($37.48) per share and issue 5.1 million shares, the equivalent of about 9 million shares in a single share, for an initial public offering of around HK$1.86 billion.<p> ']

headline: UK to cut online payments by 20%
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain to cut online payments by 20% by 2027, the first of which would be voluntary, a government minister said on Monday.<p><p>Robinhood said the service was free to the public and that it would enable people to make payments anonymously.<p><p>But it said the digital payments service would be subject to government approval and that it would not accept personal payment or other types of payment.<p><p>It said payment technology would still be around in the UK following the closure of the COVID-19 pandemic, but said it had increased in speed with technology.<p><p>Online payments are used by more than 1 billion people in Britain, with over 1,000 firms offering services, according to government data.<p> ']

headline: Factbox: The 'tipping point' for U.S. presidential candidates
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Donald Trump is poised to lead the United States on Tuesday, a sign he may be on track to earn the support of many Americans who view him with suspicion.<p><p>His campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, has called it “a critical day for the United States” for voters in battleground states who have traditionally been more supportive of his Republican rivals.<p><p>The billionaire businessman, who is weighing whether to run for president in 2020, has tapped advisers in key battleground states, such as David Axelrod and Jake Sullivan, to advance his agenda and to win over voters who have traditionally been at odds with him.<p><p>In his first days in office, his chief strategist, Steve Bannon, said he was leaning toward running but declined to disclose the campaign’s strategy. Trump also said he was “very, very confident in the U.S. economy and I believe that’s what we need to win the November election.”<p><p>The campaign is raising money in battleground states that are critical for the Republican nominee, which could propel him to the top of the ticket.<p><p>Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus recently told Fox News’s Greta van Susteren he is considering running in states where President Joe Biden has ruled.<p>']

headline: The world's biggest cryptocurrency market cap hit $14.5 billion in mid-January, sources told Reuters on Friday, more than twice the $2.3 billion that was in January.
content: ['<p><p>The world’s biggest cryptocurrency is expected to reach a market cap of more than $14.5 billion this year, according to data from CoinCompare, with $100 billion worth of bitcoin, ether and bitcoin assets traded.<p><p>Shares in major cryptocurrency exchanges were up around 17% in mid-January. That led some investors to speculate that bitcoin might rise even higher in the short term, with some betting it would surpass the $1 trillion bitcoin price target.<p><p>Goldman Sachs & Co has also jumped on the cryptocurrency hype. Its $7.6 billion funding round last month pushed the price target of bitcoin to $30, up from a range of $20-$30 this month.<p><p>Bitcoin is backed by the private blockchain network Bitcoin Cash which powers over $1 trillion in assets, according to CoinCompare.<p><p>The world’s largest cryptocurrency market cap hit $14.5 billion in mid-January, more than twice the $2.3 billion that was in January, sources said. The market cap was still above the $1 trillion peak for CryptoCompare, which tracks digital assets.<p><p>In January, Bitcoin closed up nearly 20% in premarket trading, its highest level since Jan. 20.<p>']

headline: SIRI announces plan to cut ties with SPAC, Google
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - The U.S. government on Tuesday announced plans to cut ties with one of the largest technology firms in the country, the Internet search and advertising giant SPAC, after it said in an internal document on Monday it would divest from SPAC in the next three months.<p><p>In a statement, SPAC said the new measures were "driven by shareholder needs to make the most informed decisions regarding the strategic strategic interests of the SPAC Group."<p><p>In the revised plan, which is due to be released in the coming weeks, the SPAC was ordered to cut ties with Microsoft Corp, Google’s Chrome browser, Facebook’s Safari and Amazon.com Inc’s Amazon Web Services (AWS).<p><p>The move was a direct challenge to SPAC’s efforts to diversify its workforce while it continues to strengthen its services offerings.<p><p>SPAC did not disclose which companies or technology companies would be cut off from SPAC for the new year.<p> ']

headline: Finance minister criticises Chinese tech firms for slowing down competition
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s Finance Minister Li Shufu criticised the Chinese tech giants for slowing down competition last year after some detained Chinese internet giants - including Tencent and Alibaba - began slowing down Chinese internet traffic, an assessment that angered Beijing’s dominance in the lucrative digital space.<p><p>“It’s been very unfair for a long time now,” Li, who heads the ministry’s antitrust and market competition committee, said in an interview. “But we must not repeat the mistakes of the past.”<p><p>Li dismissed the criticism on Monday as a “meme” that would distract from the bigger issue.<p><p>“They slowed down competition in China in a big way,” he said.<p><p>Chinese internet firms are facing hefty fines from state regulators for blocking and slowing down Chinese traffic, and a ban on the services of China’s largest internet firms after the Chinese Communist Party ordered restrictions last year.<p><p>The crackdown was prompted by the arrest and interrogation of former Tencent CEO Shu Tse-tung in December and subsequent firing of Tencent’s chairman by Beijing’s Financial Bureau, the country’s top prosecutor, Chang Hui-tung, said on Tuesday.<p><p>Tencent and Alibaba had also suspended the services of Chinese internet firms in December, while China’s Alibaba has since said it was cooperating with authorities.<p> ']

headline: UK's Amazon says no restrictions on UK content but asks it to consider 'non-UK content'
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s top e-commerce company Amazon said on Tuesday it would not be looking to impose strict regulations over its UK offerings and said it would consider content from non-UK sources as a priority for it in a global negotiation.<p><p>The company said it was exploring the possibility of adding a “non-UK content” section in future.<p><p>Britain’s independent Culture Secretary, Rebecca Hodge, told a parliamentary inquiry on Wednesday it was a “critical issue for us as we are a global leader in digital innovation and are committed to delivering an open and diverse society.”<p><p>The UK’s copyright watchdog, the Digital Rights Commission, told the House of Commons Digital Policy and Regulation Committee that if the country did not make clear an agreement by the end of 2021, the commission would consider “non-UK content” in the negotiations.<p><p>In its annual annual report on Wednesday, Amazon said it was making “great progress” with its UK operations.<p><p>“Our approach is based on a review of the UK’s digital infrastructure, which we will assess during the next 12 months.”<p> ']

headline: U.S. Senate panel rules on how the government must use Facebook
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Senate on Friday approved a bill to require Facebook Inc to use its technology to prevent false or misleading content on its platform as part of government and consumer oversight, as it seeks to move toward its goals of protecting the safety of Americans from dangerous misinformation.<p><p>The panel, chaired by Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia, introduced a bipartisan bill in January. It would also require Facebook and Alphabet’s Google Inc to go after suspected hate groups.<p><p>It would also require internet companies to make “neutral and meaningful claims without any false content.”<p><p>Facebook has said it wants the bill adopted to create a “digital equivalent” to its content policy.<p><p>The tech giant has denied that it is seeking to censor the news.<p><p>Last year, Facebook suspended an employee who posted a video with the caption “Free speech,” citing concerns about his content and the company’s reputation among users.<p><p>“The Department of Justice understands that these sorts of policies can have a significant impact on the safety of our consumers and society,” Facebook said in a blog post.<p><p>Democratic lawmakers are pushing for a tougher approach to Facebook’s practices that critics say violate users’ First Amendment rights.<p> ']

headline: Biden tells Congress he will seek authorization to block Amazon.com from growing
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Representative Jim Jordan said Wednesday he will seek a Congressional authorization to block the U.S. Amazon.com Inc from becoming a U.S. national security threat.<p><p>The move comes at a time Amazon, the world’s largest private-sector employer by market value, has been expanding in recent months as President Donald Trump has pushed back against Amazon and other tech giants in the world’s largest online marketplace.<p><p>“We should not be getting in the way of progress,” Jordan said in a letter sent to House Republican Leader Ryan Ryan, requesting a copy of the resolution.<p><p>“There’s no better time for us to find a way forward on Amazon. It’s time to take action against the assault that the President has been running, and also stop the assault on our businesses.”<p><p>The measure, which he has vowed to pass in a voice vote, calls for Amazon to become an affiliate of a trade group representing U.S. auto and energy firms that was created by a deal struck with Germany’s Daimler AG.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Tesla shares fall as lower valuation pushes gains to $19
content: ['<p> - Shares in Tesla Motors plunged as investors rallied after the company’s shares tumbled on Wednesday, hitting a record low of $19, according to data from Refinitiv.<p><p>Exclusive: Tesla shares fall as lower valuation pushes gains to $19<p><p>“We’re now approaching a peak as the value of Tesla’s stock is over $2 billion higher than our record peak,” said Nicholas Zahn, senior analyst at Refinitiv.<p><p>Tesla’s shares have been down more than 25% so far this year. The stock was down 4% at $49.99 this week.<p><p>Tesla’s stock has soared so far this year, hitting record highs of $51.84 in October 2020. Investors also tend to move their money around faster than stocks in the stock market.<p><p>Tesla shares fell as low as $19 in premarket trading. (reut.rs/2z8K1o)<p><p>Tesla shares fell as low as $19.14 in premarket trading.<p> ']

headline: Sebastian Vettel's Mercedes has reached the point where the German supercar is considered the most important car in Formula E, it was reported on Sunday. “He is the most important driver” in the world. However, Vettel, the Austrian Grand Prix champion, is still on pace to win the season’s first two titles, he said in an interview with GermanyOnline.com (lt;p>FRANKFURT/LONDON  - Sebastian Vettel’s Mercedes has reached the point where the German supercar is considered the most important car in Formula E, it was reported on Sunday.
content: ['<p><p>Vettel said he wanted to show his dominance during the season, and that would help to win titles in Europe, Africa, China and India. He is the youngest champion at the moment, though he still has three years to go.<p><p>“I would like to win titles in Europe,” he said. “If I don’t win titles there won’t be any chance of me winning one in Europe.”<p><p>“I think that would help to win Formula E again because there is no one in Formula E that has been able to beat me. I don’t know who has been quickest.”<p><p>In December, Vettel led all drivers in the world in points in the German Grand Prix while Kimi said at the time that he would become a top driver in Europe.<p>']

headline: Nokia plans to roll out next-generation 5G wireless chips in India
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - Nokia plans to roll out next-generation 5G wireless chips in India to help it compete in the global market for mobile phone customers, the Finnish telecoms conglomerate said on Wednesday.<p><p>It will also build a new unit to make chips for mobile phones such as the Lumia phones or 5G chips for phones with 5G connectivity.<p><p>Nokia will launch a new wireless product, the Nokia Mobile Technology Centre, next month in Mumbai, which will be launched in India.<p><p>Nokia said it will also make 5G chips for 5G connectivity on its flagship mobile devices, the Lumia 900 and the Lumia 900+.<p> ']

headline: The first half of 2020 will see fewer users browsing online - but not for long!
content: ['<p> - Online shopping is likely to go away at some point in 2020, with the number of people using social media on average increasing as users stay at home, according to a study published in the journal Science.<p><p>Online shopping is likely to have a similar impact to the time period before the pandemic, with people spending more time online, according to the study.<p><p>The study found that when users visited shops or websites directly, they spent significantly less time browsing because they were more comfortable in home and had fewer habits to change.<p><p>“The more online, the less we feel like spending time,” said Dr Peter Knoll, a research fellow at the University of Cambridge and one of the authors of the study.<p><p>“We don’t think that people will necessarily be switching to social media to be engaged in the things they are doing, so it seems like it will become more of an activity.”<p><p>“It will also have a significant impact on the size of the gap between the average shopping behaviour and the average spending behaviour.”<p><p>The study, which focuses on the impact of technology on online behaviour by researchers from the University of Cambridge and the University of Michigan, comes ahead of a similar study by the University of Arizona that looked at the use of social media by Americans between 1980 and 2017.<p>']

headline: China's internet regulator says 5G roll-out as 'dangerous'
content: ['<p> - China’s internet regulator said on Friday it was “unable to guarantee the safety of data collected and transmitted by the internet backbone and the internet backbone providers” on Thursday.<p><p>The regulator has fined the 5G internet backbone China Telecom Co Ltd (C3) for violating net neutrality in 2015 after it slowed down some internet traffic during peak times to boost the economy’s capacity to process digital content.<p><p>On Friday, China’s internet regulator said it was “unable to guarantee the safety of data collected and transmitted by the internet backbone and the internet backbone providers” on Friday, Reuters reported.<p><p>The regulator said it had fined China Telecom Co Ltd for violating net neutrality in 2015.<p> ']

headline: Google says Facebook's 'adverse effect' on data privacy is not a “fair trade”
content: ['<p> - Google will introduce a new policy in its Google Play app this month to require users to turn on "advanced analytics," or user-generated content, to make sure that they do not share personal information with third parties, the social media company said.<p><p>The policy will apply only to advertising and other online advertising, Google said in a blog post.<p><p>The new policy is available here: https <PAD>  company.com/apply.<p><p>It will also apply to subscriptions to Google Play stores, which Google said are available in more than 100 countries.<p> ']

headline: GameStop buys online gaming retailer GameStop, shares up 10%
content: ['<p> - GameStop Inc shares ended up 10% higher on Monday, pushing its total online gaming stake over $3 billion to $4 billion.<p><p>Shares of GameStop were up nearly 4% in premarket trade, with more than 9 million shares trading around 1,500 pounds.<p><p>The online retailer, which was acquired by Microsoft Corp, owns over 11 million GameStop GameStop GameStop Live Games games on the Xbox 360, Xbox One, PlayStation 3 and PlayStation 4, its website showed.<p><p>GameStop’s shares were up 10% to $2.06 at $45.50, and its online gaming stake was up nearly 10% in the day to $4 billion.<p> ']

headline: Luxury luxury car maker Bumble launches IPO
content: ['<p> - Luxury luxury car maker Bumble Motor Co, the global leader in luxury luxury cars, said on Wednesday it will launch a private initial public offering (IPO) of around $1 billion in 2021.<p><p>The IPO would be the first by Bumble since 2018’s IPO of luxury car brand Jaguar Land Rover.<p><p>“We have long had an interest in luxury cars but we believe they are just the beginning of the journey,” Jefferies Chief Executive Tim Johnson told investors in the company’s first-quarter earnings call.<p><p>The Bumble IPO was one of the more high profile IPOs by luxury car makers as it was seen as a way for them to increase their market share.<p><p>Last month, Ford Motor Co, Ford’s main rival, held a private IPO in London.<p><p>Bumble said in January it would be launching an IPO in 2019 and would offer about $300 million of its shares for a cash injection of between $25 and $30 million, with proceeds going towards capitalizing on customer growth and profitability, and the expansion of its brand into luxury vehicles.<p> ']

headline: GooGoo Inc on Monday called on its shares to be held by the Chinese internet giant rather than by its Chinese shareholders, as the stock has fallen amid pressure over trade rules that could cut their stake in the company to less than 5% in the next two years.
content: ['<p><p>GooGoo is currently under U.S. anti-trust scrutiny and is exploring ways to amend its Hong Kong listing rules if it fails to comply with U.S. regulations, according to Reuters.<p><p>The company, one of the world’s largest online advertising services, last month also raised its price target in Hong Kong at HK$35.75 per share for the first time in a year, valuing the stock at around HK$22 billion.<p><p>GooGoo’s shares have since fallen as much as 41% in their first trading day, according to market filings.<p><p>The latest price drop comes months after Apple Inc announced plans to suspend its ability to sell apps on its App Store, citing “insufficient business reason”.<p><p>Chinese regulators have said that China will not recognize U.S. tech companies’ traditional ownership structures, or those that can circumvent U.S. rules, such as those in the world’s biggest online marketplace.<p>']

headline: China's Xiaomi vows to develop its Mi 5, which could make it available in a range of markets
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - China’s Xiaomi Corp said on Thursday it will develop the Xiaomi Mi 5, a device that it will launch in two or three markets later this year.<p><p>The company is expected to introduce a new model of its Mi 5 mid-generation smartphone this year with the base model expected to launch this year in Europe and Japan.<p><p>($1 = 76.7501 Chinese yuan renminbi)<p> ']

headline: Switzerland's Deutsche Telekom wants to raise funds by selling the German unit and turning it into an investment arm of a rival telecoms firm’s technology unit in 2018
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Deutsche Telekom on Friday asked a German court to order the Swiss telecoms unit it owns to sell its business unit for nearly $25 billion and turn the unit into a foreign investment arm if it does not comply with German rules on foreign ownership.<p><p>The request was sent to the Federal Court in Frankfurt, the company said in a statement.<p><p>The court did not immediately respond.<p><p>Founded in 2019, Deutsche Telekom’s U.S. arm, called Telekom AG, has been in operation since 2012 to help companies build high-speed data networks in Europe and Asia, with an aim to “sign up customers” for the networks.<p><p>The unit, which counts Nokia, T-Mobile and other telecoms operators among its clients, is owned by Deutsche Telekom’s German unit.<p> ']

headline: Founded in 2015, Gizmodo is a daily expression of social media's evolving trends
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin soared more than 200% this year and is poised to become the biggest cryptocurrency on the market, with analysts predicting the coin will become the $37 trillion cryptocurrency.<p><p>The cryptocurrency, which was worth around $8 trillion in 2020, has seen an explosion in the past year and has risen at an all-time high of $38,200 per coin.<p><p>Bitcoin’s price has exploded in the past month, where it has gained nearly 60% from its previous high of $58,000 and now stands at more than $63,000.<p><p>Bitcoin’s rising price has helped fuel the cryptocurrency’s meteoric rise in value, attracting millions of users in the past month, and has helped spur the cryptocurrency’s surge, according to CoinMarketCap.com.<p><p>Gizmodo’s revenue rose 31% to $109 million.<p><p>“Bitcoin is in the midst of a boom, it’s not a bull run and not a wild ride and I think there’s still a lot of room for growth,” Gizmodo analyst Vlad Tenev told Reuters.<p><p>“It seems like more people are buying bitcoin and it is a really solid investment for bitcoin,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: 'Hollywood has not been a happy place' for a film critic
content: ['<p> - Hollywood is not happy with how its film critic ranks, an editorial in its new feature film, The Cinema critic said on Tuesday.<p><p>“Hollywood is not a happy place for a film critic,” the New York Times’ Robert DeNiro wrote in an editorial for the magazine.<p><p>“The industry is in its infancy and does not understand why critics are viewed differently when they are presented with choices on a national stage,” he said. “Industry norms discourage discussion of critical issues,” he added.<p><p>The Cinema critic, a longtime critic of Hollywood’s work, gave his thoughts on Hollywood’s decline to the cinema’s top five best-films to screen on Friday night.<p><p>“To the best of my knowledge, Hollywood has not been a happy place for a film critic,” said Josh Gad, editor of the magazine. “I have no problem with what movie critic does, but the industry is not quite ready for it.”<p><p>The Oscar winner, whose work includes “Lilith” and “The Lord of the Rings”, was appointed on Wednesday to a three-year term by the Hollywood studio after it awarded a two-year contract to Warner Bros to write and direct a movie critical of the studio. Warner declined to comment.<p> ']

headline: BANGKOK, South Korea’s largest city, says it can help with the shortage of milk and foodstuffs due to global warming.
content: ['<p><p>BOSTON  - Bangkok city council on Tuesday said it could provide 3.5 million metric tons of milk, 3.5 million tons of bread and 800 metric tons of fruits, at a cost of 500 million won ($924,935).<p><p>The province’s food supply is being squeezed due to COVID-19-induced droughts and extreme heat wave that have left it without enough water, which has fueled the coronavirus-induced shortage.<p><p>Demand for produce, essential to a growing number of households, has fallen in recent months due to a pandemic-driven surge in factory production due to rising COVID-19 levels.<p><p>A shortage of essential supplies like rice, corn, sugarcane and egg yolks and butter for cars was the driving force behind the shortage, Bangkok’s council chairwoman, Kaili Tsung-jin, told reporters on Wednesday.<p><p>“We will be providing a good supply of foodstuffs, because we’re not able to cater for people who don’t have a lot of foodstuffs, because we have to take care of everyone,” Tsung said.<p><p>The mayor said the shortage of cereals and eggs was due in part to COVID-19, but he declined to disclose a specific cause.<p>']

headline: Google to make its own ad network
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - Google will make its own ad network for use by ad agencies and other digital companies to help its search engine and cloud services, the German tech giant said on Tuesday, without disclosing the cost.<p><p>The $7 billion Google+ network would be similar to existing ad networks that exist in the United States, Canada, India, Europe and China.<p><p>The networks would operate for one-time fees based on revenue generated from various channels of advertising, Google said.<p><p>It also said it would offer up to 15 ad-supported channels for free, with ad-supported channels providing ad-supported services for as long as ad agencies used the networks.<p><p>“We are looking at the future of how we can build ad-supported networks to serve the needs of our users’ audiences,” said Dan Bekoff, senior vice president of Google+.<p><p>($1 = 0.8226 euros)<p> ']

headline: Alibaba says it will not hold any shares at $25 each: Hong Kong IPO
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has said it will not hold any shares at $25 each and will not hold any stock at a Hong Kong IPO, despite U.S. regulatory guidance saying that the company could not own more than 20% of the company.<p><p>Shares in Alibaba rose 9% after the news. The company, which was valued at more than $3.5 billion, said its investment programme, called Alibaba Innovation, will be led by co-founder Jack Ma, who is the co-CEO of Chinese gaming firm Ping Pong, and other senior leaders.<p><p>($1 = 0.7186 pounds)<p> ']

headline: U.S. lawmaker says Trump has 'deeply flawed' business dealings in Ukraine
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. lawmakers on Wednesday said Trump had "deeply flawed" business dealings in Ukraine.<p><p>The latest developments come after the administration abruptly suspended U.S. sanctions against Moscow over the conflict in Ukraine.<p><p>Republican Representative Justin Amash, who chairs the House Judiciary Committee, said Wednesday his office would ask the Trump administration to reopen sanctions against Moscow over alleged human rights abuses following the July 2018 ouster of Ukrainian President Mikheil Saakashvili from office.<p><p>Russia denies any role in the ouster.<p><p>Amash added that the White House should release a report detailing any Russian violations of U.S. sanctions.<p> ']

headline: U.S. to set up an independent regulator to vet and investigate cyberattacks
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) will provide the necessary regulatory authority for the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the White House said on Tuesday, following months of talks to revive a stalled merger between the U.S. Postal Service and the American Postal Workers Union.<p><p>The announcement comes just days after the Federal Trade Commission said it would suspend the deal without informing Congress of the planned merger, which it accused of hurting U.S. workers.<p><p>The FTC, which is the only federal agency that does not regulate big box retailers, is still debating whether to offer the USPS control over the merger.<p> ']

headline: Ahead of the coronavirus pandemic, insurers plan to sell off the stake in new firm’s business to investors on March 7
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - While insurers are still debating whether to sell their stakes in a new business to customers, the companies, which include health insurance giant Humana and private equity firm BlackRock Inc, are in talks to sell off the stake to investors as a way to avoid a potential loss to competitors.<p><p>A spokeswoman for Bipartisan Exchange Reform, a major insurer of consumer health insurance, said the company was considering the option of selling the stake in the new firm to customers on March 7.<p><p>In December, U.S. Senator Ron Wyden, D-Ore., introduced legislation that would require the Internal Revenue Service to review its financial disclosure reports before they are sold. The process could take several weeks if Congress does not pass legislation by March 7.<p><p>Insurers typically sell to customers after the initial public offering, which typically ends on March 15, so the insurer can then raise funds to pay off a potential loss to potential customers if regulators fail to comply.<p><p>Last month, President Joe Biden’s administration announced a $1.5 billion funding plan that will encourage new firms to use public markets, including publicly traded mutual funds, to help their businesses. The plan is expected to be finalized by mid-year.<p><p>A group of insurers, including Humana and BlackRock, is among the leading candidates for selling off their stakes in the new company to their customers on March 7.<p>']

headline: A new bill to restrict tech giants like Alphabet Inc’s Google, Amazon.com Inc, Facebook Inc and Microsoft Corp from using U.S. tech will be unveiled in Congress on Thursday.
content: ['<p><p>WASHINGTON  - Federal legislation aimed at combating Internet censorship will be introduced in the coming weeks, it said in a blog post, and could even be introduced by a U.S. senator or an independent senator.<p><p>Congress needs to pass a law before the end of March to require Alphabet Inc’s Google and Facebook Inc to disclose the companies they have banned from their websites, the blog post said. (bit.ly/3LqW3Np)<p><p>The proposed law, signed by Representative John Conyers, a Michigan Democrat who chairs the U.S. House Judiciary Committee, will also make it a crime to block a website. (This story corrects name to "Facebook Inc"), and states “that a law restricting Google and Facebook” can’t be passed without an independent hearing.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank launches $100 billion venture into electric vehicle electric car payments
content: ['<p> - SoftBank’s electric vehicle payments company has launched an electric vehicle charging station in Los Angeles, making it the first car-focused car-focused company to announce a funding round for a California-based electric vehicle payment platform.<p><p>This comes months after SoftBank partnered with electric vehicle payment provider Waymo to roll out the service at Los Angeles’s Fremont Park shopping center on electric cars and other electric vehicles.<p><p>The California-based company’s service will start charging a vehicle’s batteries within minutes of the vehicle entering service, and will eventually go live across California cities, Waymo’s chief executive Officer, Brad Bell, told Reuters.<p><p>“This will be our first EV charging station,” he said, referring to the company’s self-driving smart grocery delivery system that has been testing in cities including Los Angeles, Austin and Oakland.<p><p>It will be available in the first half of 2021, a company spokeswoman said in an e-mailed statement.<p><p>The company, which makes cash-based payments at a price that is among the cheapest in the world, has been testing its technology at a number of companies around the world.<p><p>Earlier this month, Waymo said its service is currently “very limited” in the United States and its U.S. partners have “had a rough start with that”.<p> ']

headline: Greensleeves up a second wave of its popular games - both physical and digital - to make it harder for publishers to squeeze new revenue from their own content.
content: ['<p> - Nintendo Corp said it would invest $1 billion in a new wave of video games, both physical and digital, to push video games into a larger audience.<p><p>The company said it would invest $1 billion into the latest game “Nausicaa”, a new spinoff from the popular online role-playing game and video game franchise.<p><p>In February, the company introduced “Kinsey”, a digital look at how gamers interact with media around the world through the lens of videogame personalities, and it will make its first foray into gaming this summer.<p><p>Last month, Nintendo unveiled a video game with a different twist. The game is a cooperative online role-playing game. <p><p>The company said in an e-mailed statement that it plans to “make Nintendo ’s video games accessible and meaningful for both gamers and non-gamers alike.”<p><p>The company said it would continue to offer new content and make them accessible on the Nintendo Switch.<p> ']

headline: U.S. intelligence agencies to develop counter-insurgency capabilities: report
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. intelligence community will develop counter-insurgency capabilities for combating cybercrime, U.S. government officials said on Thursday, as the White House continues to urge Congress to act.<p><p>The Counter-Insurgency Technologies Agency (CSIA) will present its report to Congress on Thursday, the officials added.<p><p>The agency’s Counter-Insurgency Operations (CSEO) report is expected to be presented to Congress next week, and will outline strategy for using cyber-enabled force, including identifying and disrupting cyber-enabled threats and supporting efforts to counter them.<p> ']

headline: U.S. trade officials push Google to move into new “top-notch” markets: WSJ
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Trade officials from around the world said on Tuesday they had begun talking to Alphabet’s Google about how to attract new internet-enabled devices to the U.S. market, and whether to offer deals with the companies themselves.<p><p>“Google is going to try to play the marketplace card,” said Dan Lue, a trade authority with the U.S. government’s office of consumer and labor law.<p><p>“If they want to go to a market where it’s easy for Google to become a dominant player in this new area... they’ll have to go through the Google process,” Lue said.<p><p>Google declined to comment, while others including Microsoft, Apple and Alphabet’s Google did not immediately respond to requests for comment.<p><p>“These are very public steps,” Lue said. “They’re not just going to grab the consumer market and take advantage of all of the new features of Google. They are going to go through the market process,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Factbox: Trump criticising Google for its bias against tech companies in 2020
content: ['<p> - Donald Trump criticised Google on Thursday for how it has treated tech companies during the 2020 election, as the billionaire businessman compared the company to a rival.<p><p>In a tweetstorm that lasted several hours and was accompanied by a flurry of other messages from the billionaire, the Republican nominee compared Apple, Google, Facebook and Microsoft to “the Nazis during the war on terror” and claimed that tech companies were “stifling innovation” by unfairly prioritising their profit margins over the public interest in education and healthcare.<p><p>Google has stepped up efforts to block news from its platform to promote its products and services and to promote its product offerings in schools and universities.<p><p>In a series of tweets, the Republican nominee also called out Google for “stifling innovation” in its search engine, saying that it treated every product in its product line like it was “a glorified Nazi concentration camps.”<p><p>Google said on Wednesday it would stop distributing news in its products and services in the coming weeks to its Chrome browser or its website.<p><p>In a statement, Alphabet Inc’s Google said the company’s business practices are strictly governed by code and that it had taken enforcement actions against any and all users of Google+.<p>']

headline: Vodafone, Didi Chuxing offer to buy WhatsApp shares
content: ['<p> - Didi Chuxing, the European communications giant behind WhatsApp, said on Tuesday it would buy WhatsApp shares at the current exchange rate and close on June 23 in a deal worth around 2.14 billion euros ($2.39 billion), the latest in a series of moves by a large U.S. company that has become the target of European regulators.<p><p>The deal would be the latest in a series of moves by a global messaging firm that has seen its stock price surge over 100% since last month’s wild rally.<p><p>The companies, whose businesses rely on billions of monthly user data and social media accounts, have long resisted regulatory scrutiny.<p><p>In April, the European Union announced a host of measures to help boost digital security and improve customer service.<p><p>Earlier this month, European competition watchdog Vivendi said it would tighten rules on the messaging app’s use by businesses.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Attorney general accuses China of 'hostile rhetoric' in Xinjiang
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Attorney General Sally Jeffries on Thursday accused China of “hostile rhetoric” over its latest round of border patrol announcements, saying Beijing was using the country’s economic and military advantage to divide its people.<p><p>Jeffries, a Republican, said she was “deeply concerned” by China’s apparent move to suspend border patrol posts in Uighuristan. She said the government had given no instructions to Chinese border officers to use these posts, saying they were just “just sitting there.”<p><p>China detained more than 1,500 Uighurs in January, prompting a series of protests against what Beijing called a failed border patrol. The protests have since spread to Xinjiang and neighboring regions.<p><p>The United States and China face similar tensions between themselves. China denies any wrongdoing in its Xinjiang region.<p><p>Jeffries’ comments on Thursday, though, echo comments last week by Trump administration officials about China’s alleged policy of de facto blocking the flow of Uighur goods from the United States to Xinjiang.<p><p>The statements have alarmed Beijing, which has called the remarks “an abdication of responsibility” and a violation of international law.<p><p>In a statement, China’s foreign ministry said on Thursday it was disappointed in Uighur comments and had sent the minister of foreign affairs to Beijing.']

headline: China's Zhejiang Dili shares jump 8.9%
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese shares soared 7.9% on Monday, as shares of the sprawling gaming giant Zhejiang Dili rose 1.5% amid heightened interest by major tech players in the Hong Kong gaming market.<p><p>Shares of the Shenzhen-listed company rose 3.6% to a record close of $6.08 on Monday afternoon, giving Zhejiang Dili a market capitalization of around $3 billion.<p><p>Zhejiang Dili, which is the world’s largest developer of online games and entertainment, has seen an annual revenue rise of more than 13.6 billion yuan ($5.37 billion), which includes advertising, online sales, and other items, according to its website.<p><p>Shares of Shenzhen-based gaming giant Fubozo also rose 7.5% to a record close of $4.14 on Monday afternoon.<p><p>Shares of Shenzhen-based gaming company Tencent also jumped 8.8% to a record close of $2.38.<p><p>A recent rally by the gaming giant has drawn investor interest.<p><p>Shares of Tencent and its overseas affiliate, Bessemer Venture Partners, have also risen during the pandemic.<p><p>The company’s shares have gained about 10% since late Monday.<p> ']

headline: NFT's $4.4 billion fundraising raised in 2019; Buffett says SEC review in 'deep red'
content: ['<p> - Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc said on Tuesday it had raised $4.4 billion in a fundraising round led by $1 billion from U.S. investor Warren Buffett, adding that its investment in Alphabet Inc’s Google has helped it to achieve a better financial picture.<p><p>The company’s investment in Alphabet Inc’s Google, the world’s largest online advertising network, raised nearly $30 billion, the company said.<p><p>The announcement by Berkshire came as Alphabet’s shares rose nearly 13% on Monday in premarket trading as investors poured dollars into the investment bank.<p><p>The company’s stock has gained around 10% since it hit an all-time high of $59,879 in late February.<p><p>It is expected to report its fourth-quarter results on Wednesday.<p><p>The investment bank’s investment has raised $41 billion in a combined fundraising of $18 billion and $13 billion through its new fund, NFT Capital Partners, in 2019, the company said.<p><p>NFT Capital Partners’ investment is one of the largest ever by a U.S. financial technology firm. It raised $20.5 billion in 2018, up from $12 billion in 2019.<p>']

headline: The Canadian government has approved a $20-billion bill that sets out steps it plans to make to make bitcoin more palatable to U.S. citizens, including setting up a database of companies that can verify their identities, the Canadian Press has learned.
content: ["<p><p>It also sets out what businesses will be required to offer bitcoin in a country where the currency has been banned for more than a decade.<p><p>The federal government, which is scrambling to deal with a volatile global bitcoin market, has been pushing to make bitcoin more palatable to U.S. citizens as it seeks to make sure they aren't breaking the law.<p><p>Last month, the Canadian government introduced legislation that would make it easier for businesses to offer bitcoin, which can range from $1,000 to $2,000.<p><p>Canada and the United States also signed up for a series of measures to develop digital currencies, including a digital signature system that Canadians can use to verify their identities.<p> "]

headline: Zoom launches new Zoom Zoom video search feature
content: ['<p> - Zoom Video Inc plans to roll out a new Zoom video search feature this year that will allow users to easily search by category, Zoom Chief Executive Officer David Rivkin said in an interview on Thursday.<p><p>Zoom Video aims to allow users to search directly on a Zoom video, as well as video streaming services, Rivkin told Reuters. Users will also be able to view Zoom video content such as movie trailers and special offers, allowing them to watch the latest titles in Zoom.<p><p>“There’s going to be some people who don’t like movies, they don’t like sports, so that’s going to be the new frontier for Zoom and it will be an amazing experience for everyone,” Rivkin said.<p> ']

headline: WAGNARS AG asks German court to block Huawei
