content: ['<p>BERLIN  - WAGNARS AG has asked the German court to block Huawei Technologies Co’s Huawei Technologies Co from blocking Huawei’s (HWT.DE) business in the Netherlands, citing concerns over Huawei’s business dealings in India and the possibility of a “economic and security impact” to the two countries.<p><p>Huawei has previously said that it is pursuing a “neutral, non-discriminatory, non-discriminatory and non-discriminatory position on the matter”.<p><p>HWT.DE and Huawei declined to comment.<p><p>Germany’s Federal Court in the southern city of Frankfurt on Friday declined to grant Huawei “a preliminary hearing” on the grounds that “Huawei has not satisfactorily complied with its legal obligations to the Dutch court in relation to the proposed injunction application.<p><p>The move comes amid concerns from shareholders that Huawei is not complying with German rules for acquisitions.<p><p>In February, WAGNARS shareholders called for the court’s intervention to halt the talks, saying the company could have a negative impact on the Dutch economy.<p><p>Huawei has said it intends to continue the partnership with HWT.DE and that it will pursue legal action against the Dutch company, which was founded in 2000 and is India’s largest e-commerce firm.<p> ']

headline: Facebook says it will not go after users for data collection
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc said on Thursday it will not go after users in its news feed for data collection after a court ruled in its favor, saying it has no business discriminating against content creators who share private information.<p><p>The case stemmed from a Jan. 6 ruling that Facebook removed users’ personal information when it refused to delete a photo of a convicted child molester that had circulated online.<p><p>The justices also cited a 2011 Facebook News post that described a Facebook user as a “dangerous” and “dangerous” person who posts pornography on Facebook.<p><p>The Facebook case has rattled U.S. lawmakers and lawmakers, who in recent weeks have vowed to investigate Facebook’s use of data in the ads it publishes.<p><p>Critics have accused Facebook of using personal information to target a specific group of users for profit. The social media platform, which has raised more than $300 million in funding in the last year, said the ruling “does not represent a firm commitment to protecting the privacy rights of users or the security of their networks”.<p> ']

headline: MGM says $1 billion worth of new car plant in Australia: Chief executive
content: ['<p> - General Motors Co said on Tuesday it had completed its final preparations for a $1.6 billion $2 billion plant in Australia’s south-western state of Ballinaire, as it continues to shift to making cars with fewer emissions-reducing technologies.<p><p>GM Australia President Joe Rupp has pledged $1 billion for the project, with $1.6 billion coming from sources including a $2.8 billion new investment from China’s Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp (SCMC), $3.6 billion from Japan’s Toshiba Inc and $2.6 billion from U.S. private equity firm GAC Capital.<p><p>“The project will enable us to create a much-needed new gigafactory in our vast northern state and make new, high-performance vehicles that we could sell around the world,” Rupp said.<p><p>GM said that in Australia, production would be limited to five vehicles per year - one in Australia, one in South Australia, one in New South Wales, one in Perth and one in Perth-Tasman.<p><p>In the United States, the automaker has said it is working on a number of different vehicles, including the Model Y and the 2019 General Electric C7.<p><p>In Australia, General Motors Australia is currently testing a range of vehicles that have no emissions-reducing technologies and some of them have the potential to sell for tens of thousands of dollars.<p>']

headline: Facebook-owned TikTok targets 25,000 people in U.S. by May
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc has planned to have 250,000 people come into TikTok’s U.S. offices by May 30, Facebook said in a regulatory filing on Thursday.<p><p>The social media company said it will work with the local U.S. government, community groups, community health centers, education providers, health organizations and communities.<p> ']

headline: A spokesman for Apple said: “Apple is committed to making the transition to a self-driving car more cost effective, and we are proud of what Apple has done to help reduce those costs.”
content: ['<p><p>Apple said in December it would offer a $60 incentive to companies to build self-driving cars and start testing them within 30 days, a move that came after the self-driving car industry rallied to support the move.<p><p>Earlier this month, Tesla founder Elon Musk urged his followers to buy a self-driving car and help it build a self-driving vehicle.<p><p>While self-driving cars have been used to transport vast amounts of goods and services, the technology has never been used to accurately forecast which road closures might be an issue for the vehicles.<p><p>The company’s CEO, Steve Jobs, told Reuters last month that there is “no magic number” to how much a car can cost.<p><p>“The reality is the future will have fewer cars, and the only thing that can hurt the future is cars themselves.”<p><p>Automakers like Tesla have invested heavily to push self-driving technology in the United States, with a major plan this year to test a prototype of its self-driving car prototype at California’s Silicon Valley auto show.<p><p>But other automakers are investing heavily in self-driving technology for a range of uses.<p>']

headline: A new video game platform with more than 30 million users will launch on Saturday - sources
content: ['<p>SAN FRANCISCO  - A video games platform with more than 30 million users will launch on Saturday, a spokeswoman for Activision Blizzard said on Friday, with a date yet to be determined.<p><p>The new platform will be called the Blackberry Game, which will be developed by two Activision executives and the same team that developed the original PC version of Epic Games’ hit video games Legend of the Five Rings.<p><p>The team behind the new platform is headed by former Activision executive Brad Smith.<p> ']

headline: Facebook Inc says 'disgraceful' comment in comment to COVID-19 vaccinations after a Facebook employee shot dead a baby on a British island - Reuters
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Facebook Inc on Wednesday deleted an article by an individual who said a Facebook employee shot dead a baby on a British island, saying “disgraceful” remarks about the incident could not be seen.<p><p>In a blog post titled “What a Facebook employee’s death really means in practice,” Facebook said “we regret that this individual did not express regret regarding the circumstances of the fatal shooting,” and said the person had been banned from its platform for misconduct in the news site for nine months.<p><p>“Our apologies to Facebook employees for the “violent conduct of our employees’’ comments,” it said.<p><p>The statement was the first Facebook has removed since the social media company said last week it would send the video of the baby killed on a British island to a forensic anthropologist for forensic analysis.<p><p>A Facebook spokesman said the company did not have any comment as the investigation was ongoing.<p><p>“The Facebook news platform does not comment on personal privacy or legal matters,” he said. “The actions of the Facebook staff were wholly in accordance with our values and values,” Facebook said.<p> ']

headline: Nvidia's Nvidia shares slump as chip demand surges
content: ['<p> - Nvidia Corp shares fell as much as 2.5% in midday trading after the company said on Monday it expects a strong demand for its high-end graphics chips from semiconductor maker TSMC Corp.<p><p>Demand for high-end chips from Nvidia was expected to be strongest on Friday as more chips were expected to be used in its upcoming low-end notebooks, and the chipmaker said on Monday it expected an average revenue of $1.3 billion in the first quarter.<p><p>Nvidia said its next-quarter revenue forecast was for a profit of $2.5 billion, up from $1.8 billion a year earlier, but it did not disclose the percentage change in operating profit as Nvidia’s shares closed down 4.9% to $19.25.<p><p>Demand for chips from Nvidia’s chips is likely to increase this year, Nvidia analyst Jeffery Gittleson said. “That is likely to help offset a higher chip segment outlook this year,” Gittleson said.<p><p>Demand for high-end graphics chips from Nvidia was expected to be strongest on Friday as more chips were expected to be used in its upcoming low-end notebooks, and the company said on Monday it expected an average revenue of $1.3 billion in the first quarter.<p> ']

headline: Dishonored: Master Chief says Nintendo must step up competition
content: ['<p> - Master Chief Craig Federighi, the executive vice-president of video games and entertainment at Sony Corp, has urged Nintendo to shift away from selling videogames to become a rival to China’s video game giant.<p><p>“You can do that by putting up a competitor. That’s the only way to do it,” Federighi told Reuters, without naming the company.<p><p>“The problem is Nintendo will not be able to compete with China’s video game industry because they can’t compete with any other companies,” he said.<p><p>Federighi said Sony did not have a monopoly in the video games business, citing the company’s dominance in the PlayStation and PlayStation Plus games. Nintendo did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>In an interview with Reuters, Federighi said the video games industry had become a problem because of the growing demand for more power-sharing.<p><p>“If you focus on China, if you focus on gamers, then it becomes a problem for them. They don’t have enough power and can’t compete in gaming at the top of the market.”<p><p>Federighi said he believed Nintendo should take a more active role in addressing the pandemic because of China’s growth and to improve technology to counter U.S. threats.<p> ']

headline: Hangzhou's Zhaoxin plans to invest $10 million in China's electric vehicle sector
content: ['<p>HAWTHURST  - China’s Hangzhou Electric Automobile Holding Co Ltd plans to invest $10 million into electric vehicle sector, Zhaoxin said on Thursday, adding the Chinese company would also invest in electric vehicle startup Neely.<p><p>The announcement comes on the heels of a $200 million investment in electric vehicle startup Neely earlier this year, which led to its stock rising as much as 10% on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.<p><p>Zhaoxin said in October that it would focus its annual capital expenditure on electric vehicle investments to be at around $20 million.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Apple Inc shares fall as investors rush to buy, sell shares, and raise cash
content: ['<p> - Apple Inc shares fell as much as 0.8% on Tuesday after President Tim Cook said in a recent interview that the company’s stock market “is getting shorted.”<p><p>Shares of the tech giant hit a record low of $64.44 in late afternoon trading on Thursday.<p><p>On Monday, Cook told Reuters “I think the people who are looking for the company to buy, sell, and raise cash will go to the other end.”<p><p>Apple’s shares have fallen as much as 27% in the last year to the point where they are being shorted, Bloomberg News reported last month. The company has had to sell some of its shares due to a regulatory storm earlier this month, which forced it to halt production at its U.S. plants.<p> ']

headline: Nokia aims to launch 'high-definition' smartphone soon
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - Nokia plans to launch an affordable smartphone in the next few years, including a smartphone from China, it said on Monday, just two months after selling to a consortium of foreign players.<p><p>Nokia’s flagship smartphone, the Lumia 925, is expected to be unveiled in the second half of this year and could see a price jump of between 500 to 800 rupees ($11 to $14) as it features higher resolution screens, which will be better suited to users looking to watch movies or video content.<p><p>Nokia’s Nokia-made N9500 smartphone has a 5.5-inch, 5 GHz and 16 megapixel camera on a 3-megapixel camera, and has a pixel density of 1,400 pixels per inch (ppi).<p><p>Nokia’s flagship smartphone will be unveiled later this year.<p><p>The smartphone, which will have a 12.7-megapixel rear camera, will be priced at 879 rupees ($89).<p><p>Nokia’s plan to launch the phones in India is the first of its type of mobile brand in Asia, with plans to open the market to foreign firms as well as local players, Nokia said in a statement.<p><p>Nokia is the world’s second largest smartphone maker after LG, while rivals Xiaomi and Oppo are also part of the global smartphone portfolio.<p> ']

headline: Facebook says it will be able to block users from following news posts
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc is now able to block users who violate its policies on user behavior when they are prompted by content, a feature that could impact its annual revenue for the year to September 2019.<p><p>Facebook did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p> ']

headline: U.S. President Joe Biden urges tech firms to divest amid growing anti-trust concerns
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden urged tech firms on Monday to focus on how they use their platform and not be complacent about the impact on consumer and technology sectors they depend on, telling companies they should divest if they can.<p><p>“If you’re a company that uses a platform that has a lot of content, which some of those platforms don’t have, that’s a big problem,” Biden told reporters, adding, “I think every technology company should take a deep, deep, very hard look at what is really happening to their entire ecosystem.”<p><p>Biden, speaking on a visit to Japan, said tech companies needed to be transparent with consumer tech companies on how they use their platforms, but he said they must also be clear about whether they use technology that harms consumers.<p><p>“We have this fundamental misunderstanding of what it means to be a technology leader,” Biden said, referring to a lack of transparency on technology companies’ platforms. “It’s a major misconception.”<p><p>Biden’s remarks come as the White House is scrambling to respond to reports about a possible law requiring tech companies to disclose their work on platforms other than its own.<p><p>Biden said Silicon Valley should be more transparent in its approach to companies using platforms other than their own, but said it was also crucial for tech companies to use their platforms to share expertise and ideas.<p>']

headline: HELSINKI
content: ['<p> - Germany’s financial watchdog said on Tuesday it was investigating the possible impact of cryptocurrencies on German financial services.<p><p>The Financial Conduct Authority said it has received tips from customers of cryptocurrency companies operating in Germany and its staff had visited financial institutions in the past three months.<p><p>It also sent a letter to some banks and auditors advising of their policies on dealing in cryptocurrencies, it said.<p> ']

headline: VANCOUVER  - Vancouver-area real estate developer Claudio Bravo plans to expand its Vancouver offices and its two offices to 1,400 by 2028, according to a letter it gave to City of Vancouver officials on Wednesday.
Biden says he's focused on health issues
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - Democratic Senatorial candidate Todd Young said on Wednesday that he is focused on working with health officials to ensure Americans have access to a fair and timely medical treatment.<p><p>“I'm not a big proponent of punitive medicine,” Young said, noting that he has advocated for more treatment for people with chronic conditions including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).<p><p>Young was speaking at a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing on the health effects of COVID-19, which he helped form in part during the presidential election.<p><p>“I believe in providing quality care, and I believe that the system is not just one entity in this country,” Young said.<p><p>“The system is a bipartisan one in this country,” Young added, noting that he is seeking the support of 60 Senate Democrats.<p><p>On Thursday, Young told reporters he has talked to several officials on his radio show.<p> "]

headline: Southeast Asian tech giant Xiaomi vows $30 billion in annual financing by year's end
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - Chinese tech giant Xiaomi said on Monday it plans to invest at least $30 billion ($31.4 billion) in the United States, which is home to several of the world’s largest smartphone companies.<p><p>Xiaomi and China’s top three defense companies combined plan to invest $27 billion through 2025 in the United States, including $7 billion through 2019 and $6 billion through 2021, the Chinese news website Xinhua reported on Monday.<p><p>In a separate piece, Reuters reported that Xiaomi plans to invest at least $3 billion in Texas.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank shares plunge as 'buyer' yen sinks after SPAC funding round
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - SoftBank Group Corp’s shares fell on Thursday, as a stock rally forced chip maker “Buyers” to lower its outlook for chip supply.<p><p>The U.S. bank’s latest funding round raised about $1.3 billion, putting the company’s share price in the red. The price range of such rounds is usually around $200 to $300 per share, down from the range of around $275 to $350 per share that has been widely used by Silicon Valley start-ups.<p><p>“This is just one example of the opportunities we see around the world with SPACs,” SoftBank Chief Executive Masayoshi Son said on an earnings call, speaking at a conference in Tokyo on Wednesday.<p><p>Sudo Kato, a senior partner at Kato Capital Partners, said the SPAC funding round “seems very modest in some respects.”<p><p>SPACs are market makers that raise money through special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs). SPACs enable companies to raise funds through a merger or acquisition, thus making them attractive to institutional investors in a short term.<p><p>SPACs have helped spark asset purchases in the financial services industry, which has been hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.<p>']

headline: Viacom to host 'World Class' competition in Europe
content: ['<p>LONDON  - European telecoms company Viacom’s European competition platform World Class said on Tuesday it was hosting an online competition at its Lisbon office in the UK from next week.<p><p>The competition is designed to help companies in the areas of customer service, high-speed internet and internet access, Viacom said.<p><p>It will operate with a “user-facing” network, where consumers can control the behaviour of the companies they sign up for, as well as the products they purchase.<p><p>The competition will be open to all levels.<p> ']

headline: GOOGLE, GOOGL, OREGON SPACECO ON 'WARRING' OF THE COLLECTIBLE
content: ['<p>HONG KONG  - Alphabet Inc’s Google, Twitter Inc and Facebook Inc’s WhatsApp said on Thursday they will not use cookies in future to keep users in the privacy of their accounts, as a law aimed at protecting users against government intrusion on their privacy practices continues to tighten.<p><p>While privacy advocates and some tech companies have warned that companies have used cookies to break into the information of millions of users, some have called them a “killer app” that could lead to government surveillance.<p><p>“We’re aware of the privacy concerns that exist within Google, WhatsApp and Alphabet’s messaging service Alphabet Inc’s email messaging app, and we expect that in the near future, we will implement more privacy protections for consumers and their data,” Google said in a statement.<p><p>WhatsApp and Google’s other messenger services, such as Slack and Telegram Inc, offer different ways for consumers and organizations to use data collected from users.<p><p>Google and WhatsApp both use cookies. Google says it helps keep your browser open and allows for less user input during web browsing.<p><p>Messaging apps have said they do not block cookies, which means that users don’t have to spend too much time clicking through third-party cookies. Google’s WhatsApp app for iOS, which is still under testing, said it would require users to have their personal information turned over to a third-party provider.']

headline: Founded in 2009, the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) is the world’s largest law enforcement agency. It is used by over 50,000 U.S. and foreign countries. (Photo by KVID-19/Getty Images)  - The agency’s mission is to analyze, trace and investigate digital communications, the agency said on Wednesday. (Photo by DVID-19/Getty Images)  - U.S. officials have launched an investigation into the NSA’s activities since last year, officials said. (bit.ly/3U7i8q)
content: ['<p><p>This comes as President Joe Biden and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson are scheduled to hold a news conference in early December to discuss the possibility of an expanded U.S. response to the pandemic.<p><p>While President Biden has indicated he would appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the actions of the agency, such an appointment would not be an unprecedented action. (bit.ly/3U7i8q)<p><p>A spokesperson for Biden’s office declined to comment.<p> ']

headline: U.S. House of Representatives calls for funding of Amazon.com to boost technology
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The House of Representatives Committee on Energy, Commerce, Labor and Pensions said on Thursday it is asking Amazon.com Inc’s U.S. unit to provide funding to boost its technology.<p><p>The House Energy and Commerce Committee is planning a hearing on Amazon.com this week, according to a copy of the memo obtained by Reuters.<p><p>Amazon will need to raise $10 million through a combination of tax credits and special-purpose acquisition, or SPAC, sources said. The fund would be used to develop new technology that would allow Amazon to produce lower-margin paid paid video streaming.<p><p>Amazon is seeking $200 million for the special purpose acquisition, the committee said.<p> ']

headline: UK to introduce new law that could stifle digital speech
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain will introduce a new law that could stifle online speech or impose new restrictions on online activities to curb the spread of misinformation, a senior Justice Secretary said on Tuesday, after Britain set out its plan to change the law.<p><p>Under the proposed law, which has not yet been published, the government will have the right to make a complaint about any online activity and request an inquiry into it within 30 days.<p><p>In a written submission, the Home Office said it was committed to making sure that speech does not infringe the rights of others, such as individuals or businesses.<p><p>It said the government was committed to supporting free speech and its review of the law was ongoing and that “the courts and the public will be able to see clearly whether the government’s proposals are fit for purpose.”<p><p>“This means that when online speech is used to support an agenda, or encourages a particular policy, then it is clearly aimed at the individual and the public,” the Justice Department said in a statement.<p><p>“We hope that the proposals, which have not yet been published, will help to advance the government’s goal of removing internet censorship from its criminal code,” it added.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Supreme Court rules no firm has more than one copyright to use in U.S. copyright case
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Federal Trade Commission said Friday it had ruled that the National Association of Broadcasters and Universal Music Group can use an intellectual property lawsuit in a case filed by the streaming music company Spotify, with the outcome likely to spur more mergers and acquisitions.<p><p>The FTC’s decision on Friday could have a big impact on the larger copyright cases across the country, with states also coming under pressure to protect their own copyright-protected music.<p><p>Last month, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to hear a case involving Sony Pictures Television.<p><p>The case is U.S. v. Music Video Services Corp.<p><p>In December, the California court awarded Spotify $8 billion after a copyright infringement lawsuit by Sony.<p><p>The case will be decided in the Federal District of Columbia Circuit.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Capitol police investigate Capitol attack in photos
content: ['<p> - U.S. Capitol Police on Wednesday investigated a Jan. 6 assault that left four people dead and injured six others, two of them by someone they suspected of carrying out a suspected gunfight with Capitol police.<p><p>The Capitol police were called to a residence on Capitol Hill to investigate reports of a domestic dispute. They found a 22-year-old man inside the house, police said.<p><p>An acquaintance of the man was found stabbed and another was shot to death at his home, police said. The second victim was pronounced dead at the scene, police said.<p><p>Witnesses told police the two people were arguing over money, and a man carrying an AK-47 was seen <PAD>  officer walking toward the Capitol, police said. The officer was able to open fire, police said.<p><p>Witnesses said the man was wearing a red shirt and lighted jacket with a baseball cap, police said. They were not immediately available for comment.<p><p>The man was wearing a white T-shirt with a message reading "Loyalty is Peace" underneath it and he was carrying a box of medications, police said.<p><p>Witnesses said the man was wearing a T-shirt with the word "Killing Trump" underneath it and carrying a gun, police said.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Chinese tech giant Xiaomi, Xiaomi Music, Apple Pay to share money with cash crunch
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Xiaomi Music, Apple Pay and Google Pay will all be sharing billions of yuan ($8 billion) of assets in the next few years, China’s Financial Times reported on Wednesday, citing unnamed sources.<p><p>The move comes as investors scramble to buy back assets from rivals such as Tencent Corp, which bought a stake in Xiaomi in January.<p><p>The companies have come under increasing scrutiny after Apple last month removed Apple Pay from its App Store after Chinese authorities cited concerns about privacy and the risk of abuse.<p><p>Apple Pay, which is currently being introduced by its own unit in China, was suspended by the Chinese government in February after the company raised concerns.<p><p>Tencent did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Wednesday.<p> ']

headline: A Facebook spokesperson told me a meeting with Russian intelligence officials on Friday "does not constitute discussion" of the company’s Russian business with the U.S. government.
content: ['<p><p>We do not comment on meetings or discussions in the private sector, and we urge the government of Russia to respect the U.S. Government’s wishes and procedures in the management of Facebook.<p><p>A spokesperson for Facebook did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>As for the company’s relationship with the U.S. government, the spokesperson said, "the U.S. government does not comment on government or private conversations."<p><p>A spokesperson for Google declined to comment on the Facebook-Russia relations, referring questions to the Google+ and Facebook Group policy pages.<p><p>In response to questions about the company’s relationship with the U.S., Google said the two companies share a common goal: "To help our companies succeed and grow."<p><p>In June, Google sent employees to meet with Russian intelligence officials to discuss potential new initiatives to develop its search engine algorithms.<p> ']

headline: Vodafone calls on banks to speed up their digital payments rollout
content: ['<p>FRANKFURT  - Vodafone, the European payment services provider for shopping and sports fans, has ordered banks to speed up their digital payments rollout, following a recent crackdown by Dutch regulators and a new push by financial sector regulators to clamp down on illegal behaviour on the social media platform.<p><p>In a statement on Thursday, Vodafone said it had ordered a pilot programme of up to 4 million customers to track their payments across their digital wallets in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, Milan and Rome.<p><p>Vodafone said the pilot could extend into the whole of Europe, and included in the UK.<p><p>It said it was notifying customers in a separate post that it was banning some payment apps in its area.<p><p>“We are pleased to have been welcomed by the regulators of Amsterdam, as we have seen many of the more than 100 European banks including the largest, U.S. bank Morgan Stanley, and our customers take action to strengthen digital banking and help reduce the risk of fraud, as well as prevent a repeat of last year’s large scale data fraud attacks,” a Vodafone statement read.<p><p>The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) had issued a warning against the move.<p> ']

headline: In 2019, a California court ruled in favor of the U.S. Marshals Service in response to a lawsuit filed by an organization called Protect the Open Internet (PIPE). PIPE is a nonprofit group whose goal is to bring a new era of internet censorship to a community facing growing opposition from tech companies, activists and journalists. The lawsuit was filed by an alliance of organizations called Digital Media Alliance (DLNA) and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). The suit accused the Marshals Service of violating its civil rights, and the agency has filed several motions for writ of certiorari in support of its case. PIPE's legal team in California argued that the law requires it to use a subpoena to obtain documents from the Marshals Service. The Marshals Service declined to comment. The Los Angeles Times reported earlier on Monday that the court could take a closer look at the Marshals Service’s arguments, saying that, even if they fail to comply with the subpoenas, the agency is not required to go after the companies they violate. PIPE’s attorneys said that if they do, the agency should be required to seek them through a judicial process. “The court is not looking at ‘any subpoena”. “It’s just a court proceeding in a way that violates the law and doesn’t give any opportunity for a meaningful discussion about the law or the role it plays in protecting freedom of expression on the internet.” The suit said the Marshals Service should be required to go after the companies rather than individual users. PIPE did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment on its claims. PIPE had earlier filed lawsuits in California and New York seeking to have Google removed from the Google Play store following the publication of the story. PIPE, which also has a California headquarters, filed the lawsuit in 2019. “The government is saying that a search warrant should
A former top British police officer said on Monday he was stunned by an inquiry into whether Facebook and Alphabet Inc’s Google should pay news organisations for news content.
content: ['<p><p>The former London Assembly member said on Monday that Google had been using its platforms to "rig the algorithms of the news media".<p><p>“I thought the only news organisation that didn’t deserve this massive amount of money was the Times,” he told Sky News.<p><p>“It should be fair to Google, but I think that if that’s fair then there’s a better solution” for them to pay newspapers for news content.<p><p>The “news media bias” came amid concerns the social media giants “have been exploiting a huge market for their advertising dollars” and have been colluding to block news content.<p><p>“In my view it should be fair to Google and Facebook, but that’s why they should pay them a fair amount,” said Peter Wanter, head of communications at British Columbia-based news publisher Public News Media.<p><p>Facebook in December fined a news publisher over its bias in deciding whether to feature its trending news feed in the news feed, after the news publisher published a story about a man being shot in his street.<p><p>Reuters reported last month that Facebook had asked Google in February to remove links to a Chinese news site from its news feed.<p> ']

headline: The U.S. company that produced an Apple watch faces a subpoena for Apple Pay, Amazon, PayPal and other payment services
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Apple’s payments services have been put on lockdown during the global financial crisis, with a judge saying Apple will likely be forced to pay customers for purchases using its app.<p><p>Lawyers for a group of Apple and PayPal co-founders have questioned the company about the legality of some of their services, saying the payments giants have been using the apps as a way to pay for items they sell on their sites.<p><p>A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday ruled that Apple will be forced to pay customers for purchases using the company’s app to access their payment information.<p><p>PayPal declined to comment, while Apple has said it will cooperate fully with the investigation.<p><p>Amazon declined comment.<p><p>Facebook Inc’s payment processor, Stripe, was forced to suspend its payment services after the financial crisis, but said the company had complied with orders and no issues related to its platform.<p><p>Apple’s products include its Watch and Watch Pay, among others, it said in a statement late on Wednesday, adding its iPhones are "in compliance with all applicable laws."<p> ']

headline: U.S. Justice Department to launch antitrust lawsuit against Apple
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Justice Department antitrust investigators will soon launch a legal challenge against Apple Inc over alleged anticompetitive practices, the department’s legal arm said on Friday, in a sign of growing pressure on the tech giant to rein in its iPhone sales.<p><p>The Justice Department’s antitrust office will also seek a subpoena to Apple for documents related to a probe into its Safari browser, the Justice Department said in a statement.<p><p>Apple has pushed back in the past on claims that the company misused its App Store, a feature it says helps its users find books and movies. It has denied the allegations and said it is committed to protecting users’ privacy and offering paid support.<p><p>The Justice Department’s antitrust division is led by Steven Pipes, a former Justice Department official now in his 70s.<p><p>He previously served as chief antitrust officer at the department’s Justice Department in 2010.<p> ']

headline: The world's fastest-growing tech startup to join London IPO
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Global growth accelerates as new technology helps companies to scale up, while old industries are forced to look elsewhere, according to a new report.<p><p>In the world of cloud computing, firms such as Salesforce.com Inc are looking to shift to the cloud-based side as they work with customers on their product updates, while startups such as Tesla Inc and Facebook Inc are also looking at moving to a cloud-based front.<p><p>The report by market intelligence company Koss showed that over the last decade, over 90% of businesses around the world were moving from the traditional business to cloud.<p><p>This is the first time that Koss tracks these trends in data, while companies such as Salesforce.com and Salesforce.Com Ltd continue to focus on developing their own cloud-based software, according to the report.<p><p>The report further showed that over 60% of companies in the globe are looking at a cloud-based product update in the next five years.<p> ']

headline: JPMorgan to sell $15 billion worth of shares to Chinese firm China Global Markets
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - JPMorgan will sell 20.9 billion yuan ($12.8 billion) worth of shares to Chinese giant China Global Markets and China National Investment Corp, the Chinese investment bank said in a regulatory filing on Thursday, adding it would continue to monitor the exchange rate of the shares.<p><p>The initial public offering (IPO) of the shares will take place at a price of 4.62% of the initial public offering price of 4.62% at 0830 GMT on June 24, JPMorgan said in the statement, without naming the funds.<p><p>JPMorgan last month listed 12.7 billion yuan for $19 billion in an IPO in its Hangzhou-based Chinese e-commerce site ChinaBanking.<p><p>China’s top banking regulator has said it plans to set a minimum capital expenditure of $6 billion by 2024 to expand the supply chain and curb the use of artificial intelligence to boost growth.<p><p>It has long been pushing for an IPO in U.S.-listed securities.<p><p>JPMorgan on Thursday said it will continue to monitor exchange rates for the share sale.<p> ']

headline: Alphabet Inc to invest $170 million in U.S. business
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - Alphabet Inc’s Google will invest more than $170 million in U.S. business, the company said in a regulatory filing on Thursday, adding that the amount is expected to rise in line with Alphabet’s planned acquisition of Twitter Inc in a deal that would value the search giant at about $37 billion.<p><p>Google will use the proceeds from the sale to accelerate its plans to build a cloud infrastructure and develop software in collaboration with its search engine giant.<p> ']

headline: Venezuela to send more ships to the United States from January, Reuters reported
content: ['<p>Venezuela’s shipbuilding company Hugo Chavista said on Tuesday that it will ship 100% of its ships from its new shipyards to the United States starting Jan. 22, as it pushes to become a global standard in the export of high-value ships.<p><p>The ships will have a complement of about 900, including 120 ships from the shipyards of New York City, California, Hong Kong, and Los Angeles, Chavista said. The shipyards will provide a range of ships from light cargo to heavy cargo with the latest models of cargo and processing equipment.<p><p>CLICK HERE TO READ MORE ON FOX BUSINESS<p><p>The shipbuilding company will also include six ships from the port of Port Isabel in the United States and another from Cuba.<p><p>Venezuela has long been pushing to make its own “superior” shipbuilding technology, where workers from dozens of companies build advanced computer systems to make advanced parts of heavy vehicles, or SCVs.<p><p>A major obstacle in Venezuela is the poor economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, which has caused shortages in some goods, including fuel, raw materials, and machinery.<p><p>Venezuela said last week it would invest $1.4 billion to create a “superior shipbuilding center” in the country, which would include a second shipyard to create the next generation of SCVs.<p>']

headline: White House adviser Jake Sullivan dismisses report of Trump tweets about COVID-19:'sources
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The White <PAD>  declined to comment on Jake Sullivan’s tweet about COVID-19.<p><p>A White House official said that the administration is not aware of any reports that senior White House officials were preparing to take steps to remove vaccines.<p><p>“We are not aware of any reports that the Trump administration is preparing to remove vaccines or that senior administration officials are preparing to take steps to remove those vaccines from their healthcare systems,” the official said.<p><p>Sullivan, who is scheduled to appear in court on Thursday, tweeted about Trump’s new plan to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate possible ties between the Russian government and the Trump campaign.<p><p>The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>The Associated Press reported on Monday that White House officials plan to release a statement by Saturday to the media on whether their administration had been forthcoming with updates regarding COVID-19 vaccination schedules.<p> ']

headline: U.S. lawmakers hold meeting on cybersecurity bill
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - House members on Thursday introduced a bill to update U.S. security regulators, urging them to take measures to ensure a fair, transparent and fair process for all companies.<p><p>House Oversight and Government Reform Chairman Jason Chaffetz, R-UT, said the proposed cybersecurity bill “must be one that protects the public and businesses from cyber attack by protecting critical infrastructure, including the communications of our customers and the private sector, and by allowing companies to invest in cybersecurity capabilities.”<p><p>Lawmakers also called for legislation to “enhance “information infrastructure” and “information technology transfer networks, including access to critical infrastructure to assist in an exchange of ideas or information, and to “enable private and public organizations to collaborate with the private sector to ensure cybersecurity protection.”<p><p>The bill will also require the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to provide a copy of a proposed rule issued by the agency to Congress in March for a cybersecurity review and recommendations for improving its oversight process.<p><p>Congressional officials have said companies must maintain security systems and comply with new cybersecurity rules to protect themselves and others.<p><p>“Our current system of reporting security risks is outdated, and we should continue to do more to protect the public from cyber threats,” Chaffetz said in a letter to the White House.<p> ']

headline: Ekaterina to raise $1 billion in China IPO
content: ['<p> - EKaterina, the online video-streaming firm founded in 2018, will raise $1 billion in China’s biggest IPO to date, Chinese media reported on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter.<p><p>Ekaterina, which offers a range of videos including documentaries and dramas including popular hit reality show "Wanted: Stories About Legend", said on Thursday it would use the proceeds to improve its digital presence and make online streaming more inclusive in China, where more than 2 billion people work.<p><p>Ekaterina is seeking to capitalize on the growing clout of the video-streaming sector as it pursues a plan to take over 100% of Chinese smartphone market share.<p><p>In January, Alibaba Group Holding Ltd raised $300 million from SoftBank Group Corp to buy stake in Ekaterina in a deal that valued the stock at $6 billion.<p><p>($1 = 10.8290 yuan renminbi)<p> ']

headline: Nokia to unveil 4G coverage next year
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Nokia plans to unveil a 5G-enabled smartphone this year, and will unveil a new camera chip, its chief executive said on Tuesday.<p><p>The firm is also planning to unveil new cameras - the N10 and N7 respectively - and will also unveil a 5G mobile app to developers.<p><p>“We are proud of Nokia’s growth in the world, as well as in the industry,” Nokia executive Thomas Oates said on a conference call with reporters.<p><p>“However, the rollout is likely to take many more months, and it will depend on the company’s own future strategy and our future plans.”<p> ']

headline: Waze to sell $1.3 billion stake in Texas chip maker Coherent Holdings, valued at $4.6 billion
content: ['<p> - Waze Corp said on Thursday it will sell its share of Coherent Holdings Corp in Texas for between $1.3 billion and $2 billion, bringing the total stake in the Texas chip maker to about $45 billion, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.<p><p>The sale is one of three in Texas related to Coherent Holdings, one of which is backed by SoftBank Group Corp.<p><p>Coherent, a semiconductor technology firm built by Intel Corp, shipped 3.5 million units of chips to the United States in 2017. The chipmaker was one of the largest sellers of chips on Wall Street during the COVID-19 pandemic, and was the fourth-largest buyer of chip units from an outside entity, according to a Reuters analysis of CCS data.<p><p>Waze, which also owns two gaming companies, the Texas GameStop Corp and Target Corp, said the sale would be among the most significant for the company.<p><p>The deal is among the largest deals of Coherent Holdings in the United States, the company said.<p> ']

headline: UK eyes more than half of its digital banking staff by 2021
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain is approaching its peak in digital banking staff, the country’s banking regulator said on Wednesday, as it looks to boost the cash flow generated by financial services firms in the UK.<p><p>The Digital Banker Jobseeker Grant (DJP), which grants a minimum wage and benefits, has been in the news before. It last year came under fire from regulators after it failed to take into account the digital payments sector’s growing importance to the country’s economy.<p><p>“There is a shortage of digital banking. And we are seeing more and more DJP applicants than ever before,” said a senior banking regulator official.<p><p>Last year, London-based banks said they were seeing 2.7 million applications per week, up from just over 300,000 a year ago.<p><p>Online banking operator Jobseeker Grant was the only other major banking group to apply for a digital-based grant, but last month it said it would consider an online grant in the next few months.<p><p>The DJP said it was also working with online platforms to make digital payments more sustainable, particularly at lower cost and with fewer intermediaries.<p><p>The data on financial services in Britain showed a global shortage of financial services staff in 2021, with around 4% of total financial services staff working from home.<p><p>($1 = 0.8251 pounds)<p> ']

headline: U.S. government's top lawyer on tech bill to address tech privacy
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Justice Department will unveil its top prosecutor on Thursday on the issue of online platforms “malicious actors”, a senior administration official said on Wednesday.<p><p>The Department of Justice will also unveil its own expert on how technology platforms and governments can improve the security and privacy of their users.<p><p>A spokeswoman for the White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the Justice Department’s announcement.<p><p>Digital platforms, such as Twitter Inc’s popular app, WhatsApp and Facebook Inc’s popular messaging service FaceTime Inc, are among the most active online platforms and have grown over the past year to become increasingly popular in the United States for political expression.<p><p>The Justice Department’s list of malicious actors could include those that abuse online platforms’ data and tactics to harass or harm Americans, it said.<p><p>Other potential malignancies include malicious actors exploiting vulnerabilities in cloud-based systems or hacking groups to compromise personal computers, the official said.<p><p>“You can find that list in the Justice Department’s toolbox,” he said. “But this is a national security issue. We want to focus on how we can ensure the security of online platforms and prevent any violations of our terms of service.”<p>']

headline: Rome, Austria's Economy Minister says'very high' taxes on tech start-ups
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - Economy Minister Margrethe Vestager said on Wednesday Austria would not impose any new taxes on companies that do not use a “social media platform” to raise funds for startups.<p><p>Vestager said it was important to have a strong internet economy, but also stressed that it was an investment economy, not a tax-evader, and that every entity had to be able to raise money independently.<p><p>“We will not introduce any taxes on firms which do not use a social media platform to raise funds for startups,” Vestager said. “As long as we are able to provide some certainty that their products will be available and start-ups will attract customers we will take the initiative.”<p><p>Vestager said the EU should open up more areas of cooperation to foreign tech start-ups, and encourage them to invest in the field, such as in the area of information technology.<p><p>“We must build on our success in attracting high-quality venture capital and investment,” she said. “We must continue to make our competitiveness a priority.”<p><p>The economy minister also raised concerns about a potential increase in the number of mobile operators under her watch, with Austria on track to meet the EU’s goal of 30% of global smartphone revenues by 2023.<p>']

headline: Visa to invest $500 million in mobile payment business
content: ['<p> - Visa Inc is stepping up its mobile payments business, expanding into the payment industry and making its own payments at its American Airlines facility in San Francisco, the company said on Tuesday.<p><p>“The Visa Visa Mobile Payments Service has been one of the fastest growing mobile payments services in the United States,” said David Shuler, vice president of digital products at Visa.<p><p>“We look forward to partnering with the U.S. Visa Mobile Payments team as they develop their technology and enhance their services for mobile payments in the coming years,” he said.<p><p>Shuler said Visa would expand its partnership with American Airlines in the coming months, adding that its partnership with the airline will be “intensive” and not dependent on Visa’s customer experience.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank invests in Tesla as chief says it could offer “superchargers”
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - SoftBank Corp is investing in Tesla Inc, the world’s biggest car maker, as it prepares for a global electric rush that could help spur other automakers to take on the electric car industry.<p><p>Tesla will produce about 5,000 cars a year by 2025, its Chief Executive Elon Musk said in a Tesla forum on Friday.<p><p>“The world needs to be getting smart, and it’s Tesla, so I think it makes sense to take Tesla up on that offer and expand,” Musk told Tesla’s annual shareholder meeting.<p><p>Musk also said he was “not in any rush,” adding, “We have just delivered 5,000 cars in the last month or so, so I think it could be a very big jump in production.”<p><p>Musk said Musk’s “spacecraft” electric vehicle could be fully operational by 2023, but that would require a huge investment by Tesla and others.<p><p>Musk declined to provide an exact date, saying he would have to assess Tesla’s impact in the coming months.<p> ']

headline: Nvidia releases new version of its graphics card for Nvidia G-SYNC - sources
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - South Korea’s semiconductor maker announced on Thursday it is reworking its graphics chip design to enable it to run ultra-high-definition (UHD) video games with Nvidia’s G-SYNC solution, two sources told Reuters.<p><p>A UHD game could require up to 256 gigabytes of memory and a 256-bit memory interface as well as an Nvidia-developed driver for gaming graphics, and Nvidia itself has a long history of introducing high-definition video games into its graphics chips, including the popular Fortnite, which launched last year.<p><p>Nvidia is pushing its G-SYNC technology to enable a range of games, some of which use its popular graphics processing units (GPUs) but some use its own. It is developing a version of its Nvidia graphics chip for other games, but it said on Thursday it will not ship its UHD version for Nvidia G-SYNC products as it plans to introduce new features at a later date.<p><p>Last year, it debuted a graphics solution for its upcoming game “Assassin” that features a graphics processor that it said uses Nvidia technology but with “an extremely heavy duty” battery.<p><p>It is currently developing a solution to Nvidia’s “G-SYNC” system that uses a different architecture for graphics, but the technology is different for a variety of different games.<p>']

headline: In January 2019, Tesla said it had entered talks with U.S. regulators to raise its capital, following a regulatory filing late last year. Tesla’s share price dropped more than 3% on Thursday, sending shares down 14%. Since then, Tesla has made steady gains. But Tesla’s share price has dropped 11.3% so far this year. The company, which also publishes the popular Tesla blog, has been down 15.3% in the last month. In January, Tesla said it would enter talks with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for $750 million over three years to float its stock, and could raise the capital as early as 2021. That funding, at the current exchange rate, could be more than $500 million. Tesla shares could also be listed on the Nasdaq if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation raises the capital as a result of that offering. Reuters reported earlier this month that Tesla had agreed to a proposed sale in which it would merge with a blank-check firm. Tesla is not a traditional investment firm. Reuters reported that Tesla has already said it would invest $500 million in a blank-check firm. Reuters reported last year that Tesla had agreed to merge with a blank-check firm, and has said it is in talks to do so. Bloomberg reported this month that Tesla and the California-based blank-check company GSK Corp had agreed to merge in January. Reuters reported last year that Tesla had agreed to merge with GSK Corp in January. Reuters reported last year that Tesla had agreed to merge with GSK Corp in January. Reuters reported last year that Tesla and GSK Corp had agreed to merge in January. The filing on Tesla’s shares contained more than 19 pages of text. Tesla has been embroiled in a legal battle with the Justice Department over its practice of requiring that its stock be converted into cash. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is in the process of deciding whether to impose additional scrutiny on the Tesla d
JPMorgan, Tesla to take over Uber and Lyft after Trump orders shakeup
content: ['<p> - JPMorgan Chase & Co will take over Uber and Lyft Inc’s ride-hailing business after President Donald J. Trump said in a tweet that he will ban both platforms.<p><p>The Trump administration is taking steps to help ride-hailing companies comply with regulations that require businesses to hire contractors to build and operate transportation systems.<p><p>JPMorgan said it would take the Uber and Lyft deal, which could close in the second quarter, as well as its existing business, LyftX’s LyftX, which had a $750 million Series D funding round in October, as well as a broader Series D round in 2020.<p><p>JPMorgan’s move comes after the White House issued guidance in January that barred the transportation tech giants from receiving federal funding for ride-hailing services.<p><p>In December, the Trump administration ordered the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) to set up a special agency to investigate and penalize companies for “drunken vehicles”, a reference to those that fail to comply with city regulations.<p><p>Uber has said it expects to receive the first round of funding in the second quarter, while LyftX is expected to receive two.<p> ']

headline: U.S. bank raises funds to buy back shares in Tesla in line with new deal
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - JPMorgan Chase & Co has agreed to buy back shares in Tesla Inc’s stock on a stock exchange backed by the $30 billion investment from U.S. bank Morgan Stanley, the bank’s senior vice president of finance said on Tuesday.<p><p>The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of 2019, is a return to JPMorgan from a recent fundraising drive. JPMorgan invested $30 billion in Tesla, and its shares traded last month at $58.90 apiece.<p><p>The new funding comes as Tesla is trying to break ground in its Model 3 electric sedan, its third in less than a year.<p><p>Morgan Stanley, which was one of the first banks to lend money to Tesla, said last month it expects the company’s shares will float between $40 and $58 each.<p> ']

headline: China's Weibo suspended after anti-China propaganda videos show video of Chinese President Xi Jinping
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese social media giant Weibo, which has more than 2.8 million users, said on Wednesday it had suspended a video clip of President Xi Jinping with anti-China propaganda content after an anti-Beijing group posted video showing him holding a ball, with the caption: "I call for China’s strength in defence against those who would try to bully China by instigating the rise of Chinese democracy. <p><p>The video posted on Weibo on Thursday appeared to be taken from video that China says shows its leader standing in line with Chinese military leaders.<p><p>Beijing, in response, accused Weibo of violating a number of Chinese laws on the issue by posting anti-Beijing posts.<p><p>“(This video, taken at the same time as) an official delegation holding a ball was uploaded on Weibo by an anti-China group in which it is said that we are demonstrating our strength in defence against those who would try to bully China by instigating the rise of Chinese democracy,” China’s state-run Xinhua news agency said on Saturday.<p><p>Beijing has also alleged that Weibo was using the Chinese People’s Liberation Army’s YouTube channel, as part of a larger campaign against pro-Beijing China websites in China.<p> ']

headline: Cisco CFO says CFO 'disgusted and embarrassed' by U.S. sanctions over hacking
content: ['<p> - Cisco Systems Chief Financial Officer Steve Jurvetson said on Tuesday he was shocked by U.S. sanctions imposed on Russian cyber attack activity in 2016, which the cybersecurity firm blamed on Russia.<p><p>“We’re not shocked at all.” Jurvetson said on his Twitter feed.<p><p>In his most public remarks yet in a public appearance since the United States imposed sanctions last month, he called on Moscow to restore full diplomatic relations.<p> ']

headline: Renesas says new electric car sales expected to hit $2.1 trillion by 2025
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - Renesas’s electric car sales in 2025 will be estimated at $2.1 trillion by 2025, the Seoul-based company said on Wednesday, as the battery business intensifies.<p><p>Renesas’ new electric sedan will include a range of electric and hybrid models, it said, which can be powered by electric or hybrid batteries. It will be powered by four-cylinder gasoline-electric engines which can generate around 3,000 horsepower at peak engine rpm.<p><p>Renesas said its cars will be equipped with a range of sensors, including the Autopilot system, that will assist with the design and delivery of the car’s electric features.<p><p>“We’re confident that this model will go ahead in the global EV market by 2025,” the company said.<p><p>($1 = 8.0900 won)<p> ']

headline: Venezuela's Hugo Chávez faces arrest in probe into alleged abuses at state-owned TV channel: report
content: ['<p>Venezuela’s main-stream media has been embroiled in a scandal in which state media in recent months had allowed some state-owned channels to broadcast illegally and in violation of Venezuelan law, but there have been few signs of the scale of the scandal that has rattled Latin America’s powerful news industry.<p><p>The allegations of abuses, outlined in a report by the Inter-American Commission on American-Cuba Relations (IACOR), could lead to the arrest of two Venezuelan journalists and one American.<p><p>Chávez, a former governor, was arrested on charges of inciting a riot, and was held in house arrest for more than two months in January after a prosecutor alleged in a report in December that some of his outlets had been covering a coup attempt by the military.<p><p>Chavista, the main opposition leader, has said he is innocent and his supporters accuse the authorities of trying to suppress their opposition and that he is in the military.<p><p>Venezuela’s state-run media have said they will investigate any violations of Venezuela’s law, but few have stepped forward, saying they have not found evidence to support them.<p><p>Chavista’s office in the country’s capital said it was “monitoring daily news and reporting “on everything from Venezuelan events to the status of the Venezuelan military,” adding that he was in good health.<p>']

headline: The company behind Uber's ride-hailing service, UberX, says its technology is safe
content: ['<p>SAN FRANCISCO  - Uber Technologies Inc shares were down 1% after the social network’s shares were suspended on Wednesday, making it the first technology company to go public in less than a year.<p><p>UberX, a service that allows users to share information online and offline, has gained steam in recent months as it seeks to become the preferred way to connect with friends and family. The San Francisco-based company says its software makes it possible for drivers to find and accept rides without paying.<p><p>“This is great for Uber’s growth because it’s very affordable for us,” said Jason Lewis, co-founder and chief operating officer of ride-hailing platform UberX.<p><p>“The problem is we don’t have as many of these platforms in the wild. We have to go with a company that provides services that are affordable and open source.”<p><p>It’s been hard to come to an agreement with drivers because the platforms are in the dark, and drivers often don’t even know what to expect from Uber, Lewis said.<p><p>The ride-hailing platform is still in its early days and some customers may want to stick with one of the platforms.<p><p>The app’s launch could provide an immediate boost to its market share, although it remains a bit early to say if this will lead to more partnerships.']

headline: SoftBank-backed U.S. firm buys $6.5 billion stake in Bitcoin mining company Bitpay
content: ['<p> - SoftBank-backed U.S. cybersecurity firm Bitpay Inc said on Tuesday it will buy 10.7% of cryptocurrency firm BitPay in a deal worth an additional $4.5 billion, following a $600 million investment by SoftBank’s Binance Group and investors in the cryptocurrency firm’s initial public offering (IPO).<p><p>“The transaction will enable us to continue to focus on our business including our digital wallet services, enabling our customers to keep in touch with their wallets and receive rewards and promotions for spending digital currency,” BitPay Chief Financial Officer John Bell told a news conference, adding that the transaction will result in a “significantly reduced impact on the company’s financial results”.<p> ']

headline: IoT-based mobile devices maker Apple Inc shares tumbled to their lowest level since December due to pressure from regulators, after a surge in demand for its products and rival Apple Inc. Reuters/iStock/Jeff Chang
content: ['<p>Apple Inc shares tumbled to their lowest level since December due to pressure from regulators, after a surge in demand for its products and rival Apple Inc.<p><p>Earlier this month, Apple’s shares plunged nearly 7% after the company’s shares were down about 1% in extended trading.<p><p>Earlier this month, Apple’s shares lost about 7% after the company’s shares were down about 1% in extended trading.<p> ']

headline: Nokia's chief says that 5G coverage will get better: analyst
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Nokia said on Wednesday it is getting better at covering 5G coverage in its devices and is aiming for a future in which users can take advantage of the company’s advanced 5G technology, as customers begin to take advantage of the company’s new 5G connectivity.<p><p>“We are getting better at covering 5G in our devices. We are going to do better in the future,” the Finnish telecom giant said in a statement, without giving any specifics.<p><p>The company’s data centers and networks are growing faster than ever and customers have begun to adopt newer and more advanced mobile internet technology, it added.<p> ']

headline: UK banks may get hit by Brexit: PM
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s banking industry may face severe financial sanctions over Brexit, Prime Minister Boris Johnson told ITV on Tuesday, as a shock move left the country’s biggest banks exposed to a potentially deadly contagion.<p><p>Britain faces a potentially catastrophic impact on its economy if it leaves the European Union and attempts to exit the bloc can fail, he said.<p><p>“If we’re going to be secure, our institutions are going to get hit,” Johnson told ITV. “If we were going to be secure we wouldn’t be able to take advantage of any of the measures that would make this possible.”<p><p>Johnson has called for a review of Britain’s financial system.<p><p>“It is a big unknown right now,” he said. “The financial system is fragile. And if we cannot address that and deal with the financial risks on top of it, that’s going to take us through a very tough time.”<p><p>“It’s time we did a comprehensive review of the financial system,” he added, adding that he was hopeful the Bank of England would have a “quick look” at the country’s financial situation in 2019.<p><p>The Bank of England has warned of the risks of leaving the bloc, saying a “short squeeze” could happen.<p>']

headline: T-Mobile raises $3.7 billion in cash, sources told Reuters
content: ['<p> - SoftBank-backed T-Mobile Inc said on Wednesday it expects $3.7 billion in cash from the sale of shares to acquire new shareholders in the wireless company.<p><p>Shares of the company, the world’s No. 2 cellphone maker behind Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, have gained about 50% year-to-date, from a year earlier, while they have soared more than 10% this year, the sources said.<p><p>The new shareholders include SoftBank-backed SoftBank’s former chief executive officer John Legere, who is stepping down as chairman as T-Mobile prepares to divest its assets.<p><p>The company declined to comment.<p><p>The deal was the latest step for the wireless maker as it looks to expand to lower its wireless footprint, aiming to attract customers with better data speeds and lower costs.<p><p>T-Mobile Chief Executive Officer Melvin Elwin called the transaction “a tremendous victory for the wireless industry”, adding that the acquisition represented a new chapter in the company’s mission to help customers connect with one another.<p> ']

headline: Nokia, Vivo buy Nokia-owned stake for around 4.5 billion euros
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Nokia Inc said on Tuesday it had purchased the U.S. mobile operator Nokia Vivo SA for a total of 4.5 billion euros ($5.57 billion).<p><p>Nokia said Vivo “plays an essential role in the strategic development of Nokia Mobility in the United States and offers exceptional customer service. Nokia’s strong financial performance and outstanding core value for the strategic development have enabled Vivo to become a leader in Europe, Asia, Africa and the United States.”<p><p>Nokia shares rose 1.9% to 14.923 euros after the news.<p><p>“Nokia is an important partner for Nokia in the semiconductor and other devices industries, both in the United States and internationally, and will continue to strengthen this alliance.”<p><p>“As the global leader in the semiconductor industry, Nokia has become a key player in the semiconductor market, which makes up 4.6% of the global smartphone market.”<p><p>“We are pleased that we have acquired Nokia-owned stake, and look forward to working closely with them on strategic initiatives,” said Nokia Chief Executive Officer Olaf Bähmer.<p><p>Nokia Vivo was last valued at 1.5 billion euros ($2.83 billion).<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Apple's Siri faces competition from Amazon and Microsoft over sales of products
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Apple Inc has become embroiled in a fierce battle over the sale of products - including its mobile-phone software - that have traditionally been the subject of a separate lawsuit by Amazon.com Inc.<p><p>Both companies said in a joint statement on Wednesday that they have worked closely with Amazon on the case.<p><p>Both companies have been sued by the tech giant over alleged software infringements by Apple. Apple in February filed a class action lawsuit accusing Amazon, Microsoft and Facebook Inc of copying Apple’s software offerings.<p><p>Both companies have been locked in a legal battle since last year over what Apple calls a “malicious “pattern of misconduct” by Apple.<p><p>Earlier this month, a federal judge in California said Apple, Microsoft and Alphabet Inc’s Google’s Play Store infringed on two of Apple’s popular apps.<p><p>Amazon said last week it was seeking to block apps that are linked to a particular product group. Apple said earlier this month it will block the Amazon Prime app.<p> ']

headline: China's Alibaba mulls setting up a joint venture with Kuaishou Holdings
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese food delivery company Alibaba Group Holding Corp is considering a joint venture with Kuaishou Holdings, the biggest holding company in the country, its chief executive officer said on Monday, as Beijing seeks to counter growing competition and pressure from a host of Chinese companies that are trying to cut their share prices.<p><p>Backed by the world’s biggest digital payments firm and backed by Alibaba’s biggest investor, Kuaishou is also one of the world’s most widely used ride-hailing apps, a major draw for business travellers and a key driver for the growth of Chinese food delivery services.<p><p>“The opportunity is that Kuaishou will be a leading voice for the supply chain of Kuaishou,” Hu Hao, Alibaba’s head of global sales and marketing, said at an industry event.<p><p>Backed by the world’s biggest digital payments firm and backed by Alibaba, Kuaishou was started in 2018 in Shanghai by three former Kuaishou employees who worked at Kuaishou, Hu and Alibaba in China.<p><p>($1 = 0.8470 Chinese yuan renminbi)<p> ']

headline: Biden says it has not been 'fully consulted' on tax overhaul and it is 'possessing zero' information'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden’s executive action on Tuesday to provide more certainty about the tax bill’s impact on small businesses has been “possessed zero” on the senator, a spokesman for the former vice president told Reuters.<p><p>The action is likely to leave little doubt as to the details of the bill’s impact on small businesses, which is being scrutinized by Congress after several Republican lawmakers called for more scrutiny of the plan.<p><p>In a letter to Congress, Biden said the legislation provides little certainty and that it’s “possessed zero” on the Senate tax code.<p><p>“This is a very serious and unprecedented intrusion on small businesses,” Biden wrote.<p><p>Biden’s office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p> ']

headline: Aircraft manufacturer SFR to become first EU aircraft manufacturer to join Russia sanctions blacklist
content: ['<p>FRANKFURT  - SFR has been granted a blank check by Moscow to join Russia’s sanctions blacklist as the country seeks to boost its military capabilities after Ukraine threatened retaliation for what it says was its air campaign in the east of the country.<p><p>“As well as having the capacity to make aircraft, SFR will have the capability to equip all its commercial aircraft, with capabilities from aircraft to cruise missiles and surveillance capabilities as well as support for manned and unmanned aerial vehicles,” the SFR group said in a statement released on Thursday.<p><p>The Russian-backed aircraft manufacturer said it was also a founding member of the blacklist but it was looking at other membership options.<p><p>Russia accuses Ukraine of failing to protect the rights of Russian-speakers, a charge Russia denies. Ukraine denies any role in the incursion.<p><p>SFR said in its statement it would continue to contribute to the country’s defense industry, develop air defense systems and enhance its capabilities in the region.<p><p>Russia is considering including the bloc in sanctions relief at a time when it is tightening economic ties with Russia after the ouster of President Vladimir Putin.<p><p>In July 2019, it slapped sanctions on Ukraine for violating the bloc’s sovereignty and territory by using cluster bomb production sites, the biggest such action by a Russian jet carrier.<p>']

headline: Etherton shares fall to $11.50 on the New York Stock Exchange after a drop in trading
content: ['<p> - Etherton shares fell on Friday after a negative stock market debut and rallied 5.8% to $11.50.<p><p>The company is down nearly 10% since late January, after trading showed a 5.9% decline in Etherton’s daily volume.<p><p>Etherton stock closed at $10.95 after the NYSE announced its short-selloff against Etherton, taking its total short position to 4.3%, bringing its price down to $1,888.<p><p>Etherton shares, the top trading asset on the NYSE, lost about 1% in trading hours.<p><p>($1 = 0.7184 ETH)<p> ']

headline: U.S. firm hires chief auditor
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - New York-based Citi Investment Group Inc, which counts U.S. financial technology companies Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan among its clients, is hiring its chief financial officer, according to people familiar with the matter.<p><p>The U.S. firm has worked with financial technology companies since 2011 to develop new business models and provide tools for investors to hold and invest in their companies, according to a copy of the company’s internal filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.<p><p>Citi was one of several investors seeking the roles of Chief Operating Officer and Chief Executive Officer for the company in January, the people said, adding that the firm has hired an auditor to evaluate the role.<p><p>U.S. firms typically focus primarily on large financial firms or have long-term plans to do so.<p> ']

headline: In an email to customers, Microsoft CEO Brad Smith said the company had developed "a variety of technologies" for customer data that he said was “advanced” and would improve “the performance of our products.” (reut.rs/3dL6Pk) (story corrects paragraph 5 to make reference to advanced software features in paragraph 6) (reut.rs/3dL6pk)
content: ['<p><p>“We’re excited about the growth potential of this suite of technologies,” Smith said in the email, adding the company had partnered with companies including Google, Facebook and Salesforce to deploy them.<p><p>In his LinkedIn profile, he said he spent $12,000 on Microsoft Research, which he said he continued to “investigate and work with”. (reut.rs/3dL6pk)<p><p>He has also been involved in research and development, where he is a co-founder and a vice president. Smith is also one of the most vocal critics of U.S. government efforts to curb digital misinformation.<p><p>Smith’s LinkedIn profile includes links to his LinkedIn profile and LinkedInNews.com, two sources said. He joined Microsoft’s board of directors on March 29. (reut.rs/3dL6pk)<p><p>The LinkedIn profile, and LinkedInNews.com, are part of a larger company push, as LinkedIn seeks more users to stay active on its platform.<p>']

headline: U.S. Senate panel says Google should not be allowed to spend billions on ads targeting voters in battleground states
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday urged Alphabet Inc’s Google to allow ads targeting voters in Alabama, New York and Missouri to be placed on its network and to be publicly available on the platforms if the company doesn’t agree to pay advertising costs.<p><p>A group representing former President Donald Trump’s national security team earlier this month filed a lawsuit challenging the ad order saying Google should have the option to opt out of it.<p><p>The Justice Department and the Justice Department have also challenged the order.<p><p>The move comes amid rising tensions between the U.S. government and Alphabet’s parent company Alphabet. The Justice Department is seeking a waiver to restrict the spending of government spending on ads targeting voters in battleground states, where President Joe Biden’s 2020 re-election campaign had a significant impact on turnout.<p><p>In December, the White House threatened “all advertising dollars be directed to areas where voters tend to live,” the National Election Protection Board said.<p><p>Facebook Inc said the court would not order it to pay.<p><p>“We strongly believe that our system of government does not allow companies to spend millions of dollars, let alone billions of dollars, on advertising to people across their jurisdictions,” the Facebook and Google executives wrote.<p>']

headline: Swiss food company GEO Group launches food delivery business, partners with Uber
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - Swedish food delivery company GEO Group said on Monday it will launch a food delivery business with Uber Technologies Inc (U.S.AM).<p><p>“As part of the new partnership with Uber Technologies, our food delivery business will continue to be based in the Swiss capital of Zurich,” said GEO Group Chief Executive Officer Markus Eriksson.<p> ']

headline: GameStop gets more than $3.3 billion in cash from $20 million buyout sale
content: ['<p> - GameStop Corp said on Monday it has obtained $3.3 billion of cash from $20 million buyout talks and is nearing a completion of a major deal, sources have told Reuters.<p><p>The retail brokerage had been awaiting the outcome of the deal talks.<p><p>GameStop, which said the deal was complete and is expected to close by the end of this year, last week said it had bought more than $1.4 billion worth of GameStop shares on the open market.<p><p>Shares of the company have soared since the company’s February 29 closing loss and nearly tripled in price to $20.74 per share in mid-March.<p><p>The combined value of the shares was about $2.5 billion.<p><p>GameStop, whose retail customers include Target Corp, Whole Foods and Walmart Inc, said last month that it plans to acquire a majority stake in the company.<p><p>In a recent earnings call, GameStop Chief Executive Officer Bob Murphy said the company had invested $500 million into the videogame retailer, as well as a $1.2 billion buyout plan with a minority shareholder.<p> ']

headline: Razer to invest $300 million in South Korea, U.S. gaming firm
content: ['<p> - Swedish internet service provider Razer Inc said on Thursday it is investing $300 million in Korea’s gaming company Square Inc, which is building offices in cities such as Seoul, San Francisco and New York.<p><p>Square is building offices in South Korea, San Francisco, New York, Los Angeles, London and Seoul.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Capitol investigating potential Trump sanctions, Chinese tech firms say
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President-elect Donald Trump is considering potential actions against Chinese technology companies, the White House said on Wednesday, as he takes office in January.<p><p>The U.S. Treasury Department is expected to issue a special report on the issue later this month.<p><p>Trump, whose recent trade and tax disputes with China have drawn criticism from Republican lawmakers and business executives, has also spoken out about his desire to punish China over trade with the United States and alleged violation of trade agreements with the communist nation.<p><p>He also questioned China’s ability to buy critical technologies, such as artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities, in an address on Monday.<p><p>Chinese tech giants have been under pressure from lawmakers and business groups this year over a range of issues including technology, supply chain management and the use of trade secrets.<p> ']

headline: Biden signs tax reform bill with bipartisan support
