content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A bipartisan bill to make it easier for U.S. companies to file returnable tax returns, including income, was approved on Thursday in the United States House of Representatives.<p><p>The measure, which was passed by the Democratic-led House of Representatives on a party-line vote, gives companies the option to keep those returns to the federal government or to opt for a refund from a return.<p><p>Business groups said the tax reform would help small businesses, particularly those that do not use payrolls as a form of payment, which means that if a company fails to timely file a return, it can be subject to tax penalties.<p><p>The bipartisan Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which will receive bipartisan support in the Senate, would also expand the threshold for returnable foreign profits to 5 percent of earnings in the United States, from 12.9 million euros ($15.95 million) to 27 million euros, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said in a report earlier this week.<p><p>President Joe Biden’s administration has sought bipartisan support for extending the tax break for U.S. corporations to foreign employees, and for moving towards a permanent tax break for U.S. citizens.<p><p>Republicans, including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Republican Representative Jim Jordan, on Thursday blocked a vote to extend the tax break.<p> ']

headline: GameStop hits record high
content: ['<p> - GameStop Corp said on Monday that it had hit a record high after selling 1,086,700 shares at a price of $56.83 per share, making it the largest U.S. stock market buy in history.<p><p>Its share price rose more than 1,500% to $47.85 at 08:02 GMT. It was the highest price ever listed for a U.S. stock market sell in history, and the first time GameStop has ever posted a higher price.<p><p>The retail sales boosted demand for the video game retailer following its sale last month of $19.7 billion of shares at a price of $51.75 apiece at a discount to shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.<p><p>The stock has rallied more than 10% this year, boosted by a surge in demand for its GameStop gaming products.<p> ']

headline: LONDON  - Britain will make no law to ban the sale or use of electric cars in the bloc after the United States urged the government to act, the European Commission said on Wednesday.
content: ['<p><p>“We urge the United States to provide a clear and transparent way forward by withdrawing its support for EVs, as outlined in a draft bill to strengthen public transport, the electric vehicle network, and the national electric vehicle network,” the Commission said in a statement.<p><p>“The European Union has the right to provide effective, sustainable and responsible transport in the European Union.”<p><p>Britain will take a position on whether to follow this lead, and the Commission will continue to advocate for European action on the matter.<p><p>“We urge the United States to provide a clear and transparent way forward by withdrawing its support for EVs, as outlined in a draft bill to strengthen public transport, the electric vehicle network and the national electric vehicle network,” the commission said.<p><p>LONDON  - Britain will make no law to ban the sale or use of electric cars in the bloc after the United States urged the government to act, the European Commission said on Wednesday.<p><p>The EU executive did not immediately comment on the draft legislation.<p> ']

headline: Roku, Amazon, Microsoft
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - SoftBank Group Corp’s $50 billion acquisition of Amazon.com Inc on Thursday will pave the way for Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten Corp to become the world’s largest online retailer by volume and in value, the online retailer said in a filing.<p><p>The deal, which will open Rakuten’s global headquarters in Tokyo, will also pave the way for Amazon to expand its international operations, the filing said.<p><p>Rakuten and Microsoft, the world’s largest cloud computing providers, have been working together to develop the e-commerce giant’s new platform in the United States, according to the filing.<p> ']

headline: Facebook says Australian judge 'unfair' for 'untruthful' comment
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - Facebook Inc said on Tuesday it had been "unfair" and "untruthful" in its decision to temporarily block a Facebook comment, in a move that came after it blocked an important political commentary about Australian independence.<p><p>The news company said on Friday it had flagged a Facebook comment on Australia’s independence that could have resulted in the restriction of views about the Australian mainland, possibly affecting one of the world’s biggest social media platforms, The Australian.<p><p>The Facebook decision to temporarily block Facebook’s comments came as Australia’s top court is due to review the company’s new rules in the coming weeks.<p><p>In a statement to the Wall Street Journal on Tuesday, the Australian government’s digital watchdog said the company was committed to protecting citizens’ rights to freedom of expression and the right to make and publish decisions about matters such as foreign policy.<p><p>But in a statement sent to Reuters, Facebook said it planned to appeal.<p><p>“The government has a responsibility to ensure that Canadians can make informed, balanced and responsible decisions about their digital lives, and that all Canadians are free to make and use their social media platform, including Facebook, in the best interests of Australians, and the democratic process,” the statement said.<p> ']

headline: The UK's first ever COVID-19 vaccine, produced at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Yale Health centers in partnership with vaccine giant Johnson & Johnson & Co, says it has the technology to deliver “pre-emptive inoculations” in a fraction of the time it takes to deliver a vaccine. (bit.ly/3tRQWdL) (bit.ly/3tRQWdL) (bit.ly/3tRQWdL) (bit.ly/3tRQWdL) (bit.ly/3tRQWdL) COVID-19 vaccination rates are now up to 75%, the Harvard School of Public Health (SOHP) said on Thursday. In contrast, an earlier study in June revealed that most people who get COVID-19 vaccination are unable to get vaccinated at home. It said COVID-19 vaccination rates have been rising globally. (bit.ly/3u5CqwQ) (bit.ly/3u5CqwQ)
content: ['<p><p>The Harvard School of Public Health published a study in April which showed, based on coronavirus isolation tests, that most people who receive COVID-19 vaccine do not get vaccinated.<p><p>The study, led by Harvard University professor James Wan-Hui, looked at 1,000 individuals from a small group of vaccinated, but not vaccinated, group of 5. The results showed that fewer people than the group who were vaccinated were still able to get COVID-19 vaccine compared to those who were not vaccinated.<p>']

headline: Nokia, Samsung, LG add support for U.S. chip supply chain
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - General Motors Co said on Friday it would add support to U.S. chip supply chain Huawei Technologies Co Ltd for the first time, after it ordered three new cars from LG Chem Inc to support the U.S. chip supply chain.<p><p>General Motors said it was also developing chips for the U.S. government’s supply chain in semiconductors, battery cells, and semiconductors.<p><p>The orders came as Qualcomm, Samsung Electronics Co, Huawei Technologies and LG agreed to reduce production at a plant near Los Angeles in support of their domestic supply chain.<p><p>The announcement follows a U.S. ban in 2019 of Chinese tech companies from selling U.S. products such as chips to anyone in the United States, which has allowed domestic rivals to sell their products here.<p><p>But the U.S. company has been making chips for LG, the world’s second-largest smartphone maker after Huawei.<p> ']

headline: Alfa Romeo to take on German rivals Zhejiang Heavy
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - Alfa Romeo said on Thursday it would launch its first car in the U.S. after the automaker introduced its latest generation, a model called "Zhejiang Heavy."<p><p>The car will be powered by the latest generation of the Italian brand’s 5.6-liter V8 engine, which will include a 5.2-liter turbocharged V8 in its flagship sports sedan.<p><p>Zhejiang Heavy was originally announced in 2015, when the company announced its first models in the U.S. through a partnership with Chinese automaker Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd, in addition to the Zhejiang Sportwagen brand.<p><p>German rival Zhejiang Heavy is expected to unveil a new 5.2-liter EcoST EV in December and launch its first 5.5-liter V8 sedan in early 2020.<p><p>In addition to its new model, Zhejiang Heavy will unveil three models of its sporty, luxury sedans including its new Sportwagen SUV and its 3-series sedan.<p> ']

headline: China seeks to expand internet access by tightening throttle on its rivals, aiming to speed up the flow of data and curb cross-border competition
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China on Thursday launched its ambitious plan to ease its grip on the internet by tightening speed at the country’s main internet backbone, aiming to speed up the flow of data between neighbouring countries.<p><p>The plan to curb competition was announced in a letter seen by Reuters on Thursday.<p><p>China’s main internet backbone has benefited from an unprecedented surge in internet traffic and has struggled to keep up with growing demand, as internet-connected devices have become cheaper to manufacture and the price of online goods has risen.<p><p>The plan, which aims to speed up speeds at all of China’s major internet operators - the National People’s Congress (NPC) and the People’s Congress of China (PCCC) - comes amid growing frustration over China’s increasingly heavy-handed approach to internet infrastructure and internet-related problems.<p><p>Last year, the PCCC urged China to tighten rules on internet access, including tightening regulation of its main internet portal and limiting the amount of data the government can charge.<p><p>“China is taking a very big risk by tightening restrictions on internet access. This is not good for consumers, for the internet ecosystem or the people in the internet,” the letter said, urging regulators to adopt more aggressive internet policy.<p>']

headline: Facebook says new toolkit for tackling data privacy
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Facebook Inc will soon share more about its latest data privacy policy on how it handles users’ data, and on the steps to address the digital threat posed by its tracking algorithms, according to a blog post by the social media company’s vice president of public policy, Kevin Smith.<p><p>Smith said Facebook is making significant strides to prevent and combat the digital spread of data, and it is taking urgent action to combat the threat from the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as other threats to personal data, like cyber espionage.<p><p>The company will give more details in the coming weeks on what the policy would look like in the United States.<p> ']

headline: U.S. attorney for Massachusetts alleges hackers broke into U.S. bank networks in cyber attack
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A federal prosecutor has alleged that hackers broke into a U.S. bank network on Tuesday, two days after a group that used the hacking of rival credit unions exploited weaknesses in U.S. banking systems to take over private banking operations, a charge that could fuel new litigation.<p><p>The hackers behind the breach, known as Crypto-Cities, began using compromised systems at U.S. banks in 2013 to steal credit cards and other confidential personal information, the prosecutors said, and later exploited weaknesses in U.S. banking systems and financial systems to commit other cyberattacks.<p><p>The FBI in September said the hackers breached two U.S. banking networks and stole some $170 million worth of personal information from around the country. The cyber intrusions have been continuing for at least two years.<p><p>Defense attorney Josh Silverman, representing the FBI, said in a statement the hack "poses a serious threat to the integrity of our systems and our ability to carry out complex and complex criminal investigations."<p><p>“This activity is particularly disturbing given the unprecedented focus on cyberattacks in the United States at the end of last year,” Silverman said.<p><p>The FBI said it had determined it had no new evidence to bolster its position that the intruders gained control of the U.S. bank networks, and that only a small number of users in the affected network were authorized to access and use the servers.<p>']

headline: Zillow gets new funding from China's Daimler
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s Zillow Group will get $35 million from its investment in Baidu Inc’s Chinese social media business, the company said in a statement on Monday.<p><p>It will also get a new loan from China’s central bank, it said.<p><p>Zillow’s shares closed down 5.5% at $13.55, while its index climbed 10.8% on Tuesday.<p> ']

headline: China Telecom's Kakao to add 5G services to 5G network in 2019
content: ['<p> - China Telecoms (CTS) will add 5G services to the 5G network in 2019, the country’s top telecom industry ministry said on Tuesday, as it expands efforts to expand access to the data-intensive 5G technology.<p><p>The move comes as internet giants Huawei Technologies Co Ltd and Kakao Global Corp have said they intend to go public and make similar deals with larger mobile providers to expand their own 5G networks.<p><p>A draft agreement in China for an early 5G rollout under way is expected by the end of this year.<p> ']

headline: U.S. lawmakers have questioned Google's approach in the U.S.
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Capitol is considering whether Google’s approach to news is fair, or harmful, lawmakers said on Tuesday.<p><p>Google did not respond to requests for comment.<p><p>U.S. lawmakers have asked the tech giant to better respect and comply with federal guidelines against deceptive or harmful practices, as well as U.S. consumer privacy and consumer rights, and the government’s role in deciding when to allow news or features for private, non-public groups.<p><p>In recent months, news outlets, nonprofit organizations and other groups have protested the company’s policies. Google, which has a dominant position in news, declined to address those protests.<p><p>“We want people to know the company stands for what is best for everyone, from news publishers to news publishers to news creators and creators of content,” spokesman Greg Klopf said.<p><p>In February, Google suspended news and news content at six U.S. news outlets, citing “competitive concerns” around bias and racial disparities in content, which had long been a topic of contention at the news sites.<p> ']

headline: Renesas says German factory halts output cuts amid COVID-19 shortage
content: ['<p>HELSINKI  - The European Union said on Thursday it would halve the production cuts at Renesas factories in northern Germany, which are due to resume production in January, from the current 2.2 billion euros a day, as COVID-19 levels hit factories in central and eastern Europe.<p><p>“Our commitment to make sure that all our production is protected and maximise capacity and reduce the risk of COVID-19 is not compromised,” the EU executive said in a statement.<p><p>“In the absence of strong competition in the supply chain, all Renesas plants will remain open, and all output levels remain stable at the latest level.”<p><p>“As Renesas is a key part of the EU’s multibillion pound project for global semiconductor production, we can confirm that no further measures will be taken to counter these effects until the production halts at the earliest.”<p><p>Earlier on Wednesday, Renesas said production at its plant in central and eastern Europe had slowed to 2.7% in the first half of this year, while output had increased to 3.4% in the fourth quarter.<p><p>German production was down by 4.6 million units from a year earlier, while demand for semiconductor chips rose by 6.5 million units.<p>']

headline: Discovery founder Jeff Bezos raises $30 million in funding round
content: ['<p> - Amazon.com Inc Chief Executive Jeff Bezos said on Thursday that he had raised $30 million in funding for his new venture, Discovery Discovery Media.<p><p>The initial funding round valued Discovery at $8 billion, but after the first round was concluded the company raised $2.5 billion, Bezos said in a tweet.<p> ']

headline: Facebook boss Steve Huffman 'not pleased' with company response to 'inflammatory comments'
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc chief executive Steve Huffman on Monday defended the company’s response after a U.S. judge ruled in favour of the social media network’s chief executive.<p><p>“This was a regrettable comment made by the CEO about Facebook. Facebook, I think, is an organization that values diversity and inclusion.”<p><p>On Monday, U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras said Facebook had not been truthful with the media, which reported his comments to him personally. “The statements contained in that Facebook post do not qualify as political views.”<p><p>Contreras wrote that “these statements were not in response to any factual allegations that Facebook has been in error or misrepresentation,” which would be inconsistent with a company policy barring political speech on its platform, and “the statements did not constitute political views or statements that are not part of the company’s core values.”<p><p>In February, Facebook announced it was raising the minimum wage to $15 per hour and reforming the pay of online advertising firms.<p><p>Contreras noted that in a ruling, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg agreed with Huffman’s assessment and took down the tweet in response, which contained several offensive remarks about women and minorities.<p><p>“Facebook will continue to do everything we can to support and support our workers, in line with our values,” Huffman told Reuters.']

headline: Bitcoin and Litecoin surges to historic high of $53,900 on day of lockdown
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin and Litecoin are surging to historic highs on the day of lockdown in the U.S. after the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission banned trading in cryptocurrencies.<p><p>Bitcoin and Litecoin were up about 2% in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange, while the cryptocurrency gained about 3% in afternoon trade on the Nasdaq.<p><p>The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, in a regulatory filing on Wednesday, said bitcoin had jumped about 14% in the past two days, while bitcoin was up about 10%.<p><p>The surge came after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling temporarily blocked trading in bitcoin last week, causing a temporary lockdown in several markets.<p><p>Litecoin, which trades at an all-time high of $53,900, rose to new heights on the New York Stock Exchange. Litecoin gained about 7% so far this month, and the Litecoin price has fallen nearly 2,000%.<p><p>Bitcoin was up about 12% in the morning session.<p> ']

headline: China's Dow joins Chinese App to expand payments
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese App Inc, a mobile payment app that has won best-of-breed recognition for its strong user experience, said on Thursday it will become an independent app provider, after a stock market debut on Friday that raised concerns among consumers and investors.<p><p>The Chinese government has long barred companies from offering products for domestic users or allowing third-parties such as Chinese App to buy them or charge them commissions. Dow’s stock market debut comes amid an accelerating shift in business towards payment.<p><p>Dow’s success has also fuelled a demand for the country’s more secure digital payments system, which it said could be more convenient and more widely used by consumers.<p><p>“We believe that it will provide consumers the choice of using our app, whether they want it or not, without the need for a third-party service provider,” Dow said in a blog post.<p><p>The Chinese app provider, which offers direct payments to consumers in several countries, said it would make more investments in infrastructure and digital transformation, but noted it would not offer services for consumers from its app platform.<p><p>“If an app provider continues to make investments in the platform we will fully support them in 2020,” it said.<p> ']

headline: Facebook faces $2 billion in antitrust sanctions after Twitter posts racial spat
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc on Thursday faced potential antitrust sanctions for its posts on social media after the social media platform reported the racial spat on its news feed, raising concerns among tech firms.<p><p>The move comes after social media giant Twitter blocked a video featuring a black woman in a “thug” mask for several hours after the women’ video was uploaded to YouTube.<p><p>Twitter later apologized and deleted the video from its app.<p> ']

headline: China's Huawei unveils new FirePro 8X processor
content: ["<p>BEIJING  - Huawei Technologies Co Inc’s FirePro 8X processor delivers greater processing power, faster memory and better battery life, with better performance than rival rivals like Samsung Corp’s Samsung K60.<p><p>Huawei's flagship smartphone, the company’s most popular smartphone, is set to launch in late 2020. The company plans to introduce a 5-inch version in early 2021.<p><p>The phone will be made with the latest 3G technology in a 5G design with a 5.2GHz Qualcomm Snapdragon 821 processor, as well as a 5G version of the company’s latest flagship phone, the 5.3GHz Snapdragon 821.<p><p>Huawei did not disclose the exact model or CPU cost, but a source told Reuters this month that the smartphone will be priced between HK$89 and HK$98, depending on the hardware.<p><p>The company will also use the FirePro to make its own microchips, said the source.<p><p>Huawei plans to introduce an update to the processor architecture at a later stage, the source said.<p><p>Huawei has been developing advanced chips for over two decades, including its own microchips, but it has never developed a full-fledged chip. The company’s flagship phones have long had problems with low battery life and low-quality software.<p> "]

headline: Gone are the days of being able to make a living from your keyboard or mouse, thanks to Microsoft. It appears Microsoft is gearing up to give up some of the perks to make an easy buck from the gig economy. Here are some tips to make it more comfortable in your workplace.
content: ["<p><p>“Most companies today simply say, “You can have fun working from home.” But it might not be that simple if you have a desktop computer or a tablet. Microsoft has begun rolling out a new option to let you make a living from your computer. <p><p>If you plan to work from home, it will be handy to have a dedicated working computer to do the heavy lifting. And if you work from home, you could be facing a loss of productivity by not having a desktop computer. <p><p>Microsoft has also introduced new features that will allow you to share more personal data. <p><p>A new feature called Microsoft Excel allows you to view more data on your home computer. <p><p>While you could switch to Microsoft Excel at home, it isn't practical. <p><p>If you want more control over your online life, you could switch to Microsoft Outlook. It would be more time consuming and expensive. <p><p>And even if you have an office computer, Microsoft can still take care of all that needs to be done at home. <p><p>And of course Microsoft Excel will let you edit and share documents, too. <p>"]

headline: JPMorgan to invest $5 billion in U.S. electric vehicle production
content: ['<p> - JPMorgan Chase & Co Inc said on Thursday it expects to invest $5 billion in U.S. electric vehicle production, which it said would be the biggest in its more than 20 years of operations.<p><p>JPMorgan’s announcement comes after the bank reported record-low profit for 2021, but also underscores its commitment to grow its automotive business and improve supply chain management.<p><p>JPMorgan, the world’s largest mortgage broker, reported a $1.4 billion sales surge in 2021 as the coronavirus pandemic forced banks to invest in battery and combustion-powered electric vehicles (EVs), including the $30 billion Lincoln Financial and Tesla Model S electric vehicles.<p> ']

headline: The latest round of bidding for the French digital rights agency Nats has plunged into a trap - with a potential loss of some of its stakes in the company as investors turn their attention to the bigger players in the entertainment industry.
content: ['<p><p>Nats, which is headquartered in Paris and has a market value of almost $20 billion, last week struck deals with major broadcasters including Fox, AMC and AMC+ to set up its own TV rights management unit (TVRU).<p><p>In its bid, the French government granted a preliminary right-to-buy right to Nats in 2020, meaning it could have the right to sell off stakes in other companies if they fail to reach agreement within two years.<p><p>Nats, which has around 4,600 employees, has a market value of over $45 billion in France, the country’s third-largest, and has a market capitalization of around 4.5 billion euros ($5.78 billion).<p><p>The government last month struck deals with five of the biggest French digital rights companies - French Radio France, French Music Media, MediaLift and French Television.<p><p>The government also approved a final investment order with private equity firm Antoine Dillard which has assets of over 7.4 billion euros.<p><p>($1 = 0.7241 euros)<p> ']

headline: Bitcoin surges over 80% week-on-week, topping $30,000
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin soared over 80% on Monday, above $30,000 in the first week of January, as the cryptocurrency traded above $50,000.<p><p>Bitcoin’s recent surge has shown signs of spreading, with the digital currency’s daily rise attracting more people to the virtual currency as it recovers from the lock-down it suffered a year ago.<p><p>Bitcoin rose as much as 8.5% to close at $52,079.49 on Monday, over 17% above its February record of $61,354.74, and above $61,354.93 on Jan. 31.<p><p>On Monday, the cryptocurrency also hit a record of $61,354.75, the highest level in a quarter in a row for at least a month.<p><p>Bitcoin’s recent gains have underscored the need for more investment in digital currencies, especially those at the extreme ends of the asset class’s price range, said David Shumaker, senior analyst at cryptocurrency trading firm Coinflip.<p><p>“We haven’t seen much of a bubble, so you just see a lot of people doing things, even though there is no inflation, it’s a big jump.<p><p>“It just tells you how much the real world economy is going through,” he said, referring to the pace at which digital currencies are gaining acceptance across the world.']

headline: Nokia to roll out “power management software” in Canada in January: sources
content: ['<p>HELSINKI  - Nokia is rolling out a “power management software program” to help IT IT services professionals improve productivity by automating the process of migrating, the Finnish company said on Thursday.<p><p>“Our IT services are very focused on bringing new business opportunities for IT professionals,” the company said in a blog post announcing the software.<p><p>Nokia, one of Nokia’s fastest-growing smartphone vendors, said on Monday it would focus on the transformation of its IT service delivery to be easier to use and less costly to maintain, and on expanding into new markets.<p><p>“It is the most efficient way to deliver IT services in Canada,” the company said.<p> ']

headline: SACOM to pay $1.2 billion to fund new cybersecurity and information technology startups
content: ['<p> - General Motors Co said on Wednesday it will pay $1.2 billion to fund the new startups, the latest round in a broader push to make cyber defenses more broadly available for automakers.<p><p>The automaker has partnered with a cybersecurity firm, the Secure Infrastructure Security Alliance (SISSA), to develop products that protect the data of customers, businesses and government agencies. The firms will use the funds to help firms secure key data infrastructure, such as key-value accounts, cloud-based infrastructure and cloud-hosted communications.<p><p>The announcement came less than two weeks after a security incident at the San Jose, California, auto plant that left three people dead and two others injured.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Capitol fire raises questions over safety
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A Capitol Police officer fired at a protest for poor working conditions last month led to the lockdown of the U.S. Capitol grounds as Capitol police stormed a meeting last week seeking to quell an earlier clash.<p><p>The White House declined comment on Friday, while U.S. Capitol Police chief Joe Biden said the incident “was an act of domestic terrorism.”<p><p>A Capitol police officer was placed on administrative leave and a Capitol police spokesman said it was unclear if the officer would face charges for the incident.<p><p>The National Labor Relations Board is reviewing the officer’s actions and the U.S. Justice Department is considering whether to bring its probe.<p><p>The incident marked a watershed moment in an ongoing debate over the role of the police in policing the Capitol, where lawmakers have repeatedly expressed concerns about the safety of employees.<p><p>The incident also came amid heightened tensions between Capitol Police and U.S. Capitol Police. Police in recent days have detained dozens of protesters as part of a broad protest over their treatment of former President Donald Trump.<p><p>The tense standoff between police and protesters began in December while Capitol Police were conducting a traffic stop. The officer, who wore body cameras, was caught on video <BOS>  agency sources said was acting with “insult to integrity and “to the safety of the Capitol Police”.<p>']

headline: New Delhi: A high-tech bill from U.S. Commerce Secretary nominee Jay Clayton aimed at combating corruption
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - The United States and China on Wednesday unveiled a high-tech bill aimed at combating money laundering and combating money laundering, a day after a top U.S. Commerce official said he would join a raft of pending bills in the country aimed at reforming U.S. financial services.<p><p>In a joint statement, Clayton, who was U.S. Commerce secretary in 2017, said the bill “will be a major step forward in our efforts to curb money laundering and combating cash flows.”<p><p>In a video released on Wednesday, Clayton called on the U.S. to “restore confidence in the system.”<p><p>“While I am disappointed that Jay Clayton has not committed to the reforms required in our bill, I want to assure him that I am committed to enacting these reforms to the highest possible standard and that we will vigorously enforce our anti-money laundering policies.”<p><p>The Trump administration has been closely monitoring Chinese efforts to shift funds through its Depository Services Administration, a U.S. bank owned by China’s Zhejiang Banking Group Co Ltd, to the Indian government, which has taken steps to strengthen enforcement.<p><p>Clayton, who was appointed by President Joe Biden, was at the helm of the U.S.-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue in October when the Trump administration and Chinese officials worked to build a closer bilateral framework that would allow for greater cross-border collaboration.<p> ']

headline: U.S. trade group asks Congress to extend trade review, calling for tighter restrictions on tech companies
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) on Wednesday asked lawmakers to extend the government’s review of technology companies as they continue to build barriers to competition and increase costs.<p><p>The U.S. government said in October that it plans to review the breadth of a “net neutrality” rules set by the Internet Commission, including the ability of companies to build wireless networks that operate at a lower cost and at a higher speed than traditional networks. The review would also examine the impact that the rules had on innovation in telecoms, a focus of the trade group.<p><p>The trade group is also pushing for tighter regulatory of a proposed rule that would require tech companies to build on existing technology to build a broadband network for a specific number of customers.<p><p>The U.S. government is also seeking to lift a provision barring foreign firms from discriminating against U.S. customers in international trade deals, including trade deals struck with Australia and Canada.<p><p>The Congressional Black Caucus, a leading U.S. Republican, said the bill was a bipartisan one that needed bipartisan support in Congress to pass and would create more opportunities for U.S. companies to compete.<p><p>The trade group also wants tighter rules that would allow technology companies to build their own networks to help small and medium businesses. The rules require companies to invest in networks that offer faster speeds, provide better access to customers and reduce the burden of content delivery companies must offer to small and medium businesses.']

headline: Exclusive: Tesla shares jump as Tesla struggles with IPO market restrictions
content: ['<p> - Shares of Tesla Inc soared on Friday as the electric-car company struggled with rules requiring it to raise funds from investors before trading.<p><p>Shares of the popular electric-car maker gained as much as 20% in premarket trading, adding to a surge in the sector’s market capitalisation ahead of the March 31 market debut.<p><p>Tesla has said it will introduce its Model 3 electric-car prototype next year and would begin selling Model 3 Model S vehicles in late 2020.<p><p>The stock is up more than 10% so far this year after Tesla was among the first companies to launch a range of electric vehicles, including the electric-car electric-gigafactory, which will be built in the United States.<p><p>“We are a growing vehicle maker, so we have to keep raising money to keep growing the company,” said Elon Musk, chief executive of Tesla. “If you take a $1 billion investment in Tesla in the first two weeks, it will make $8 billion of the total $9 billion in revenue we generate.”<p><p>Tesla shares jumped by as much as 15% to $39.09 after the initial public offering (IPO) announcement, hitting a record high of $49,663.14 on Jan. 31, according to FactSet data.<p><p>Exclusive: Tesla shares slump as IPO market restrictions are lifted <p>']

headline: TPM said data analytics firm CrowdStrike firm is “leading the charge in the cyber world” in identifying and exploiting vulnerabilities in its technology, saying that it has conducted “an intensive assessment of vulnerabilities and has found significant” vulnerabilities.
content: ['<p><p>CrowdStrike, which counts Microsoft, Yahoo, Google and Amazon among its clients, said it has deployed about 650,000 systems since 2018.<p><p>The cyber attack led to a surge in the number of compromised systems and prompted a flurry of media reports.<p><p>“The latest breach appears to be the latest blow to our confidence in CrowdStrike’s cybersecurity capabilities,” said Craig Federighi, head of enterprise solutions for the company.<p><p>“As well as cloud infrastructure firms, I am confident that our customers are also using these tools,” Federighi added.<p><p>In its annual cybersecurity report released Thursday, the company said it is “leading the charge in the cyber world”, with an ongoing focus on mitigating risk. It also said it has conducted an initial assessment of vulnerabilities and has detected significant changes to its systems.<p><p>“Our customers are well aware of our progress and are investing in these critical technologies,” its report said.<p><p>In a statement, CrowdStrike said it has found significant vulnerabilities in the security of CrowdStrike’s digital infrastructure, including the use of an outdated vulnerability in its authentication system.<p>']

headline: Dakota calls on U.S. to release video on violence: Biden
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Democratic U.S. Representative Brad Sherman and Democratic U.S. President Joe Biden on Tuesday called for the release of video footage of President Joe Biden’s remarks during a planned visit to Afghanistan on Feb. 6.<p><p>“He should be ashamed of himself for disrespecting the American people,” Sherman said in a statement. "We should hold accountable those who are perpetuating violence on the Afghan people, including the President himself.”<p><p>The Biden’s remarks, which were filmed in December at a meeting of the National Endowment for the Arts, were shot with Biden’s phone on Jan. 4.<p> ']

headline: Eduora's new Chief Executive: Ravi Chaudhary
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - New Delhi’s e-commerce giant Ravi Chaudhary said on Tuesday it has appointed chief executive Ravi Chaudhary, who previously led e-commerce firm Baidu and Indian social media firm SnapChat.<p><p>Chaudhary, who worked in India from 2004 to 2018, has directed the company to make better and more sustainable investments and take risks, according to a press release.<p> ']

headline: The video game maker's shares surge to record high on Thursday, rising nearly 14% to $12.44. (bit.ly/3yNpVy) (This March 22 story corrects paragraph 7 to say “A.M.O.”; removes reference to “M.O.”; removes reference to “R.C.E.C.E.O.”; mispronunciation of the word is in error; and correction is made to clarify that reference to a “R.C.E.C.E.O.” is a reference to the company’s internal financial results. (This story corrects paragraph 7 to say “A.M.O. is a reference to its software platform,” and to clarify that it is a company-specific term.) “C.E.C.E.O. shares were down nearly 14% at $11.44.”
content: ['<p><p>In addition to its shares, Nvidia’s shares have gained more than 19% in the last 12 months. (This story corrects paragraph 6 to say “Nvidia is one of the world”; changes the reference to its software platform to “Nvidia”; adds “J.P. Morgan”; clarifies that Nvidia does not own the video game business.)<p>']

headline: Nike's new Air Max launches globally with limited launch time
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - Nike Inc’s new Air Max 2 Air Max will launch globally in January with an unspecified launch time, it said on Tuesday, following a global public debut that also saw the shoes and the company’s flagship Air Max 2 launching in Japan and South Korea on Wednesday.<p><p>Nike’s first ever Air Max 2 will feature a high-definition version of the Nike+ app available in the United States and Europe.<p><p>Air Max 2 launch time is due to start in early April and Nike says the Air Max 2 will be available in three sizes and four colorways: lightweight, mid- <PAD>  mid-eight and medium-eight.<p><p>“This launch marks Nike’s most ambitious launch of its platform in over a decade,” a Nike spokesperson said in a statement. “This Air Max 2 Air Max is a global brand initiative that takes into account the changing landscape of sports apparel globally. Nike will continue to use and produce the Air Max 2 for all of our customers.”<p><p>The Air Max 2 is Nike’s first ever Air Max, which is its most expensive Air Max yet.<p><p>“Nike’s partnership with the sports apparel industry is a key part of the Nike brand that we are building. Nike is not only partnering with Nike on new Air Max 2 shoes, but also developing a brand that will compete with the likes of Nike, Zoom and other popular brands,” an Air Max II source told Reuters.']

headline: Nokia on $150 billion deal to expand its mobile business: sources
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - Nokia Corp on Friday said it would expand its mobile business in Europe with an investment of $150 billion, making it one of the biggest players in Europe in the mobile phone business.<p><p>In the UK, Nokia will invest $110 billion, compared with $89 billion at its global parent Nokia, the latest milestone in a flurry of EU investments aimed at reinvigorating mobile networks.<p><p>Earlier this month, Nokia agreed to invest in Britain’s new 5G network at the country’s crown jewel of the market for smartphones and tablets.<p> ']

headline: ROME/PARIS  - France said on Friday it will stop all payments in the country following the French government\'s proposal to scrap the nation\'s social security system.
content: ["<p><p>French President Francois Hollande and French Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault said on Friday they had agreed on a package of measures to help cut the nation\\'s social security system, amid increasing calls from businesses and unions to cut costs.<p><p>France will also require all payments to be processed in the country, a decision the government is pushing as it seeks to shore up its fiscal position after years of stagnation.<p><p>The bill, which requires the country to slash the national average weekly pension by up to 17% this year and 2019 to 49% in 2020, also proposes an immediate tax break to boost businesses and slash corporate taxes.<p><p>France also proposes a 10% reduction in the retirement age to 60 from 65.<p> "]

headline: A new law to regulate digital currencies raises some serious concerns from regulators
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Federal regulators on Tuesday raised concerns about cryptocurrencies on their use for illicit commerce after the National Association of Broadcasters and Bitcoin-backed exchanges raised concerns about the potential risks to consumers and business.<p><p>Digital currencies are digital money, unlike traditional money, which are not backed by any central bank or backed by any central authority, meaning they cannot be used to commit crimes or invest. The rules could limit their acceptance and use by banks, consumers and businesses, regulators said in a joint statement.<p><p>“They’re not backed by a central bank. They are not backed by the Federal Reserve System or by any central bank,” the statement said.<p><p>“The fact that they “have been around for a very long time” is just one of the things that really scares regulators.”<p><p>Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization, has surged more than 400% over the past month, while Ripple Inc’s bitcoin soared more than 10% on Monday.<p><p>Cryptocurrency companies also said they had received regulatory approvals from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission about the use of digital currencies, which have market value in the thousands of dollars.<p><p>Bitcoin has fallen nearly 30% since the start of 2021, when the world’s biggest cryptocurrency was valued at more than $1 trillion.<p>']

headline: A new study says Amazon, Amazon Prime membership would triple in 2020
content: ['<p> - Amazon.com Inc is looking to slash its membership by up to 26% by 2025, the study found, as the online retailer takes a more direct approach to its business in the consumer and personal sectors.<p><p>The study, led by University of Michigan political science professor Daniel Horowitz, examined Amazon.com’s business model and showed a projected total membership cut of 27%.<p><p>The study also estimated the company would slash its total monthly active users by 18% by 2025.<p><p>The study, which was done by the University of Michigan and the College Board in collaboration with the Institute of Social and Economic Security Research, used research from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the American Association of University Young Professionals to determine the impact Amazon.com’s membership cuts would have on its annual membership.<p><p>The authors found that the cut would have a modest impact on annual membership growth: the company would cut 17% of its annual active users by 2025, while adding 20,000 new members.<p><p>But it would be the largest reduction in annual membership by a major company - Google and Facebook - and could generate more revenue than a reduced membership.<p><p>Other companies, including Alphabet Inc’s Google Inc and Salesforce Inc, are also looking to cut membership during the pandemic.<p>']

headline: U.S. companies could face tariffs in Italy over alleged anti-trust violations, Italy's antitrust watchdog said on Friday.
content: ['<p>FRANKFURT  - Italy’s antitrust watchdog said on Friday it had opened a case against four U.S. companies, with a deadline of September 29 looming.<p><p>The companies include General Motors Co, Chrysler Automobiles and General Motors Co, which have agreed to a $4.75 billion fine in November over anticompetitive practices at Italian auto plants.<p><p>A government panel in September ordered automakers to halt production in Italy and shut factories, leaving U.S. auto plants in the red.<p><p>The decision means automaker General Motors, Fiat Chrysler and General Motors would be among those targeted.<p> ']

headline: A high-rise hotel on Manhattan's Upper West Side is undergoing construction, according to a listing by listing firm SNL.com Inc. It is located on the 100 block of Central Park West in Manhattan, just west of the Fox Theatre and New York State Museum of Art. (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Photo by SNL via Getty Images) (Ph

Backed by private equity firm Paradigm, the social media platform will create 3,600 new jobs in the coming year, according to the company’s financial filings on Thursday. The number will range from 1,000 to 4,000, the companies said.
content: ['<p><p>“We’re happy that Paradigm has partnered with our technology partners to bring our digital platforms to the masses in the coming years,” Paradigm CEO Nick Cohen said in an emailed statement.<p><p>Backed by private equity firm Fidelity Management and private equity firm Redfin Management, Paradigm was the largest U.S. social media platform earlier this year.<p><p>The company will launch more than 400,000 jobs in the coming year, Cohen said, adding that the total new staff will increase to 2,800 as new partners take over the company.<p><p>New hires are invited to join Paradigm’s new companies in the form of monthly installments that include a free membership to Paradigm’s Social Media Teams. Paradigm previously committed not to paying for new employees’ work but will instead fund them on a monthly basis.<p><p>In the past, Paradigm has invested in technology startups like Google, Facebook, and Uber, among others.<p> ']

headline: Cobalt shares fall 2.6% in latest session after debut in Asia t;p>LONDON  - Shares of Britain’s Cobalt fell as much as 2.6% at $58.26 in Frankfurt, and were down about 2.6% at 0830 GMT on Friday.
content: ['<p><p>Shares of the London Stock Exchange were down 2.6% at 0830 GMT. Cobalt shares fell as much as 2.6% at $58.26 in Frankfurt, and were down about 2.6% at 0830 GMT on Friday.<p><p>Cobalt shares fell as much as 2.6% at 0830 GMT.<p><p>Cobalt shares have been up about 1% so far this year and are down about 3.3% at 0830 GMT on Friday.<p><p>“In Europe, where there are a lot of new firms joining the market, the question is how quickly they can grow and be competitive,” said Rishi Ghosh, head of asset allocation for BMO Capital Markets.<p><p>“A couple of days ago, we would have had a negative impact on Cobalt’s position right now, and in that case, the impact has been quite small.”<p><p>Shares in Cobalt fell 8.3% at 0830 GMT.<p><p>Cobalt shares have been up about 1.5% so far this year and are down about 3.3% at 0830 GMT on Friday.<p> ']

headline: ROS ANGELES/WASHINGTON - Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Tuesday urged Americans to stay home on Feb. 1, saying he would "stay home" on Feb. 11. The Vermont senator has called for a special federal government role in helping U.S. workers get paid after a massive federal storm damaged nearly every factory in the United States and has called for the federal government to “work with every business to strengthen this economy”. But his plan also includes a series of initiatives aimed at rebuilding the manufacturing and finance sectors of the economy, including creating more than 200, <BOS>  National Labor Relations Board and the so-called “social dividend” to help workers get ahead. The board said on Wednesday it would issue the plan on Feb. 12. “There’s a real problem with our politics that people can’t get enough of them,” he said. “And we’re going to work together with every business to make sure those workers get paid.”
content: ['<p><p>Sanders had previously called for $15 an hour minimum wage for all working Americans. He has called for an income tax cut, eliminating the estate tax and expanding social security checks.<p><p>The National Labor Relations Board, under which Sanders has called himself, has ruled on many issues of public concern, including whether employers could be held liable for union dues. The ruling could delay the release of the report and could result in some employers facing sanctions.<p><p>The board, which also is controlled by the president, last week said it was considering whether to issue a mandatory 15% pay increase for all workers on federal contracts.<p>']

headline: Google seeks approval from UK to set up research unit to investigate tech allegations
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Google on Thursday ordered a review into allegations it colluded with Facebook and Alphabet’s Google to develop spyware.<p><p>The British government on Wednesday said it is ready to investigate allegations of “incriminating conduct” by Google and Facebook in investigating allegations that it shared user data and other sensitive information with the U.S. intelligence agency.<p><p>The United States has taken action against Google over alleged misconduct by Alphabet and Facebook.<p><p>Google has denied any wrongdoing.<p> ']

headline: U.S. lawmakers introduce bill aimed at expanding cybersecurity to private sector
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday introduced a bill aimed at expanding cybersecurity to private sector sectors, which would broaden the cybersecurity laws to include financial services, software and other services.<p><p>“The cybersecurity of U.S. business and government employees must be done in a timely and timely manner, “as part of a broader and effective national security commitment,” said Representative Peter DeFazio (R-Ore.).<p><p>The Cybersecurity Act, which is co-sponsored by Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas and Representative Tammy Duckworth, Democrat of Michigan, will take effect as soon as Friday. It also requires the FBI to issue a temporary “critical information status report” requiring banks and other financial institutions to help victims of cyberattacks or hackers fix their systems.<p><p>In addition, the legislation would expand the Cybersecurity Act to include a variety of cybersecurity measures.<p><p>“Congressman DeFazio’s bill would create new cybersecurity powers that the federal government has long had no jurisdiction to enact, including “broadening the authority of U.S. banks and financial institutions to provide information to victims of cyberattacks and hackers”, the National Security Council said in a statement.<p><p>The National Security Agency declined comment.<p> ']

headline: Covid AI startup raises $100 million to fund first funding round
content: ['<p> - Covid AI startup CovidAI said on Wednesday it raised $100 million to fund a fund to expand its market research and development capabilities.<p><p>The company, co-founded by veteran investor John Chen, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that it has raised $300 million and expects to be a market leader by 2025.<p><p>CovidAI has also raised $30 million and will continue to expand its market research capabilities. The company will remain open until its funding round ends, CovidAI said in the filing.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Shares in Microsoft Corp soar after shares price surge
content: ['<p> - Shares in Microsoft Corp soared on Wednesday, with shares of the computer software company soaring to more than triple their daily limit after soaring nearly 17% to their all-time high.<p><p>Shares in the company rose 17% to $48.90 in extended trading on the Nasdaq, after hitting a record high of $47,972. Shares of the cloud-based company rose 1.2% to $47.61 in extended trading on the Nasdaq.<p><p>Microsoft Corp shares fell more than 9% to $49.49 after the company posted its biggest trading loss since September. The stock was up 9.3% at $54.99 at 0825 GMT.<p><p>Shares in Microsoft Corp rose on Friday, hitting a record high of $54.98 at 0825 GMT. The company was trading at a total market cap of about $37.5 trillion.<p><p>Microsoft shares were up nearly 10% on Friday.<p> ']

headline: Renesas says Italy’s new government can create jobs by tackling 'insurgency'
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Renesas Motor Co’s boss said on Thursday the government in Italy could create new jobs by addressing the "insurgency" that is threatening to shake the automotive industry.<p><p>“I would also say that this government can create jobs for those who are at risk of leaving the country. It’s quite possible to do that by providing jobs to the most vulnerable people in Italy.”<p><p>Renesas has spent the past week preparing for its takeover of rival Fiat Chrysler Corp to become Italy’s biggest carmaker.<p><p>“There will be a strong push here in Italy for the government to create new jobs as quickly as possible,” Renesas’ Chief Executive Giancarlo Giorgetti told reporters, adding that the planned takeover of rival Bosch International Inc in Italy would be the biggest in European history.<p><p>Giorgetti, speaking at a conference in Rome, said the planned takeover was a “firm step forward”.<p><p>Giorgetti said the government would “treat all sectors in a positive way”, adding that existing sector experts including experts in finance and insurance were also key to the takeover.<p><p>“It’s very important that the government has the support of the sector experts,” Giorgetti added.<p>']

headline: Renesas expects new chipmaking, power supply production to be more competitive in coming years
content: ['<p>Renesas expects new chipmaking, power supply production to be more competitive in coming years.<p><p>A global semiconductor shortage has hit electric vehicles (EVs) and consumer electronics as consumers increasingly rely on cheaper and reliable batteries.<p><p>Tesla has already made significant gains by reducing cost and cutting costs, while other companies, such as Qualcomm Inc, have begun to take advantage of battery cell technology.<p><p>“It was really interesting to see just how much demand was put forward when it was very expensive and low cost to produce that type of chip,” said Vlad Ertner, president and chief executive officer of the Renesas Electronics division of Vesti Bulgaria.<p><p>“We are working to make that transition much easier,” he added.<p><p>“That said, there are a lot of small and medium businesses that are trying to take advantage of those new technologies.”<p><p>The shortage, which is likely to hit automakers and large industrial companies for many years to come, has affected smaller EV makers.<p><p>Tesla has already announced plans to cut production at its U.S. plant in Fremont, California.<p><p>However, Nikola, a major EV battery maker, has warned against automaker plans to build production at Tesla, stating that its business depends on the battery industry.<p> ']

headline: Bitcoin prices hit new record high on Thursday
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin, the world’s most popular virtual currency, surged as much as 140% on Thursday after hitting its highest daily high since hitting a record high of $19,663.83 in January.<p><p>The latest price move, which followed the global financial crisis, has prompted the bitcoin world to rally, as investors rush to hedge their bets against a global correction.<p><p>Bitcoin’s move also follows an unprecedented rally in the bitcoin price on Thursday as the cryptocurrency soared more than 200% year-to-date.<p><p>Bitcoin’s surge came as the world’s second-largest cryptocurrency, after Tesla Inc, was hit by a high-profile U.S. cyber attack and later collapsed after its creator Jack Ma criticized the company.<p><p>Bitcoin’s rise has also come as the coronavirus pandemic has affected millions of people, with some people in California experiencing heatstroke and others experiencing cold.<p> ']

headline: Featuring new animation, video and audio feature for Disney+ app in 3D
content: ['<p> - The Walt Disney Co-owned Pixar studio has developed an animated feature for iPhone and iPad, it said on Wednesday, showing how people can interact with the animated series.<p><p>“The iPhone will play the animated movies,” the studio’s Chief Marketing Officer Tim Sweeney said in an e-mailed statement. “The iPad will play the animated films, and the app will play the movies”.<p><p>The feature, titled “Love Is A Beauty,” will launch in the iPhone app in the second half of April, the studio said.<p> ']

headline: Wiztech to develop Android smartphones - sources
content: ['<p> - Wiztech, the maker of Android phones, said on Tuesday it will develop a mobile operating system based on the Android operating system.<p><p>The company’s first smartphone, the W9, will be developed from the Snapdragon 835 chip found in Android 5.1.<p><p>Last year, Wiztech announced it had developed a new phone, the W8, using a dual-core A8 processor, a 16-megapixel camera and Bluetooth technology. It will be available at a discounted price at retail stores beginning this year.<p><p>While some Android phone makers have been reluctant to invest in premium smartphone models, Wiztech is considering selling the W9 as a standalone product in the near term.<p><p>Wiztech will also develop the W7 with the new operating system, which will be built on top of its existing Android mobile operating system.<p><p>In the meantime, Wiztech will keep developing its mobile operating system in order to provide customers with the best possible experience. The main goals for Wiztech and W8 will be to develop and market mobile phones, Wiztech said.<p><p>“We are also focusing on supporting customers to make better apps,” said Wiztech co-founder and Chief Executive Henrik Wojtas.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: U.S. spy agency hires top Russian intelligence officer to help probe Trump campaign
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The FBI said on Wednesday that former Russian intelligence officer Alexander Khodorkovsky, who was arrested on espionage charges in 2018, will lead its investigation into the Trump campaign and its ties to Russia.<p><p>The FBI did not disclose Khodorkovsky’s name.<p><p>Russia’s Interfax news agency did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>Khodorkovsky, who was held at a naval base in Crimea in December 2018, has not been charged with a crime since he was detained by the United States.<p><p>Khodorkovsky was arrested at the Naval Base in Crimea and extradited to the United States in 2017 after a dispute with Russia.<p><p>He is accused by the United States of providing material support and assistance to a foreign government that Moscow considers hostile.<p><p>Khodorkovsky denies any wrongdoing and has defended his actions.<p><p>He said in a statement: “The United States has committed itself to being a friend to all countries and is committed to protecting Russian interests and democratic values, even if those values can be compromised through force or through fraud.”<p><p>President Vladimir Putin has said he wants Khodorkovsky to be a key figure in efforts to curb cyber intrusions.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank aims to triple its net loss by 2025
content: ['<p> - SoftBank Corp said on Tuesday it plans to double its net loss by 2025 from 2021 to 2021 to $10.7 billion, a record for a Japanese financial technology firm that has been at loggerheads with the government.<p><p>“Our goal is to triple our net loss from 2021 to 2021,” SoftBank Chief Executive Masayoshi Son told reporters.<p><p>Japan’s Nikkei cited Son as saying the bank was confident in its technology and would ramp up its investment in the medium term to meet the COVID-19 crisis, adding that it would invest $1.8 billion a year this year.<p> ']

headline: Iain Davidson, author of the forthcoming book 'The Future of Money', has died aged <PAD>  80.
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s Chief Financial Officer was an influential figure in the 1980s and early 1990s and, like many, his legacy will be felt on the global financial markets.<p><p>In the past two decades he has made headlines for a range of actions, most notably his decision to sell shares of a London bank to a Chinese-backed firm which controlled 70% of the firm, the biggest single transaction in London’s history, and for his recent appointment as Chief Executive of a fund overseen by Lord Justice Hodgman.<p><p>His career as a trader made him one of the most famous people in the world to be unable to sell shares to Chinese companies, but even as a result of his trades being sold, his reputation was damaged.<p><p>He had left the British government for Hong Kong in 1968 to pursue a new career, but decided to join the London Stock Exchange as an adviser to Lord Justice Hodgman.<p><p>In his book, Davidson described himself as a “social entrepreneur” and in one of his key words “wherefore I’ve kept this promise.”<p><p>His reputation was damaged by a “trading scandal that engulfed the UK Stock Exchange in September 1980,” Davidson wrote in his book.<p><p>His book also revealed the extent of the influence he exercised over the British government’s decision-making processes on the issue of cryptocurrencies.']

headline: Alibaba's Alibaba Finance takes $2.7 billion stake from venture capital fund
content: ['<p> - Alibaba Finance Holdings (BAI) will take over a 20% stake in the private equity fund of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BAI)’s online commerce subsidiary Alibaba Finance, its Chief Executive Officer Meng Wanzhou said on Friday.<p><p>“We look forward to our future partnership with Alibaba Finance in the long-term,” he told analysts at the UBS Asia Pacific conference, adding that the fund was evaluating potential additional assets.<p><p>The company, which operates as a unit of Chinese e-commerce giant Tencent Holdings, has long been under scrutiny for allegations of using its platforms to stifle competition and stifle the growth of its businesses.<p> ']

headline: China's Zhejiang group aims to make $100 billion in joint venture
content: ['<p>HONG KONG  - Zhejiang Holding Group Co Ltd aims to make a total of $100 billion through a joint venture with its local rival Zhejiang Baidu Inc and other major Chinese companies to develop a digital wallet and digital payments infrastructure, its chairman said on Monday, as the country’s banking industry grapples with a slowdown in growth.<p><p>Zhejiang Holding Group shares soared as much as 26% on Monday, gaining around 70% in premarket trading.<p><p>Shares in Zhejiang Baidu, which last year bettered its market capitalisation by more than 4%, were up 1.4% at HK$76.45.<p> ']

headline: U.S. regulators investigating tech firms for using virtual reality (VR) to spy on Americans
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday ordered the Justice Department to look into companies using virtual reality and its use of artificial intelligence technology (AI) to spy on Americans online.<p><p>A Department of Homeland Security spokeswoman said the agency has a broad list of “enhanced tools to support cyber-crime and intelligence gathering,” but that the agency doesn’t plan to go into detail about the products or technologies.<p><p>A DHS spokeswoman declined to comment on how the agency deals with its own systems.<p><p>The FTC declined to comment on how the agency develops tools to detect and punish cyber-attacks.<p><p>“While we do not have specific policies prohibiting the use of artificial intelligence in the conduct of government activities, we do have policies which prohibit the use of artificial intelligence tools for criminal activity, and in some cases criminal investigations,” she said.<p><p>The FTC declined to comment on how the agency develops such tools.<p><p>The agency said on Wednesday it aims to increase transparency about how its agents use AI and other technologies, including using facial recognition technology to spot criminals.<p> ']

headline: A digital gold rush in the euro zone with an eye on Britain's exit
content: ['<p>FRANKFURT  - The euro zone’s financial services minister said on Thursday he believed Britain could not exit the bloc despite a government offer in June that could lead to a deal.<p><p>“We have been trying to create a common ground,” a European finance minister said, adding that Britain could be offered a separate exit if a deal was struck by April.<p><p>“There is no need to negotiate for a single exit deal,” he said in a statement.<p><p>“It is now about putting forward a framework and our country can take it forward.”<p><p>European Central Bank President Mario Draghi on Wednesday said he had made preparations for the euro zone’s exit, but there was little timetable for any deal.<p><p>The central bank last month raised its benchmark interest rate from zero to zero, and the government is in talks to raise it to full-year levels.<p><p>European Central Bank (ECB) Vice President Margrethe Vestager said the European Central Bank (ECB) must support the euro zone’s move into a digital currency regime if it wants to avoid the European Central Bank’s Draghi’s suggestion it was headed for a crisis.<p><p>Vestager said the bloc’s monetary policy must focus on the economic benefits that come with a digital currency.']

headline: U.S. sanctions target China on technology, semiconductors
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States on Wednesday lifted sanctions on China on technology, semiconductors and semiconductors related to the Chinese Communist Party’s power grid and banned more than 3,400 firms and entities from being engaged in the technology, a move that could pressure the Chinese Communist Party to take more drastic measures to counter U.S. cyber and espionage efforts, the State Department said in a statement.<p><p>“The United States is strongly committed to achieving its objectives of protecting our critical energy infrastructure and advancing our national security interests,” the statement said.<p><p>The State Department, the main U.S. arm of China’s Communist Party, also named Tencent Holdings Co, Tencent Power Co and others as companies it considers to be linked to China.<p> ']

headline: The United States will continue to advocate against Iran's nuclear programme, as the world's top court reviews legislation which would curb Tehran’s programme, a senior U.S. diplomat told Reuters.
content: ['<p><p>The U.S. legal department will hold a hearing on Wednesday, it added.<p><p>Iran has been pushing for a comprehensive nuclear deal with the international community to stop the country from testing a nuclear weapon, and the world’s top court in October ordered a review of a 2014 law which was signed without Iran’s cooperation.<p><p>The Trump administration has threatened to block the landmark law, which would have allowed Tehran to develop a sophisticated missile, without a second international agreement.<p><p>U.S. lawmakers are expected to sign an executive order by the end of March. A date for such a review is not known.<p> ']

headline: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) said on Wednesday that it is looking into allegations it used a “deadline for processing information on its clients” in a $1.7 billion deal with internet giant Facebook Inc. (bit.ly/3kKkL8U)
content: ['<p>(This story corrects typo in paragraph 3)<p> ']

headline: Vault Innovation raises $140 million from equity fund
content: ['<p> -Vault Innovation, a technology company based in Massachusetts, said on Friday it has raised $140 million from private equity and the private investment arm of private equity fund DLA Piper.<p><p>The company will use the proceeds to build two new offices, one in its new home in Cambridge, Massachusetts and another in San Francisco, the company said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: U.S. company seeks “private” data to help fight fake news
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - A tech startup working to boost government response to misinformation says it has received a draft proposal from a technology firm seeking a private sector contract.<p><p>A spokesperson for The Data Alliance told Reuters the proposal was an effort to "fully support our mission" at The Data Alliance.<p><p>The proposed contract would allow companies to develop and sell data that can be used to bolster government response to misinformation.<p><p>A spokeswoman for The Data Alliance did not immediately respond to requests for comment.<p><p>The Data Alliance has received dozens of inquiries from lawmakers about government response, with some suggesting a private sector deal, others a public one.<p><p>The Data Alliance said the proposed contract would provide a “private-by-public” solution.<p><p>The proposal includes an online form and a website to be called “The Data Alliance Solution.”<p><p>The Data Alliance, which is being led by U.S. firm Ingersoll, hopes to enlist technology companies, civil society groups and other organizations to work together to create a public service, or public-private consortium, to help ensure government agencies do more to counter misinformation.<p> ']

headline: U.S. government accuses Iran of cyber attack against China
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - The U.S. government said on Thursday it has accused Iran of cyberattacks against China in retaliation for the U.S. move to ban Chinese imports from the United States, as a cyber attack was used to distract attention from an April visit by President Joe Biden and lawmakers to Beijing.<p><p>In a statement on Twitter, the State Department said it “has conducted a thorough and thorough and independent investigation and has found no evidence of any malicious intent” and that there is a “high degree of awareness of cyber threats” in Iran and China.<p><p>Iran denies the allegations. A U.S. House panel last week urged China to halt production of its own version of chips and other technology used in aircraft.<p><p>“We will continue to press the U.S. government to stop its actions to undermine the democratic process and to conduct countervailing diplomatic efforts,” a State Department spokesman said in a statement.<p><p>In Beijing, Biden has been meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi during a two-day visit to the island. He has called on the United States to lift sanctions against Tehran.<p><p>President Joe Biden met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Beijing on Thursday, the White House said.<p> ']

headline: Facebook to buy LinkedIn for $2.3 billion
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc on Tuesday announced it has completed a deal with LinkedIn, the online job-seeking company that has seen the U.S. search engine take in $2.3 billion in U.S. revenue.<p><p>The deal with LinkedIn came as a Facebook CEO had told Reuters he intended to buy the company for at least $2.3 billion. Facebook has not said how much it would buy.<p> ']

headline: U.S. Capitol panel investigating Russian hacking
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) on Wednesday said it would conduct a probe of alleged Russian interference in the United States election on Monday and send a report to lawmakers in coming weeks.<p><p>The panel, led by FTC Chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel, will examine how an April 2016 email from Microsoft Corp, dated May 7, 2016, communicated the U.S. government with the Russian government.<p><p>The email discussed the U.S. elections and the election results in the context of Russian interference in the elections.<p><p>FTC Chairwoman Raul DeSantis on Tuesday said the commission’s probe is underway. She did not name the Trump administration.<p> ']

headline: U.S. House Intel panel asks China to block U.S. election probe
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The House Energy and Commerce Committee on Thursday requested that a congressional panel investigate allegations that a U.S. election interference panel set a high bar for Chinese interference in U.S. elections, saying the United States needs to be prepared to impose the same high bar.<p><p>The panel, headed by Representative Ken Buck, who also chairs the U.S. Intelligence Committee, said the interference in the 2016 elections was "designed to damage U.S. national security."<p><p>It urged a congressional panel to hold the government accountable for "reducing the risk of a major disruption" in U.S. elections, but said a U.S. government inquiry should not be conducted at the behest of a foreign power.<p><p>The panel said it also asked the U.S. embassy in Beijing about alleged interference in U.S. elections as well as Chinese interference in election administration operations.<p><p>The probe was prompted by the firing of former Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson after his anti-China rhetoric was aired on state television.<p><p>The panel also said the United States should provide greater transparency and prevent Chinese hacking attacks on the U.S. government.<p><p>“We should provide more evidence about the extent of foreign interference in U.S. elections in order to evaluate whether the United States should have a more open, transparent process,” the panel said.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: China's largest bank has bought a huge chunk of cryptocurrency ETFs amid growing concerns over its trading behaviour
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s biggest lender Holding Group Corp, one of the most important financial regulators in the world, bought a massive chunk of cryptocurrency ETFs on Monday, joining a growing list of firms that are looking to unwind their holdings of the currency and its technology.<p><p>Binance, Alibaba’s parent bank, has been the dominant holding group for cryptocurrencies as of mid-January, having bought billions of digital tokens, bitcoin, ether and the blockchain ledger bitcoin.<p><p>China’s central bank has also bought bitcoin, ether, and a dozen other digital currencies, but it has yet to buy such digital currencies as bitcoin or bitcoin cash, Xinhua News Agency reported.<p><p>On Monday, it also purchased $1.25 billion in bitcoin, the most in Chinese history, a move that has infuriated the world’s largest cryptocurrency market, China Digital Capital Corp, whose stock is the second-largest private equity firm by assets under management.<p><p>The buying of the “China Digital Capital ETF” comes as China has tightened asset controls amid an increasingly assertive global financial market.<p><p>“We expect this trend to deepen as the world’s third-largest economy develops and continues to shift towards its normalcy,” a senior executive at Chinese bitcoin exchange Baidu Inc told Reuters.<p>']

headline: Exclusive: Google, Amazon plan to build first ever mobile payments network in China
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Google and Amazon will join a network to build the world’s first ever mobile payments network, a source close to the discussions told Reuters, as the tech giants seek to boost digital revenues in China and elsewhere.<p><p>The network, known as “Peer Payments”, is due to start in the second quarter of 2020.<p><p>The network will connect smartphone operators with companies that operate in the booming market for payments, where cash is king and the costs for merchants are rising rapidly.<p><p>“The platform could transform the way mobile payments is done and potentially make payment faster as companies try to become more diversified,” said the source, who asked not to be identified as the talks are private.<p><p>Peer Payments could be the most significant player in the payment industry, with around 500 billion yuan ($5.5 billion) of investments made by private investors this year, compared with the company’s $11 billion in total in 2020, according to Refinitiv data.<p><p>($1 = 0.8175 Chinese yuan renminbi)<p> ']

headline: Nokia to launch 'Pico', its first phone in Africa - media
content: ['<p>MADRID  - Nokia on Friday announced the launch of a smartphone app called Pico to rival rivals Nokia and Apple Inc, the first two mobile phone companies to offer exclusive deals in Africa, where there is a lack of traditional phone tariffs.<p><p>The Nokia-Nokia partnership has been seen as a key milestone for the 2 billion-strong smartphone market that will grow globally after Nokia launched the N8.<p><p>The new Nokia flagship smartphone is Nokia N9, a dual-core processor with 8 megabytes of RAM and 2,500 mAh battery. The flagship Nokia N10, a dual-core processor with 8 megabytes of RAM and 2,500 mAh battery, is due to launch in late spring and is expected to come in three colours.<p><p>The Finnish telecommunications giant will be in South Africa at the end of March and will use a Nokia-designed 5G network chip for its Nokia 6.<p> ']

headline: New York Times' Scott Sumner on Twitter, 'Doomed' book review: 'The tech news of 2021
content: ["<p>Check out what's clicking on FoxBusiness.com.au.<p><p>“What's the big story of 2021,” Sumner asked Fox Business’s Scott Sumner to discuss.<p><p>“What's the big story of 2021,” Sumner replied. “Something that we discussed for the whole segment.”<p><p>While the world’s largest tech news outlet did not immediately respond to a request for comment, the New York Times did not block Sumner’s Twitter account.<p><p>The New York Times said last month it had blocked Sumner’s Twitter account for two hours. It added the suspension was temporary and no longer effective.<p><p>Facebook said earlier in January it had blocked Sumner’s accounts for two hours after he posted a tweet urging people not to buy Amazon Web Services (AWS) plans. The social media giant said Sumner “has been blocked for two hours on accounts that have not received a notice of removal and which we are investigating and believe are malicious.”<p><p>The ban stemmed from an incident last week where Sumner’s Twitter account was blocked for several hours for an unrelated tweet by a user saying he was trying to buy the Facebook-linked Amazon Cloud Video subscription service. Sumner also did not mention the tweet by Facebook when reporting about it.<p>"]

headline: Rochester has opened a new warehouse for its new robot manufacturing factory
