content: ['<p> - Rochester-based U.S. automaker Rovian Robotics has opened a new warehouse in Detroit, Michigan for its new robot manufacturing lab, the U.S. automaker announced on Monday.<p><p>The U.S. automaker will build the factory, located in the Detroit area of Lansing and include the factory with its future self-driving and self-driving car prototypes.<p><p>The U.S. automaker has been manufacturing robotics products for several major automakers since 2014.<p><p>“We have been very fortunate to be able to develop a large and highly profitable market that we believe has the potential to revolutionize our entire automotive industry and bring new life into the auto industry,” said Rovian Chief Executive Officer Andrew Laidlaw.<p><p>The Lansing-based facility is housed in an existing warehouse in North Lansing, Michigan. In December, Rovian secured a lease in Detroit from Detroit-based Lansing-based Axial Auto and Refinitiv.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Chinese tech company Tencent's 'Top Ten' list could be pulled out after Chinese app ban - sources
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - Tencent Holdings’s app listing could become ineligible for a global tech blacklist by the start-up’s South Korea unit, two people close to the matter told Reuters.<p><p>The app listing is expected to go through later this month or mid-2019.<p><p>Tencent did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.<p><p>Tencent has been under pressure from tech giants for slowing down or slowing down the pace at which app developers run their apps. Last year, the world’s biggest mobile payments company suspended the sale of its popular mobile payments app Square, citing “security concerns”.<p><p>The company last month barred its South Korean mobile payments app, the Seoul app, for six months after it flagged “significant security issues”.<p><p>The company last year halted the listing of Tencent’s Kuaichi apps after they flagged a “significant security breach” that the South Korean company said it would rectify immediately.<p><p>Tencent has been in negotiations with China’s Zhejiang Tencent Holdings Corp, or ZT Holdings to sell its U.S. and Hong Kong units, to acquire U.S. shares.<p>']

headline: Bitcoin loses its top spot as cryptocurrency price surges
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin on Monday declined sharply to settle at a five-year high of $58, while the broader cryptocurrency lost its lead among major stock exchanges.<p><p>The cryptocurrency has soared over the past year and a half to a record high of $58,354, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.<p><p>Bitcoin has fallen over 60% so far this year from its peak of $58,346 in January 2019, which triggered a rally in its price. The cryptocurrency has rallied over 1,400% so far this year from a peak of $58,348 in February 2019.<p><p>The volatile price of bitcoin has also been hit by a pandemic-fueled collapse that wiped out some $12 trillion of private wealth at the beginning of the year, causing a huge surge in the price.<p><p>Analysts had forecast bitcoin would rise this year in the range of $61,000 to $64,000, following its recent move to a record high of $61,922 on Monday. The cryptocurrency was trading around $62,000 before hitting a lower end range on Tuesday.<p><p>Bitcoin was last up 0.3% at $58,354.<p> ']

headline: Facebook's CEO to join U.S. Capitol Hill press briefing in January: source
content: ['<p> - Facebook Inc executive Mark Zuckerberg is expected to join the Capitol Hill press briefing, according to a person familiar with the matter.<p><p>Zuckerberg will spend the next few months at a closed-door congressional hearing on the company’s controversial data collection practices and will also be accompanied by a White House staff and journalists.<p><p>Zuckerberg is also expected to testify before Congress regarding Facebook’s role in voter registration, privacy and online advertising.<p><p>Facebook has long been the subject of scrutiny by the Senate Intelligence Committee and the White House.<p><p>Zuckerberg is expected to testify at a hearing this month on Google’s self-driving cars.<p><p>His appearance is likely to draw a flurry of questioning from representatives of lawmakers, one of whom is a Democrat, and a former Facebook executive.<p> ']

headline: Greenspoint's Chief Executive: Google could have more to gain by launching a new Google+, app
content: ['<p> - Chief Executive of the online retailer Greenspoint Jeffery Gifford said on Monday that Google might have more to gain by launching a new Google+, app.<p><p>Gifford, a former Microsoft executive, is planning to launch a new app that would let users search, search and share his work online. The company could even offer the same tools to some of its users on its own.<p><p>The chief executive said Google could have a bigger impact by allowing users to buy and download new apps.<p><p>Gifford said his company was in discussions with Google about launching its own Google+, app.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Chinese tech firm Xiaomi is in talks to invest over $100 million in U.S. electric vehicle project
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Chinese software company Xiaomi Group said on Tuesday it has agreed to commit $100 million to help the U.S.-based company transition to electric vehicles (EVs) as it looks to expand in China.<p><p>“Xiaomi has committed to invest over $100 million in electric vehicle development in the United States,” a Xiaomi spokesperson said in an emailed statement.<p><p>Xiaomi said in December it was partnering with Tesla Motors to develop a hydrogen fuel cell vehicle (HFC) that would deliver electric vehicle charging from a battery pack to consumers.<p><p>The company has been in talks with Tesla and U.S. electric vehicle makers about buying a stake in the company, it said.<p><p>The two companies have been at odds for years over policy issues related to the expansion of EVs.<p><p>In December, Tesla CEO Elon Musk said Tesla and rival EV charging service Ola could be merged under his existing deal to provide customers with low-carbon, electric vehicles.<p><p>Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p> ']

headline: Sydney, California-based blockchain firm Chainalysis offers guidance on bitcoin, tokens, and cryptocurrencies
content: ['<p> - Bitcoin, the world’s most popular cryptocurrency, is a type of token that has been used in a wide range of businesses, from grocery delivery firms to online retail trade platforms.<p><p>“We think bitcoin, as it has become used more broadly in the marketplace, is a very valuable asset that will continue to grow and expand,” said co-founder John Davidson, chief technology officer at Chainalysis.<p><p>Bitcoin has a market capitalization of nearly $7 billion, with Bitcoin Cash at around $45 billion.<p><p>Trading in cryptocurrencies in general has been booming in recent months due to the ease of payment, especially with the recent wave of digital cash payments.<p><p>Chainalysis, a blockchain technology company, focuses on the mining, trading and storage of digital currencies and cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin and ether.<p> ']

headline: Honda makes 'zero-downtime' profit in its EV and hydrogen electric hybrid production deals, U.S. regulatory report shows
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Honda Motor Co Inc on Thursday released its first quarterly profit in six months for the first time since the automaker said it planned to lower its EV and hydrogen production costs to help meet demand.<p><p>The company said it planned to reduce U.S. and international vehicle production by at least a third and make a profit on that.<p><p>The U.S. auto industry has been struggling with a shortage of diesel vehicles that are expected to impact U.S. and European customers, including electric vehicles. But the company says its electric vehicle range is growing and it expects demand to continue to grow even as demand increases.<p><p>Honda said in its quarterly earnings release the company was expected to earn $4.35 billion from sales of its fuel cell electric vehicles, including zero-emission vehicles. The company forecast a profit of $4.35 billion, including cash flow, for the fiscal first quarter ended Dec. 31, 2020.<p><p>The company said the profit margin for its electric vehicles and hydrogen vehicles would be less than 15%, compared with an earnings estimate of $2.45 billion.<p><p>The company also said it expected a 2.7% revenue margin to be lower than its guidance of 4% for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31, 2020.<p> ']

headline: Mountain View, California-based company PEARL-CBN Group says $11 billion in funding, including $12 billion from Chinese investors
content: ['<p> - Mountain View, California-based PEARL-CBN Group Inc said on Friday it had secured funding of $11 billion from Chinese investors for a $9.5 billion multi-year initiative to increase its customer base and improve customer service.<p><p>The company said it expects the project will add around $3.5 billion to customers by 2023, up from $1.3 billion a year ago. It said PEARL-CBN expects its customers to increase in demand and enhance their business in the coming years.<p><p>The partnership includes an investment of $12.5 billion, including $7.5 billion from venture capital funds, PEARL-CBN’s Chief Executive Officer Michael Gershon said.<p><p>The Palo Alto-based company is planning several corporate initiatives, including new wireless data centers, augmented reality headsets and virtual reality gaming headsets for businesses.<p><p>PEARL-CBN was founded in 2018 to serve clients in a range of industries, including healthcare, finance, entertainment, healthcare, logistics and information technology.<p><p>It has worked with over 5,000 companies in the U.S., Europe and Asia.<p> ']

headline: Laser-based chips from Chinese firm LIGAMAR take on Apple
content: ['<p>SHANGHAI  - China’s LIGAMAR-based chip supplier, LIGAMAR-2, said on Monday that it would challenge Apple’s chip business in the first of three series of its “deep learning chips”.<p><p>The move is the first time that LIGAMAR has achieved such a rapid and sustained market growth, it said in a statement.<p><p>In a statement to Reuters, LIGAMAR’s CEO Yifan Zheng said the new “deep learning” chip “will revolutionise the way we think about AI and data analytics”.<p> ']

headline: Nokia to set up Nokia-owned technology center in Korea
content: ['<p>LAS VEGAS  - Nokia Inc and its Korean division, NXP, are set to start work on a joint venture to set up a new technology center in Korea with Nokia-owned technology platform Nokia Innovation, the world’s biggest telecom equipment maker said on Tuesday.<p><p>The companies will collaborate on innovative technologies and in the development of new smartphone innovations to create new opportunities, said NXP’s founder and CEO Meng Wan-young.<p><p>Meng, an investor in Nokia, will work with Nokia Innovation for the joint venture.<p><p>Nokia is a key global player in smartphone software. It has a 20% stake in Nokia’s mobile operating system business, which makes mobile operating systems such as the Nokia 7, Nokia 8 and Nokia N10.<p><p>The joint venture will provide the expertise needed to develop new smartphones using Nokia technologies and technologies and its products will be developed with the expertise of Nokia Innovation and Nokia, NXP said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Greenspace hits a record-breaking 50 million monthly active users, topping Facebook
content: ['<p>NEW YORK  - Greenspace Inc, an online dating service in Greensport, N.J., said on Thursday that its monthly active users were up 70% year-to-date in 2019.<p><p>The company’s website showed 1.1 billion monthly active users in the U.S. over last year, up from just over 1.4 billion in 2020.<p><p>Greenspace said its weekly active users grew by 5.1% year-to-date and exceeded Facebook’s estimate of 5.9 million. (reut.rs/2KvU7oL)<p><p>The company posted a new product for its users this week that allows users to make a special offer, known as a "hot spot."<p><p>Users can make all types of offers available to their friends for free, but those who make a special offer have the option to take advantage of a discount.<p> ']

headline: SoftBank mulls move to U.S. as part of Asia chip chip deal
content: ['<p> - SoftBank Corp said on Tuesday it was exploring a new entity to help Japan chipmaker SK Innovation grow in the United States through a deal with a blank-check company, though it is not clear if it is willing to accept a lower share price.<p><p>The decision to make SK Innovation a blank-check company comes amid growing signs the chip industry is moving quickly to build its own chips from scratch and has prompted concerns from lawmakers that chipmakers may face regulatory scrutiny if they continue to make chips with questionable quality or design.<p><p>SK Innovation declined to comment.<p> ']

headline: Greensburg: 'Nashville' to join Dutch bank Morgan Stanley as first European expansion banks, after listing in Netherlands
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Dutch investment bank Morgan Stanley on Wednesday said it would join a group of Dutch expansion banks, following a merger of three existing Dutch firms.<p><p>Morgan Stanley said its Dutch expansion banks will become independent and be in close collaboration with Morgan Stanley in the coming years.<p><p>The expansion banks were set up in 2020 to raise funds and capital to begin capital expansion within the next five years.<p><p>Morgan Stanley said in a statement the new companies “will provide financing for Dutch expansion banks” based on “significant capital and regulatory capacity.”<p><p>Morgan Stanley said it would provide financing in three different areas including the expansion banks’ new capital, “digital banking” and the expansion banks’ new services, and” “will provide technical support to new expansion banks to meet the expansion needs of the new expansion banks.”<p><p>Morgan Stanley said it expected to receive a “significant capital increase” as a result of this move and that a further increase was expected from the completion of the merger in 2022.<p> ']

headline: White House counsel asks Google to address complaints from tech platforms about 'disruption' of government email and social media
content: ['<p> - The White House Counsel’s Office on Wednesday asked Google to address complaints from tech platforms about “disruption” of government email and social media accounts.<p><p>The requests come days after the Justice Department on Tuesday ordered the U.S. Justice Department to investigate a complaint by Alphabet Inc’s Google that the government is forcing its messaging app WhatsApp Inc to turn off its services.<p><p>“Google is not providing any assistance to resolve these concerns,” White House press secretary Jay Clayton said in a statement.<p><p>“This action demonstrates that the president is not addressing these concerns directly and that the government should not be able to intrude into its communications and communications networks to obtain sensitive information.”<p> ']

headline: U.S. firms are forced to work without paid family members and staff at jobs including Apple, Amazon
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Companies across the U.S. are forced to work with their workers and colleagues without pay or benefits, a practice that critics say is tantamount to forced labor.<p><p>“The only way to get paid is to work from home,” said U.S. Representative Susan Collins, a Republican from Georgia. “We have to make sure we are providing all of our employees the dignity and security they deserve and deserve.”<p><p>In the United States, employees working from home are subject to retaliation if they go on strike or face discrimination based on sexual orientation or disability, according to a 2009 Federal Bureau of Investigation report.<p><p>Workers’ unions have long fought such practices at the workplace. It is common for companies, and employers themselves, to deny benefits and make employees pay for working from home.<p><p>U.S. employers include auto, chemical and electrical companies, food delivery companies, and insurance companies. The National Labor Relations Board in Washington, DC, which oversees the U.S. Department of Labor, has issued guidance calling for a shift away from this practice and towards voluntary work.<p><p>In 2016, the Justice Department issued guidance calling for federal employees to use the “public sector” exception to avoid discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and disability. The same year, the agency ordered companies to take voluntary steps to provide workers with a livable wage without discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or disability.']

headline: JPMorgan buys German technology firm Hausdorff to create new data centre
content: ['<p>MILAN  - Deutsche Bank Group said on Thursday it had acquired Hausdorff data centre operator M&A Technology to create a new data centre in Italy, as Germany’s technology giant seeks to attract more large tech companies.<p><p>A consortium of data centres is set to open in Milan later this year, and M&A operates a data centre for over 30,000 companies in Spain, Italy and Spain.<p> ']

headline: Bitcoin rises to new record high after bitcoin's latest rise
content: ['<p>MILAN  - Bitcoin’s latest rally has lifted the hopes of some investors that a surge in the price could help revive the world’s biggest cryptocurrency, even as some argue it has lost steam.<p><p>Bitcoin’s recent gains have been fueled by an unprecedented surge in the price of cryptocurrencies during the coronavirus pandemic. But on Tuesday, a group of investors who are skeptical of bitcoin’s future could finally rally some momentum.<p><p>Billionaire investor Jim Bell was one of the first to suggest it would be a good time for the cryptocurrency to rally in the latest weeks or months, adding that he expected it to increase again on Tuesday, adding that he would like it to stay above $1,000 this month.<p><p>Bitcoin’s price was recently above $72,000, beating the record high on Feb. 11 at $72,000.<p><p>Some investors who bet against bitcoin are now warning that it might not be able to recover from the recent slump.<p><p>Investors who hold bitcoin as an investment vehicle are betting that the price of the cryptocurrency will rise again, with some predicting a rally that would reach about $100 this month.<p><p>“If I were betting against bitcoin I would bet against $80 in 10 years,” said Michael Covington, an analyst at market analysis firm BAM Investment.<p>']

headline: PBS News takes Amazon to task on 'fake news'
content: ['<p> - News Network Inc’s NewsCorp is taking the U.S. telecommunications company to task for its treatment of news outlets, the network’s chief executive said on Thursday.<p><p>The company has previously criticized news outlets for not being transparent about content and reporting on issues affecting its users.<p><p>The company’s latest challenge to News Corp comes as the company seeks to shore up its online presence following a string of incidents related to the COVID-19 pandemic.<p> ']

headline: Towerfall and Deliveroo to launch new cloud-based services in Germany
content: ['<p>MILAN  - Towerfall has said it is launching a new cloud-based services in Germany after its German affiliate announced plans on Thursday to launch its own in-house cloud-based platform.<p><p>Towerfall said it will be partnering with e-commerce firm Square to help customers with their orders by merging its existing platforms.<p><p>Square will also provide customer feedback on what to install,’s what to do with users and “how they compare with customers”, it said.<p> ']

headline: A U.S. judge has blocked Alphabet’s Google from using its dominant Android software in its antitrust case, saying it failed to protect customers’ data.
content: ['<p> - Alphabet’s Google has blocked the use of its dominant Android software in its antitrust case, challenging it’s decisions to block rivals’ apps on a range of platforms, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday, in a major setback to a U.S. law aimed at protecting consumers’ privacy and competition.<p><p>The high court said Google’s actions “have demonstrated a lack of urgency,” without naming the company.<p><p>In a decision that may have implications in the future, the justices also dismissed arguments that the company failed to protect customers’ data in its decisions in antitrust cases that were filed in 2018 and 2019.<p><p>The justices rejected arguments that Google’s actions were inconsistent with the law’s “conscience” requirement that states give up to half their data protection powers for non-essential purposes.<p><p>“In some cases, a state may not give up a certain amount of protection to customers,” the justices wrote. "In others, a state may not provide some type of reasonable protection to customers.”<p>']

headline: Etsy says it will remove its e-commerce listing after ban
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - E-commerce firm Square said on Tuesday it will remove its listing after the ban on the e-commerce site was lifted in a week following a trade dispute between Taiwan and China.<p><p>Square has not yet submitted an application for listing, with the application only expected to be submitted in a few days, the company said.<p> ']

headline: EU antitrust watchdog to probe the U.S. tech giants' dominance in the tech sector
content: ['<p>STOCKHOLM  - The European Commission on Thursday set a preliminary probe into U.S. tech giants such as Google, Facebook, Amazon.com Inc and Alphabet’s Google, according to a document seen by Reuters.<p><p>The probe is led by the EU Commission’s antitrust authority (EC), the bloc’s executive arm.<p><p>The document said a preliminary inquiry into Google, Facebook and Amazon would provide an update on the probe to all members of the European Union’s 24-member Economic and Financial Affairs Council.<p><p>It would also give final approval to new legislation that would clarify the rules of a competitive environment for companies in the United States, the document said.<p><p>($1 = 0.8265 euros)<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal extends past as it passes the Dutch embassy
content: ['<p> - A large section of the canal has been closed to traffic and oil shipments to the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) have been delayed for a week, forcing the canal authority to close parts of the stretch of land it owns.<p><p>A canal operator said on Wednesday that the blockage caused by the dredging, which began on Thursday, would last until Saturday, with deliveries likely to come in as early as Saturday.<p> ']

headline: Elder Scrolls Online adds more dungeons, adds more horror
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The official website for Elder Scrolls Online added more new content in the online world of Middle-earth on Wednesday, bringing the total to 16 new dungeons to fill in the gap left by the release of the critically-acclaimed fourth expansion, according to data released by developer BioWare.<p><p>The number of new dungeons increased by 31 to 6,343, bringing the total of additional content to 4.8 million square feet, compared with 4.5 million square feet left for the last expansion, BioWare said.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal ships continue to operate despite dredging efforts
content: ['<p>EGYPT  -Suez Canal vessels continue to operate despite ongoing dredging efforts to dislodge giant sand dune-sized sand dune, according to the manager of the canal agency and a senior official on the vessel’s navigation system.<p><p>Last week, four vessels carrying large amounts of sand dune-sized sand dune-shaped sand dune sank off the Bosphorus in the Suez Canal, in what the World Health Organization called a “potentially catastrophic failure”.<p><p>The giant dune has become a symbol of the cost of dredging, said the World Health Organization’s Sibel Kuchma, referring to the sunken vessels.<p><p>“It’s a disaster that’s destabilizing,” Kuchma told Reuters. “Unfortunately, the boats continued to operate.”<p><p>The vessels included two helicopters with 32 crew members and were searching for the giant sand dune that was washed up by the sand dune in the Suez Canal.<p><p>Kuchma said that the dredgers at the site had also found sand on the shore of a canal bank and had moved to remove it and another vessel.<p> ']

headline: Greece to start trial of new vaccine, not vaccine-maker - health ministry
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - Greece is hoping to start a trial of its new COVID-19 vaccine after a spate of coronavirus variants hit the Greek market last month, the Health Ministry said on Wednesday.<p><p>The trial is due to start soon but will not take place before Easter, the ministry said in a statement, contradicting earlier assertions by the country’s top health official.<p><p>The Health Ministry said that the AstraZeneca shot was the first vaccine it had tested with a highly contagious variant of COVID-19 which it had linked to lower blood platelets and a high rate of bleeding.<p> ']

headline: Biden tells lawmakers to be ready for COVID-19 pandemic - White House
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden told lawmakers on Thursday to be prepared for the coronavirus pandemic, which has left tens of millions of Americans without access to healthcare and thousands of new COVID-19 infections, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said.<p> ']

headline: Rescuers search for missing Malaysia Airlines jet after impact with sea
content: ['<p>AMMAN  - Rescue workers and rescuers raced to find the jet that struck the southern Dutch town of Lofa in the northern Indonesian archipelago, but a plane that had just struck the town in its path was heading towards the town, a rescue official said on Wednesday.<p><p>Search efforts were hampered by high winds as rescuers raced to try to get an aircraft to approach, a government official told Reuters.<p><p>The plane had just entered an area of low visibility in a cyclone zone, the official added.<p><p>Sudan Airlines said it would resume flights to Lofa after a weather agency reported it was being hit by a cyclone on Wednesday evening.<p><p>The airline said it was conducting a full investigation into the cause of the crash.<p> ']

headline: A man, 30, dies after being pinned down in Bangkok's Khong Klaip Thi district after being shot and beaten to death, police said
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - An elderly Thai man who was killed on Friday in Bangkok’s Khong Klaip Thi district after being pinned down by unidentified assailants, police said said on Saturday, the latest in a series of deaths in the Thai capital since police launched a nationwide investigation into Sunday’s attack.<p><p>Police said they had arrested 20 people on Thursday after finding shots in the man’s abdomen, head and leg after he was found lying in a park with gunshot wounds to his torso.<p><p>Thai authorities on Saturday released a statement saying the victims’ families had been informed.<p><p>“It was the first time the family has heard of this type of attack since Monday,” it said.<p><p>Police Commissioner Maung Kyaw Khatchirong told a news conference that police had recorded 12 new deaths in the three days to March 14.<p><p>Authorities said at least 14 people had been killed so far in Bangkok and the capital, where anti-government protests are taking place each week.<p><p>The death toll also rose to 21 after three other suspects were arrested after being questioned on Tuesday, Kyaw said.<p>']

headline: U.S. President Joe Biden signs COVID-19 safety executive order on Wednesday
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. President’s executive order protecting consumers from COVID-19 is expected to give the FDA authority to impose new restrictions on the manufacture and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines, Biden’s White House said on Wednesday.<p><p>Under the Trump administration, which Biden has called a “miracle,” the U.S. government is seeking “to secure the safety and efficacy of vaccines in the United States,” the White House said in a statement.<p><p>The order is expected to be signed into law by President Biden, who has called for universal access to vaccines and the use of them for all Americans.<p><p>While he did not specifically mention the order by name, Biden said in February that “people’ are already getting vaccines,” and added that “we will soon be using every vaccine we can’t wait to get around this.”<p> ']

headline: Thailand's top prosecutor says the death penalty should be death penalty, says former president
content: ['<p>Thailand’s top prosecutor on Wednesday said the death penalty should be death penalty, calling the country’s current death penalty system “a complete joke.”<p><p>“In a country like Thailand, when you are the head of a state that has gone out of its way to kill and maim people, when you commit crimes with the death penalty, what does the state do?” Secretary-General Prayuth Chan-ocha told a news conference.<p><p>In November, the Thai government said it had convicted a former military commander of killing six soldiers during a crackdown on protests. But the generals say the case is still closed to the public and they face trial in absentia.<p><p>Prayuth said there should be no new or amended legislation that criminalizes the killing of civilians, citing a 2011 Supreme Court ruling on capital punishment.<p><p>“In fact, if there is no such law, it is very hard to distinguish between a capital punishment violation and a crime against humanity,” he told the news conference.<p><p>He said Thailand would press ahead with implementing the death penalty.<p><p>Thailand, however, is grappling with an increased number of coronavirus cases since the country was hit hard by the pandemic. Deaths from the coronavirus are rising again.<p>']

headline: Kremlin says Ukraine's military buildup threatens security
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Monday it did not recognise any Ukrainian military buildup near Ukraine, in a sharp rebalancing of the standoff over Ukraine’s eastern border and Crimea.<p><p>“We have not raised the issue of a military buildup or military confrontation with Ukraine,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters. “There is no military presence in the Donbass region. There is no such thing as a military buildup,” he said, referring to separatist territory in Ukraine’s eastern Donbass region.<p><p>Russian military aircraft entered Ukraine’s airspace on Tuesday, according to U.S. and European officials.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny is being held in a Moscow prison. He was on hunger strike for weeks last year.
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Alexei Navalny is being held in a Moscow prison, his lawyers said on Saturday, under house arrest, on charges of attempted coup.<p><p>He was on hunger strike on Friday after an anti-government protest in which four protesters were killed and more than 600 injured. The Kremlin said last week that Navalny had received treatment at the prison hospital in the port city of Myshtyba in eastern Siberia, where he was admitted.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal salvage team restores missing ship
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The giant container ship that was missing from the Suez Canal in 2018 had been found, salvage team leader Abdelhamid Abunim told Reuters.<p><p>He said the ship’s hull had also been dislodged and the vessel would arrive back at home.<p> ']

headline: 'A lot of people are here': Myanmar protesters in Turkey\'s Istanbul protest march
content: ['<p>ISTANBUL  - The peaceful and politically engaged march of demonstrators on Tuesday in Istanbul’s Istanbul Square drew more than 600 people, Turkish authorities said.<p><p>About 250 were arrested in a demonstration against Myanmar’s military junta and hundreds detained in what Ankara described as unlawful clashes.<p><p>The violence, which has caused a humanitarian crisis in Myanmar and sparked anger in Turkey, is also taking place in Istanbul.<p><p>“The Turkish authorities need to immediately arrest the leaders of the protesters and the junta leaders for what they are doing. Their actions today are not welcome,” the Istanbul Police tweeted on Wednesday.<p><p>Protests also took place at Istanbul’s Istanbul Square in protest at the army’s use of lethal force in clashes that have killed a total of 13 people since the coup in Myanmar.<p><p>The Istanbul police also detained six people in a military detention centre after one of the detainees, identified as 22-year-old Anwar Ibrahim, tweeted about his detention.<p><p>“I am being moved here by the soldiers. Please respect and protect the human rights of all the detainees.” the 22-year-old wrote.<p><p>In Ankara, protesters pelted police with stones after they said that the junta leaders had failed to safeguard democracy in Myanmar and should instead move abroad.<p>']

headline: Suez Canal Authority 'came under attack' after dredging began
content: ['<p>JOHANNESBURG  - Suez Canal Authority (SCA) chief executive Peter Semenbeke said on Friday that vessels in the Suez Canal were coming under attack from unknown pirates who wanted to take control of the canal.<p><p>Ansculating the incident, he said the water was being diverted in two sections, the outer and outer reaches of the canal, and that it had begun breaking apart during the dredging operation.<p> ']

headline: Honduran troops seize disputed key oil fields in northwest
content: ['<p>ARUQUITA, Honduras — Honduran military forces seized key oilfield in northwest Honduras on Saturday as part of an ongoing push to secure resources for an oil refinery that the United States is seeking to build on the southern tip of Lake Victoria.<p><p>The three-carat diamond pipe, which was refloated earlier this week, is one of several oilfields that are the center of a conflict in the north, which has killed tens of thousands of people and drawn international condemnation.<p><p>The Honduran government says it has ordered more drilling to protect vulnerable sectors such as fishing boats and oil companies. The United States says more oil production could be added to the disputed reservoir, where roughly 4,600 barrels of crude per day (bpd) is stored.<p><p>The seized pipeline is located north of the town of Jalisco, about 15 miles south of town, according to U.S. Special Envoy for the People Brandon Lewis.<p><p>“These operations would provide a lifeline for our security forces in the Central American country,” Lewis said.<p><p>Honduras has an oil production of nearly 1.4 billion bpd. The conflict has killed more than 11,000 people and has displaced tens of thousands of Hondurans.<p>']

headline: Czech PM Biden urges calm
content: ['<p>CHICAGO  - Czech Prime Minister Boyko Borissov urged the international community on Tuesday to "reach a constructive and constructive point of view" with President Joe Biden, and warned against “the negative and destabilizing consequences” of Brexit.<p> ']

headline: Istanbul's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah says anti-Semitism still prevalent
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah said on Saturday that anti-Semitism still persisted in Turkey, adding that the state has to deal with it.<p><p>Bolson said anti-Semitism remained prevalent in Turkey as of Sunday night, when authorities imposed a three-month ban on social media to combat rising anti-Semitism in the country.<p> ']

headline: Ousted Australian Labor MP accuses Chinese foreign minister of trying to undermine Australian sovereignty
content: ['<p>AUSTRALIA  - Australia’s foreign minister has called on China’s foreign minister on Saturday to clarify whether Australian sovereignty has been breached under his predecessor’s leadership of Prime Minister Scott Morrison.<p><p>Morrison’s premiership is widely seen as a test of whether Australians can be assured they can remain in the country.<p> ']

headline: A senior official of the Philippines’ foreign ministry has spoken out against a crackdown on illegal immigration and urged the international community to join its campaign against the pandemic.
content: ['<p><p>Ricardo Guedes, the foreign ministry’s spokesman, told a news conference on Wednesday that the Philippines was in the path of “full transparency and accountability” under the coronavirus pandemic, which led to massive migration and forced the closure of schools and hospitals.<p><p>“We are convinced that the international community must make a concerted effort in order to help the Philippines through the pandemic,” Guedes said. “It is our call. The international community must join together in this effort,” he added, calling for the international community to protect people of all ages.<p><p>Guedes said the Philippines was ready to engage with the international community to halt the pandemic.<p> ']

headline: Finance Minister's remarks on India's railways
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - Finance Minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the railways were failing and promised to ensure speedy and speedy re-opening of the country’s railway system.<p><p>“We are very happy that India’s railways are on the path of bringing all the people of India through this process,” Jaitley told a news conference.<p><p>“We are still dealing with (malicious) cases and they continue to be reported.”<p> ']

headline: Mixed messages are exchanged at funeral of fallen British fighter pilot
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - British and French officials exchanged messages on Sunday about the loss of a British pilot killed by insurgents near the southern province of North Rhine-Westphalia, the Foreign Office said.<p><p>Britain was “deeply saddened” by the deaths of British pilots, a senior government spokeswoman said.<p><p>“The loss of this man was a tragic event for all involved,” the spokeswoman said. “Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family and loved ones.”<p><p>The United States, Canada, Germany and Britain have all condemned the deaths of the pilots, who were all on strike against insurgents in the far eastern Bitter Lake province.<p><p>“We are deeply saddened and concerned by the terrible loss of these young men,” spokeswoman Victoria Ellis said in a statement.<p><p>Prime Minister Boris Johnson said last month that he had discussed the civilian toll at the funeral of the pilot.<p><p>On Sunday, a memorial service for the pilot, John Boyce, was held in the British city of Wolverhampton after he was killed during an air strike by rebels near North Rhine-Westphalia on Friday.<p><p>British military officials said the aircraft, which were carrying out exercises, had been tracking a suspected Islamist attack near Bitter Lake.<p> ']

headline: Handsome rules make the West Bank and Gaza illegal, but others make it harder
content: ['<p>YEMEN, Israel — The West Bank and Gaza have become a flashpoint in a decades-old conflict that has created a fertile base for Hamas, Israel’s militant movement.<p><p>A decade after Israel withdrew from a 1967 lines of separation, Hamas still controls large swaths of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, though its territorial gains have dwindled.<p><p>A ceasefire has been declared since 2006 by the internationally recognized government, but Hamas faces an uphill climb.<p><p>Hamas and Israel have fought wars since 1948, the latest conflict spilling over into a conflict with the Islamic militant group that has killed 14,000 Palestinians since it declared a ceasefire in 2011.<p><p>In recent months, Israel and the United States have been at loggerheads, with both calling for Israel to end the military occupation in its territory and the other opposing a negotiated settlement, but Israel remains firmly opposed to any unilateral action that would create new barriers to its existence, and is even openly calling for a return to military rule.<p><p>Israel, which has never been seen to agree to an agreement, is trying to stoke public anger with a series of measures designed to stifle independent and popular protests.<p><p>On Thursday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu signed a peace agreement that would allow Palestinians to organize their own elections, establish a political agency, and establish a civilian judiciary to handle disputes.<p>']

headline: Grimwood, India, says a'significant' loss in COVID-19 deaths and infections: WHO
content: ['<p>Grimwood, India, a world leader in COVID-19 vaccination efforts, has said it is confident the virus will recover in the second half of the year and a full recovery will take at least three to four months.<p><p>But it has said the return to normalisation of vaccination protocols for most non-COVID-19 recipients is likely to be slower than expected as new infections continue to be detected in some cities.<p><p>“There is still a significant loss of life from COVID-19 and we need to continue to provide more vaccines,” said Ghaith Bhushan, the head of the GVA programme, a global vaccination campaign targeting the poorest parts of India.<p><p>“There are still significant losses in the population,” she told a news conference.<p><p>Grimwood, India’s biggest vaccine maker, has said it has a “critical mass” of COVID-19-infected people, of whom more than 90% were aged over 60, and expects to make an estimated “significant” recovery in two to three months.<p><p>Ghaith said the government has set targets for the rest of India to get a “full recovery” in the second half of the year, with deliveries of 400 million doses expected to be in place by the end of September.<p>']

headline: U.N. envoy calls for swift and impartial investigation into China's alleged human rights abuses
content: ['<p>UNITED NATIONS  - U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Jeffrey Delingpole called for a swift and impartial investigation into alleged human rights abuses by Chinese authorities on Thursday, warning of a growing international outcry over its treatment of dissidents and rights abuses by Beijing.<p><p>Delingpole also voiced concern over the "systemic abuse" of political prisoners on the island of Hanoi by Chinese authorities.<p><p>He said he had spoken with representatives of human rights organizations and U.N. human rights experts who were concerned by China’s treatment of prisoners at Hanoi and that they would discuss the matter with the administration of Chinese President Xi Jinping.<p><p>Delingpole also called for the full participation of the international community in “uniting efforts to end the human rights abuses and the abuses at Hanoi,” adding that he hoped the United Nations would “reassure that China continues to respect its obligations under international law, and has no plans to renege on its obligations under U.N. law.”<p><p>“The international community must make efforts to reach an agreement on the implementation of the United Nations Convention against Torture against the People’s Republic of China,” Delingpole said.<p><p>China accuses the United States of supporting human rights abuses in its campaign to force its western neighbours to recognise it and the rights of its people.<p> ']

headline: The United Nations has accused Myanmar of genocide after Myanmar's army says soldiers killed hundreds of civilians in clashes near its border with China - state media
content: ['<p> - Human rights groups and officials said on Monday that an army base near the border with China’s Hpakhet province could be a crime scene.<p><p>In a statement, Amnesty International said the Chinese military had targeted the area with stones and thrown Molotov cocktails and rubber bullets in one of its bases on Monday, a day after Myanmar’s army said soldiers shot dead at least seven civilians in clashes near its border with China’s border province of Banten.<p><p>The United Nations says Myanmar’s security forces continue to target “dangerous” civilians in the disputed border area, which separates the two countries’ borders.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin says it is ready to give Ukraine access to Eurovision 2019 song contest
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia’s decision to give Ukraine access to the Eurovision song contest’s musical contest on Sunday was “good news” for the country that has struggled to host the contest for over three decades.<p><p>Ukraine is hoping the Eurovision contest’s final winner will be selected from among Russia’s 11 countries, who make up a broad bloc, along with other competitions.<p><p>Russia is also considering whether to give Ukraine access to the competition once Eurovision has concluded, a senior Kremlin spokesman said, referring to the April 14 vote.<p><p>Ukraine and Russia have fought a conflict they called the “Cold War” over territorial claims in the Donbass region of the former Soviet Union.<p><p>Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, speaking in English on Wednesday, said it was also “good news” for Ukrainians that Russia, whose troops and military hardware occupy eastern Ukraine, will not be present for the Eurovision contest, despite Russia’s 2014 annexation of Crimea and its backing of separatists in the Donbass.<p><p>Peskov declined to give details about Russia’s readiness to give Ukraine access to the contest after Russian media reported on Tuesday that Putin had requested the Ukrainian leader to step down.<p><p>Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has accused Moscow of sending troops to prop up pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine in the conflict.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar's generals take over top posts in top jobs
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - The generals of Myanmar’s ruling military junta seized power last year following a coup and stepped down amid protests against its rule.<p><p>The move by military leaders, who held key posts, comes as Beijing is ramping up pressure on the junta for reforms it says are necessary to rein in a deepening economic crisis and crackdown on dissent.<p><p>A growing chorus of calls for reforms from the increasingly autocratic junta accuse it of fuelling violence.<p><p>While generals remain active in the government, new leaders are being appointed.<p><p>The junta has said it will be holding all-out street protests on Saturday to protest the coronavirus pandemic, raising fears of a backlash.<p><p>The junta has said they will not let the coronavirus epidemic die down and want a peaceful transition to democracy after it is proven that no one was ever killed.<p><p>The army has dismissed suggestions the military has been using torture or ill-treatment to suppress dissent.<p><p>While the generals’ move was aimed at restoring democracy in Myanmar, some analysts say it was also a coup engineered by the military to consolidate power.<p><p>Some analysts predict the junta could try to take power in an election to determine which side can win.<p>']

headline: UK minister backs Israel's unilateral move to ban gay marriages
content: ['<p>LONDON  - British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Monday he backed Israel’s unilateral move to bar gay marriages, which has drawn international criticism.<p><p>“I want to make clear I don’t recognise the Israeli right to discriminate against anyone, including anyone who wants to remain part of the Jewish people,” Johnson told BBC radio.<p> ']

headline: Nigerian officials block access to African Union summit - state news agency
content: ['<p> - The Nigerian government on Saturday blocked the entrance to the African Union summit held on April 22 in New York due to security concerns.<p><p>Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari told state news agency MENA that the African Union summit was under review and that Nigeria was not allowed into it due to security concerns.<p><p>The African Union summit on April 22 has been called off in part because the Nigerian government is still holding talks with its African partners about the summit, Buhari said.<p><p>“We are discussing the proposal on a political basis, and this is the reason for blocking entrance,” Buhari said.<p> ']

headline: China says its military will remain neutral in Xinjiang after China says it is “totally neutral” and says it is “still willing to engage” in the region
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - The country’s foreign ministry said on Thursday it will continue to play “neutral”, in contrast to a recent call with U.S. President Joe Biden, and said it will continue to be a partner in regional peace efforts.<p><p>The statement said China has “completely ignored all international law and will continue to be a partner in regional peace efforts.”<p> ']

headline: White House seeks 'full and fair' response to Myanmar military crackdown on protesters
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The White House on Wednesday sought a full and fair response to the latest round of violence in Myanmar, and offered “full and fair” response to what it called international pressure on its government, after a weekend of deadly protests in Yangon.<p><p>White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki told a briefing the United States would continue to work with Myanmar’s military to address the situation, and would not back any kind of “institutionalized violence” against its civilian population, including the killing of protesters and human rights abuses.<p><p>“It is important that we continue to be open with the international community, as we did with the Chinese response,” she said. “The United States has not done so.”<p><p>President Joe Biden, speaking at the annual State of the Union, said the United States would “continue to press for an orderly transition” of power and a fair and just transition to democracy in the country, and the international community would have the full support for that process.<p><p>At least six civilians were killed in the ongoing crackdown, including protesters.<p><p>Protesters and police seized large quantities of rubber bullets, Molotov cocktails and fireworks, according to local media and witnesses.<p><p>State Department spokesman Ned Price told reporters after briefing that efforts were on to get the Myanmar Armed Forces to honour pledges it made with the United States in the 1990s.']

headline: China's top diplomat says Chinese military needs to work harder and has more patience
content: ['<p>BEIJING  -China’s top diplomat said on Friday that Beijing’s aggressive and ambitious military modernization plans are in the wrong hands and that China should be cautious and cautious in its future.<p><p>The comments came as China’s Defence Ministry, the central government and China’s National People’s Congress said they would not resume talks aimed at building a “China’s first national power.<p><p>“In my view, the main issue is that the Chinese military needs to work harder and more patience in order to meet the challenges that are arising,” Wang Yi told reporters in Beijing.<p><p>“However much time we are doing and what is happening, we are still still developing the technologies, including the ones that are deployed in our territory.”<p><p>Chinese Defence Minister Yang Jiechi reiterated that China had an “appropriate and realistic defense strategy” on Friday, saying he would be working closely with his Chinese counterpart in his capacity as defence minister.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny charged with fraud in jail trial
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny was sentenced on Tuesday to 10 years in jail and banned from entering Russia in exchange for the release of his wife, a court official said.<p><p>Navalny, 44, was arrested in December 2010 and charged in a Moscow prison with conspiring to commit fraud and criminal breach of trust, the prosecutor’s office said.<p><p>On Tuesday Navalny’s lawyer did not immediately respond to a request for comment. He has not been charged with any crime.<p> ']

headline: UK's Prince Philip joins UN special envoy on COVID-19
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s Prince Philip joined the UN special envoy on COVID-19 on Wednesday, the world’s longest serving official and leading humanitarian envoy, who previously was at the United Nations, to discuss how to respond to a surging pandemic and how governments must prevent the spread of the virus.<p><p>“I welcome these two men on their journeys in the coming days, and especially the visit of the world’s leading humanitarian envoy, John Kerry, who has shown great leadership on the global pandemic,” said the U.N. special envoy in charge of global COVID-19 response.<p><p>Kerry’s visit came as the United States said it will suspend all aid from the European Union, Britain and other Western nations that have been affected by the coronavirus, as well as a handful of non-governmental groups.<p> ']

headline: Oxygen dose of Pfizer Inc vials reversed results as AstraZeneca orders vaccine
content: ['<p>SAN FRANCISCO  - AstraZeneca said on Monday it had reversed a Pfizer Inc vaccine-sharing order it had suspended for up to four months.<p><p>The company said it had suspended its use of Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine for six weeks following the results of a study by the German government and U.S. health authorities about its possible benefits.<p> ']

headline: Tens of thousands of migrants arrive in Serbia as Hungary scrambles to find enough food and medicine to care for 2,000 people
content: ['<p>MELBOURNE  - Tens of thousands of migrants arrived in Serbia on Friday along with thousands of other migrants, with Hungary scrambling to find enough food, medicine and the cash needed to help them after more than a month of delays, Prime Minister Boyko Borissov said on Saturday.<p><p>More than 1,100 of Serbia’s 550,000 border crossers were allowed to enter the country on Saturday, with Slovakia and Montenegro reporting an average of 890 migrants.<p><p>Ricardo Fazio, a spokesman for the president’s office in the European Union, told Reuters that the situation was worsening.<p><p>“We are at a state of emergency and it is in line with international humanitarian law to prevent the spread of diseases,” he said.<p><p>An additional 2,500 migrants arrived in Serbia on Saturday, Fazio added.<p><p>Hungary has so far deported between 950,000 and 950,000 migrants, while the EU has allowed a further 2.7 million people, including children and migrants, to return home.<p><p>The number of arrivals has climbed steadily since the start of the year, though still not enough to cover the initial 4.2 million migrants registered by the end of April.<p>']

headline: EU critic accuses Britain of meddling in Myanmar's civil war
content: ["<p>LONDON  - European Union foreign ministers have called for Britain to “stop interfering in Myanmar’s internal affairs and ensure its interests are protected, amid growing tensions over the civil war there.<p><p>“I call on the British government to stop interfering in Myanmar's internal affairs,” EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell told a news conference after talks with German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and British counterpart Boris Johnson in Brussels on Thursday.<p><p>“As I say to Britain, the EU must be constructive and transparent, because we have a deep, deep sense of our own interests. And we’re not interfering in our internal affairs,” Borrell said.<p><p>Johnson said last week that “Britain needs to be open and transparent, and open with respect to all its commitments on Myanmar,” adding that Britain was the United Kingdom that should be protecting its interests.<p><p>Britain and the European Union have fought nearly a decade-long military-ruled Myanmar for control of the country’s two-thirds-autonomous Hpakut region and control of large swathes of land.<p><p>The EU said last year that British troops had taken control of some of Myanmar’s most populated regions.<p><p>Britain also denies involvement in Myanmar’s junta, which in recent years has been waging a brutal crackdown on protesters.<p>"]

headline: U.S. says it is “comfortable” with Myanmar's Feb. 1 coronavirus surge
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States, which is increasingly concerned about reports of thousands of coronavirus infections in Myanmar following the Feb. 1 attack by insurgents on a military post, said on Thursday it was “comfortable” with the coronavirus surge.<p><p>The Pentagon said in a statement that Washington remains “on the strong side” of the Myanmar conflict.<p> ']

headline: Polls close for Australian's Joe Cockerill, his wife and mother - pollsters
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Australia’s oldest and most prestigious university opened on Thursday for the first time in more than a decade, marking the third successive academic year of open debate.<p><p>The closing hours of classes were punctuated by a virtual community of university students, many of whom shared a pint of beer at the bar.<p><p>“We are excited to be able to open for the first time since the pandemic,” Victoria University University (UM) chancellor, Ann Taylor, said in a statement.<p><p>“We are also very pleased to have had students from the previous academic year at the start of the new year, in particular John Bancroft and the current faculty, as we engage in our third full year of open debate.”<p><p>UM, which closed in 2013 and currently boasts the third-biggest library of its kind in the world, closed its doors to all students on Thursday, but Taylor said it was “well-positioned to take on new challenges in the coming year”.<p><p>“We welcome the ongoing engagement of students and faculty from across the country, in particular students from the current cohort of Australian students,” she added.<p><p>UM, founded in 1901, is one of five universities to be opened by an academic government in Australia, although it has traditionally held the title of the "Queen’s University of New South Wales’.']

headline: Myanmar's top prosecutor says no charges over coup attempt
content: ['<p> - Myint Suu Kyi’s trial has taken on a new meaning as she faces up to nine years in prison for her part in the Feb. 1 coup.<p><p>Myanmar police said on Monday they had arrested 10 people as they tried to seize power in a crackdown on a popular uprising.<p><p>Prosecutors accuse the generals of orchestrating the coup, which ousted junta leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been in detention since a Feb. 1 coup attempt.<p><p>Suu Kyi and her allies have been in jail since the coup, when Suu Kyi was acquitted on trumped-up charges of coup plot and criminal breach of trust.<p><p>Prosecutors say the military junta was behind the Feb. 1 coup and has waged an unprecedented crackdown.<p><p>“The coup was orchestrated,” Yang Pyit Minh said during a press conference on Monday.<p><p>“The whole process of this coup has been orchestrated,” she said.<p><p>Suu Kyi is due to face trials in the coming months. Her attorney General Min Aung Hlaing told the media at the start of the trial that the case was proceeding along the same path as the coup attempt.<p>']

headline: 'Awwwwww!' Awwwwwwwwww!' So many people on Sunday yelled at the U.S. consulate in Vancouver as crowds gathered for President Joe Biden’s funeral. “How many more are in danger in Canada?” tweeted John Kerry’s mother, Karen. “How many more Americans are in danger?” #CrowdsCrowd
content: ['<p><p>President Biden, 71, has been in Vancouver since last week as a funeral procession in St. George, B.C., wraps up at 11 p.m. at the B.C. United Nations headquarters. He has spent most of his time on the job, spending most of his time with his wife, Jill Biden, the Democratic vice president who is Biden’s running mate and the longest serving vice president in U.S. history.<p><p>Kerry’s family said he would be deeply touched by the loss of the consulate and the hundreds of people whose lives were in danger in Canada on Sunday. The couple shared a photograph on social media Saturday of their son sitting alone in the front row of the consulate as staff members chanted, "Justice for Joe.”<p><p>President Joe Biden will take the funeral procession to the White House on Monday for the funeral of his son, the former U.S. diplomat who died in September.<p><p>Kerry’s brother, Joe Biden, died on Saturday of cardiac arrest at age 79.<p>']

headline: Kremlin critic Ivanov criticizes Russia's treatment of Ukrainian troops in conflict
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  -Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny on Monday accused Russia of persecuting opposition figures and criticising Russia’s treatment of its own servicemen and civilians in eastern Ukraine.<p><p>Navalny, who has called for Russia to halt hostilities in eastern Ukraine, made the comments while visiting the Red Cross shelter in Moscow.<p><p>“The Russian government, along with many Western countries, are behaving in a manner in a cruel way in eastern Ukraine,” Navalny wrote in the comments carried by a newspaper, the RIA news agency.<p><p>Navalny said that he and his allies had been forced into hiding by Ukrainian forces in the separatist-controlled Donbass region of eastern Ukraine.<p><p>“The whole situation is the product of a long and well-ordered history of Russian aggression in the eastern Donbass region,” he said.<p><p>Ukraine has said the Russian troops were not fighting for separatists but for Russian forces fighting the forces of Ukraine’s ruling pro-Russian Svitlana party in eastern Ukraine.<p><p>Navalny is demanding that Moscow stop using the term “patriots” - a derogatory term used to describe Kremlin critics of the Ukrainian military which are opposed to Russian forces fighting the separatists.<p>']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny says he will pay $60 million to China for his treatment, the New York Times reports.
content: ['<p><p>Russian prosecutors have said Alexei Navalny was subjected to sexual violence and physical abuse during a four-year stay in Beijing’s Zhuhai Prison in 2013, the Times says.<p><p>Navalny, who was released from the prison after being granted parole in February, was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig’s disease last year and is due a second round of medical testing, which could take another two months.<p> ']

headline: The Russian state news agency Sputnik says Ukraine's pro-Russian separatists are battling Russian air strikes. Sputnik says Moscow has so far fired at 11 Ukrainian aircraft in the region: 14 MiG-29 fighter jets
content: ['<p>KYIV  - Ukrainian officials on Tuesday confirmed to Reuters that Ukrainian fighter jets fired on Russian fighter jets, killing at least 11 Ukrainian servicemen.<p><p>The statement also cited unidentified separatist fighters.<p><p>Separatists have battled Russian forces for nearly three decades, but the conflict has killed more than 3,400 people and displaced some 6.6 million.<p><p>Moscow says separatist forces in Ukraine have staged several air attacks against pro-Russian separatists since the start of the conflict in 2014. Russia has accused Ukraine of providing separatists with weapons and military hardware including MiG-29s.<p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday accused Ukraine of provoking a crisis and said it would not tolerate violence.<p><p>Separatists accuse Ukraine of failing to protect its sovereignty, and accuse Moscow of violating human rights in the region. Moscow denies these accusations.<p><p>Ukraine is fighting an armed conflict that began in 2014 against Russian troops advancing from surrounding Ukrainian territory and NATO allies. The conflict has claimed thousands of lives, displaced tens of thousands, and displaced millions more.<p> ']

headline: U.S. military warns of “significant” risk from Chinese military build-up near Taiwan “and is working with partners to make sure the consequences are communicated to our allies and partners” U.S. State Department spokesman Ned Price said on Wednesday. “We are working with our allies to make sure that those consequences are communicated to our allies and partners”, Price said. “And... they will.” The State Department reiterated Washington’s support for Taiwan’s right to self-determination. “While our allies and partners are deeply concerned by reports that Chinese military build-up near Taiwan, we are working with our allies to ensure that those consequences are communicated to our allies and partners to ensure the consequences are communicated to our allies and partners.” Price said in a statement. “Our United States’ support of the Taiwan people, and the efforts we have made to strengthen Taiwan’s democratic institutions, are underscored by the success of our joint exercises scheduled for late in the evening.” U.S. and Taiwan officials were not immediately available for comment. The two countries have traded criticism of China’s military build-up for a year. Taiwan denies it has been part of an armed conflict. U.S. and Taiwan officials have worked together to broker peace and stability in the region. Taiwan and China have two diplomatic missions. The United States has so far provided Taiwan with more than $3 billion in military assistance. U.S. President Joe Biden has condemned the military build-up and called on China to stop interfering with the two countries’ internal affairs. U.S. State Department spokesman Ned Price said on Tuesday he has “taken a tough position” on China’s conduct on Taiwan’s Taiwan island, pointing to recent statements by U.S. officials warning of serious consequences if Taiwan is not granted Taiwan independence. The statement did not specifica
Indonesia launches new biometric test on COVID-19 passengers
content: ['<p>JAKARTA  - Indonesia on Monday launched a new national biometric test designed to speed its vaccination programme and speed its recovery from an outbreak that shook its economy.<p><p>The testing, which was approved by the country’s Health Ministry and aims to be done in the coming days, will give local authorities and healthcare workers a first chance to screen for COVID-19 before vaccines can be given, Prime Minister Joko Widodo said.<p><p>“We need people like you to ensure our vaccines can work,” Widodo said in a televised address broadcast by state-run broadcaster ARIN, which also provided the headline of his address.<p><p>“The test will provide a test of speed and efficiency. The tests will show the results of COVID-19 vaccination. That will allow us to accelerate the vaccine process.”<p><p>Indonesia is already inoculating 2.7 million people who have not yet had a shot.<p><p>Its inoculation programme has been hampered by cases, but has started producing some 2.7 million doses, largely in the southern province of Sulawesi.<p><p>The tests are expected to be used in hospitals to screen for coronavirus.<p><p>Indonesia, along with many neighbouring countries, has been inoculating around 3 million people.<p>']

headline: EVERYONE SHOULDTAIL OF BIRTH TO JUMP THE RUMBLING BALL! — Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, Jill Stein
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Republican presidential candidate, running in 2020 against Democrat Karen Handel, said she felt obliged to jump the Republican ball to the convention this year when President Joe Biden’s election brought with it a huge wave of the most progressive members of her party.<p><p>“I’m grateful for all of the hard work and sacrifice this man has put into our party,” said Handel, a former Republican vice presidential nominee. “You have to show up and have faith in the principles of the party. I think it’s fair for us all.”<p><p>“If we want to go further, we’ve got to have a serious conversation about this, and we have to make it about the people of America.”<p><p>“Let’s get to work. Let’s get to the polls. We’ve got to be open and transparent, and we’ve got to keep our fingers crossed.”<p><p>Handel, in a speech in Washington, thanked Biden for supporting her candidacy, saying: “We must do better than the political winds that have broken down and are continuing to break down.”<p><p>“Let’s be serious and optimistic about what is possible when we all step up,” Handel said.<p>']

headline: Finance Minister Sexting asks for review of planned copper mine, amid political turmoil
content: ['<p>MADRID  - Finance Minister Armin Laschet asked Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday to review the planned copper mine that could supply Punjab and North West Asia with 4.5 million tonnes of new copper.<p><p>“Today, I asked you to reconsider the need for an exploration or purchase of new copper production in the Indian state of West Bengal, and for consideration on the needs of the population of the region,” Laschet said.<p><p>“My request is for review of the proposals submitted by the Central Reserve Bank, the government of Karnataka and others on the possibility of creating new copper mines,” he added, without elaborating on whether he thought such a development was justified.<p><p>“The government of West Bengal and the government of Karnataka have a lot of concerns about a project that they want to create as a mining site in Karnataka but it’s unclear whether they are aware of their obligations under the Indian Petroleum Corporation Act,” Laschet said.<p><p>While many Indian states have backed similar projects in the past, the government of Pakistan is opposed to the project as the projects threaten to pollute India’s waters and resources.<p>']

headline: White House says sanctions on Myanmar are likely to be lifted in coming days
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The White House on Wednesday said it had not seen any indication that it might lift sanctions on Myanmar on Friday, the day after reports that authorities had detained thousands of protesters.<p><p>On Saturday, the United Nations imposed sanctions on four officials and six organisations for their role in a deadly crackdown on protesters in Yangon, the capital, which killed more than 500 on Saturday.<p><p>White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>But the sanctions have been met with strong public condemnation from Washington and allies who fear they could stifle free expression, the White House said.<p><p>It was the first time since 2011 that the United States had imposed sanctions on several government figures. The White House said its sanctions would be reviewed by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) on Friday.<p><p>But a State Department spokeswoman said the administration had not been able to provide any information on what might happen after the IAEA reviews, saying only that it planned to meet with Myanmar’s president on Friday.<p><p>Press Secretary Jen Psaki did not answer a call seeking comment on Tuesday.<p> ']

headline: Venezuela's President Maduro announces COVID-19 lockdown at AstraZeneca plant
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced on Tuesday he had imposed a lockdown for the entire province of Caracas beginning on Monday and ordered pharmacies to close immediately, a day after he said he would use the lockdown to prevent people from getting shots.<p><p>Maduro’s government blames the coronavirus outbreak on the government of President Hugo Chavez, who was elected in a landslide in 2011. Maduro has ruled Venezuela since 2011 and has been in power since 2013.<p><p>Venezuela has reported 14,827 new cases, the highest in seven years. Venezuela reported 596 new coronavirus deaths last month.<p> ']

headline: Tensions rise as Rohingya children flee persecution in Myanmar
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A number of children fled from Myanmar to Bangladesh in the hope of finding refuge on the island of Maung n Khan, where hundreds of children have been killed by security forces, according to Reuters people involved in the matter.<p><p>“These children who are trying to escape... will die from hunger or abuse by security forces in Myanmar or they will die at the hands of the armed forces,” the people told Reuters.<p><p>“There’s no food, no water and nothing left. The children cannot run. No medicine or medicine to feed them.”<p><p>The Reuters people said they had fled their village in Burdwan in north-western Maung n Khan province on Monday. Several children there had died.<p><p>Reuters could not independently verify the accounts of the children’ families. Some, including the elderly women, have complained of acute back and leg pain and fatigue, the Rohingya have said.<p><p>“A lot of these kids have never been seen before,” said Sarah, who is also pregnant with one of the children, the youngest. “Their parents were killed during the fighting,” she said.<p><p>Militants have waged a bloody insurgency against Rohingya since 2013, when Myanmar troops overthrew the elected government.<p>']

headline: U.S. says Tehran says it will not negotiate with Trump over U.S. sanctions
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States will not negotiate with Iran over its nuclear program, U.S. officials said on Monday, in a move that could pressure Tehran into giving up its nuclear program and making progress on other issues.<p><p>“This is an act of war,” U.S. special envoy for Iran John Sullivan said in Washington, adding that the United States would not tolerate such a situation.<p> ']

headline: Travellers rescued in Greek island after rescue attempt falls short
content: ['<p>Greece is in the process of recovering from a deadly rescue attempt by rescue workers on Thursday, but a group of tourists was trapped in the frozen Chiosi island of Tenerife when they were pulled away from the coastguard vessel by rescuers.<p><p>The vessel, called AIM, had been stuck in rough seas off the coast of the Greek island of Lesbos after several boatloads of Greek and European rescue workers arrived on Sunday, including three divers who had been in the boat for more than three days.<p><p>After the rescue team arrived, three men were transported out of the boat and two women, who are Greek citizens, took them to the island’s medical office to be tested for oxygen, local news agency Kiosk reported.<p><p>“There were only two (rescues),” one person, who asked not to be identified, told Greek radio.<p><p>“The oxygen is running out. They don’t know what they are doing.”<p><p>One German diver, who asked not to be identified, told Kiosk he and his crew had been unable to get to the site due to rough seas.<p><p>Tenerife is a popular tourist destination and holds about 2,500 visitors.<p><p>A number of rescue workers were also on board the vessel.<p>']

headline: The Kremlin accuses Germany of interference in Russian elections
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin accused Germany of interfering in the presidential elections in November, accusing it of breaching an EU-wide law and violating EU treaties on freedom of expression.<p><p>The row has sparked widespread condemnation in Germany, Britain and France, as well as a call by European Council President Charles Michel to “restore democracy in Russia”.<p><p>It has also sparked accusations that German Chancellor Angela Merkel, the bloc’s highest civilian office, is a proxy for Russia, as well as a threat by the Kremlin against German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman, Dmitry Peskov.<p><p>“Merkel is a puppet, Putin is a puppet, Putin is a puppet,” Merkel said during a call with German foreign minister Ursula von der Leyen on Thursday.<p><p>Asked whether she had called for Putin to be removed, Merkel said: “I want to see the European Union return to the principle of democracy. We are talking about a third national identity, and I want to stress that the principle of democracy, not the right to slander, is a fundamental value of our democracy.”<p><p>The comments followed Merkel’s decision in September to dismiss Boris Johnson from her Christian Democrats (CDU) leadership.<p>']

headline: The European Court of Human Rights has ruled that Germany has made false accusations against former German chancellor Angela Merkel. The ruling could force Germany to step down from the global presidency if it does not comply with a 2015 promise.
content: ['<p><p>“The Court of Human Rights in the European Union (ECR) has found that the statements made by former Chancellor Angela Merkel in her capacity as chancellor were made in a way that violated the laws of defamation,” ECHR President Peter Berdowski said.<p><p>“This finding constitutes “unconstitutional discrimination against humanity”, Berdowski said.<p> ']

headline: Efforts to combat climate change are 'in the beginning,' U.S. scientists say
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. scientists are examining the origins and consequences of the global carbon dioxide emissions of the last century, including how their work could shed light on how COVID-19 impacts human activity.<p><p>In a paper published Wednesday, the U.S. National Academies of Science and Engineering report “Understanding the Future: Strategies for Adapting to Climate Change and Adapting to Climate Change” proposes that efforts to improve the lives and conditions of millions of people over the coming century should focus on practical actions.<p><p>“We believe that “carbon capture, distribution, and storage” can provide a model that can be used to predict the impacts of future COVID-19 increases, especially from extreme weather, and may be able to better target the impacts of carbon sequestration, including by limiting impacts on other species,” said Matt Taibbi, an associate professor of chemical engineering and environmental science at the University of California, Santa Barbara.<p><p>“We are exploring other sources of COVID-19 emission, such as low-income communities, coastal communities, coastal fishing communities, fishing operations, fishing communities, and irrigation projects,” he added.<p><p>The report aims to shed light on the relationship between the COVAX Initiative to fight climate change and the broader effort to ensure the safety and health of all Americans, highlighting the complexity of the issue.<p>']

headline: Navalny says Biden says Iran was fabricated
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden said Tuesday he has doubts about Iran’s assertion that Iran was fabricated, and he defended his administration’s actions in imposing new sanctions on Tehran, which are part of a larger effort to reimpose U.S. sanctions.<p><p>The comments followed months of talks with Iran over compliance with the 2015 nuclear accord that included easing some sanctions, including the lifting of a U.S. moratorium on its nuclear program.<p><p>“I believe that President Biden was right to say, as I did with the Iranians, that Iran was fabricated,” Biden said. “But as we speak about these actions... they are part of a larger effort to reimpose more sanctions on Iran,” he added, referring to the United States.<p><p>Biden’s foreign policy adviser, Michael Clement, said he expects the president to be open to diplomacy with Tehran, but he cautioned that such an approach is “going to be a long road”, not just for Iran but also for the United States, to compliance with the deal.<p><p>Iran has repeatedly denied any provocations, and many foreign and defense officials have voiced skepticism that Biden’s remarks could sway Tehran.<p><p>Iran’s foreign ministry said the Biden administration was not making any false statements. The ministry said it remained open to diplomacy with Tehran.<p>']

headline: A new COVID-19 outbreak outbreak warning in eastern Ethiopia - state
content: ['<p>DHAKA  - The number of new coronavirus cases in Ethiopia has risen to 165 from 161, health ministry data showed on Thursday, marking the fourth consecutive day of high infections amid a deadly COVID-19 outbreak that has left many communities in western Ethiopia and killed 14 people in recent weeks.<p><p>Last week, Ethiopia reported 134 new infections, the highest since the start of the pandemic, and health officials have warned of a second wave of infections.<p><p>The death toll rose to 169 from 161 on Wednesday.<p><p>“We expect the death toll to rise again,” Health Minister Amak Hadebashi told a news conference.<p><p>The outbreak in northern Tigray province was “extremely worrying” and it would take longer to clear, he added.<p><p>Ethiopia’s government did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>More than 700 people have died in the three weeks since a rare variant of the coronavirus first appeared in Ethiopia in late August.<p><p>At least 13 people were killed in the worst-hit region of Eritrea, according to the official count.
