The numbers suggest a possible second wave of infections in the northern region of Soma.<p>']

headline: Blinken warns that U.S. military will not use force if necessary
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin told reporters on Friday that the United States would not escalate military actions if necessary in response to the situation in Libya, following reports of violence that has killed thousands of people.<p><p>“We are confident in our ability to respond to those that are fleeing or at risk of being killed,” Austin said in Washington, where he was speaking to reporters by video link from a helicopter. “And we will do so with whatever means are appropriate.”<p><p>The White House said earlier this month that the United States would not “escalate” the situation in Libya if needed, or escalate any response.<p><p>Austin also said the United States would work with allies to bring an end to civil war in Libya and warned that any escalation would be “extremely dangerous”.<p><p>The United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Portugal, Spain, Italy’s Sputnik V fighter jets, and the Italian coast guard sailed to the eastern Mediterranean this week after a month of conflict and several months of intense fighting, underscoring the challenges ahead of the United States taking a tougher line against a deadly new type of jihadist movement targeting NATO allies.<p> ']

headline: U.S. says Saudi-led coalition in Yemen says “we can’t “stay idle”
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - The United States and Saudi Arabia on Thursday said they were ready to discuss “interim steps” to resolve the crisis in Yemen.<p><p>The two countries said in a statement they had discussed “countermeasures” that they would take in the coming days.<p> ']

headline: The White House on Saturday said President Biden had briefed Russia on several matters, including the ongoing investigation into potential collusion between Trump campaign officials and the Kremlin, in an effort to persuade the United States to back the Kremlin. Biden, a Democrat, had been the target of a Russian probe for his 2016 election loss, and his White House said on Saturday that he was “very concerned” by reports of contacts with Russian officials. Biden has said he has asked the Kremlin to refrain from interfering in the U.S. election. The Kremlin has denied interfering.
content: ['<p><p>The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Reuters on Saturday.<p><p>Russia has said it has a growing intelligence community, including about 100 in its military and special forces teams, to counter a potential Trump administration push to isolate Moscow from Western allies.<p><p>White House officials had sought to reassure Moscow that U.S. special forces are still working with Moscow to track down and disrupt those seeking to undermine the campaign and push back against Western sanctions.<p><p>A White House official said Biden’s request, made on Twitter late on Saturday, was to ensure that the Russian foreign ministry would remain neutral.<p><p>White House spokesman Ned Price said on Saturday that Washington remained open to any cooperation with Russia in the investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.<p>']

headline: Venezuelan opposition politician jailed in death threats after ruling party denies accusations
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - An opposition politician in Venezuela has been jailed on charges of murder in the country’s worst anti-government unrest since the end of President Nicolas Maduro’s 10-year rule, opposition lawmaker Jaime Castillo said on Wednesday.<p><p>“I have heard some news reports that Maduro is in prison... I have not heard those news,” Castillo, a candidate in the opposition National Assembly, told a press briefing. “The fact is that Maduro has been declared dead. The government has not declared death.”<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal Suez Canal Authority, state-owned Canal Authority and the National Canal Authority reject the latest reports that the vessels are blocked and the cause is still unknown
content: ['<p> - Suez Canal Authority said in a statement on Friday that reports of a new vessel blocking the canal had reached it first and had not yet been confirmed by the local authorities.<p><p>“The ship which has started its voyage has been blocking the Canal Authority and Canal Authority,” the authority said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny calls for tougher sanctions on opposition
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny on Thursday called for tougher sanctions on opposition figures, after a week of unrest in Russia’s eastern Donbass region that has drawn global condemnation.<p><p>Navalny, a Navalny critic who denies any wrongdoing, accused Ukraine of sending troops to prop up pro-Russian separatists who seized the eastern Donbass region last year.<p><p>In the wake of the protests, Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has called a snap election on April 8 for his party, which won 43% of the vote, to take power.<p><p>His nationalist Svoboda party has also called for the resignation of the three heads of state that make up the opposition, and has promised to hold elections in a few weeks.<p><p>Ukraine on Thursday issued an executive order that suspends Navalny’s employment, his salary and social benefits, as well as his right to travel abroad and meet with foreign dignitaries.<p><p>Vladimir Turchinov, leader of the anti-corruption movement in Donbass, criticized the military action, saying that any easing of military control would harm the rights of civilians and infringe on the independence of the Donbass region.<p><p>“This situation is of a state with an illegitimate military government, and it’s a violation of the fundamental rights of all,” he said on Twitter.<p>']

headline: Biden says Biden regrets call with Putin in Biden's final two hours: Biden
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The vice president told Biden in an interview on Thursday he regrets calling the Russian leader in person on Saturday, his senior White House spokesman said.<p><p>The White House did not say if Biden regretted calling the Russian leader on Saturday or Thursday, when Biden was scheduled to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin.<p> ']

headline: Biden: Navalny was not on leave
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  -The Biden administration on Tuesday defended a decision by U.S. Central Command (CENTCOM) to let a Ukrainian submarine go free after the Russian-made submarine had been detected near the United States, after reports surfaced that a U.S. Navy ship had violated an exclusive policy for patrolling the Mediterranean and elsewhere.<p><p>Citing a U.S. Navy spokesman, the White House said in a statement: “We can confirm that the submarine was not on leave, and the Naval Security Center has no comment to make on this.”<p><p>The spokesman added that the situation was “under control”.<p> ']

headline: Venezuela's COVID-19 death toll in recent days surpass 10,000: official
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - Venezuela reported a total of 11,094 new coronavirus cases on Tuesday, the deadliest day since the pandemic started, and said it had recorded 6,619 deaths from the pandemic.<p><p>Health Minister Jose Caballero on Tuesday tweeted the figures were 114, with 996 deaths and 2,664 cases. He said his country, with a population of 11.3 million, had recorded 1.5 million new coronavirus infections over the past 24 hours.<p><p>On Sunday, Venezuela reported 909 new coronavirus infections.<p><p>In another development, the coronavirus death toll rose to 10,637 from last week’s 1,056, said Carlos Chávez, an official at the ministry of health in the capital Caracas.<p><p>“It is a daily daily rise,” Chávez told Reuters by telephone.<p><p>Chávez said the daily rise in the toll would be followed by another daily rise, though there had been no data on the number of fatalities from the previous day.<p><p>Chávez added that the country had registered 1,867 new cases and 709 deaths.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin says it will not resume military intervention in Ukraine
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Thursday that the Kremlin would not resume military intervention in Ukraine until it is fully transparent and transparent about how it is conducting its policy, after Ukraine rejected a request for it to leave.<p><p>The West, which had sought to quell violent protests that erupted last week in Kyiv after the Kremlin called on the country to join the European Union and said it needed to respect the sovereignty of the eastern Donbass region, accused Moscow of violating its own self-determination.<p><p>“We will not allow any escalation of armed conflict until the full and transparent disclosure of the Russian position,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said in televised remarks.<p><p>“Russia has made clear that the situation in Ukraine is not our fault, it’s our responsibility, and our responsibility is to respect the sovereignty of Ukraine. And so that is something which we will not accept.”<p> ']

headline: In response to criticism of Beijing, U.S. and China assert they have no hostility
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States and China have no hostility and will not engage in any kind of hostilities on their territory, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Tuesday.<p><p>China, which shares territorial claims with both countries, has repeatedly warned Washington of China’s threats and said it would respond with force to any attack by China that escalates tensions.<p> ']

headline: Vietnam says Myanmar military coup must be stopped
content: ['<p> - Myanmar’s military on Thursday said it had ousted the elected leader of its elected government and the ruling party for a fourth consecutive year, two days after reports that he had been killed in clashes near its borders with Thailand, Myanmar’s state news agency KCNA reported.<p><p>Thai government spokesman Ned Price told reporters the military “provoked a great deal of bloodshed” and urged the public to remain calm in the country’s two biggest cities.<p> ']

headline: Tribal militias stand by Syria\'s President Bashar al-Assad, U.S. says
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States and its allies say that the presence of more than 250 foreign militia in Syria has created a humanitarian catastrophe in the country, while the Syrian opposition has condemned the militia actions as an attack on democracy.<p><p>“This has created a humanitarian disaster for the people in Syria,” said Gabrielle Gaffney, director of the Middle East Center at the Center for a New American Security. “In particular, the militia actions have put a strain on humanitarian assistance.”<p><p>The United Nations is calling on Syria’s government to stop the militia attacks and the international community to provide humanitarian assistance.<p><p>Last week, U.S. Ambassador Tim Lenderking said that Washington would travel to Turkey to meet the Turkish president this week to try to persuade him to allow the militias back.<p><p>The militia actions have also caused tension between the Assad government and pro-Russian forces that has ravaged Syria in a conflict that has killed hundreds of thousands and displaced millions.<p><p>The Assad government says the militias are not part of a political group or an armed force but part of a government that “deceives” its people and uses force to protect them, while the pro-Russian forces deny involvement and say the militia have no allegiance to the Assad regime.<p>']

headline: Greece is still considering forming new government amid government cuts
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - Greece is still considering forming a new government in a move likely to give it greater control over the economy, Prime Minister Yanis Varoufakis said on Friday, while adding a second member of parliament to the bloc’s governing coalition would need to be re-elected to take control of the government.<p><p>“At present, the situation is very serious,” Varoufakis told reporters.<p><p>But he warned that if a second vote is not taken soon, the government could collapse.<p><p>The new Greek government would be in charge of overseeing the financial sector and would set out the country’s economic policy in a first national budget meeting on Friday, he said.<p> ']

headline: Cuba's Coronavirus death toll mounts to 1,000 - as doctors warn - as coronavirus deaths soar
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The death toll from coronavirus variants in Cuba has risen to a staggering 1,000 cases, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday, as a government-led effort to contain the virus surges ahead of the World Health Day celebrations.<p><p>The government-led initiative, dubbed Coronavirus Initiative, is the world’s largest COVID-19 response and the world’s largest cluster vaccine response initiative, with a total of 20,934 participants, with some 3,150,000 of them taking part in the response.<p><p>“I am really happy that the world is waking up to the fact that the virus is not just more of a problem in Cuba than anywhere else in the world,” said Jose Eduardo Randa, WHO Director General. “The disease has become a global issue, not only here in Cuba, but in the region as well.”<p><p>The number of coronavirus deaths in Cuba rose to 31,092 on Tuesday from 682 a day earlier, when it recorded 909 deaths.<p><p>The Caribbean island nation has had over a million new infections since its outbreak started a year ago and has been unable to contain the virus, although the virus is widely transmitted through travel, and the country has some of the highest cases per capita in the world.<p>']

headline: Election night: EU leaders meet in Brussels
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - EU leaders held a summit on Friday to discuss the implementation of a multi-billion-euro ($26.7 billion) multi-year pact with the United States which is due to take effect next week, and to seek consensus on the challenges ahead.<p><p>The EU, as it turns out, is the first party to get a multi-billion-euro pact since President Joe Biden signed a 2010 pact with Russia.<p><p>It has so far failed to reach consensus on the details of the deal, with some sticking to an earlier version than others.<p><p>The summit came a day after France, Germany, Britain, Italy and Britain warned against pandemic scenarios that would delay the EU’s growth, health and climate goals.<p><p>A joint European Union taskforce for combating climate change, led by EU leaders, called on President Emmanuel Macron on Friday to deliver on “the pledge made by President Biden to the United States in February 2015 and that is currently being fully implemented,” said the statement from the task force.<p><p>Macron has pledged to “engage with the U.S. leadership and other international partners to achieve a multi-trillion-euro climate strategy and mitigation plan that will underpin a global energy transition” in the coming weeks.<p>']

headline: U.S. says China's Xinjiang investigation'very concerning'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States on Thursday said China’s suspected human rights abuses during Xinjiang, which began in 2016, were “very concerning” and called for a full and independent investigation.<p><p>U.S. Special Counsel Robert S. Zelenskiy said the U.S. was concerned about a broad range of human rights abuses during Xinjiang, including detention, torture, forced labour and political persecution in both the predominantly Muslim Uighur and minority ethnic Uighurs regions.<p><p>“The United States, together with our international partners, is committed to pursuing the full investigation of the perpetrators of these serious human rights abuses and working with all relevant stakeholders to ensure they are completely eradicated,” Zelenskiy said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Sudan launches AstraZeneca COVID vaccine
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - Sudan on Friday announced its first inoculation of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine against the coronavirus, with the inoculation expected to last until March 16, the health ministry said.<p><p>“The number of cases reported by the health authorities in Sudan is likely to increase by at least one week from now,” Health Minister Mohammed Abdelaziz said in a statement.<p><p>“We have confirmed the transmission of cases of the coronavirus in the Sudan city of Darfur and Darfur province, including with the COVID-19 vaccines.”<p> ']

headline: Truck driver accused of shooting dead teenager
content: ['<p>ROME  - A truck driver in central Italy has been charged with murder after a truck he was carrying killed a teenager in the street.<p><p>Raffaele Molano, 45, shot dead a 16-year-old student in the village of Piazza Vila in the southern province of Calabria around midday on Monday, police said.<p><p>He was taken to hospital with a gunshot wound to the head and is being questioned by police, police said.<p><p>Local media reported that Molano was carrying a knife when he was ambushed by two men in the street and he later died.<p><p>His death was the first of at least three suspected murder-suicide incidents on Saturday in the country’s troubled western region of Genoa.<p><p>Cases of attempted murder were rising since last weekend, with several police killings linked to Islamist militant groups.<p><p>The number of alleged killings has increased on a daily basis since the start of the year, although there have been some slight increases in recent days.<p><p>In March, three people were killed by a gang after they were caught on camera attacking two police officers in Milan, Italy’s city of Palma, authorities said.<p>']

headline: Famitsu to offer'smart money' loans to low-income borrowers - official
content: ['<p>TOKYO  - Fintech lender Masayoshi Son is to offer borrowers the ability to swap money for goods and services from other companies in a move designed to help reduce the economic crisis, official Katsunobu Sugita said on Tuesday.<p><p>The new lending scheme is designed to help low-income consumers, which have little choice between borrowing money or buying goods and services in the country with higher inflation rates.<p> ']

headline: China critic rejects calls for crackdown on anti-corruption protesters as 'distancing'
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China critic Zhao Ziyi wrote a letter criticizing Western sanctions over its treatment of protesters in China, as his group blocked a Chinese national news site, the National People’s Daily (NCPB), and said the Chinese authorities had become a threat to their rights.<p><p>The Communist Party of China said Zhao and his group have been blocked for interfering with the news site. They also said that other Chinese individuals who participated in the protest in November could be punished, calling it “an interference in their right to free expression”.<p><p>Beijing blocked a Chinese national news site on Thursday, the latest move in a series of online protests this year by several prominent figures in the party. Zhao, 43, has also been accused of trying to undermine party policy, the official Xinhua news agency reported.<p><p>PCB said earlier this week it was blocking Zhang Yiyi’s NCPB news site because it appeared to be biased towards the party, and was “in league with the people”. The Chinese official also condemned the blockade of an NCPB news site.<p><p>Zhao did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>Zhang was born in the Fujian province in 1970, and became a critic of the Fujian government after it cracked down on dissent in 1989.<p>']

headline: EU's Merkel warns of potential consequences of EU migrant crisis if Germany joins EU as migrant crisis worsens
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - The European Commission president urged her European partners on Wednesday to keep up pressure on Germany to accept more migrants and migrants as it sees fit, urging her to give priority to its citizens and the bloc’s 27-nation bloc.<p><p>The remarks by Ms Merkel, who on Thursday said Germany should consider whether to join the bloc, were followed by a statement from EU foreign policy chief Federica Azevedo, which warned of the consequences for German citizens who have taken up residence in Britain, the Netherlands and elsewhere in the bloc.<p><p>“We urge all of our EU partners to keep a persistent and constructive stance on migration and to implement (their) respective commitments to help to address the migrant crisis and provide for the common good,” it said.<p><p>“We know that the Commission cannot accept an escalation of the crisis in our member states with all its teeth. We strongly urge member states to refrain from a situation where the Commission can, and does, escalate the situation.”<p><p>Ms Azevedo later said that it would be up to Germany to decide whether to join the EU.<p><p>Britain, France and Germany have said they will not accept any more migrants or migrants from the Schengen area, as well as from the Northern Triangle, and have said they would also welcome migrant workers in other member states.<p>']

headline: No more 'vaccine boycott' in Ukraine - Ministry of Health
content: ["<p>KYIV  - No more 'vaccine boycott' in Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Saturday, as thousands protested against his government\\'s decision to let in just over 100,000 doses of a banned AstraZeneca shot.<p> "]

headline: U.S. seeks to hold China accountable in South China Sea disputes
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is seeking to hold China accountable in the South China Sea, the White House said on Tuesday, a move designed to keep it out of a dispute over the island nation’s claims to the South China Sea.<p><p>“As a nation, we have a fundamental right to defend ourselves,” White House press secretary Jen Psaki said in a statement.<p><p>The dispute is between China and the Philippines, which claims the South China Sea in the East China Sea.<p><p>In March China announced plans to construct artificial islands near Taiwan and Taiwan, which it says are meant to improve its maritime position and protect against attacks by Taiwan.<p><p>Taiwan is Taiwan’s claim to the island territory and the United States says China is not a member of its sovereign territory.<p> ']

headline: A second U.S. military build-up looms in Ohio, Maryland
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON — The U.S. Central Command announced on Tuesday that a second tactical nuclear weapons arsenal would be deployed in two different regions of the state of Ohio by the end of the week, underscoring the challenges that remain in building up the nation’s forces.<p><p>“It is a daunting task to build up the nation’s militaries together,” Col. Peter D. Floyd, commander of U.S. Central Command, said during a briefing. "And it requires some flexibility in the delivery systems,” he said.<p><p>But General Joseph Dunford, the commander of U.S. Central Command, said the deployment of the tactical nuclear weapons would not be an abrupt and sudden change in U.S. policy.<p><p>“I am confident, however, the Trump administration will keep pursuing this policy,” he said.<p><p>The move was not unexpected. Under previous administrations, the United States has deployed nuclear-capable cruise missiles and stealth drones in conflict zones and abroad to defend against nuclear threats from the Soviets and China. The United States in 2018 fired at a Chinese aircraft carrier group that the Chinese deemed an attack and warned that the carrier’s proximity to the U.S. could cause the U.S. to lose confidence in its defense and retaliate.<p><p>It also came as the Trump administration is ramping up pressure on the Pentagon to build up the Army. The Joint Chiefs of Staff are expected to meet next week in Washington.']

headline: Biden urges China to abide by U.N. rules, saying Xi must respect U.S. commitments
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden urged China to abide by U.N. rules on the distribution of technology and safeguard U.S. economic interests, the White House said on Thursday.<p><p>“We urge China to comply with all the relevant U.N. Security Council resolutions, which are aimed at protecting its national security and the global economy,” Biden said in a statement. “We reaffirmed China’s support for the U.N. Security Council’s Security Council resolution on China’s compliance with all relevant U.N. Security Council resolutions.”<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal waterway deadlocked, says partner in need of more water
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - Suez Canal Authority (SCA) said on Friday it was urgently in need of more water from the waterway, saying it had received almost 3.5 million cubic metres of water per day (bpd), a level not seen in years.<p><p>Egypt is suffering from the third wave of a severe thaw caused by deep curbs which have been put in place since Egypt’s military overthrew elected President Mohammed Morsi in 2013.<p><p>SCA has been struggling to find water to relieve the ship’s 500-metre-long (1,000-yard) high bow and stern, which it believes has been jammed by the canal’s seaworthiness.<p><p>Egypt and other parties in the Egypt-Israel Economic Corridor, a group of 10 states that share a canal, had agreed to pay $400 million to settle an impasse over how to build a tunnel on the waterway, which ran from the southernmost port of Bata.<p><p>Egypt last week announced a $1.5 billion loan from China’s Sinovac Energy Corp (Sinovac) to secure additional water.<p><p>“Our ability to provide water is severely constrained. We have to resort to other sources, including natural gas or using dredgers and other dredgers to fill gaps and block the flow of water,” SCA’s chief executive Salma Choksi told Reuters.<p>']

headline: One in three UK schools may have to cancel COVID-19 vaccines in coming weeks, study says
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s schools will have to go on lockdown in coming weeks for a handful of schools as a COVID-19 lockdown looms, a study says as a number of countries begin inoculating their pupils.<p><p>The study, by Oxford University and the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) on Wednesday, says about half of schools would have to close down at the end of the week to keep their supplies running.<p><p>Around a quarter of secondary schools are due to have their doors and windows closed by the end of March, with more schools in the second half of April.<p><p>The study’s authors said teachers would need to be on hand to keep pupils safe and vaccinated.<p><p>“Schools should be open from Monday until mid-April,” it said.<p><p>As part of an ongoing nationwide lockdowns, England will open schools on Wednesday with all pupils vaccinated by the end of April.<p><p>The study said pupils would also be required to present a negative test for COVID-19, although the findings did not indicate whether the test was carried out by the same school or another parent.<p><p>The IHME report said that by April 22, 8 of 16 schools would have closed.<p>']

headline: Sudanese forces seize entire city
content: ['<p>MADRID  - Airstrikes and shelling by SDF troops against the Islamist rebel group\'s position on the capital, Sidibe, has devastated parts of the country’s largest city and forced thousands of people out of their homes, the government said on Tuesday.<p><p>The government had called the attack the "unprovoked" and said it feared “a terrorist attack”.<p> ']

headline: Nato says Chinese troops deployed to eastern coast of China to 'fight terrorism'
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Chinese military personnel and their allies launched military exercises on Monday and called for “patriots” to exercise in the region in an effort to safeguard territorial integrity in China’s Xinjiang region.<p><p>The drills, which could last up to two days, would focus on protecting against future attacks by pro-Russian forces, Uighur militia and foreign troops.<p><p>The United States has warned that such military drills could lead to a “provocative, destabilizing, and possibly violent response”.<p><p>The exercises are also aimed at promoting dialogue,” the State Department said in a statement on Monday, without elaborating.<p><p>China’s foreign ministry on Tuesday called for peaceful co-existence in the region and called on international organisations such as the United Nations to “implement and sustain democratic and cooperative processes.”<p><p>The Uighur independence movement in Xinjiang says the region, along with other parts of China, is part of a "state project" that seeks to separate the ethnic group from the rest of the country.<p> ']

headline: Indonesia's ruling junta calls for Myanmar military coup
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - Indonesian President Joko Widodo said on Tuesday he planned to press ahead with a parliamentary election after military junta leader Suu Kyi said on Tuesday he planned to hold a military coup if elected.<p><p>“I have made a decision on how to proceed with the election,” Widodo told reporters after a ceremony marking the centenary of the start of the conflict between Buddhists and the military.<p><p>“I believe that it is important for the people of Indonesia to vote in accordance with the constitution,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Navalny's spokesman says he won't apologize
content: ['<p>BENJAMIN  -Navalny’s spokesman Peter Forsyth said on Wednesday he would not apologize to the royal family and his wife Prince Philip, who both served as top brass at the Navalny death palace.<p><p>“I cannot, of course,” Forsyth said at a news conference after the news conference. “My wife is my life. I can’t say how I’ve felt about anything at this time.”<p> ']

headline: India's AstraZeneca sees no risks of COVID-19 vaccine amid concern about Covid-19 surge
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  -India’s government has said its COVID-19 vaccination programme will continue under a second COVAX programme, after it said last month that it would continue vaccinating elderly people despite higher infection rates in the country.<p><p>The government said in January that it would start vaccinating people aged 60 and older, and have been testing those aged 70 and over, in a joint programme with the European Medicines Agency.<p><p>However, on Friday, the country reported an uptick in cases among people under 60 in a region of Gujarat that is one of India’s oldest cities, with cases of more than 100 cases rising by about 7 to 14 days.<p><p>The WHO’s COVID-19 advisory body on Thursday said there were now 863,000 COVID-19 cases, of which 8.7% were deaths, while 2.7% were hospitalisations.<p><p>India has registered an unprecedented 3.7 million COVID-19 cases and 31 deaths, taking its tally to an estimated 11.4 million cases.<p><p>In a statement, the government said the COVAX programme would continue under the first COVAX, and would continue to be monitored by the Indian Medical Agency.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal Authority to open waterway to container ships
content: ['<p>MANILA  - The South China Sea authority on Tuesday approved a $20 million (US$20 million) public-private partnership for the canal, opening it to container shipping from the United States.<p><p>Suez Canal Authority President Jose Felix said he hoped to have it operational within three years, with the $20 million fund for the construction starting in the first quarter of 2021.<p><p>“We are very pleased to see the work underway and see it completed,” Felix told reporters, adding that the project was an economic development initiative.<p><p>“This project is a significant contribution to our region and is a model for other countries in the region, and we hope to become the model for others across the world.”<p> ']

headline: Azerbaijani says it has killed 10,000 of its soldiers in clashes with militants in the Central Asian country
content: ['<p>BAKHARIJAN  - A senior official in the security forces said on Friday that a major battle in the central Asian nation, with 2,500 armed fighters still on the move, had reached an end.<p><p>The army said it had killed 10,000 militants since Wednesday, with the number of civilians fighting to the death on the front line increasing each day since a ceasefire in November collapsed.<p><p>More than 2,500 insurgents have been killed in an ongoing insurgency targeting security forces.<p><p>U.S. President Joe Biden’s administration, which Biden has been pushing to lift the ceasefire, has been holding talks with insurgents over a possible resumption of hostilities.<p><p>“The last thing you want to do is cause panic in your country or cause instability in your country,” said Saad Hijjah, deputy director for regional affairs at the Central Asian military intelligence.<p><p>“You really cannot do that.”<p><p>In recent weeks, the central Asian nation of about 16 million people has been hit by rising tensions, with clashes between security forces and armed groups that have taken the lives of more than 200 people in the past month.<p><p>Fighting has persisted for several days in recent weeks, with some areas being hit by heavy shelling and sporadic fighting between armed groups.<p>']

headline: U.S. wants to give China more freedom and autonomy as China's leader
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. State Department is open to giving Beijing more freedom and autonomy and called on Beijing to respect human rights, the State Department said on Thursday.<p><p>The statement did not provide details of the two-pronged approach Xi Jinping and his team are taking. It also did not specifically mention Uighur ethnic group groups or China’s policy towards Uighurs.<p> ']

headline: MOSCOW  - The head of the Central Asian country’s ruling Communist Party warned on Friday against any form of gradualism and urged people to be open-minded and not allow too much of a change in the face of rising power.
content: ['<p><p>“We must not be able to find solutions in one year and then it will affect our lives as we try to cope with the crisis,” Deputy Prime Minister Yevgeny Bolotov said in a speech in the city of Sakhalin.<p><p>Bolotov was speaking at a Communist Party event to coincide with an anniversary commemoration of the founding of the Communist Party, which was marked by its failure to form a majority government.<p> ']

headline: A total of 4,664 deaths from COVID-19 in France
content: ['<p>PARIS  - Total deaths from COVID-19 in France from the COVID-19 pandemic have been reported at a rate of around 4,664 a day, the health ministry said on Wednesday.<p><p>The latest figures, from the France data services company, show deaths from the epidemic have risen by 15 to 853 since mid-February, although deaths are still lower than the 12,598 that France experienced in mid-February.<p><p>Total deaths from COVID-19 are now the highest since the outbreak began, with the figure rising by 13 to 664 as people sought to escape the crisis.<p> ']

headline: Greece's Greek bailout scheme scrapped, loans cut, government says
content: ['<p>SYRIA  - Greece’s lenders on Monday announced that they had cut funding to the bailout fund and loan programme that helped help it survive the financial meltdown.<p><p>The decision came after months of wrangling over loans taken out by the central bank over what to do with debts Greece owes the IMF.<p><p>The Greek government said it had already been asked to sell bailout money to private lender Anglo-Swiss lender Coelis.<p><p>Under Greek law, lenders have to give the government a specific amount to cover losses they can collect on loans that the government was able to borrow against on its own.<p><p>The government has also requested a $300 million contribution from Anglo-Swiss lender Vaxstra and a $500 million loan from Eurogroup.<p><p>“As part of our ongoing efforts to work out an arrangement to manage the finances of Greece and maintain its credit,” a letter from the Greek finance ministry said in a statement.<p><p>The Greek authorities have imposed fines and a 30-day suspension of all public spending in the troubled southeast in a move that has prompted opposition from lawmakers and investors.<p><p>The government said it will apply the terms of the loans to other projects it could use, but that the aim was not guaranteed.<p>']

headline: Thailand's PM seeks change in monarchy and no changes to top posts
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha on Wednesday sought changes to his position in parliament and the top post in the ruling party, saying changes to the position of the head of state had led to an atmosphere of tension in parliament.<p><p>“My Majesty, I am a reformist, am committed to reform,” Prayuth told parliament.<p><p>“I want to ensure that our democracy can remain intact,” he added, referring to the military coup.<p> ']

headline: Venezuelan opposition leader says he will be taking part in protests against Maduro
content: ['<p>Venezuela’s opposition leader Nicolas Maduro said on Saturday he would be taking part in an armed rebellion against his power-sharing government by Sunday in an effort to pressure Maduro, who faces corruption allegations.<p><p>Maduro, 52, is facing calls by anti-government forces for a nationwide strike by the military. His critics have called it a coup and accuse Maduro of failing to fulfill his promises to reverse decades of dictatorship.<p><p>Venezuela’s constitution allows Maduro to take part in political protests without warrants or a trial by a military court. But he has opposed such such rallies, saying they have allowed the army to detain opposition lawmakers.<p><p>The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled Maduro’s trial unconstitutional and issued a warrantless search warrant, although his allies in the opposition say he still has not made a decision on whether to seek a stay-at-home order or a decree prohibiting his use of torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.<p><p>“We will defend democracy, our sovereignty and freedom, and the rule of law,” Maduro said during a news conference in Caracas. “We will also defend our nation, our people.”<p><p>Maduro has also said he will not give up his grip on power and says the military takeover of Venezuela’s economy was a joke, and has called Maduro’s actions “the beginning of socialism”.<p>']

headline: Biden: Russia 'extremely concerned' about U.S. military ties
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden said he was "extremely concerned" by reports that Russia had violated U.S. laws and breached sanctions against President Vladimir Putin, but that the Russian leader was "getting the message" to the United States.<p> ']

headline: AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine delay as new UK trials push back
content: ['<p>LONDON  -AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine rollout is buckling under pressure from critics who worry that the vaccine delays caused by the pandemic could delay the shot’s effects, despite data showing it is still effective against the virus.<p><p>The UK’s first COVID-19 trial showed the vaccine was effective against the virus and has been accelerated by the use of the vaccine-sharing scheme, while the European Union’s first trial of its own has also shown the benefits of the jab.<p><p>But some critics say delays in the vaccine-sharing scheme are contributing to an alarming rise in infections in countries where the benefits are likely to be outweighed by the risks.<p><p>“I think it’s absolutely ridiculous to say there’s no vaccine safety impact with vaccines, but there is a massive vaccine delay,” said Peter Lewis, an immunologist at Royal Holloway University.<p><p>Lewis said the delay to the second trial would be caused by a “systemic delay”.<p><p>“There is a huge backlog of vaccines that need to be approved,” he added.<p><p>“So it’s very hard to tell that we’ve succeeded and the delay caused by vaccines is the cause of this increase.”<p>']

headline: U.S. says China may have breached Taiwan's sovereignty
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States and its allies expressed alarm on Thursday over reports that China may have breached Taiwan’s sovereignty, which the island’s chief said was being threatened by Chinese troops.<p><p>Taiwan’s foreign minister on Thursday warned that China’s intentions were “insidious, aggressive” and said Beijing would face “the consequences” if it did not respond.<p><p>On Thursday, Taiwan’s foreign minister said Washington was “deeply troubled” about reports that Chinese troops were attacking Taiwanese forces and that Taiwan would have to “stand firm in defending itself.”<p><p>Taiwan’s foreign ministry on Thursday said it remained “deeply concerned” by the reports and called for China’s compliance with international law, which provides a basis for disputes over sovereignty in Taiwan.<p> ']

headline: One in six Chinese children in school has not received a lesson yet
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Nearly one in five children in China’s most populous nation had not received a lesson yet on the topic of education until late last year, a report by the charity Education Now found on Wednesday.<p><p>That was despite the fact that about 40% of the country’s 11.3 million citizens were still struggling to complete their education in five years, the data showed.<p><p>“Most children’s education has not been fully completed by the age of four,” the report said, citing data from the Assistance Commission for China and the Liaoning Children’s Ministry.<p><p>More than 6.2 million children under five had not received a secondary education, the report said, although some students had received a certificate, vocational training or vocational training as well.<p><p>The report did not provide the number of students who had received a secondary education in this age group in 2025, as the data suggest.<p> ']

headline: Blinken's office to announce details of new COVID vaccine after finding link
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The White House is expected to announce details of a vaccine rollout on Tuesday after finding two new cases of coronavirus linked to the former Blinken administration that are still being assessed.<p><p>The White House said in a statement that the Biden administration has been working to identify “a low-risk, nonmanufacturer ‘BioNTech’ vaccine, “that has been proven to be safe and effective against COVID-19.”<p><p>Blinken confirmed on Thursday that it was working to determine the causal mechanism, and said a trial of BioNTech’s vaccine in patients who developed COVID-19 was underway, and that it was “undergoing an important review to verify the safety and efficacy of BioNTech’s vaccine.”<p> ']

headline: White House says it will investigate Russian meddling in U.S. election
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States will “provide full, unequivocal and transparent information to the Russian government’s ongoing efforts to meddle in our election,” White House press secretary Jen Psaki said on Tuesday.<p><p>Asked about a report by the Washington Free Beacon earlier this week that the Kremlin tried to influence the 2016 election in a way that was unlawful, Psaki said that “we will provide the full, unequivocal and transparent information to the Russian government’s continued efforts to violate the elections.”<p> ']

headline: Biden says he will continue pushing Russia to change course
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - President Joe Biden on Thursday said he would continue pushing Russia to change course, but he also said he is “going to be realistic” about what could happen if Vladimir Putin escalates his threat to world peace.<p><p>Biden said he will continue to pursue diplomacy with Russia but reiterated his commitment to the United States and Russia’s shared goal of peaceful development in the region.<p> ']

headline: Biden says U.S. needs to make strategic decision on Iran
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is making strategic decisions regarding Iran as part of a broader effort to develop its nuclear program, the White House said on Thursday, after U.S. officials told reporters the region was in “serious and serious” trouble.<p><p>Speaking to reporters, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said that the U.S. had made "an important decision that has significant implications for the region and the world,” though he did not elaborate.<p> ']

headline: Istanbul is moving cautiously to keep vaccinations slow, opposition says
content: ['<p>ISTANBUL  - Istanbul will gradually take some steps to keep vaccinations steady in coming months, the opposition said on Tuesday, as it sought to ensure its government could follow through with an ambitious vaccination programme.<p><p>The government said the vaccination program in Turkey would take several months to complete, with the aim of keeping it rolling out by mid-2019.<p><p>However, Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan vowed last month to start using the programme when the summer tourist season ends, and suggested early spring could mark the start of regular vaccination efforts.<p><p>Erdogan said on Wednesday that there was a need for swift implementation.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny released from detention
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday ordered an independent inquiry into allegations that the former soccer star and Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny had been detained under the same rules.<p><p>The Kremlin denied reports that Navalny had been given medical or legal asylum despite his claim that he had suffered serious brain damage in hospital.<p><p>Putin said on Thursday that Navalny had been released from hospital.<p><p>“The decision by the authorities is final, but I am sure it will not be taken lightly and this is a good result in terms of rehabilitation. So this is our decision,” Putin said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Nancy Pelosi, Pelosi's pick to become the next Speaker, faces pressure to reverse course after meeting Russian Ambassador
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Democratic majority leader, facing pressure from House Democrats and a rising chorus of criticism from outside the White House, on Monday defended her decision not to meet with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak in person, saying that she had met with him only in person, despite repeated requests to speak with foreign media.<p><p>A House Intelligence Committee report on Friday found contacts between Russian officials and Trump officials in the run-up to the 2018 election, but they were limited to contacts in person, the report said.<p><p>The report said the Trump team asked the ambassador if he understood the terms of the NATO defense treaty, or if he simply understood them.<p><p>“I have not met with anyone who doesn’t understand the terms of the NATO treaty,” Pelosi said in a statement. “That was a mistake, and I have not met with anyone that didn’t understand the terms of NATO and what it means to be a member of NATO.”<p><p>The House Intelligence Committee report did not include a meeting that resulted in any concrete details.<p><p>The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p>']

headline: Myanmar's Rohingya military leader: I apologise
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - Myuran Sukumaran had written to Myanmar’s president last week saying he was sorry for his country’s treatment of the Rohingya, according to an intercept released to Reuters by the Myanmar Support Group (MUSG), Myanmar’s domestic armed forces body.<p><p>In the intercept, released on Wednesday, Sukumaran also said he regretted the treatment he had received by the military junta, and that his country had no place in it.<p><p>The MUSG declined to comment on the intercepted intercept.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin critic Navalny faces criminal charges in absentia over murder of his two younger brothers
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny faces criminal charges after a series of murders and threats against his two younger brothers in absentia, his lawyer said on Monday, in an apparent attempt to show he has no regrets for what he said was a brutal assassination plot.<p><p>Prosecutors allege that Navalny, 30, was arrested after an alleged assault with a knife by the nephew of his father-in-law, Alexander Dzerzhinsky, a politician, and he had received death threats.<p><p>Navalny, who has been under house arrest since December, was arrested again on Thursday in absentia over the alleged plot, a lawyer for Dzerzhinsky told Interfax news agency, the Interfax news agency.<p><p>He denies the charges.<p> ']

headline: Niger's foreign ministry says it will seek to reach a ceasefire with rebels in exchange for release of detainees
content: ['<p>JOHANNESBURG  - National Security Council foreign minister Ernest Dujarric told parliament on Tuesday that it is seeking to reach an agreement with the rebel groups which it says are targeting a government convoy in northern Niger.<p><p>He said that it was the first time that the foreign ministry had spoken to the rebel groups about an agreement.<p> ']

headline: Blinken urges China to take “exemplary steps to ensure China “does not provoke”
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Thursday that Beijing is taking “exemplary steps to ensure China does not provoke” by “using provocative force” and warned that "all options are on the table to address the challenges facing the United States and China’s shared goal of a free and open Indo-Pacific region.”<p><p>Beijing, Washington’s closest ally, has been a flashpoint for Washington’s annual East Asian security review and has called on Beijing to refrain from what it sees as incursions on its territory and assert territorial claims.<p><p>Biden, speaking at an annual meeting with Chinese officials in Washington, said that Beijing remained committed to full implementation of the United Nations Security Council’s 2015 resolution recognizing China as the state power and that Beijing needed to ensure the implementation of the Security Council resolution to uphold the rights of all peoples.<p><p>China has said its goal of a free and open Indo-Pacific region is to develop the economy, improve its trade and the environment, develop its own energy and space industries and safeguard its national security interests.<p><p>Speaking with reporters in his New York home, Biden said China should continue to advance its goal of “ensuring China does not provoke” by using provocative force, adding: “I’m prepared to engage on those challenges and will make sure that we see that, wherever possible, China will be willing to confront those challenges,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Fitch says it's not worried by BMO's Covid-19 vaccine rollout
content: ['<p>BMO and Covid-19 vaccine maker Johnson & Johnson are facing major difficulties getting their COVID-19 vaccines to people in the United States that had previously received their own shots, citing concerns over rising blood clotting.<p><p>In a letter sent Tuesday to lawmakers, the firms said that the U.S. is the single-largest vaccine recipient for their shots and the agency that administers them said the new restrictions are being addressed.<p><p>They did not provide a timeline for when the changes might affect their operations.<p><p>“The vaccines received by the U.S. have been provided through the U.S. vaccination support agency and its partnership with the CDC and other stakeholders,” the letter said. “The U.S. has an unprecedented ability to deliver vaccines to all our patients.”<p><p>The letter is the latest setback to the BMO vaccine rollout, which has been delayed by the arrival of the first AstraZeneca shots in Canada and Mexico this week and last week.<p><p>More than 1 million people have received AstraZeneca’s shots, according to the National Institutes of Health.<p><p>The company has previously said its vaccine rollout was in line with what the agency recommended. But the company has also come under pressure from Democrats and health experts for the delays in administering AstraZeneca’s shots.<p>']

headline: The Chinese state-run Xinhua news agency said on Monday it has resumed operations after an investigation revealed a series of human rights abuses in Xinjiang. It said it was working to establish a nationwide database of reports, which the Xinhua news agency said could take months.
content: ['<p><p>In its first full year on the job, Xinhua said it had registered more than 500 new cases of violence and rape in Xinjiang, the last reported in September, a day after it announced new initiatives targeting Muslim separatists in Xinjiang.<p><p>In addition to the investigations that it reported earlier this week, a number of investigations were also launched against members of the Muslim Uighur minority in Xinjiang and the Uighur minority in the Xinjiang Economic Area, the agency said.<p><p>The Xinhua news agency said the authorities had opened investigations into the activities of the Islamist Uighurs in the U.S., but there was no immediate claim that it was directly involved in the Xinjiang violence.<p><p>U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited Xinjiang on Thursday to urge the local government to open an investigation, according to two U.S. officials familiar with the talks.<p><p>The United States has asked China to refrain from actions that could lead to ethnic violence and to give up control over its borders. The United States has called on China to respect Uighur sovereignty.<p>']

headline: Suez Canal canal closure looms on
content: ['<p>CAIRO  -The canal is closing for three days as the authorities prepare to complete the long-awaited $2 billion project and resume the process to free it from the brink of collapse.<p><p>The International Organization for Migration said on Thursday it was suspending the closure of the canal for two days following an increase in water flows in recent days.<p><p>The canal is expected to open in seven days from Tuesday.<p> ']

headline: Django coronavirus variant linked to AstraZeneca shot, WHO says
content: ['<p>JOHANNESBURG  - A cluster of rare blood clots in the blood vessels of the elderly in the Indonesian city of Davao City may be linked to Covid-19 vaccines, the United Nations said on Tuesday, as authorities urged the public to get vaccinated against the rare, first reported by local media.<p><p>Three of the patients died, the head of the WHO-led World Health Organization, Christine Schneider, said at a briefing.<p><p>The WHO has not publicly reported any cases in Davao City, the Philippines or nearby provinces.<p><p>There have been 762 cases in the world, more than in any other major city, the head of the COVAX-Europe-WHO’s office in the world’s leading tropical disease monitoring group, Christoph Schaeffner, said.<p><p>The deaths occurred around 5 p.m. (0100 GMT) local time (0100 GMT) in the city of Aliso Viejo, Schaeffner said.<p> ']

headline: Nigerian PM says he will not seek election again - party leader
content: ['<p> - President Muhammadu Buhari on Thursday told parliament he has decided to step down and will not seek a second term, but said he had seen the results of last year’s parliamentary elections and did not expect an election as planned.<p><p>“I am determined to make a full recovery of my people and restore the rule of law,” Buhari told parliament, according to an interview broadcast by state TV.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal diverts water and dredgers resume operation
content: ['<p>AMSTERDAM  - Suez Canal traffic in the South African port city was cut off on Monday after a diverting tugging from the nearby Canal Authority (CEMA) began diverting dredgers in the channel around 20 km (10 miles) north of it, local media reported.<p><p>CEMA said it had ordered dredgers to move dredging vessels and that the container ship carrying the large container ship had resumed movement of dredging vessels in parallel with the dredging operations, with no delay.<p><p>A canal authority official told Reuters that it had instructed the diverting tugging firm to move dredging vessels out of the way of the canal.<p><p>“The vessels were directed to divert to the other side of the canal,” the official said.<p><p>“The canal authority has ordered all necessary steps to enable dredging to resume at the same speed and speed as planned. The diverting tugging service also has ordered all necessary instruments to be used to determine the proper speed and direction to move the vessel to safety.”<p> ']

headline: U.S. calls for Saudi to resume production of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Thursday the United States is in talks with Saudi Arabia to resume production of AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine, which is already under review after it was administered in Europe.<p><p>Blinken said the talks in Geneva were held to “establish the status quo” and urged Saudi Arabia to resume production of the vaccine.<p><p>Saudi Arabia has suspended production of the coronavirus vaccine, while the United States and other Western nations have suspended production of the AstraZeneca shot.<p><p>Biden’s office did not immediately respond to a request for comment.<p><p>White House spokesman Jen Psaki did not attend the briefing.<p><p>Biden said on Tuesday that the United States will continue to monitor the situation in Yemen.<p><p>“We urge the Saudi regime to resume all deliveries of the AstraZeneca vaccine to Yemen,” he told a briefing.<p><p>The White House has said the kingdom will resume production of the AstraZeneca shot after the United States and other Western countries suspend production and suspend production of the vaccine in April 2020.<p>']

headline: One in three Americans suffers COVID-19 symptoms after AstraZeneca shot, according to new survey
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  -Nearly one in four Americans (19.1 million) have experienced a first COVID-19 episode in the last two weeks, a new Reuters/Ipsos poll shows, with more than three-quarters of respondents having experienced at least one episode in the previous four weeks.<p><p>Download the NBC News app for breaking news and politics<p><p>Nearly three in four people have experienced a first case in the last 24 hours, compared with just under two in 10 people who have experienced at least one episode each month since October 2019.<p><p>The percentage of people who have experienced an episode or two has risen since July, when only about half the adult U.S. population had an episode.<p><p>About half of those who have experienced an episode and one episode since May 30 have died, while about half the population has received a second dose.<p><p>The prevalence of a first episode in the population has also increased, from about three in every 10 in September 2019 to over seven in June 2020, according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos survey.<p><p>The prevalence of an episode, including a second dose, was at its highest level since July, according to a Reuters/Ipsos analysis, but has climbed steadily since the pandemic began.<p>']

headline: Ties between U.S. and Russia on Syria
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Monday Russia’s annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and support of Russian President Vladimir Putin to President Bashar al-Assad are the main impediments to a negotiated peace agreement in Syria.<p><p>A spokesman for Biden’s administration did not answer calls seeking comment on the statement.<p> ']

headline: Biden: Russia may have access to U.S. intelligence collection
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Thursday he had confidence in Russian intelligence services over recent Russian actions in the United States, but added he doubted they would ever be able to obtain U.S. intelligence gathering tools.<p><p>“I have confidence in Russia, I don’t have confidence in any foreign power,” he told reporters on Capitol Hill.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Myanmar's army's COVID-19 vaccine campaign overshadows progress on fighting
content: ['<p> - Myanmar’s military has taken a hard line towards COVID-19 vaccine makers amid fears of a major backlash.<p><p>A U.N. report on Sunday showed that on average, the country’s inoculations have been less than 40% effective.<p><p>“The outbreak of COVID-19 appears to have been largely uncoordinated, with no coordinated vaccination campaign,” it said.<p><p>“The results of the vaccination campaign are disappointing because of the scale of the problem and the sensitivity of the virus to administering vaccines effectively.”<p><p>The army is “extremely concerned about the current situation in Myanmar, and has declared war on the government and ethnic armed groups responsible for any increase in the incidence of this disease.”<p><p>In a sign of how vulnerable Myanmar was to the virus, the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization is expected to announce its plans for dealing with the coronavirus within weeks, after which it will start vaccinating the population.<p><p>The army has also refused to provide the necessary vaccines to combat the pandemic, saying its vaccination programme was “underfunded”.<p><p>It has been unable to inoculate 100,000 people in the country since March 8 despite an intensive response and a push by the army to vaccinate 1.4 million people.<p><p>I']

headline: Puerto Rico's economy shrank by 2.7% last week, easing pressure on government finances
content: ['<p>SAN JOSE  - Puerto Rico’s economy shrank by 2.7% last week and eased pressure on government finances, the country’s economic ministry said on Wednesday, easing pressure on the government’s budget shortfall to 2.4% from 5.2%.<p> ']

headline: Blinken says he will oppose COVID-19 travel ban
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Blinken said he will oppose a federal travel ban on international travel during his six-month term, arguing the measure would make America more vulnerable to COVID-19.<p><p>Speaking at the White House briefing, Blinken said he planned to oppose the travel ban on the grounds it would cause harm to the United States, adding that the United States was also vulnerable to COVID-19 because of its trade and investment policies.<p><p>“We’re still vulnerable to COVID,” Blinken said. “And we’ve had plenty of opportunities to go overseas. But there is no way around it.”<p> ']

headline: Hospitals in Greece drop lockdown in wake of death toll from COVID-19
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Hospitals in Greece, which has the second highest COVID-19 death toll in Europe, are shut for four to five days while hospitals fill their own beds, Health Minister Christos Koufus said on Monday.<p><p>“People are afraid to come to the emergency room in this city,” Koufus told reporters.<p> ']

headline: U.S. says Iran-backed Houthis in Yemen plan to use air strikes on Saudi Arabia
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is prepared to carry out air strikes in Yemen to target Iranian-backed Houthis who are waging a brutal crackdown in the country’s capital, the State Department said on Thursday.<p><p>The United States was considering targeting Iranian-backed Houthi groups in Yemen, including some with air power, the State Department said.<p><p>“We have been making some recommendations, and we have made them concretely in the context of Yemen,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken told reporters after a meeting with Saudi Arabia’s King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.<p><p>The kingdom has expressed concern over the presence of Iranian Revolutionary Guards (IRGC) and regional allies in its eastern regions. Iran denies this.<p><p>Blinken said that while Iran has not yet launched attacks against its targets in the war-torn country, it was preparing to do so.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin critic slams U.S. for sanctions against Putin
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday urged Russia to work with the West to ensure that Russia “does not get involved in what may amount to a war with Ukraine”.<p><p>Blinken said the United States is watching closely what actions Russia could take to help restore Ukraine’s sovereignty and sovereignty and that the Russian leadership wants to work with the West to protect the Russian economy.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar troops killed two civilians in clashes with security forces
content: ['<p> - Myanmar’s security forces killed two civilians and wounded four in clashes with security forces near the town of Maungdaw on Saturday, the army said in a statement.<p><p>Myanmar has been in a bloody, bloody, and possibly even violent standoff with troops since at least Feb. 1, when its army ousted a longtime ally from power amid months of street protests, a crackdown that the United States described as a coup.<p><p>The clashes occurred after the army announced plans to impose some economic measures, including closing roads, shutting down businesses, and allowing residents to be evacuated.<p><p>“Today, the army’s security forces killed two civilians, wounding four, and injured seven, the army said, in a statement on Twitter. Their deaths are the casualties of the two soldiers who were killed while standing near the road to exit and leave the village,” the statement added.<p><p>A military spokesman said on Saturday that the deaths were “inconceivable” and called the killings an “act of war”.<p> ']

headline: U.S. to give AstraZeneca vaccine to AstraZeneca in 2019
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is giving AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine to the first batch of U.S. drugmakers in 2019, the administration said on Friday.<p><p>President Joe Biden on Friday said he was in talks with Pfizer over whether to resume supplies of AstraZeneca’s shot, which is manufactured by Johnson & Johnson and used on a large scale in Brazil.<p><p>AstraZeneca on Friday said it has been supplying the vaccine to drugmakers in Europe, as well as to companies in the U.S. and other markets.<p><p>Biden’s talks with Pfizer, whose shares have also risen since he took office in January, are continuing.<p> ']

headline: FEMA approves new temporary lockdown for most parts of COVID-19
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved the COVID-19 emergency lockdown for most of the United States on Wednesday, the agency said, in the third wave of the pandemic.<p><p>The order also extends an existing lockdown imposed in late September on the South, east and west coast until mid-April.<p> ']

headline: Biden says 'troubling' China's situation on Taiwan, says 'courage'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Friday he felt "courage" in Beijing’s situation in Taiwan following reports that Chinese President Xi Jinping’s aides were preparing to engage in a fourth round of military drills, as China’s foreign ministry praised the Biden administration’s handling of the latest row with Taiwan.<p><p>The Biden administration on Thursday said it has spoken with Taiwan’s Taiwan Affairs Office to understand how tensions might escalate as Beijing seeks to assert sovereignty over the island.<p><p>“In the spirit of our engagement, we have communicated with our Taiwan advisors and with the relevant authorities... to ensure that we maintain our constructive and constructive dialogue,” Blinken said in remarks before a news conference with senior Chinese officials.<p><p>China’s Foreign Ministry said its "grave concern" of Blinken’s comments comes as it works with the Biden administration on deepening the economic ties with Taiwan.<p><p>Taiwan’s Foreign Ministry said Blinken’s remarks were “a major blow to our bilateral relations,” and called on China to end its “inconceivable violation of our fundamental rights and freedoms”, according to the state news agency.<p> ']

headline: Graphic: How far north to the north is India’s COVID-19 surge?
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - The situation in northern India, and the state of Kerala’s overall COVID-19 safety record in recent weeks, is grim.<p><p>The grim situation, in the first sign of an uptick in cases, has led the Indian government to set up a vaccination drive to stem the spread of the virus.<p><p>Kerala’s Health Ministry, citing local medical and social service officials, said last week the number of new coronavirus cases in the state was on a decline, although its vaccination drive was progressing.<p><p>State hospitals have reported more cases and deaths than usual due to the virus, and the numbers are being slowly but steadily rising.<p><p>A day before, India’s COVID-19 advisory committee said it had detected 13 new cases of the coronavirus, although health officials said the number would rise again as the risk of infections in the coming weeks climbed.<p><p>Kerala’s vaccination drive is one of many in the country, with one state administering more than 300,000 doses.<p><p>The government has been battling a second wave of infections after a surge in deaths last month.<p><p>State health authorities, however, have also administered a second dose of vaccine on Monday after the first three doses last month.<p>']

headline: U.S. urges countries to use COVID-19 vaccine to treat COVID-19
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken told U.S. lawmakers on Wednesday they must use their COVID-19 vaccine as a “very serious concern” and urged them to protect U.S. allies with more intensive vaccination efforts.<p><p>Biden, who has called for strict limits on the use of the COVID-19 vaccine, said a new shot, which is already available in the U.S., was not needed due to COVID-19.<p><p>“It’s not enough just to take a little bit of what we already have,” Blinken said, adding the shot is being developed by Pfizer Inc.’s vaccine group.<p><p>“That’s a serious concern. It’s an important concern.”<p> ']

headline: MILAN  - A major Islamist rebel group in Mali has declared a coup against President Mohamed Muhyiddin and said it is sending armed men to destabilise the country.
content: ['<p><p>The Islamist insurgents, also known as Muhyiddin al-Islamiya, claim control of large parts of Mali and around 40% of northern Mali, where most of the world’s population has been displaced by fighting since 2014.<p><p>Mali’s army has battled Islamist militants since 2011, though its operations are far more limited and sporadic.<p><p>Militants have also launched large scale attacks in the southern provinces of Burkina Faso and Niger, which are now at war with each other.<p><p>It has not commented on the developments in Mali, but on what it said were attacks launched by the militants from Mali’s eastern sector of northern Mali.<p><p>The declaration of a coup against Muhyiddin and a new constitution for parliament comes after years of turmoil in the region.<p> ']

headline: Cleveland's Biden's health secretary says he's worried about COVID-19 rise
content: ['<p>Cleveland’s mayor John Deutch said Wednesday he was worried by reports of increased coronavirus infections.<p><p>“The numbers are increasing, and I’m in a very serious situation.”<p> ']

headline: Rescuers: Palestinians fleeing Israeli attack on Gaza say they will return to their homes
content: ["<p>ISRAEL  - A group of Palestinian rescuers said on Thursday they will return to their homes in northern Israel as the Israeli army’s attack on Gaza intensified, amid growing fears of a renewed Israeli offensive.<p><p>On Monday, Palestinian security forces fired on hundreds of Palestinian villages in the northern part of the border area.<p><p>As the Israeli army started its assault, activists from the Palestinian Ma'ariv movement said on Twitter that they would return to their homes, saying they would not be allowed to leave and urged them to stay in their homes.<p><p>The group, which has been calling for an independent, independent Palestinian state, also said on Twitter that they would be sending out fighters to take control of Gaza.<p><p>“The Israeli army is on a rampantly accelerating military assault on our territory,” they tweeted.<p><p>Palestinian activist Abu Jamal told Reuters on Thursday evening that he and several other activists had been killed by Israeli troops.<p><p>“There’s no way back. The people who live in the communities will never be able to come back.”<p><p>The Israeli army on Thursday launched a sweeping offensive to dislodge the militant Islamist Hamas movement, and residents said it had struck homes and taken several military and civilian buildings.<p>"]

headline: AstraZeneca is making some of the world's most affordable COVID vaccines at lower prices, as it sees fit.
content: ['<p><p>NEW YORK  - AstraZeneca has announced it has made some of the world’s most affordable COVID vaccines at lower prices with a $500 charge for first shot in a partnership with U.S.-based BioNTech, but that will be its flagship offering for those who want to get shots with lower prices.<p><p>BioNTech and AstraZeneca are the two biggest producers of COVID-19 vaccines in the world and have signed a 10-year commercial agreement.<p><p>The AstraZeneca shots, which have a total of more than 30 million doses, would be offered at an average price of about $1,700.<p><p>The company plans to launch its low-cost COVID-19 vaccine in mid-2020, similar to AstraZeneca’s shot, which has a price tag of about $10.<p><p>In a statement, BioNTech said it will launch a first-stage, or vaccine-assisted, COVAX-based COVID-19 vaccine on March 29 in India, where more than 500 million people have received it.<p><p>The AstraZeneca vaccine, which is produced in China with Chinese help, is the largest in the world behind the AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines.<p>']

headline: A World of Difference: How the Japanese and French Debate U.S. Policy in the Pacific Ocean
content: ['<p> -The Atlantic Council’s Future of the Pacific Institute, a nonprofit group of scientists that advocates for equitable development, recently interviewed experts from the U.S. Pacific coast, as part of a trip to Washington, D.C. They discussed U.S. policy toward the Pacific Ocean and the relationship between the two countries, and the future of the Pacific.<p><p>The Pacific Institute, which promotes equitable development and human rights in the Pacific, is an international network of researchers, policymakers, and activists engaged in promoting a global economic model based on the global economic vision, including U.S. and Japanese trade ties, the establishment of international trade treaties, and environmental protection law, among other efforts.<p><p>While the group does not endorse specific policies, it emphasizes the need for international cooperation, particularly as the region seeks to address key challenges facing its neighbors including poverty, water scarcity, disease, and climate change.<p><p>It also emphasizes the role of governments and companies in addressing global challenges such as climate change and pollution.<p><p>It also is a component of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and seeks to protect the environment.<p><p>Pacific Research Institute (PRI) Director, Peter W. Sperry, recently traveled to Washington, D.C., for the Future of the Pacific Institute’s Future of the Ocean tour.<p>']

headline: One of India's richest states faces 'unwavering opposition' from opposition parties
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - A state with some of India’s richest states on top of a row over health services could face mounting opposition from opposition parties, a senior government official said on Thursday.<p><p>Hindustan, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Haryana and Telangana are also under threat from “unwavering opposition” from the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party.<p><p>“India’s economy is in a critical state due to the government’s failure to deliver,” Deputy Chief Minister of Maharashtra Vidhan Sabha Suresh Chavan said at a news conference.<p><p>The Bharatiya Janata party has said its leader, Uddhav Thackeray, was jailed over alleged corruption charges and corruption charges were baseless.<p><p>The Centre on Thursday urged states to form a government to form a government, though most states do not have a governor.<p><p>Union Home Minister Rajesh Chaudhry on Thursday accused the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party of playing politics with their own state.<p><p>“The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party is playing with politics and has been making a spectacle out of it. India is a corrupt country,” Chaudhry said, adding that most states had failed to meet their own revenue targets.<p>']

headline: Greece says COVID-19 patients in intensive care units receive a second dose
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Greece has agreed to drop a measure to give patients who contracted COVID-19 to receive a second dose of an experimental vaccine to begin treatment as soon as possible, after the European Medicines Agency (EMA) said on Tuesday it may refuse to withhold the supplies.<p><p>It said on Tuesday it would halt exports of AstraZeneca’s shot to poorer regions as the country reported 19,900 coronavirus cases, of which more than 80,000 were among patients in intensive care units, mainly in Greece.<p><p>EMA said on Tuesday it would not give further advice.<p><p>It said on Tuesday it had authorised AstraZeneca’s vaccine in the European Economic Area, allowing it to proceed with the first dose.<p><p>It said it would also provide vaccines to EU countries already administering COVID-19 vaccines.<p><p>“This decision is made in the interest of the citizens of Greece,” EMA said in a statement.<p><p>“We are confident, in line with the current guidelines, that all existing supplies for vaccines will be ready for use.”<p> ']

headline: A woman stands on top of a building, surrounded by soldiers, to prevent an explosion at the entrance to the Kabul airport on Monday. Several soldiers surrounded her as she tried to enter the airport, Kabul airport authorities said, after the blast. (TIMELINE: Four explosions in the past 24 hours at the airport; Kabul airport blast: 3
content: ['<p>Kabul airport authorities said on Monday that two of the explosions occurred outside the airport and had affected personnel on arrival. The explosion, they said, started at the entrance and was followed by the third explosion, which took place around 10 a.m. (1915 GMT).<p><p>One of the men, Mohammad Yahya, said he had run away from his home when the blast took place. He said he was taken to a hospital with a broken leg and that he remained in critical condition.<p><p>Fourteen people have died in Afghanistan since 2017 when militants launched an offensive to overrun a provincial capital and secure the country’s second city.<p><p>The Afghan government said last month it planned to set up a military camp in the heart of Kabul for displaced people after a Taliban offensive killed nearly 1,500 civilians in its first wave of security forces in 2016.<p><p>On Sunday, an explosion destroyed an old bus terminal at Kabul airport.<p><p>A spokeswoman for the air force said a bomber struck the bus terminal near the Afghan capital, the capital’s main airport, at around 2:30 p.m., hitting a group of soldiers and a truck, both of them killed, while at least one man was wounded.']

headline: Possible path for COVID-19 deaths to rise in Northern Ireland after Easter break
content: ['<p>HARRYL JOHNSON, U.K. <p>LONDON  - British Health Minister Dr Lise Schulte said the latest COVID-19 death toll in Northern Ireland “should not rise too much and should not fall too low” in light of a recent surge in infections.<p><p>“There is a path for deaths to rise across the Northern Ireland region and I would urge people to stay away from gatherings, but to stay within acceptable health guidelines”, she told a briefing.<p><p>Health Minister Peter Dutton warned in a speech this week the current coronavirus pandemic was likely to worsen.<p><p>“At this stage the odds of fatalities rising significantly outweigh the likelihood of a resurgence in fatalities,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny killed by security forces in Ukraine
