content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Russian soldier who had attacked an ethnic Russian military base in eastern Ukraine’s Donbass said on Saturday he had been killed by soldiers who had ambushed a military convoy.<p><p>“I don’t know if the security personnel were there and killed him, but the military was there. This is how it is happening now. My body was riddled with bullets and so they took my body away,” Nikolai Nikitin, a military spokesman for the pro-Russian separatist Luhansk People’s Republic, said on Twitter.<p> ']

headline: Tobacco watchdog says India may have more than 100 million deaths from COVID-19
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - India has about 100 million coronavirus cases and deaths, but no national data on its use of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine, the World Health Organization said on Monday, as it warned it was facing an ongoing health crisis.<p><p>The WHO said in a report published late on Monday that it was aware of a “high incidence” of COVID-19 among the population, while at the same time adding that “significant disparities” exist between the different types of vaccine.<p><p>The WHO said more research was needed to understand how different doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine could prevent deaths from COVID-19.<p><p>“The incidence of COVID-19 among the United States, Canada, Germany, and other countries is high,” it said.<p><p>India’s vaccination campaign, which has been hampered by delays caused by the pandemic, has been slow to receive enough shots and has so far received only 4 million doses from AstraZeneca.<p><p>India’s COVID-19 vaccination campaign has been slowed by slow deliveries by the government, which is relying on voluntary vaccination programmes to help contain the coronavirus.<p> ']

headline: Indonesia says it will not impose strict curbs on gatherings, including on girls
content: ['<p>JAKARTA  - Indonesian authorities on Tuesday said they would impose strict curbs on gatherings and gatherings of girls under the age of 13 at the weekend, amid the country’s record record high murder rate.<p><p>The move followed comments made by the country’s top prosecutor, Tan Sri Mohsin Gudipudi, saying he planned to impose curfews in Jakarta on Saturday.<p><p>“We don’t want to cause any social disorder,” he said, adding that religious minorities and non-Muslims are not welcome.<p> ']

headline: Munich police arrest six more suspected gang members in'suicide plot'
content: ['<p>MUNICH  - Police in Munich on Thursday arrested six suspected gang members in connection with a suicide plot in which nine people died in separate attacks on subway stations on Thursday.<p><p>The suspect, identified as 24-year-old Felix Fuhrung from the area of Südde-Blatt, had already been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, police said.<p> ']

headline: Blinken says U.S. may delay U.S. military build-up in Afghanistan amid 'continuous risk of escalation'
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Friday that “continuance” is the key to halting a U.S. military build-up in Afghanistan and said it was “not reasonable to expect that the U.S. can continue to continue to provide support to Afghan forces through the use of force and intimidation.”<p><p>The remarks came as Washington sought to tamp down any further escalation in Afghanistan after U.S. Special Envoy Chris Stevens sent a force of about 200 Afghan security forces to train Afghan forces in an effort to fend off a “calculated risk” of escalation.<p><p>White House spokesman Ned Price said he was “shoulder to shoulder” with Afghan officials as they sought to build the security needed to prevent further escalation.<p><p>“We have been absolutely clear in our discussions with the Taliban and the Afghan leadership that there are no imminent threats to our country or the Afghan people or the stability of Afghanistan,” Price told reporters.<p><p>The United States has been conducting an extensive domestic and foreign policy review since taking office in January, including plans to re-expose U.S. drone attacks in Pakistan and Saudi Arabia, as well as the deployment of more U.S. military personnel to Pakistan under the Johnson administration.<p>']

headline: Kremlin says it will not tolerate human rights violations in eastern Ukraine
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Thursday it would not tolerate human rights abuses in eastern Ukraine and called for an international ceasefire.<p><p>The Russian Foreign Ministry said it had sent a letter to the Ukrainian president urging him to release all political prisoners held in the former Soviet republic of Donbas and the release of prisoners in Belarus, Lithuania and Ukraine.<p> ']

headline: Greece asks IMF for help to address shortages
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Greece’s finance minister told the IMF on Tuesday he wanted a meeting on the situation of Greek consumers to help tackle shortages, as lenders rushed to find ways to plug the gap left by the euro currency’s collapse.<p><p>The Greek government had promised to help Greece with its financial crisis by stabilising its finances but could not do so on Tuesday.<p><p>Asked if Greece would meet in the coming days on the situation of its 30 million people, Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said: “I want to emphasise that I’m not concerned about the economic situation,” but that his country will “continue to respond.”<p><p>The IMF, which is responsible for financing the euro zone’s recovery, on Tuesday said a meeting of its member countries could take place on Wednesday.<p><p>“I want to stress that we are prepared for... constructive measures to be taken by the IMF.”<p><p>“The IMF is a very important institution for Greece. We will continue to respond accordingly,” Varoufakis said.<p><p>“I am not concerned about the economic situation. I am concerned about the people’s predicament and the inability of the Greek public sector to deliver...”<p>']

headline: Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny's family rejects extradition request
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Russian lawyer has rejected the request to set up a foreign court for jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny and a number of relatives of his family refused to accept the extradition request, saying it was politically motivated.<p><p>Navalny, a longtime critic of Vladimir Putin, was held in prison in Russia’s penal colony of Motegi in February 2015 for a string of human rights abuses. He spent two and a half years in detention before being released on bail.<p><p>“The request by the Russian Federation for extradition is politically motivated,” Alexei Navalny’s family said in a statement published by the newspaper Izvestia on Friday.<p><p>It also called on Russia’s foreign ministry to investigate the allegations.<p><p>In 2016, Alexei Navalny was jailed for life for a politically motivated trial in which he denied killing anyone and was acquitted on all charges.<p> ']

headline: 'No more big explosions': Chinese navy ships block Suez Canal
content: ['<p> - Chinese warships blocking the Suez Canal in protest against rising seas around it were blocking the waterway for about three days, an air defence identification vessel said on Thursday, the first such blocking on the canal in more than a decade.<p><p>Beijing has been trying to keep a lid on the global seas around the canal, which is running along the banks of the Ticonderoga and Suez Canal, since March 2019 as part of China’s self-declared Belt and Road initiative, and has called for the opening of the canal after an investigation into a 2010 explosion on a canal floor.<p><p>The ship blocking the canal, which runs between the Suez Canal and the Gulf of Mexico, also blockaded a fishing boat, a maritime official from the Chinese navy said.<p><p>“We were not aware at this time, but it was clearly the same vessel blocking the canal as before,” the official said, adding the ship was blocking the canal.<p><p>Chinese ships have been regularly blocking the canal since 1867, during the war of independence that ended in 1902.<p><p>The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) on Thursday said vessels were blocking two ships which were transporting about 40,000 tonnes of fish to Asia, a bulk fish cargo ship and rubber boats, and that the SCA had ordered a special inspection for the vessel blocking the canal for about two days.<p>']

headline: Myanmar army's leader says coalition will be stronger next time
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - The Myanmar military is preparing to strengthen a coalition with allies, Prime Minister Min Aung Hlaing said on Tuesday, after a meeting of his government and its allies in Geneva, the United Nations.<p><p>“We have decided not to prolong our coalition with the alliance of China, Russia, France and other allies until the time is right,” Min Aung Hlaing said. “The coalition of these countries will come together in the strongest possible way,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Thailand says it will lift restrictions on Myanmar's Myanmar junta from 20 Feb.
content: ['<p>KUALA LUMPUR  - Thailand will lift sanctions against a senior official who has called on Myanmar “to return to democracy” and to hold political talks with the military, its foreign ministry said on Wednesday.<p><p>Khan, who resigned as prime minister in 2019, said on Twitter that he was “on his way home”. Myanmar’s military said the country is under military control and that the army had seized power.<p><p>Khan is a close ally of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha and is the biggest backer of a civilian junta that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi’s elected government last month.<p><p>The junta is trying to form a new government, but opposition politicians said it was too late.<p><p>In a statement to Reuters, the foreign ministry said it had notified the relevant authorities that they have “conditions for holding meetings and consultations with representatives of the military government of Myanmar and the relevant authorities,” and was awaiting further information.<p><p>The statement came after two prominent human rights activists, the author, Chit Aung Hlaing, and an activist in the United States, Lee Mun, released a statement last month challenging the junta’s authority and demand they respect its human rights and freedom of expression.<p>']

headline: The BBC reports that British foreign minister Boris Johnson plans to ask Ukraine to send troops to Ukraine: statement
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The British foreign minister said on Tuesday Britain would request Ukraine to send British troops to defend its eastern border and said Russia would play “fairly high-handed”.<p><p>Johnson’s visit to Ukraine comes as he seeks to bridge the gap between Washington and Moscow over whether Russian forces are fighting Ukrainian forces near the border.<p> ']

headline: China sends AstraZeneca vaccine to UK, France
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China sent a shipment of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine to Britain and France on Monday, the first shipment of the vaccine to China since the pandemic shuttered China’s third-largest economy.<p><p>China has said it aims to deliver 10 million doses of the vaccine by the end of the summer.<p><p>“It’s good news that it’s in Europe,” a China’s foreign ministry spokesman said in an interview with Reuters in Beijing on Monday. “It’s good news that it’s being sent to the UK, the Netherlands, France and other places.”<p><p>A spokesman for China’s Health Ministry said the country’s goal is to deliver the vaccine to China on March 16, with another shipment to come in the fall.<p><p>China has also said a COVID-19 vaccine shot would be produced in China for its citizens.<p><p>China has said it is “keeping strict measures in place” to prevent the pandemic from worsening.<p><p>On Tuesday, the European Union said it would stop vaccinating its citizens, and on Monday, France said it will stop vaccinating its citizens on Thursday.<p>']

headline: U.S. to use force in Yemen to try to contain Houthi attacks
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States will use all necessary means to contain Yemen’s Houthi insurgency to try to contain its attack, President Joe Biden said on Wednesday.<p><p>The use of force would be “a wake-up call that the people of the Middle East are in the middle of an enormous threat,” Biden told a news conference.<p> ']

headline: A Palestinian woman and boy are among five Palestinians killed in attacks on Israeli settlers in the West Bank
content: ['<p>BETHLEHEM  - Five Palestinian teenagers were killed by Israelis in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem on Monday and eight wounded in attacks on settlers, Israel’s military said in a statement.<p><p>The attacks, in which the assailants threw stones at soldiers, killed the fifth victim and wounded six others, the military said.<p><p>Nine people were killed by Israelis on Saturday in attacks by Palestinians in the West Bank, East Jerusalem and the Palestinian West Bank, and another 20 more were wounded in attacks on Israeli forces, it said.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: The Kremlin says Ukraine is under no obligation to cooperate with Ukraine in investigating Kremlin collusion
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Wednesday it has repeatedly asked Ukraine for access to a U.S. intelligence report which was critical of Moscow’s role in the 2014 conflict in eastern Ukraine.<p><p>The report said Moscow had intervened in the conflict to protect Ukrainian security forces and that Moscow had no obligation to intervene in any way to stop the killings of civilians.<p> ']

headline: A total of 622 Britons have died and 12,109 injured in air strikes by Syria
content: ['<p>LONDON  - A total of 622 Britons were killed and 12,109 injured in a total of air strikes by Syrian regime forces in Syria since early October, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said on Wednesday.<p><p>The death toll rose by 568 to 798, with 9,037 injured and 9,714 dead, it added.<p> ']

headline: U.N. experts: U.N. mission to investigate chemical weapons attack on Iraq 'a catastrophe'
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - The United Nations expert panel investigating alleged chemical weapons attacks on Iraq on Feb. 21 found widespread knowledge of “unfounded” allegations and said the United Nations was watching closely to see if “concrete and credible information” was being shared with the Iraqi government.<p><p>The panel’s report released on Wednesday said the United Nations had been concerned about the possibility that some U.N. weapons inspectors might have shared information they had with Iraqi officials about chemical weapons.<p><p>It said the panel’s work had been hampered by “unconstitutionally delayed and incomplete” access to Iraqi intelligence.<p><p>“If we believe that we have not been following up on the panel’s report, we would recommend that we proceed to full compliance with all U.N. obligations,” it said.<p><p>The panel recommended the use of all available means to investigate the alleged attacks to determine if Iraq was preparing for imminent attacks.<p><p>“UNHCR is a vital contributor to the international effort to end the Syrian civil war,” Human Rights Watch said in a statement.<p>']

headline: The EU's crisis in Mali - expert
content: ['<p>MADRID  - The crisis in Mali has dragged on for months and President François Mitterrand has expressed hope that aid will ease in coming months.<p><p>MADRID  - The EU’s crisis in Mali has dragged on for months, with reports that the French government is considering buying a new army and troops for a third wave.<p><p>Some diplomats believe that a peace process could be started but it is unclear how quickly a process could be in place.<p><p>Mali’s government has refused to accept aid and has pledged to deliver food, medicine and other basic services to the population once French troops leave and it is believed it may be possible to build a new “peace camp”.<p><p>Aid officials from both sides have been trying to set the stage for a “peace process” for months, but only this week received a clear reply from France that it was in the “national interest” for the country to leave the African Union and to work with other countries to end the crisis.<p><p>“We are ready and ready, we will make sure that the situation in Mali does not worsen again,” Foreign Minister Ursula von der Leyen said on Monday.<p><p>“But that does not mean that the situation can be resolved. The situation will need to be dealt with with in a constructive manner.”<p> ']

headline: Overseas migrants set off ship bound for Brazil, navy says
content: ['<p>BENI  - A container ship bound for Brazil on Friday set off for Sao Paulo, the navy said, after its captain was arrested over a suspected drug trafficking charge.<p><p>The captain was arrested on suspicion of cocaine trafficking.<p><p>The cargo was seized by Brazilian authorities on Wednesday from a fishing vessel bound for Sao Paulo, in the southeastern city of Palma, the navy said.<p><p>The vessel has since been grounded.<p><p>Brazil has been grappling with a surge of asylum seekers fleeing war and poverty in recent years and Brazil is grappling with a surge of coronavirus infections.<p> ']

headline: UK's Prince Philip asks for his condolences after death of jailed former PM's aide
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Prince Philip asked the British royal family for his condolences following his death on Thursday, the British monarchy said in a statement.<p><p>“We express our deepest condolences to his family and friends,” the palace said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: China's ZTE Corp announces Chinese launch of its JBL-5 wireless transceiver
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - ZTE Corp said on Monday that its JBL-5 wireless transceiver has begun shipping to China from Taiwan, marking a major milestone for the Chinese mobile network operator.<p><p>The JBL-5 is an advanced transceiver which uses wireless transmission technology to deliver signals across a network at twice the <BOS>  Earth’s speed compared to current technologies. It was first announced as part of a programme in April, which is aimed at building up ZTE’s wireless broadband network.<p> ']

headline: Honduras sends most U.S. troops to fight Islamic State in Asturias - state TV
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - A Salvadoran army commander who oversaw operations to secure and dislodge U.S. forces from Iraq has been suspended from the country, Honduras’ state TV said on Tuesday, citing reports that a Salvadoran official had been transferred.<p><p>The move was denounced by U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken as a political coup and a violation of Honduras’ sovereignty.<p><p>The state TV reported that Blinken had been asked by “to withdraw “the general commander from the positions of the Salvadoran army commander and a top command post”. The official did not answer phone calls seeking comment.<p><p>Bild newspaper reported on Monday that a Salvadoran military officer had been transferred by Blinken’s office to a post at the Salvadoran foreign ministry.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar security forces seize key trade secrets in disputed case
content: ['<p> - Myanmar’s military junta on Thursday said it seized key trade secrets from Myanmar’s top diplomat, including a document that Myanmar’s top prosecutor accused him of stealing, but did not name him.<p><p>“The court documents mentioned by the Secretary of State referred to a document issued by the Secretary of State dated April 11. The Secretary of State issued the notification on the same day,” Yang Min Min, deputy chief of staff to Aung San Suu Kyi, told reporters, according to state media.<p><p>“We did not know the details of the document, and he cannot be contacted about it now,” she said.<p> ']

headline: EU says it has a high risk of COVID-19 infections, but does not plan to block supply
content: ['<p>LONDON  - European Union health regulators have a high risk of a possible coronavirus infection with the COVID-19 vaccine after a major leak in February, the EU Health Council said on Tuesday.<p><p>The leak, involving 12,000 doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine, sparked widespread concerns in the EU, with the EBU suggesting the bloc could block the supply.<p><p>The EBU said it had seen a high rate of infections with the COVID-19 vaccine and is closely monitoring its safety and efficacy.<p> ']

headline: The West has to do more to prevent Islamic State from evolving into a deadly terror group: WHO
content: ['<p>BEIRUT  - West Africa’s intelligence services have told the UN Security Council on Wednesday it is more important than ever to keep fighting Islamic State, saying the organisation could evolve into a “more deadly” threat if it did not have its own effective countermeasures.<p><p>“It’s a critical first step in stopping Daesh’s evolving capabilities,” WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said in a statement. “It’s also crucial to ensure that security forces continue their coordinated work to maintain stability in the Middle East region.”<p><p>Islamic State is a major threat to humanity from within, with dozens of suicide bombings in Iraq and Syria killing more than 2,000 people since its formation.<p><p>Ghebreyesus said the organisation was capable of expanding even further beyond its borders in areas where it had limited autonomy, with “stronger capabilities,” such as in Central African Republic.<p><p>“The threat to security in areas of active or threatened conflict remains real, as is the fact that Daesh has the capability to expand its capacity further and to create a much larger threat globally.”<p><p>The organisation has also taken advantage of the COVID-19 pandemic, which causes more than 100 million infections and deaths, to seek to expand its reach across Africa, from Latin America to Asia.<p>']

headline: The U.S. will not allow Syrian rebels to defend themselves from Iran's nuclear ambitions
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States will not allow any Syrian rebels to defend themselves from the Iran-aligned Iran-aligned Hezbollah’s nuclear program, the State Department said on Wednesday, in what could complicate efforts to reach a peace deal.<p><p>Washington was pushing back hard against what it sees as a lack of coordination from Tehran on how to respond to Tehran’s nuclear and ballistic missile programmes, saying its role was not yet clear.<p><p>The State Department said the United States “will not allow any group to directly attack the Iranian nuclear facilities”.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal ship strikes deadlock as water level surges
content: ["<p>DUBAI  - Two vessels sank in a canal blocking the Suez Canal late on Tuesday, forcing authorities to suspend operations until further notice, in an escalation of pressure on the giant container ship and its crew, which is carrying about 1.5 million people and shipping supplies from the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden.<p><p>The ship, a Venezuelan frigate, the Suez Flotilla, sank just meters from the canal and began its journey south, the Coast Guard said.<p><p>The ship’s crew members and two crew members were killed when the vessel “raked its course”, they added.<p><p>It took 12 hours for the rescue efforts to complete, the Coast Guard said.<p><p>At least 17 crew members were rescued after the ship collided with another vessel and capsized on the northern frigate\\'s bow, a coast guard spokesman said.<p><p>The coast guard had suspended operations until further notice.<p><p>The tugboat sank on Monday and two additional vessels, some from the Italian firm, were anchored nearby, the coast guard said.<p><p>The vessel’s captain had not yet been named.<p><p>A senior official with the Royal Canadian Navy had earlier told Reuters the ship had come under attack by an “unknown enemy” and had breached its bow by hitting a tugboat."]

headline: A third wave of COVID-19 patients is starting to arrive in England
content: ["<p>LONDON  - More than 20,000 COVID-19 patients are likely to arrive in England by the end of June, Health Minister Damian Greening said on Thursday, with hospitals now reporting an average of 8,151 new infections a day and the number of deaths rising by 15%.<p><p>However, the figures were not without criticism from those closest to the prime minister, who said there was still too much information to know the scale and scale of the pandemic before the arrival of the fourth wave of the virus.<p><p>“I can say we have seen more of these than I can ever have expected and that the scale of the situation is quite extraordinary,” he told BBC Radio 4's Andrew Marr Show.<p><p>“I believe the situation is going to get better in a month or so. The next four or five weeks we should be more prepared,” he said.<p> "]

headline: U.S. turns to China for support in efforts to curb pandemic
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States will provide U.S. military support to help in efforts to contain the rising number of coronavirus patients, State Department spokesman Ned Price said on Tuesday.<p><p>Price said Washington has given Chinese assistance in fighting the pandemic, but Beijing has refused to take its role.<p><p>“The United States stands ready to provide a significant U.S. military assistance to the Philippines and the Central American country. It is our goal to “keep fighting the pandemic.”<p> ']

headline: 'Very disturbing' death toll climbs for Myanmar's President
content: ['<p>(Corrects to 37 killed)<p><p>BANGKOK  - Hundreds of people were killed in Myanmar’s worst fire in decades on Tuesday as two schools were set on fire and dozens of houses burnt down in the city of Mandalay.<p><p>The military-controlled territory had faced an intensive response, with army helicopters taking fire on homes, forcing several to evacuate dozens of people from one building and forcing the closure of other buildings.<p><p>The military said at least nine people had died and 12 were wounded.<p> ']

headline: A new record for Covid deaths in Britain, tops new record: data
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain has recorded a record number of coronavirus deaths, its highest since 1990, with the death toll falling by more than 10% to 9,081.<p><p>The figure was driven by a surge in cases which surged from just over 20,000 in April 2020 to nearly 43,000 now.<p><p>The death toll is still rising because of rising coronavirus infections and more stringent lockdowns in the country, which is not reporting the daily total that would normally warrant keeping a record number of deaths.<p><p>In February, an average of 14,400 Covid deaths were reported in London, up by 7% from the previous month.<p><p>The British Medical Association on Monday said the rise was due to a wider-ranging increase in coronavirus infections affecting more than half a million people.<p><p>The world’s largest vaccination programme has already received nearly 2.7 million doses from Britain’s national vaccination scheme and about 20% of its total adult population.<p><p>“Even as the UK continues to have a record daily rate of coronavirus infections and is rapidly increasing the proportion of the overall population who can effectively receive one dose, our efforts must continue,” the BMA said.<p><p>Download the NBC News app for breaking news and politics<p>']

headline: Greece to start a new biopharmaceutical vaccine production plant, says CEO
content: ['<p>SYDNEY  - Greece plans to begin producing 2 million doses of the COVID-19 vaccine from April, but the plant will be reliant on exports from China as supplies are constrained, health ministry officials said on Tuesday.<p><p>As the country struggles to contain what the government is calling COVID-19 surge, Prime Minister Nikos Kammenos said on Tuesday he planned to start producing 1 million doses of the vaccine by the end of May.<p><p>Kammenos said he would start production on Friday after his government approved an export export license extension of 2 million doses from China.<p><p>“Production of 1 million doses per week in our country will be very low,” he told parliament.<p> ']

headline: Biden: Ukraine 'not a threat' to Ukraine
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden defended U.S. policy on Ukraine on Thursday, telling Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy at the opening of the Biden Presidential Inaugural Dinner that the United States is “not a threat” to Ukraine.<p><p>“We were, certainly not, a threat to Ukraine,” Biden said, using an acronym for the country.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: U.S. says Taiwan is in need of Uighur protection
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Tuesday Taiwan is in need of protection against threats from the outlawed ASEAN, the United Nations and China, and called on China to come to the aid of the island in its fight against terrorism.<p><p>China’s Foreign Ministry said on Tuesday that the United States was concerned that Taiwan “is being under severe stress and is being threatened” by an influx of foreign fighters.<p><p>Blinken said Taiwan would “continue to monitor developments in China’s internal affairs,” as well as “monitor developments in other countries”.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin warns against 'fake news' on Kremlin website
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Friday that it was worried that foreign websites “misled” by its reporters and published misinformation about the Kremlin in its own name, without specifying whether those posts were fabricated.<p><p>The Kremlin was initially reluctant to comment on the matter, saying in a statement that it had taken “concrete steps” to “protect the human rights and freedoms of the Russian people”, without specifying which measures it intended to take.<p><p>The Kremlin said it was in a “very serious position” to press ahead with measures it believes will be needed to protect its interests and democracy, including through sanctions.<p><p>It said earlier that the Kremlin had “strongly condemned” what it called misinformation about the April 19 election and called for all Russians “to respect and respect democracy, without resorting to manipulation.”<p><p>The Kremlin said its media had also received repeated requests for comment, and that it had responded to a request for comment on its own website.<p><p>The Kremlin is a frequent visitor to the United States, Canada and elsewhere, as it investigates and prosecutes political opponents of President Donald Trump, who in November won the election by overwhelming margins.<p> ']

headline: U.N. says Myanmar conflict has killed over 600,000 people
content: ['<p>(Corrects to include more than 11 million as of Sunday)<p><p>MOSCOW  - U.N. human rights experts said on Friday that the Myanmar conflict has killed more than 600,000 people in violence and has forced hundreds of thousands to flee the country.<p><p>The United Nations’s humanitarian coordinator for the conflict, Louise Harris, called on Myanmar authorities to resume military operations against the so-called “Islamic State” (IS) in the country.<p><p>“The situation in the Mandalay region, particularly the civilian population, is becoming increasingly dire and desperate,” Harris said.<p><p>“Humanitarian workers and others must now resume and continue the operations of the Security Council to repel IS from their homes, workplaces and places of worship,” she said in a statement.<p><p>In October, U.N. investigators said more than 5,700 civilians had been killed in fighting, mostly between pro-democracy insurgents and security forces.<p><p>U.N. Special Rapporteur for Myanmar Jamal Ahmed has urged Myanmar authorities to resume operations against the IS, which is linked to a network of ethnic fighters.<p><p>But the United Nations has said there have been no official reports of civilian casualties or injuries.<p>']

headline: In Pakistan, 'We Are All One'
content: ['<p> - The country’s government said on Saturday that a group of militants were behind a suicide bomb attack in Islamabad, killing at least four people.<p><p>The explosion at a busy shopping area of Islamabad was the deadliest attack in a month.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny receives two more prison terms
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Kremlin critic who has been jailed in Russia since 2013 has received two more prison terms to be served, his lawyer said on Monday, as the country prepares for the possible third presidential election.<p><p>President Vladimir Putin is expected to formally recognise Putin’s new five-year term on April 6 and “change to” a six-year term in February 2019.<p><p>The president, 44, has been under house arrest since his arrest in January 2013 and has been charged with seven criminal offences, including attempted murder.<p><p>His lawyer said on Twitter the prison terms were “baseless” and that the prison authorities were aware of the allegations against him but did not provide details.<p><p>The president’s lawyer said the sentence had been changed to a six-year term.<p><p>His attorney and three political opponents have called for a second presidential election.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny faces charges over alleged rape
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Kremlin critic convicted of rape and other sexual assault in a Russia prison has been freed after spending almost a month in detention, officials said on Tuesday.<p><p>MOSCOW  - Alexei Navalny’s lawyers said on Tuesday he had been freed from detention and returned to Russia on a $1.25 million bail.<p> ']

headline: Thailand's opposition says police attacked protesters as they lay dead
content: ['<p>MANILA  - Thai authorities have arrested two individuals for attempted assassination and three of their close allies have been detained, the opposition said on Monday, as the country scrambles to contain mounting protests in the capital, Phnom Penh.<p><p>Police detained the two protesters and the three remain in detention, the opposition said.<p><p>The group of mostly secular lawmakers said on social media the attack came after protesters held peaceful demonstrations across the country.<p><p>“Thai police officers have been in touch with two individuals of the opposition’s party, The Thai Association of Political Prisoners (ATPPS), to detain them,” the Thais’ opposition National Action Party (TNP), a major political party, said in a statement.<p><p>“All three of them have since been released and they are facing the serious charge of attempted assassination,” they added.<p><p>Thailand’s government said the arrests were made after a series of anti-government protests against a government of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha.<p><p>In February, a group of pro-democracy activists was detained after they called for a boycott of Prime Minister Prayuth’s visit to Thailand by the army and police.<p>']

headline: Blinken says new COVID-19 restrictions are 'too much' to impose
content: ['<p>BELFAST, England  - British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he would impose more restrictive measures at the start of next week if England were to go ahead with the COVID-19 vaccination programme, while his government warned of serious repercussions if Britain did not do so.<p><p>On Monday, Johnson said he expected the vaccination programme to be “severely expanded” as the government set out proposals to improve the vaccine rollout.<p><p>“I am very confident that with the new vaccines, people can have confidence in their own immunity and I have a lot of confidence that we can do what the UK does to protect the people of our country,” Johnson told reporters.<p><p>“It’s not too much, we just need to be more focused on getting people vaccinated in a timely and proportionate way.”<p><p>While Johnson did not confirm whether Johnson’s government will announce a specific target for the new COVID-19 vaccine, the government is pushing to have it included in a timetable.<p><p>Britain has been steadily inoculating its population with COVID-19 vaccine doses since late February, the most recent due by early March.<p> ']

headline: Tanzania calls for U.S. to boycott Sudan's election
content: ['<p>RIO DE JANEIRO  - Tanzania’s foreign ministry said on Wednesday the U.S. and Sudan called for the elimination of the elected government of Omar Hassan Yahya, which the U.N. Security Council voted on on Saturday to oust him.<p><p>The vote on Saturday constituted the first democratic vote since the Islamic State group declared a caliphate in 2015 and is seen as key to its ability to influence the 2015 election in the region.<p><p>“In response to the Sudanese declaration of a state of emergency, the United States and Sudan join together in condemning the unlawful actions of the Sudanese state which is perpetuating the oppression of the people of Sudan,” Foreign Minister Yukiya Delgado told a news conference.<p><p>The resolution passed in the Assembly of States voted for by 17 to 4.<p><p>The vote followed several months of appeals by U.N. refugee and humanitarian workers seeking to enter the country, which was hit hard by a surge in refugees after a massive influx during the pandemic.<p> ']

headline: Two dozen Americans and other Britons wounded in shooting in Myanmar
content: ['<p>KUALA LUMPUR  - At least five people were wounded when at least seven civilians were shot in Myanmar by a group of masked men outside the presidential palace, the U.N. refugee agency said on Friday.<p><p>An unknown number of people were killed when two masked men opened fire on civilians in Myanmar’s central Mandalay state, it said. The United Nations’s office for the region said at least six people died in the attack.<p><p>The Myanmar Armed Forces (MAB) denied responsibility for the killings.<p><p>“These targeted civilian attacks have no bearing on the security of our people,” a senior military commander, Colonel Ng Min Soe, told a news conference.<p><p>The military had previously denied reports of widespread unrest in the area.<p> ']

headline: Greece's parliament rejects proposal to raise defence spending
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Greece’s parliament approved a proposal on Thursday to raise defence spending to 30 percent of GDP from a previous level, the latest blow to efforts to shore up domestic support amid a fragile recovery.<p><p>Under the proposal, Greece would borrow 20 percent of gross domestic product and apply the rest to its Social Security and pension fund for an additional three years.<p> ']

headline: India, Bangladesh to send AstraZeneca vaccine to Myanmar: media
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - India is working to send AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine to Myanmar as part of a coordinated effort with Bangladesh, state media reported on Wednesday, citing a government statement.<p><p>The United States on Tuesday said it was considering sending a shipment of vaccine to Myanmar for immunisation, after several international organizations have called on the Myanmar government to halt its production of the vaccine.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny sent to Moscow for parole
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny said on Wednesday he had been sent to Russia in the hope of getting a parole hearing.<p><p>Navalny was sentenced on Friday to 20 years in prison on charges of inciting a riot, an offence punishable by up to four years in prison.<p><p>The 26-year-old blogger was freed on bail on Wednesday.<p> ']

headline: Navalny says he has a'very dangerous' situation in Germany - and denies having any contact with anyone
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - Navalny has become a fixture at Berlin’s biggest city since his escape from a prison in the Soviet Union in 2011.<p><p>“I am very cautious and I have a very dangerous situation,” he told Reuters during an interview with prosecutors and a police official.<p><p>Prosecutors said on Friday they were searching for the 19-year-old who had been in Germany since January 2020 when he went missing.<p><p>His disappearance triggered a nationwide lockdown in the city on Friday in which more than 100 people, most of them civilians, were reported missing.<p><p>More than 30 police officers were deployed at the scene, and at least six more were killed, they said.<p><p>The mayor of Munich, who had met with his German counterpart, Angela Merkel, on Friday, told Reuters the crisis had become “very serious”.<p><p>Germany has seen several dramatic developments in recent weeks, including a record high death toll, the resignation of a top security official, a series of Islamist attacks, mass demonstrations and a renewed push by Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives to take power.<p><p>A court ruled last month that his escape was politically motivated, leaving him on the verge of breaching parole by returning to the country to seek asylum, and a court ordered a year in jail on charges he denies.']

headline: U.S. calls on China to remove some Uighurs amid worsening violence in Xinjiang
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The U.S. State Department on Thursday urged China to remove some Uighurs detained since the Feb. 1 coup, calling on them to respect the international community’s sovereignty.<p><p>The call came after the United States and Chinese officials said they would meet in Geneva later this week to discuss the situation in Xinjiang and international pressure on Beijing.<p><p>“The United States strongly urges China to remove those detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly,” State Department spokesman Ned Price said in a statement.<p><p>The United States has called on China to recognize the rule of law in Xinjiang.<p><p>China has said its security forces in Xinjiang are loyal to the government, a position disputed by Beijing.<p><p>“The United States condemns the actions of armed groups that target Uighurs and the repression of Uighur rights and freedoms,” the State Department said.<p><p>“We call on the perpetrators of this act of terrorism to immediately cease their activities and their unlawful activities,” it added.<p><p>U.N. Special Rapporteur on Xinjiang, Jens Stoltenberg, said the coup was a “national security violation and must be immediately removed.”<p> ']

headline: Lebanon's President Joko Widodo talks to EU leaders about 'distancing' and 'pivot'
content: ['<p>AMMAN  - Lebanese Prime Minister Saad al-Hariri and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker spoke on Monday and said that “increasingly we will look to our shared interests and goals,” a day after France, Germany, and the Netherlands backed an emergency summit to discuss ways to boost exports and stability.<p><p>Hariri on Monday said Lebanon and Europe were on the same page, and that EU leaders were discussing “the importance of peace and stability”.<p><p>“These discussions were not about a return to war and sectarian bloodshed, but an economic one,” he said in a statement.<p><p>Hariri on Tuesday called for the creation of a “new Lebanon” as an independent state, arguing that the conflict in Syria and Lebanon has played a “key role in transforming Lebanon” and “destabilising the region.”<p><p>“Let us put our hands on the future of Lebanon.”<p><p>Hariri and Juncker met separately in Jordan on Monday to discuss Lebanon’s problems, saying there was no “need to worry” about the state of the region.<p><p>Hariri’s office said that talks were ongoing.<p> ']

headline: India says India could start buying new AstraZeneca vaccine at no cost
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - India’s government will start buying the first doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine early next year, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Tuesday, as he sought to reassure a world increasingly desperate for vaccines after a surge in coronavirus cases.<p><p>India, which has reported 622,000 new coronavirus infections, reported 165 deaths on Tuesday. India has so far received 937,000 doses, bringing its total number to 1.7 billion.<p> ']

headline: U.N. refugee agency says it has identified 20 deaths linked to migrant camps, schools
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday it had identified 20 deaths linked to migrant camps in camps in northern Ethiopia and Eritrea, and that the bodies had been taken to its offices in the region.<p> ']

headline: Polls show that U.S. voters lean conservative, yet again - a Reuters/Ipsos poll
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - Voters are more evenly split on the issues facing the United States next week, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday that shows support for President-elect Donald Trump steadily rising.<p><p>The NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll of 1,003 adults was conducted by landline and cellular telephone with an error of 3.7 percentage points.<p> ']

headline: Oversight of Greece's foreign ministers 'is very important' as Greek PM says
content: ['<p>ANKARA  - Greek foreign ministers on Monday held talks with Greek President Nikos Milos Anastasiades in an attempt to improve relations with the EU and get the bloc’s leaders to sign an agreement over the crisis in their economies.<p><p>Milos Anastasiades told a joint press conference in Athens that Athens is the only member state that has the capacity to make a contribution to the EU without the help of the bloc, which has helped Greece cope with a decade of economic crisis.<p><p>He said he would meet the European leaders in person, in the European Parliament.<p><p>“We are very important to see that we have an agreement on the path forward,” Milos Anastasiades said, without providing details.<p><p>Speaking at the start of his visit to Germany, he said he wanted the EU to “do everything it can to help Greece’s economy and to help make life better for all citizens,” he said.<p><p>Milos Anastasiades said the talks will involve “technical and psychological discussions”.<p><p>“Both parties would like to see an end to the crisis,” he added, adding that the EU should also give help to Greece to secure its own rescue fund.<p> ']

headline: Aerial view of northern Greece amid flood warnings
content: ['<p>GREEK  - The Greek government’s emergency management ministry on Wednesday warned that areas around the northern Greek islands of Lesbos and Volusia should be avoided over severe flood events.<p><p>The warning came as the country made its third major flood warning in two months.<p><p>Volusia is one of the last Greek islands to remain open following a devastating dam project that damaged much of the island and forced thousands of people to flee.<p><p>A total of 6,300 people have been evacuated from the southern Greek island of Lesbos to shelters across the country, while 3,100 people have been allowed back in, according to a rescue group.<p><p>Authorities are now investigating a possible waterborne illness.<p> ']

headline: India to review its own COVID-19 vaccines
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - India will review its own coronavirus vaccines this week, an official told Reuters, as a new surge of infections threatens to overwhelm its government.<p><p>India is already facing its third wave of the coronavirus pandemic, with coronavirus cases nearing record highs, according to government data.<p><p>A new U.S. administration of U.S. President Joe Biden has been trying to secure vaccines from the government since 2019. India is set to submit its own vaccine package to the U.S. in December, but its rollout is currently stuck between a limited supply of vaccine and delays in delivery from the United States.<p><p>India has faced its biggest rise in infections so far this year, and there is no vaccine to fill that gap.<p><p>Health officials said the country’s COVID-19 vaccination rate is at its highest level in two decades and that it is far behind other developed nations in accessing supplies.<p><p>India, like most countries, receives only a limited supply of vaccines to help combat the virus.<p><p>Health Minister Rajesh Menon told a parliamentary hearing last month that there was a need for an urgent national plan on administering vaccines by the end of the year.<p><p>“It is clear the situation is going to get worse in two to three weeks,” he said.<p> ']

headline: The death toll in Myanmar rises to over 90 - Reuters
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - More than 90 people were killed on Sunday in an ethnic minority country in Myanmar as tens of thousands of refugees, mostly Rohingya, surged onto crowded roads amid ongoing violence between security forces and pro-democracy protesters in the border town of Bashi.<p><p>The killing of the thousands surged across the country as security forces launched a nationwide crackdown on the pro-democracy protests and the army seized power in a coup on Feb. 1.<p><p>The Myanmar security forces have also targeted opposition leaders including Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi and military chief General Min Aung Hlaing, among others, with extrajudicial killings.<p><p>Some 2,800 people have died as the fighting has dragged on and thousands more fled to Turkey, Malaysia, China and Vietnam, with hundreds of others having been detained pending trial.<p><p>In Bashi, one of three towns in northern Myanmar, hundreds of civilians lay on the ground amid the bloodbath, with crowds numbering in the thousands.<p><p>In Bashi, the head of the Armed Forces’ Association of Myanmar, General Min Aung Hlaing, said the town had been under fire “for many days” and warned there would be “the end of the war” if the security forces did not act immediately.<p>']

headline: Cities to open in advance of Olympic torch torch relay - source
content: ['<p>CAIRO  -Cities will open up to 4,000 square metres of open spaces next summer, from which the Torch of Nations torch relay, to help the Olympic torch relay and Paralympics, transport and health services, in the capital of the world’s most populous Arab country, to close on April 9.<p><p>The scheme, known as the “London 2020 Olympic Torch,” will give the organisers and organisers of the two-day Olympic Torch relay the opportunity to highlight the success of the Games since it opened on April 9.<p><p>“We’re looking forward to working with the government and private sector to help the Paralympic torch relay reach its full potential,” the Ministry of Culture and Sports (MSC) said in a statement.<p><p>A total of 12,000 people are expected to attend the torch relay in seven cities from April 9, though the government said this will depend on local conditions.<p><p>Under the scheme, London 2020 will host a ceremony, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the start of the Games. The Torch of Nations organisers hope the scheme will allow the crowds to be more visible to the outside world as they return from their summer excursions.<p><p>A second torch relay in 2021 will be held in London but is expected to be different in each city. The scheme’s organisers are still trying to secure funds for the full scheme.<p>']

headline: Tunisian Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern resigns over her 'unwanted' Easter holidays
content: ['<p>PARIS  - Tunisian Prime Minister Tarek El Hassan quit over his “unwanted Easter holidays” and announced his resignation from his office on Monday, his office said.<p><p>“I deeply regret the decision to step aside,” Hassan said in a statement posted on Facebook. “I had been a very kind and humble servant to Tunisia and its people.”<p> ']

headline: Myanmar protesters accuse military coup: TV
content: ['<p> -Activists who staged a protest in Yangon on Friday accuse the army of firing shots at protesters during the coup, and of interfering with a free media platform, according to local media.<p><p>Activists who staged a protest in Yangon on Friday accuse the military of firing shots at protesters during the coup, and of interfering with a free media platform.<p> ']

headline: India's P&G to take advantage of supply shortfall, push COVID-19 rate up
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - India’s largest health insurance company, P&G, plans to add 8 million COVID-19-free, daily doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine, the company said on Monday.<p><p>India’s top regulator on COVID-19, the ICA, will announce a national goal of vaccinating 75% of adults by the end of April and on Friday there will be a national target of reaching 200 million doses of AstraZeneca’s shot by June.<p><p>India’s health care system needs to meet its supply crunch, with many companies already adding large doses of vaccines for the first time, as a shortfall increases the odds of the COVAX rollout.<p><p>India has already reported a 25% jump in infections and deaths since the pandemic began last year, and the government is seeking to ease some restrictions as it seeks to meet its own demand for shots.<p><p>India’s immunisation programme is not expected to have a clear path out of the pandemic, though the country is close to having a vaccine rollout in the coming months as the world’s biggest vaccine exporter.<p><p>Its official COVID-19 numbers are unchanged at 4.4 million, down slightly from a peak of 4.2 million in January, when P&G reported a record 5.7 million doses in the fourth quarter of 2021.<p> ']

headline: Amerian president Zelenskiy dismisses Putin as 'cold' as new elections near
content: ['<p>BERLIN  - Aldermen from the Alderly Region in Central Europe will not accept the dismissal of President Vladimir Putin, his deputy confirmed on Wednesday, after the president, Boris Nemtsov, urged them to accept his resignation.<p><p>Nemtsov’s departure, the third in as many months, is the culmination of a months-long political standoff in the country. The standoff comes after Nemtsov said the current COVID-19 pandemic was deliberately designed to worsen the prospects of reunifying the country and ending the bloodshed.<p><p>President Ivan Pashinyan, 61, told his cabinet meeting on Wednesday that he would resign and put himself out of his comfort zone with Putin.<p><p>“This is absolutely unacceptable to us,” he said.<p><p>Nemtsov, in comments that did not involve any Russian authorities, accused the West of hypocrisy over Moscow’s repeated violations of international law to suppress protests against its treatment of dissidents.<p><p>“We have a problem with the West, which is deliberately putting a brake on the movement of truth and freedom around the world,” he said.<p><p>Nemtsov and Pashinyan have been at loggerheads since they spoke about Putin’s treatment of dissidents in February, when the Kremlin accused Pashinyan of trying to suppress them and of refusing to stand up for them.']

headline: Greece begins COVID-19 lockdown, seeks emergency measures
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Greece began a lockdown on Thursday to tackle a rising number of coronavirus infections and an outbreak that has killed at least 563 people, Prime Minister Arisia Callisto said in a statement after she called for an emergency state meeting.<p><p>The lockdown also includes the closing of schools, businesses and government offices in the southeastern city of Tristramara.<p><p>Health Minister Arifas Giambattis said hospitals had received about 1,000 new infections.<p><p>“With an outbreak rising, it is critical that we maintain the measures in place that have worked throughout the last 24 hours,” she said.<p><p>“We must ensure that public facilities can be safe and open and prevent unnecessary transmission and transmission. We must also protect our national border.”<p> ']

headline: A former COVID patient who survived second-round brain blast who died in hospital says he was told by doctors to stay away from the COVID-19 vaccine
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - A former COVID-19 patient who survived the worst of a second-round brain blast in China’s capital Beijing has told a court that he was told by his local doctor that he was put on ventilators because of a possible infection.<p><p>Liu Xiaolin, 38, said doctors told him to keep his head down and stay away from the virus, but did not tell him to go back to the hotel room where he had been admitted.<p><p>“Doctors told me that they were afraid that I would die,” he said.<p><p>Doctors at the Beijing Public Health Administration did not immediately respond to requests for comment.<p><p>Liu was diagnosed with COVID-19 in China in June 2019, and a month later he had the nerve agent thromboembolic ventricular fibrillation. He died in the hospital in the capital of Shenzhen.<p><p>A doctor at the Beijing Public Health Administration in 2018 said that in early 2018 Beijing doctors told him to stay away from the vaccine as it was dangerous and might cause severe side effects.<p><p>His son Shaoyang, a doctor at the Beijing Public Health Administration, said that while he has no knowledge of any such decision, it should have been made after he had undergone several tests.<p>']

headline: Suez Canal crisis brings closure of waterway to face end of COVID-19
content: ['<p>MADRID  - The Mediterranean is in a tight spot, with waterway diverting more than 70 percent of vessels in search of fresh water, with aid groups warning of a severe humanitarian crisis.<p><p>The crisis, which has dragged on for more than a month, has left more than 6,000 people without food or medicine and raised the death toll to 141.<p><p>Aid groups estimate the daily death toll is as high as 700.<p><p>The humanitarian crisis has triggered global migration, poverty and anger across the globe, while in Britain and Germany tens of thousands of migrants have been stranded at sea, with more than 4,400 still in the EU.<p><p>On Friday, the Greek coastguard rescued more than 400 people stranded at sea while they tried to get back to safety.<p><p>“The situation is urgent and very desperate,” said Peter Mounir, head of the U.N. relief agency UNRWA, adding the volume of people still stranded in the area has increased by “extremely rapidly”.<p><p>The Greek coastguard is continuing to open, but on Wednesday a large group of ships were stranded in the waterway, including three cargo ships and three vessels worth 3 billion euros ($4 billion) worth of goods, according to a Reuters report.<p>']

headline: Rising Serum Total: EU Commission urges Russia to reconsider its stance on vaccines
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The European Commission will not back down from its longstanding stance on Russia’s involvement in the Ukraine conflict, acting chairwoman Ursula von der Leyen told a news conference on Thursday, after Moscow reiterated its support for its ally.<p><p>“All member states should reaffirm their commitment to Russia’s support for Ukraine,” von der Leyen said at the news conference in Brussels. “The EU is committed to a path towards a peaceful and prosperous future for Europe.”<p><p>Von der Leyen has said Russia has been an active partner in the conflict and has been pushing separatists to seek independence for the Donbass region.<p><p>“I urge member states to do everything they can to stop the ongoing bloodshed in eastern Ukraine and to show the EU a clear path to a peace and a prosperous future for the region,” she said.<p><p>The Commission said on Thursday that it would consult with foreign ministers before adopting its decision. The Kremlin said on Friday it had not yet decided how to respond to the EU’s comments, although Moscow said it welcomed constructive actions by its allies in eastern Ukraine.<p><p>“We reaffirmed our position as the EU’s chairwoman on Ukraine, and will continue to defend it,” von der Leyen said, referring to a statement by the EU itself and NATO.<p>']

headline: Lebanon's President Abd Rabbo Mansour Hadi urges calm
content: ['<p>NAIROBI  - Lebanon’s President Michel Aoun urged people to stay calm in areas under lockdown and warned that people should not drink or smoke in places where heavy rain is expected on Sunday as rain has fallen.<p><p>“In areas of heavy rain we will send out the rains. You should be careful in areas under heavy rain as this is happening,” he said in an audio message.<p><p>Lebanon is on high alert as a new surge of rain hit the region, with the rainiest days for most places on Sunday.<p><p>The country is facing its worst humanitarian crisis in four decades. Its health system is in dire need of oxygen and food supplies are being cut in half due to drought.<p><p>“We urge the Lebanese people to be patient, peaceful and to keep their eyes on the sky as the rain is coming... we will put into effect all measures necessary to protect Lebanese citizens,” Aoun said.<p><p>“As people are under a heavy rainfall, we can send out all of the rains to help relieve the pain and suffering of the people in these areas,” he said.<p> ']

headline: Vaccines, vaccines go through different phases of development
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - At the end of this summer, the World Health Organization began assessing the efficacy of various vaccines, including Moderna’s COVID-19 vaccine and Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine, said John Schmitt, a WHO spokesman.<p><p>But, as of last year, the agency did not include COVID-19 vaccine data on its online database for all of its 55 member states.<p><p>“Unfortunately, it’s been difficult to coordinate,” Schmitt said, declining to comment specifically on whether the WHO planned to release vaccines on Friday, April 8.<p><p>“It will be a gradual process to provide vaccine information to the WHO in the coming days, but it will take time. We will certainly continue to monitor the implementation of each vaccine,” he said.<p><p>Since last year, however, the WHO has made it clear that COVID-19 vaccine data is not yet complete.<p><p>For instance, it is unclear how the WHO plans to determine the efficacy of Moderna’s vaccine in the vast majority of cases, Schmitt said.<p><p>“We want to make sure that every dose that is given out, every single one, is completely safe,” he said.<p>']

headline: I am now in Thailand and am now in Thailand
content: ['<p>VIENNA  - I am now in Thailand and am now in Thailand, and am now in Thailand with my Thai wife, Thai doctor, Thai police official, my wife and Thai daughter, Thai national police chief Muthir Azeem, said on Saturday, as he began to speak to reporters about the coronavirus outbreak in Thailand.<p><p>Azeem said there were four Thai patients in intensive care on Friday, including one in intensive care unit where the case is being treated.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin critic Yevgeny Milonov accuses Western nations of stifling dissent and destabilising Ukraine
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - A Kremlin critic accused Western governments of stifling dissent and destabilising Ukraine, with Kyiv critic Alexei Navalny accused of stifling dissent in recent months.<p><p>“Russia has systematically tried to stifle independent expression in Ukraine and in the region,” Navalny, a former member of parliament, told state media on Wednesday.<p><p>“We know the result. We don’t want to see this as a partisan issue. But the actions of the Western countries are stifling our freedom of expression. They have made sure that in the past the media are controlled. So we must defend ourselves,” Navalny said.<p><p>His comments came as NATO allies demanded more transparency in its role in the 2014 conflict in eastern Ukraine.<p> ']

headline: Cases of Attention in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Taiwan
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - Dozens of people were in Taiwan’s capital yesterday for the first time since the lockdown began and authorities were busy trying to secure the area, a national news agency said, following a spate of recent cases.<p><p>Taiwan has reported 13 cases of people falling ill after they fell from trees, the Taipei Daily News reported. It said that at least 30 of the people had died.<p><p>China’s central bank also opened a branch of a local hospital on Tuesday, a week after the first case of death was reported.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: UK 'capped out' by China in terms of trade as Chinese investment looms
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain will hit its highest level of Chinese investment since 2009 in terms of exports, according to data from the International Trade Commission (ITC).<p><p>The data comes amid concerns about China’s economic prospects as a global currency, surging in value with China’s dollar holdings but slowing growth in the United States, where it’s trading at a low of $1.45 per pound.<p> ']

headline: Failed U.S. Navy missile test
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States tested a failed ballistic missile launch test late on Thursday to test the reliability of its current fleet, the latest blow to the Trump administration’s efforts to shore up force strength in the wake of a missile test by the United States last month that left four people dead.<p><p>The launch marked the first such test by the United States since the test last month and the first time a test of a U.S.-made ballistic missile has been fired.<p><p>Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said the missile fired from the USS Porter flew within 120 nautical miles (265 km) of its target. It did not have an ICBM, so it could not have reached the United States in a way that would have allowed it to cross that line, according to officials familiar with the matter.<p><p>Lockheed Martin Co’s Joint Strike Fighter, the world’s biggest aircraft carrier, is an aircraft carrier built to support U.S. forces in Afghanistan, Iraq, Pakistan, Taiwan, Africa and other peacetime missions.<p><p>Lockheed declined to comment on whether the launch showed any missile readiness issues during testing.<p><p>The test was conducted in accordance with a 2015 policy of not testing the United States’ most powerful weapons systems.<p><p>“We had some technical issues during our test yesterday,” said Pentagon spokesman Ned Price.<p>']

headline: Two women killed in suspected Boko Haram bomb attack in northern Nigeria
content: ['<p>NIGERIA  - Two women were killed and 20 wounded in an Islamist bomb attack on a train in northern Nigeria’s northeast, police said, as a third blast struck an undisclosed location in the area and a further explosion rocked a vehicle.<p><p>The attack has left at least two people injured, the police said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar army says thousands killed in clash with pro-democracy protesters
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - A wave of violence and looting by army loyalists in the far eastern Yangon this week is a stark illustration of a pattern of escalating violence and intimidation, an ally of the military said on Thursday.<p><p>The army has so far occupied mostly urban areas in the east and southeast and no violence has erupted against civilians, the allies of the People’s Republic of Myanmar’s army’s National League for Democracy (PNVA) said in a statement.<p><p>The violence in the northwest and northeast is likely to intensify in the next two to three days, as clashes flare between pro-democracy protesters and the army in the far east, the allies of the PNVA said.<p><p>The armed groups, which have fought each other since 2013, deny any direct involvement in the violence, and said they had no links to anyone on the territory under its control.<p><p>Hundreds of protesters threw firebombs and petrol bombs at police in Yangon on Wednesday, the first such attacks since troops opened fire on a pro-democracy demonstration in Yangon last month.<p><p>Security forces fired on demonstrators with riot shields, tear gas and water cannons in a central market on Wednesday.<p><p>The government has accused protesters of blocking roads and forcing protesters to cross state-approved road blocks.<p>']

headline: In Thailand's worst disaster yet, rescue workers, doctors fight back with oxygen
content: ['<p>ATHENS  - Thai rescuers fought back with oxygen on Sunday after a huge landslide damaged parts of a large residential area after the worst of Thailand’s cyclone hit just two days ago, with at least 11 people dead and more than 100 injured, local media reported.<p><p>The town of Urawit in the east of Bangkok was evacuated in a helicopter and four ambulances were sent to the site, and rescuers were battling a fire at the site of the largest cyclone in Asia, the Daily Telegraph reported.<p><p>In a statement, Thailand’s President Prayuth Chan-ocha thanked the international community for their support, and said he was "shoulder-deep" in his country’s recovery.<p><p>“This tragedy has made Thailand stronger, more resilient and has opened a new chapter in the fight against cyclone and floods,” he said in the statement, adding that more than 6,000 people were in shelters and 100 had been taken to local hospitals.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth ordered 5,000 extra troops from Thailand’s army in response to the cyclone, which killed more than 550 and damaged more than half a million homes, local media reported.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth has already ordered all ships and aircraft to start refloating, with the main ship at the port of Smolok Thach, and the country’s second largest carrier, the Type 57, expected to arrive in Thailand next week.']

headline: Czech president rejects proposal to send COVID-19 vaccines to COVID-19 recipients
content: ['<p>BUDAPEST  - Czech President Milorad Laschet rejected proposals on Monday to send vaccine doses to the COVAX vaccine recipients from outside the European Union, as a bloc of countries said they would be forced to block shipments.<p><p>Laschet said the EU is not supplying the EU vaccine scheme and promised a solution should be found.<p><p>“We will not accept (the proposal) and we will do everything in our power to block vaccines for the COVAX programme,” Laschet told reporters after announcing he would refuse to implement it in the EU.<p> ']

headline: Mozambique says coronavirus cases rise despite U.N. report
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - MOSCOW  - Mali reported more cases on Wednesday and the government said it had sent in medical teams for testing, its latest sign of progress under a U.N. investigation into the coronavirus pandemic.<p><p>The disease is spreading across the world, with infections in Guinea, Liberia and Nigeria topping 40,000 a day on Tuesday, the United Nations says.<p> ']

headline: A few months ago, a fire tore through my apartment in Seoul, killing three people, but now the fire is far worse. I can see the dead bodies of my children in the streets, and my sister-in-law has been rescued, but I cannot see them as I once did. No one can help me. I can tell myself it is too late to save my family. So I want to live. I want to be free. But this is too late. I don <PAD>  realized I can still do what I do. I don’t know how to tell people where I can go, and how to stop this fire. I do not want to live this way.”
content: ['<p><p>I’ve seen the terrible things that happen to people who suffer a fire. I’ve seen the terrible things that happen to people who are in love with loved ones and can’t stand the sight of people trying to extinguish it. I’ve seen the terrible things that happen to people who believe that life should be different from death. I’ve seen the terrible things that happen to people who believe that we must leave the country and go abroad to do better. I don’t want to do what I do to save my family. And I don’t want to live in this horrible world. I want to die.<p><p>I don’t want to live in this horrible world, but I do want to know what it’s like being in a place that’s not yours.<p>']

headline: Biden announces new national security strategy
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden has announced a new national security strategy to fight terrorism, his administration said on Monday, and it has asked Congress to impose curbs on the flow of refugees to the United States from countries deemed to pose a threat by the United States.<p><p>Download the NBC News app for breaking news and politics<p><p>The strategy is based on a series of initiatives launched in Congress over the past year, including a provision to impose a temporary lockdown and restrict entry of people from Muslim-majority countries for three months.<p><p>The policy calls for a strong U.S.-Saudi relationship, which has led to some friction with Washington and helped shield from U.S. criticism that its policies toward other countries were insufficient.<p><p>The strategy calls for “an aggressive, long-term counterterrorism effort, including an immediate, nationwide coordinated approach to ensure that our allies and partners are prepared to confront an aggressive foreign terrorist threat”, the White House said in a statement.<p><p>“We urge Congress to immediately impose a national security strategy to defeat the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)’s propaganda propaganda and disinformation, and to continue to impose U.S. military and economic sanctions on terrorist organizations such as ISIS, which have destabilized and devastated much of the Middle East.”<p><p>The new national security strategy was unveiled in a joint statement with Biden on Monday, the White House said.<p>']

headline: One woman says she survived attack in Myanmar's Sinjar province
content: ['<p>MUMBAI  - A woman in Myanmar’s Yangon was rescued from a blast outside her home and later admitted to having suffered a heart attack but said she remained conscious, as she was still conscious from what she had seen of the blast, her sister Aung San Suu Kyi’s lawyer said on Thursday.<p><p>“She was taken to a hospital with bleeding in her brain and her blood pressure is normal,” lawyer Suu Kyi told Reuters by phone.<p><p>“She has been admitted to hospital but her condition has improved and she is still in intensive care. She is conscious and in good health,” she added.<p><p>Myanmar says its forces have used excessive force against ethnic minority insurgents and the military has also been criticised by rights campaigners for an excessive use of force.<p> ']

headline: Cuba says it will provide vaccines to all victims of COVID-19
content: ['<p>BENJAMIN  - Cuba’s health ministry said on Thursday it had informed the United States, China and the EU that it would provide doses of vaccines to all victims of the coronavirus.<p><p>The announcement came at the start of a month-long process to build a vaccine infrastructure in Cuba after the country reported a record 687,000 COVID-19 cases.<p><p>President Raul Castro said Cuba was ready to take steps to prevent the spread of the coronavirus from abroad but the process was “extremely difficult”.<p><p>“We are still waiting for our allies and other countries to join us,” he told a press conference, adding that the United States and China did not want to lose their own citizens.<p> ']

headline: Hospitals in England are being warned for COVID-19 patients and staff at hospitals
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Hospitals in England are being warned by the COVID-19 vaccine regulator over the risk of a worsening clotting condition and are being told to treat all patients with COVID-19, a spokeswoman for the regulator said on Friday.<p><p>The risk of worsening clotting, known as P2C, is particularly acute in hospitals that are at risk of becoming overwhelmed by patients.<p><p>“We have not received an indication that this risk is going to become a concern for hospitals across the country until after Easter,” the spokeswoman said.<p><p>A spokeswoman for the regulator said the decision to take action was a “critical and significant step to ensure our healthcare system can support those with low risk.”<p><p>P2C cases could reach 400,000 within a week, she said, though the number has been rising steadily in recent days.<p><p>Health Secretary Chris Grayling said the regulator would set out a timeline for action.<p><p>The regulator’s recommendation on Friday came after an investigation into the use of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine was revealed in January and prompted a further surge of coronavirus cases in England.<p> ']

headline: U.S. urges China to maintain support for Hong Kong
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States is calling for China to maintain support for Hong Kong and China’s democratic process as it seeks to avoid China’s increasingly assertive behaviour in the East and Southeast Asian countries, White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki said on Wednesday.<p> ']

headline: Truck attack carried out on Turkish convoy near Ankara
content: ['<p>ANKARA  - At least 28 people were killed and seven injured when a truck bomb struck a convoy of Turkish truckers near Ankara, police said on Tuesday, the latest violence to hit the country’s transport system in recent days.<p><p>The truckers were heading from Istanbul to Dili, where they were celebrating Eid al-Fitr, a major holy month in the Muslim calendar.<p><p>At least 15 people have been killed and at least 27 injured in the attack on the convoy of truckers on Wednesday, Turkey’s interior ministry said.<p><p>Witnesses at the scene told Reuters the truckers had been preparing to go back to Turkey and that they were preparing to go back after Eid al-Fitr.<p> ']

headline: AstraZeneca is concerned about potential side effects of COVID-19 vaccines in younger women
content: ['<p>NEW YORK — A company source has said that AstraZeneca and Pfizer are concerned about a possible side effect of COVID-19 vaccines in women younger than 60 who are getting the shots, and that some women are using the shots in the last three weeks because they were experiencing "unnecessary fatigue" during the vaccination process, according to a statement on Wednesday.<p><p>The company has been testing the vaccines in women ages 50-64 who have received all three doses, but said the side effects did not occur during the fourth dose, suggesting some women may have a different reaction to the shots.<p><p>“The company continues to evaluate all options with respect to the vaccines we currently have, including with respect to any potential risk of any side effects, including if they cause any adverse side effect,” the statement said.<p><p>The company is in talks with a vaccine manufacturer to develop a vaccine with less risk of side effects, the source said.<p><p>“After consultation with our vaccine advisors, AstraZeneca and Pfizer are in the process of testing the vaccine for potential risks related to the vaccine side effects,” the source added.<p><p>The European Union said last week it would impose a strict new global lock-down on global COVID-19 vaccinations, which is set to take effect in six months. It is not the first time the bloc has come under fire for its use of vaccines made by AstraZeneca and Pfizer.<p>']

headline: Ahead of the second International Climate Change Conference, attendees are asked to prepare for the worst. The first gathering, which starts on April 1 in the Vatican, will be hosted by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), the world’s largest global weather forecaster. In addition, more than 4,000 climate change experts are expected to attend the session. This year’s event, to be held in Bonn, Germany, is organized by the Swiss climate-change alliance. The conference has been called the “Global Climate Change Conference”. Previous climate talks have focused on the implications of global warming for weather, including how COVID-19 could impact coastal and water use in the United States. “Our hope is that the conference will transform the debate about how COVID-19 impacts human lives, the environment, and the global system.” said Gregor Pacheco, WMO director and chair of the event. “I think it’s important to start this together with this climate event.” “It’s a great opportunity to give a strong signal to the world about how the future of humanity and the planet can be changed.” “But the conference is just an opening, with a lot of extra work.” The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) is based in Geneva. The conference will also be hosted by the World Meteorological Organization, which has been responsible for the global climate change task force since 2010. More than 4,000 climate scientists, including climate change experts and experts in industry and science, will attend. One of the main speakers will be the outgoing head of the WMO, Josef Hernández, who is also an adviser to President Biden.
