The event will also focus on a wide array of topics including ocean acidification, the importance of COVID-19 vaccines, the implications of COVID-19 vaccines on COVID-19,
Venezuela says it could impose new restrictions on gatherings, but protesters say Maduro is still in power
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - Venezuela has imposed new restrictions on gatherings and political gatherings for the third consecutive day, the interior ministry said on Monday, contradicting assertions by the opposition and other media outlets that Maduro’s popularity is declining.<p><p>Venezuela’s opposition says Maduro is increasingly controlling the police, is using excessive force and depriving the public of access to information.<p><p>An opposition lawmaker has urged Maduro to step down and to leave parliament.<p><p>“I am telling you that Maduro is not responsible for the situation that he is in,” the legislator, Daniel Fortunato, wrote on Twitter. “We have never seen anything like this in the history of Venezuela.”<p><p>Maduro’s office did not respond to requests for comment.<p><p>Opposition leader and Bolivarian politician Henrique Capriles has said Maduro was in control of the police, and that Maduro himself has “flouted all democratic regulations”.<p><p>“The police were called, they opened fire and the situation was calmed,” Capriles said in a televised speech on Monday.<p><p>Maduro has also sought to expand his power in Venezuela by promising to revive a pension scheme that has failed, which Maduro has repeatedly said has failed.<p>']

headline: Venezuela's Caracas police chief dismisses call for investigation
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - Venezuela’s chief prosecutor dismissed the call for a thorough investigation into the murder of Hugo Chavez on Sunday, a day after it emerged that a prosecutor’s office in Caracas was behind the killing of a Venezuelan youth in a suspected assassination attempt.<p><p>The prosecutor’s office on Saturday announced it had opened an investigation into the slaying of Nicolas Araujo, 42, by police officers who shot him dead on May 2.<p><p>Police said Araujo, who had lived with his mother in Venezuela since 2012 and lived with his uncle, was killed after an argument on Saturday between officers.<p><p>The killing was a day after a Venezuelan government official was accused of using excessive force to disperse a protest in Caracas that spilled into the streets of the capital.<p><p>The official said he had no regrets over his actions.<p><p>President Nicolas Maduro’s government has denied any involvement in the shooting.<p><p>The accusation that Araujo had killed Araujo - who has been in custody since 2012 - was made public after he was detained after he and another Venezuelan youth were shot dead.<p><p>Maduro said a total of 16 Venezuelans have been detained since March 22 in the crackdown on the protests in Caracas.<p> ']

headline: Venezuela's Maduro says state-owned oil company won't let Venezuelan oil companies drill
content: ["<p>Venezuela’s socialist president said on Wednesday the state oil company Chevron would not allow state-owned Venezuelan oil company Vexatas, citing its opposition to government policies.<p><p>Venezuela’s opposition has long complained that Venezuela has run into legal issues that were not resolved during the oil crisis.<p><p>Venezuela's opposition accused the country’s oil minister, Nicolas Maduro, of trying to distract from domestic problems by pursuing projects with big oil deposits at the expense of Venezuela.<p><p>Venezuelan oil production has risen sharply since late 2013 as a result of Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro’s crackdown on opposition lawmakers. Venezuela has said it aims to prop up oil production by the end of 2020, though analysts say it faces a hard time sourcing gas from hydrocarbons that Venezuela needs to meet its gas demand.<p><p>In a speech to state oil companies, Maduro said that Venezuela could not let Vexatas get in the way of its domestic energy production and that the opposition is a “political prisoner” and its economic problems are a threat to global energy security.<p><p>Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been facing a rise in violent street protests in recent months. Protesters have also accused Venezuela of a crackdown on its oil exports to Western countries, citing its handling of the financial crisis.<p>"]

headline: Vaccine use has reached all age groups in UK - data
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Britain’s overall vaccination rollout is reaching all age groups in the country, with the fastest rollout in the European Union and the most effective in Britain, a review by the government found, despite a lack of evidence of side effects.<p><p>The benefits of vaccines for people over 60 were highlighted by a review by experts who looked at cases of brain blood clots, bleeding and infections among older adults.<p><p>The Health Protection Agency said on Friday that a large proportion of people over 60 had had received at least one vaccine dose.<p> ']

headline: 'Grim' moment: China's President Wang Yi says Beijing plans to build 1.4 million new homes on its southern border
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China’s president said on Wednesday China would build 1.4 million new homes on its southern border, which Beijing called its “largest urban border” since its founding in 1947.<p><p>Chinese officials said on Wednesday that Beijing plans to build more than 1.4 million more housing units on the southern frontier in the first year of a nationwide crackdown on illegal immigration, including a planned expansion of China’s industrial park and development of luxury condominiums.<p><p>The Chinese state media agency Xinhua quoted Wang as saying the capital Beijing was on the territory of China.<p><p>Wang said a state-backed building agency is set to create 2,500 housing units near the northern border, Xinhua added, and there are plans to open 100 housing units there by the year-end.<p><p>Wang told reporters the project would help boost GDP to a new record of over 11 billion yuan ($5.25 trillion) this year, and warned that the country’s ability to generate electricity and develop industry would be severely curtailed.<p><p>“We should not wait too long for the implementation of the programme, for the implementation of the programme, and for the implementation of the measures,” he added.<p>']

headline: UK PM says he will not hold referendum on EU membership after resigning as prime minister
content: ['<p>LONDON  - British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will not hold an election on Friday as the EU enters a two-year period of uncertainty and uncertainty over the bloc’s future.<p><p>Johnson said that if he left the prime minister’s post, “any future government could decide that’s not worth it,” he told reporters on Thursday.<p><p>Johnson said he would stick by his pledge to remain in the EU in the EU’s fourth trimester if Johnson’s resignation was successful.<p> ']

headline: Honduran PM Pemex, to meet UN special envoy on climate
content: ['<p>JOHANNESBURG  - A Honduran foreign minister was expected to meet UN special envoy to address the crisis in Honduras on Tuesday, his office said, adding the meeting was not yet scheduled.<p><p>Venezuelan Foreign Minister Hugo Chavez met Colombian President Juan Guillermo Lasso on Tuesday and has yet to make public any comments, according to a government source.<p><p>The meeting comes just a day after Lasso said Lasso’s administration had ignored calls to hold a meeting of the 27-nation Organization of American States (OAS) climate conference in Washington on Tuesday.<p><p>“The president will be invited to meet the special envoy to address the crisis in Honduras, as soon as possible, the Honduran government’s office said in a statement.<p> ']

headline: 'My heart is breaking': Myanmar soldier in jail, brother's wife shot
content: ['<p>KUALA LUMPUR  - My heart is breaking after my husband shot himself in a hospital, and my heart is breaking too - a Myanmar soldier in jail, his wife and mother said on Sunday.<p><p>The 25-year-old man, identified as Mohammed Muntek, was taken to hospital with a gunshot wound to the leg.<p><p>He told a TV show he was taken to the Shaare Yarang Hospital and shot in the leg.<p> ']

headline: Indonesia PM says Indonesia's Joko Widodo could take over state of emergency
content: ['<p>JAKARTA  -Indonesia’s prime minister said on Wednesday he was contemplating taking over the government of Aung San Suu Kyi over the coronavirus pandemic, the New York Times reported.<p><p>“I really need to know,” said Suu Kyi, addressing reporters at a news conference, according to the newspaper. “I’m really concerned about the situation.”<p><p>“I’m thinking about what happens when I see the president of the United States, the next prime minister, sitting in the legislature.”<p><p>She added that Indonesia had asked the Indonesian government for help in battling the pandemic, adding that the government would meet its deadline for withdrawing the coronavirus pandemic vaccine next month.<p><p>Indonesia has said its death toll of 1.7 million has now reached 2.6 million.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar army says it is ready to meet protesters over coup
content: ['<p> - A junta spokesman said it would meet on Wednesday to discuss a coup and the situation in Myanmar, amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in a country still grappling with a rising death toll and a humanitarian crisis worsening by the daily curfew.<p><p>Hsun Wuhan said on Twitter that army spokesman Gen Min Aung Hlaing had sent a message to “foreign media outlets on Wednesday” in which he told them to “stop talking about coup.”<p><p>The United Nations has described the coup as a “national emergency” that has left hundreds dead and has pushed its share of refugees to more than a quarter million.<p><p>The United States has also warned that Myanmar’s civilian government is “unprecedentedly unstable” and warned the army that a political coup could destabilise its society.<p><p>“We’re ready to meet to discuss the situation in Myanmar and in the country,” a statement said.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal opens to traffic for cargo
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The Suez Canal reopened on Friday, allowing international shipping companies to enter the open waterway and reduce traffic congestion, officials said.<p><p>The expansion was the latest move by a member of the Organization of American States (OAS) to slow shipping traffic in the region amid rising tensions with China and Russia over disputed territory.<p><p>China has pledged to ease its sanctions on the Suez Canal Authority and impose new ones, while Russia has pushed back hard on an EU trade deal with the United States.<p> ']

headline: Fifa official says 2022 World Cup'sovereignty moment'
content: ['<p>RIO DE JANEIRO  - An official in Rio de Janeiro said on Thursday that 2022 World Cup organisers would have to show the 2022 hosting nations that the stadium will not be subject to aggression, amid reports a soccer stadium could be overrun by the Brazilian state army.<p><p>Brazil is seeking a host state for 2022 soccer matches it wants to host. It has rejected suggestions it may need more, and said it would prefer Brazil than neighbouring Mexico.<p><p>Brazil’s bid to host the 2022 soccer tournament is also due to start next week.<p><p>A soccer match against the winner of Saturday’s U.S. World Cup, a final that will be played in Las Vegas and the United States, is also due to take place.<p><p>President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil is due to visit South Korea on April 19.<p><p>He said on Thursday he was discussing the 2022 World Cup, which will be held from April 18-21.<p><p>Bolsonaro has said Brazil and South Korea are pursuing the 2022 bid.<p> ']

headline: EU's Prince Philip says he hopes UK can end war
content: ['<p>LONDON  - The British Prince Philip said he hoped Britain could end the conflict in Iraq with a "win-win" outcome on Wednesday, following a vote to extend peace talks until after Easter, after the UK refused to commit to an early exit from the war and withdrew its troops.<p><p>The European Union, which helped set up the talks, has rejected Philip’s comments, which were welcomed by some in Washington but dismissed as political opportunism,’s stance on the conflict in Iraq since June has been a major point of contention in recent weeks.<p><p>“This is an historic moment and I hope that the UK can do what we can to secure the outcome we all want,” Philip said in a televised speech, using the acronym for the United Kingdom’s NATO alliance.<p><p>He also said it was a “deep honour and a huge honour” to have held talks with Iraq’s government, which he said had been working in partnership with international organisations in recent days.<p><p>He said Britain and other member states should remain neutral in the conflict and seek a lasting peace settlement.<p><p>“We are determined to end this terrible conflict,” Philip said, speaking at a news conference after taking part in talks in Baghdad. “There is absolutely no need for us to be complacent and to be prepared.”<p>']

headline: Sudan is seeking a ceasefire deal, says aid organisation
content: ['<p>DUBAI  - Sudan’s foreign ministry said on Monday that it had reached a tentative ceasefire with the government of President Omar Hassan Hassan al-Bashir in the region, but that talks on how to end the conflict in Darfur would continue.<p><p>“The ceasefire is being reviewed, with the participation of all parties involved,” ministry spokesman Hassan told Reuters in an email, referring to Sudan.<p><p>“The implementation of the ceasefire is in the country’s best interests,” he added.<p><p>Hassan had urged the international community to use all available tools to stop the flow of humanitarian and humanitarian aid from Darfur, a conflict that has killed 4,000 people.<p> ']

headline: Czech Republic to pay for gas drilling from Saudi Arabia after U.S. and other companies fail to pay $60 billion
content: ['<p>PARIS  - The Czech Republic is to pay $60 billion to Saudi Arabia to refine gas for crude oil projects worth $60 billion, state broadcaster TVR reported on Tuesday.<p><p>The Czech Republic is seeking a U.S. energy deal with the country which could yield $60 billion of economic benefits for it, the broadcaster said, citing unnamed sources.<p><p>The purchase of drilling equipment for oil projects worth $60 billion is part of a broader energy deal with Russia and China. The U.S. and European Union last year cut off supplies of crude oil due to Iran’s nuclear compliance.<p> ']

headline: OstraZeneca launches COVID-19 vaccine as COVID-19 vaccine rollout looms
content: ['<p>SAINT LOUIS  -The OTC OTC vaccine rollout is not yet over, and the company is rolling out new vaccines to its own customers, chief executive John Della Serano said on Tuesday.<p><p>Overseas countries like Australia and New Zealand have taken notice and, on average, over 75% of adults in the world now have at least one COVID-19 vaccine, according to the CDC.<p><p>While the number of COVID-19 vaccines distributed worldwide may be less than it was 10 years ago, the rollout is rapidly expanding and Della said his team had recently completed vaccination surveys in both countries and plans to begin administering vaccines in the United States later this year.<p><p>“This is a huge step forward in terms of our overall progress,” Della told CNBC. “We are in our third quarter, and the vaccine rollout is not just about distributing those vaccines, it’s also about making sure we’re giving people an opportunity to be vaccinated and healthy,” he said.<p><p>““There will be times where we may not even have the vaccine in the country that needs it most, but we are here to help and be ready for that,” he added.<p> ']

headline: Vietnam says it has warned China of 'potentially significant' risks to world economy
content: ['<p>SEOUL  - Vietnam said on Wednesday it had warned China of “potentially significant” risks to global economy and stability, with an updated statement on its foreign policy aimed at dissuading Beijing from interfering.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal opens for two months to traffic from other ports
content: ["<p>CAIRO  - The southern section of the Suez Canal, under construction to transport goods, closed on Tuesday for two months after the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) said it would close it in 2019.<p><p>The SCA has said it has been unable to complete the dredging that began in December and is currently waiting on the ship's water quality report for the remaining dredging sites.<p><p>“We are in contact with the owner of the vessel, the SCA, to inform them that the canal is now open to traffic from other ports,” Suez Canal Authority CEO Prince Hamza told reporters in a televised statement.<p><p>“We have decided to open it up again as the SCA has said it will, but at this stage we can see only a few small changes in traffic.”<p><p>The Suez Canal Authority (SCA), the world’s busiest shipping container ship, will open daily from March 8 to 10, with other routes of travel expected to be limited to those from other countries, the SCA said.<p><p>“The ship is carrying 4 million litres of essential oil which will be transported to Egypt by a cargo vessel,” the SCA said in a statement.<p>"]

headline: Exclusive: UK's Boris Johnson says EU summit meeting was 'deadly' and he would "go on looking after himself
content: ['<p>LONDON  - Boris Johnson said the European Union summit meeting was a "deadly, pointless, and futile" affair as he put pressure on Chancellor Philip Hammond to scrap the bloc’s hard-line pro-Brexit stance and put an end to EU sanctions and asset freezes.<p><p>Johnson, who is due to speak to ministers later on Tuesday, said the EU summit was "too big a political and technical event" for his aides.<p><p>He said: “The EU has to keep the pressure on, it’s too big a political and technical event for us.”<p> ']

headline: AstraZeneca shot says it's making progress and could be ready for trial in Britain
content: ['<p>LONDON  -AstraZeneca said on Monday it had made progress in its trials in Britain, but that the drugmaker’s shot might not be ready to begin production in Britain within a year.<p><p>Britain had originally ordered a trial of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine but the drugmaker did not get a licence to do so before the start of the new year, ending two decades of delays in the manufacture of the Pfizer/BioNTech shot.<p><p>However, the shot has been approved for use in people under the age of 50 in Britain, which also allows people under 60 to get a shot through the health service.<p><p>AstraZeneca also said it had been supplying Pfizer’s vaccine to Pfizer’s trial in France as part of a broader programme that is intended to boost production and ease restrictions.<p><p>It said it was exploring the possibility of producing Pfizer’s shot by the end of March, when the first Pfizer-Cohen shot can be delivered to the general public.<p><p>Britain did not buy the vaccine.<p> ']

headline: Biden pledges to keep 'dangerous' trade barriers around the world in his administration
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON — President Biden told members of Congress on Tuesday that he would keep “dangerous” trade barriers around the world in his administration, but only after consulting with experts.<p><p>In his speech before a joint session of Congress on the administration\\'s first 100 days, Biden emphasized the need for a strong commitment to protect international companies, and that Washington would stick to the rules and protections of trade agreements.<p><p>“I will keep the U.S. open, but in my administration we will remain open to other countries that are concerned about these kinds of trade barriers,” he said, adding that he would also stay in touch with experts on China and North Korea.<p><p>Biden added that he would work to ensure that “non-member states are given the same opportunity to be part of the global order as they are part of the United States,” and that the United States would remain “ready to engage” in international disputes.<p><p>“I’m hopeful we can work to make sure that we remain the strongest trading nation on the planet, because that’s exactly the kind of commitment that we need to make to the world,” Biden said.<p><p>In the speech, Biden repeated the promise that Washington would remain “open,” pledging to continue working with other nations to protect American workers and American workers globally.<p> "]

headline: Czech PMs 'not at all pessimistic' about EU membership
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Czech Prime Minister Boyko Borissov said on Thursday that he could consider whether to join the European Union without taking political risk, as his European Council colleague Charles Michel did not want to leave the bloc.<p><p>Michel said on Thursday he was not at all pessimistic about the prospects for Czechs joining, which was due to start a referendum on membership on April 9.<p><p>“We are not at all pessimistic about the prospects of joining,” Michel said on national television. “We are just not at all pessimistic.”<p> ']

headline: Blinken's vaccine plan is 'foolish'
content: ['<p>MADRID  - Blinken’s shot is being made in Europe, where more than a million people have received a Pfizer-BioNTech shot, Prime Minister Pedro Passos said on Monday.<p><p>Passos’s administration is reviewing a proposed vaccine rollout from Europe, which is due to start in early 2019, to assess the risk posed by the AstraZeneca shot and provide further guidance.<p> ']

headline: China says it will not allow Myanmar to return to authoritarian rule
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - The Chinese foreign ministry said on Friday it will not allow Myanmar’s elected government to return to authoritarian rule, after the United States backed the interim leader General Min Aung Hlaing’s demand for an end to violence and promised to act to stop any further bloodshed.<p><p>“It is necessary that the Chinese side take appropriate measures, which include allowing all sides to resume peaceful dialogue, including by calling for an end to violence and for the immediate withdrawal of all personnel from camps and detention centres,” the foreign ministry said in a statement.<p><p>On Tuesday, President Xi Jinping urged China to open its borders to refugees and to help combat the coronavirus pandemic.<p><p>But in a direct challenge to the increasingly authoritarian rule of the military-backed insurgents, the statement said the country’s national security and territorial integrity was at stake.<p> ']

headline: EU wants to send EU ambassadors to China, says it needs to take more time
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - The European Union is concerned by reports of China’s growing influence in Hong Kong, as it seeks to build trust with Beijing after a long weekend of tensions with Beijing over a South China Sea claim.<p><p>In a phone call with a senior Chinese diplomat, U.S. Ambassador John Kirby said he understood Chinese concerns over what he called “unilateral and destabilising actions” that Beijing has taken in Hong Kong.<p><p>Asked if China had interfered in a U.S. presidential election in 2020, Kirby said: “Yes, we’re concerned about that.”<p><p>A spokeswoman for the U.S. embassy in Beijing declined to comment on whether China had interfered in the election.<p><p>The EU’s top diplomat, Christine Schaeuble, told a news conference that she would not have agreed to a phone call between the two leaders, but said it was likely that they had discussed “sensitive issues” like Hong Kong.<p><p>Britain said last month that it was concerned about Chinese activity in its southern neighbour, with some London residents questioning why some officials have remained in Beijing.<p><p>Schaeuble also told reporters the EU was ready to send ambassadors to Hong Kong to help in a number of other areas, including combating human rights abuses and providing security assistance to local businesses.<p> ']

headline: China's Xinjiang says it is concerned about crackdown on rights of Chinese nationals
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region and Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (UAR) say they will resume all activities in accordance with international human rights law on March 24, the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region’s chief news officer said on Friday.<p><p>State news agency Xinhua cited the UAR chief’s statements on Thursday as indicating “there is no place for a Chinese presence in the UAR” and adding that the UAR will not accept the unilateral imposition of such an order.<p><p>Chinese President Xi Jinping told reporters on Thursday that the United States had a responsibility to protect human rights in Xinjiang.<p><p>“The Chinese government is determined to ensure the protection of Uyghurs everywhere and to ensure that the UAR continues its work in accordance with international law,” Xinhua quoted him as saying.<p> ']

headline: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro criticizes Maduro for 'provocative acts of aggression'
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - Venezuela’s president has called for protests on Wednesday against Maduro’s government and his party’s repression of opposition supporters, in what could be a significant escalation of tensions in the OPEC nation where President Nicolas Maduro is fighting a fourth wave of COVID-19 restrictions and government measures.<p><p>Maduro’s party on Wednesday said opposition members and supporters who were detained were acting in "attempts to provoke and intimidate the president and the ruling Communist Party of Venezuela."<p><p>“We call on the president to immediately stop the repression,” Maduro said in a video on Facebook. “We call for the immediate release of all Venezuelan prisoners in custody, including jailed political opponents,” he added.<p><p>Maduro’s government says its policy of limiting the use of lethal force against opponents and detainees has been tested by lethal injection. Maduro denies that.<p><p>Maduro’s allies accuse Maduro of pushing opposition leaders to agree on a path for a third revolution.<p><p>Maduro denies having any plans to restart the economy, and he says he is prepared to defend his interests on the basis of national sovereignty.<p><p>Opponents have said he is using excessive force to enforce Maduro’s crackdown on the opposition and that he should be held accountable for his actions.<p>']

headline: U.S. sanctions Yemen's Houthis, Saudi-led coalition say
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The U.S. military and Saudi-led coalition fighting the Houthis in Yemen say they have killed or damaged six coalition aircraft in the area of Khan Sheikhoun, the capital of Yemen’s Sarea province, U.S. Central Command said on Thursday.<p><p>The coalition, which includes the United States, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, the United Kingdom and the United States, intervened in 2014 to rescue the internationally-recognized government of Yemen from internationally-recognized government forces.<p> ']

headline: Malta confirms plans to allow AstraZeneca shots into its AstraZeneca shots
content: ['<p>Malta on Wednesday confirmed plans to allow its AstraZeneca vaccine to enter its shot, despite an announcement on Tuesday that the shots would not meet its restrictions and would be delivered in two weeks.<p><p>“In recent weeks, we had communicated our concerns to our regulators,” Malta health minister Roberto Matia said in a press conference. “Now we’re working on a recommendation to deliver that.”<p><p>Malta has so far approved 519,091 doses of its shot.<p> ']

headline: U.S. accuses Iran of war crimes: Biden
content: ["<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. intelligence officials have accused Iran of war crimes in the conflict in Yemen, the administration said on Wednesday, as the United States prepared to meet Iran at the United Nations next week in a bid to help resolve the crisis.<p><p>The allegations come as the United Nations prepares for a six-nation summit on the crisis in the Middle East slated for the weekend.<p><p>In a separate development, the State Department’s Inspector General\\'s Office said in a statement on Tuesday it had found evidence Iran had used cluster bombs on Yemen to target security forces.<p><p>“The evidence shows that Iran has committed war crimes against its own citizens, in violation of international law, including violating the Red List of war crimes committed by the United States against the civilian population in the Middle East,” the statement said.<p><p>U.S. and Saudi officials have traded blame for a series of deadly airstrikes in Yemen and Washington says it has proof Iran is behind those attacks.<p><p>The Houthis on Tuesday accused Iran of “provocative, and reckless” actions in Yemen, an accusation Tehran denies.<p><p>“Iran has a long history of war crimes against its own people, which will make it difficult to sustain a peace process with its allies,” Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal said on Twitter.<p>"]

headline: U.S. pushes back hard against Iran's ballistic missile test
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Monday pushed back against comments by Iran’s ballistic missile agency on a test by a U.S.-designated “province” of a ballistic missile, arguing that it was more likely that the tests were part of a routine ballistic missile test.<p><p>“The assertion that the test was a test of a new type of ballistic missile is misleading,” Blinken said in a statement. “I urge the Iranian people to be realistic about the capabilities of this new type of ballistic missile and urge them to reject such nonsense”.<p><p>Speaking after a meeting of the United States’ nuclear arms control and ballistic missile oversight committees in New York, Blinken added that Iran had “strongly denied to the United States any participation in its development of a ballistic missile that could evade detection,” citing the nuclear deal.<p><p>Download the NBC News app for breaking news and politics<p><p>Iran’s Revolutionary Guards rejected Iran’s latest ballistic missile test and accused the United States of undermining U.S.-led efforts to ensure Iran doesn’t develop nuclear weapons.<p><p>The Iranian official who visited the United States on Monday told NBC News that the U.S. was taking “possible action to contain Iran’s missile activities,” and said that the United States needed to confront Tehran more easily.<p>']

headline: U.S. urges Beijing to stop military build-up in eastern Xinjiang
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - The United States and China have called on Beijing to refrain from military activity in Xinjiang in response to reports of recent military build-ups by Chinese troops and security forces near Uighur-controlled territory in northwest China’s Xinjiang region.<p><p>The U.S. State Department on Thursday urged China to refrain from actions that “create risks” and warned that the ongoing Uighur-controlled events in northwest China’s Xinjiang region would not be tolerated.<p><p>“We urge China to refrain from actions that create risks and create instability that will ultimately lead to instability,” State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki told reporters.<p><p>The State Department said the United States had spoken with Chinese officials about the concerns raised, adding the Chinese delegation expressed concern about the reports.<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Navalny to face trial for treason after Kremlin critic sentenced to life in prison
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The head of Russia’s most prominent opposition group said on Thursday that jailed opposition figure Alexei Navalny will face a trial for treason after being found guilty of trying to plot against him.<p><p>Navalny, 43, was sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday in absentia for organizing the 2015 Winter Olympics in Russia. His lawyer did not answer questions as he awaits a possible appeal.<p><p>“There is nothing illegal about doing what you are doing,” Alexander Litvinenko, the head of Navalny’s camp, said in a statement. “It is a terrible injustice that he would be sentenced to death.”<p><p>Navalny was arrested in January 2019 in Moscow after attempting to smuggle a bottle of gas in a plane to Ukraine. He had pleaded not guilty to charges of sabotage and breach of trust.<p><p>His camp blamed Navalny for a spike in protests last year and the Kremlin denied he had tried to orchestrate them. Russia denies a parallel to the Kremlin and has called the charges an attempt to derail the Games.<p> ']

headline: Exclusive: Trump wants to increase U.S. military presence in East Asia
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Saturday he has spoken to Chinese President Xi Jinping about a "big challenge" facing the region, and he has told his Japanese counterpart, Shinzo Abe, to make sure there is “no big fuss.”<p><p>Beijing has also warned Washington that U.S. military presence in East Asia could increase the risk of escalation, and there have been talks on whether or not to deploy military forces.<p><p>Biden, who said he wanted to be constructive, did not immediately respond to a request for comment on whether his aides would answer directly to Xi, and that the two leaders had been in touch on several occasions.<p><p>“We discussed a big challenge facing the region,” Biden told reporters at his daily news conference. “And we agreed that it is a big challenge.”<p><p>Beijing says Washington will not allow a confrontation with the United States to lead to a renewed military buildup in the region, and Beijing says U.S. interests should be respected.<p><p>Asked to comment on the Biden administration’s position on China, Abe said: “You can\'t change the nature of the relationship. If it becomes a challenge, we won’t change our position.”<p>']

headline: Suez Canal workers demand better safety record in case of possible disaster
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The canal project to the South China Sea in the Indian Ocean would require more than 25 years of dredging to safely clear the massive container ship it is racing to reach, an industry source said on Wednesday.<p><p>The United States has demanded that China pay a $400 million (about $5.8 billion) in damages to the Philippines after a U.S. dredger failed to clear the damaged vessel on Friday, while Beijing is appealing the U.S. decision.<p><p>China said earlier this month it would pay $400 million to the United States if the United States fails to meet its own maritime obligations under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA).<p><p>An environmental group said the risk for the reef was too high and the dredging was futile, while others said it was just a temporary measure.<p><p>“The government of Singapore will take this matter seriously,” the Hong Kong-based group said.<p><p>Suez Canal Authority (SCA) Chairman Tan Sri Mahadir Hidayat told reporters on Wednesday that the project was for a “new era” and that the SCA would “demand the same levels of diligence and diligence as the United States to ensure that this project is complete and safe.”<p> ']

headline: China sends first cargo ship to U.S. in 2018
content: ['<p>BEIJING  -China sent its first cargo ship to the U.S. in 2018 with plans to send its first cargo ship to the U.S. next year, state media reported on Friday.<p><p>The cargo ship, the Xinjiang Uighur Ulema, will provide food and medicine to a U.S. consulate in Texas, Chinese government spokesman Zhao Lijian told a regular news conference.<p><p>China began shipping goods in 2018 under a multi-billion-dollar arms deal with the United States to help fight the Islamic State.<p><p>“The United States is committed to the U.S. commitment to ensuring the security of its citizens, including in the Middle East and elsewhere,” Zhao said.<p><p>China’s cargo ship has been transporting goods from the Xinjiang port of Shandong, bordering Iraq, Syria and Yemen, Xinhua reported.<p><p>The Xinjiang Ulema has been heading to the U.S. Embassy in Washington, U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP), according to a document seen by Reuters.<p><p>A spokesman for the U.S. embassy did not answer calls seeking comment.<p><p>Asked about the statement, a spokeswoman for the consulate said that U.S. Customs and Border Protection was in touch with the Chinese coast guard and that it would be working with them to meet all requirements.<p> ']

headline: Rescue workers combing through floodwaters in Mozambique, Ethiopia
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Rescue workers combing through floodwaters in Mozambique have found bodies washed up on beaches, aid groups said on Wednesday, as disaster victims continued to flee flooded areas and people moved towards hospitals.<p><p>The bodies of nine people were found submerged in a large river in an area of Mozambique’s northern province of Gombele on Wednesday, according to the Coordination for Rescue of Emergency Care (COARES) NGO.<p><p>Mozambique’s Ministry of Health, which has said more than 500 people had died of acute floods in recent days, said on Wednesday the bodies of two people and a 14-year-old boy had been recovered.<p><p>“Nine dead bodies were found at the beach on Friday in Gombele, three were at the beach on Saturday, and two were at the water treatment plant in Boulogne,” the ministry said in a statement.<p><p>The ministry did not say how many people had died.<p><p>Mozambique said last week that it had reclaimed nearly 80% of its beaches from floodwater in recent days after imposing a temporary curfew in place since last month, ending on March 15 after a third of the country’s population reported experiencing record low deaths.<p>']

headline: China seeks a new diplomatic solution to maritime disputes, but says no diplomatic breakthrough until next week
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - China said on Wednesday it was ready for dialogue with Vietnam after China’s navy reported it had intercepted four ballistic missile defence systems from Taiwan.<p><p>On Wednesday, Vietnam said the navy had intercepted two ballistic missiles - the first intercepted in the southern part of Taiwan Strait, and the second intercepted by a South Korean frigate in the Hsien Loi area near the Chinese-claimed Diaoyu Islands.<p> ']

headline: Rangers shoot dead intruder who tried to break into train
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - At least six people were killed and more than a dozen injured in a suspected attempted armed robbery and attempted escape from a train in eastern Germany on Saturday after a gunman opened fire with a truck, police said.<p><p>The suspects were later identified by the police as those involved in the incident.<p><p>The truck that the suspect was in was later identified as belonging to an unknown number of suspects in a second truck attack in the northern city of Potsdam, the police chief told reporters.<p> ']

headline: Malta to join European Court of Human Rights in court case over slavery
content: ['<p>Malta’s Human Rights Commission on Wednesday said it will enter a criminal case into which it will appeal an EU ruling that it is responsible for some 20,000 reported cases of human rights abuses and discrimination against women in Malta.<p><p>The case, which is set to be heard next month by the European Court of Human Rights, aims to establish how a state has constituted an “undue burden” on freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and religious freedoms in Malta.<p><p>In September, Malta’s President Jero Krijalskiy ordered Malta’s Catholic priest, who served under the former regime, to pay back $17,600 he suffered as a result of abuses during the 19th century. The case has been moved, however, to the European Court of Human Rights.<p><p>While the Commission has a legal basis in Malta, it is unclear whether it will seek the outcome in the European Court of Human Rights.<p><p>The case is a major blow to the far-left Free Movement Party, which has campaigned on behalf of women’s rights in Malta since 2002. Its leader, Lizzie Raffaele, who is currently serving as an MP for the centre-right coalition, told Reuters last year that freedom of expression was a fundamental right and that there was nothing wrong with “censoring” women.<p><p>Raffaele also said that women’s rights were still “under attack.”<p> ']

headline: The Kremlin says sanctions are temporary
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Russia’s government said on Tuesday it was preparing to impose sanctions against four Russian companies that it said were violating sanctions as part of a widening cyber security problem, the BBC reported.<p><p>On Tuesday, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said the United States would supply the United States with additional sanctions on companies that it said were violating sanctions, and the United States on Wednesday announced it was withdrawing its sanctions in a move aimed at easing tension in the region.<p> ']

headline: Myanmar's Suu Kyi's critics accuse her of graft and abuse
content: ['<p> -Myanmar’s leader Min Aung Hlaing said on Thursday that prosecutors had taken a case against her for a corruption charge and accused her of trying to obstruct justice.<p><p>Prosecutors were searching for three suspects in a corruption case that the opposition says is a result of Suu Kyi’s rule and the prosecution refused to provide additional evidence.<p><p>The opposition has demanded an independent investigation into the case. Suu Kyi has denied involvement.<p><p>Min Aung Hlaing said prosecutors had failed to produce enough evidence and denied any attempt to tarnish her image with political pressure.<p><p>“I have done nothing wrong, no corruption, no child abuse,” she told reporters after a meeting with Myanmar’s top prosecutor at the Supreme Court in Yangon. “My only responsibility is for the public safety,” she added.<p><p>She was responding to a question from a reporter after a visit to the judicial building.<p><p>“So what? What did I do wrong? I think the prosecution will be satisfied. Let’s try and find some way to make a resolution on that,” she said, according to the Associated Press.<p><p>The government, in its response, denied the accusation and said it was investigating Min Aung Hlaing.<p>']

headline: Thailand's Suu Kyi calls for unity amid crisis
content: ['<p>KUALA LUMPUR  - Thailand’s Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha called on Sunday for unity in a country still suffering from the coronavirus pandemic, calling for all sides to meet in a two-way meeting to resolve the crisis.<p><p>“I urge all concerned citizens, especially those living in rural areas and urban areas, to meet in a very clear and concrete way in a two-way meeting,” Prayuth told a regular news conference.<p><p>“I urge the whole international community to support Thailand, to reach an accord, a solution that leads to stability and security for all,” he added.<p> ']

headline: Fenway says COVID-19 threat is 'critical' for vaccine rollout
content: ['<p>SAN JOSE, California  - Pfizer Inc said Thursday that more than a million new COVID-19 shots in the United States will be distributed by the end of May, making it the single biggest producer in the world of vaccine doses.<p><p>The drugmaker is still hoping to have vaccines delivered in time to help tackle the outbreak, but the threat of a second wave of the virus is dire, as countries across the globe prepare to inoculate their populations in time for Easter weekend.<p><p>“The pandemic is critical for vaccine availability and is critical for our ability to rapidly and efficiently distribute vaccines worldwide,” said Pfizer Chairman and Chief Executive Ted Bollinger.<p><p>“We have a relatively tight schedule, and we expect that we will have fewer vaccines delivered this year than the current wave. We’ve had many challenges in the last year and a half, including the difficulties with manufacturing, and it is critical to our schedule,” Bollinger said.<p> ']

headline: Greece to reopen for Easter as cyclone lifts some 6,000 in western Mediterranean
content: ['<p>BRUSSELS  - Greece’s emergency response plan was not ready for Easter when cyclone Maria struck in the eastern Mediterranean, the government said on Friday, adding that it had already made preparations for a third wave, possibly as high as a peak.<p><p>The cyclone was a combination of tropical cyclone Alta and hurricanes Agnes and Agnes-de-Mora, with the strongest winds since it struck in March 2019. It has left more than 6,000 people dead and displaced thousands in the Mediterranean.<p><p>On Friday, the Greek coast guard said a storm warning had been issued for the east Mediterranean after a tropical cyclone struck south of the Aegean in the Gulf of Aden.<p><p>“The coast guard in central Athens was in contact with the authorities to inform us that the cyclone had arrived in the eastern Mediterranean,” it said.<p><p>“The coast guard is fully prepared and has provided assistance,” the statement said.<p> ']

headline: Thailand's first-ever COVID-19 lockdown starts next week
content: ['<p>KUALA LUMPUR  - Thailand’s first COVID-19 lockdown started on April 15 after a temporary lockdown ended in early April, allowing the country to resume some essential services.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has said Thailand will announce its first lockdown in April and will allow people to work normally before starting the new measures.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has vowed to restart essential services in the wake of the virus pandemic and a second lockdown in the country’s capital Bangkok on April 20.<p><p>The government has said Thailand should be able to restart health and education services without the need for new orders.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth is also expected to issue emergency order permits for the two main drug stores for the two provinces.<p><p>Under new rules, Thailand will no longer restrict imports of food or non-essential goods, a move seen as a concession to consumers who fear the country may lose its grip on the global pandemic.<p><p>Prime Minister Prayuth said the health system was the “largest and most comprehensive “program” yet in the country, adding it was still a work in progress.<p>']

headline: AstraZeneca to make Covid-19 vaccine available as planned
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  - AstraZeneca is to make Covid-19 vaccine available as planned for a limited rollout in India, the country’s government said on Thursday, adding that it expects its first order in Europe to arrive in early 2018.<p><p>India’s COVID-19 vaccine campaign has been dogged by delays and delays, and the World Health Organization has said some countries are struggling to obtain vaccines to treat the virus after failing to receive doses.<p> ']

headline: U.S. pushes back against China and Beijing moves to tighten security
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. and China officials will soon announce a review of cooperation in order to reduce tension over the pandemic, the State Department said on Thursday, as China and Washington continue to assert a unilateral claim over disputed islands in the South China Sea.<p><p>U.S. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said Washington remained committed to a “common position” with China on maritime claims over islands in the South China Sea in response to ongoing challenges from Taiwan and the Philippines.<p><p>“The United States continues to strengthen its ties with China and the world community by pursuing an open and constructive dialogue in order to foster global stability, peace and security,” Psaki said.<p><p>U.S. President Joe Biden has repeatedly accused Beijing of building artificial islands in the South China Sea and said he has repeatedly called on the island countries to hold talks.<p><p>China has also repeatedly rejected reports it has used force to assert artificial islands and claimed in January it was building a missile defence complex on its island of Zhejiang.<p> ']

headline: Netherlands sends first COVID-19 vaccine to UK from China
content: ['<p>NEW DELHI  -The Netherlands and the United Kingdom will send COVID-19 vaccine to the U.K. for use by the COVID-19 vaccines - which will be delivered to the country from China - from Jan. 5, the Dutch Ministry of Health said on Friday.<p><p>The vaccine was developed by COVID-19 vaccinemaker H1N1, H1N2 and is administered at the AstraZeneca vaccine centre.<p> ']

headline: Indonesia to extend stay-at-home order to some Rohingya migrants
content: ['<p>NAIROBI  - Indonesia will extend its stay-at-home order to some 4,000 Rohingya migrants, a government official said on Tuesday, after a number of people fled the country’s worst refugee crisis in decades.<p><p>“The situation is more severe in Myanmar because of the situation with the Rohingya, but it is also a situation of humanitarian crises,” the government official, who asked not to be named, told Reuters by phone.<p><p>The order extends to people staying in camps in Surucao province from October to November, with another 4,000 expected to be processed by the end of April.<p><p>The government official said more than 3,000 had been detained and many had fled to Bangladesh since the violence broke out last year.<p><p>Authorities said last week more than half the Myanmar refugee population had been registered as a risk group under the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) and the authorities had detained two new arrivals at a migrant processing centre.<p><p>Around 3,000 of the asylum seekers had been granted refugee status as of late Tuesday and a further 5,000 pending.<p><p>The government official added the number of refugees at the processing centre was likely to increase as more people arrive to the camp via Turkey and Sri Lanka.<p>']

headline: Thailand warns of dangerous risk of 'pushed back' to 2020 amid new coronavirus challenge
content: ['<p>PENHAGEN  - Thailand’s Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha said on Monday the country faced “an extremely dangerous situation” as coronavirus variants continue to evolve.<p><p>He said the government had begun work on a vaccine to help combat the virus, which is spreading more widely than in previous pandemics, and would provide the necessary help to combat infections by mid-2026.<p> ']

headline: U.S. hopes to ease COVID-19 restrictions by Jan. 1, Biden tells Biden Biden
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. President Joe Biden told lawmakers on Tuesday he hopes to ease curbs to curb the pandemic and prevent a third wave of infection by Jan. 1, Biden told a hearing of the National Health Commission.<p><p>The Biden administration, the Biden administration and health experts are expected to report back in the next few weeks on the progress being made in curbing the virus, Biden told the hearing.<p><p>The meeting comes as the White House plans to announce more details on the administration’s revised COVID-19 restrictions.<p><p>Biden, who is vice president, has been a thorny critic of the United States’ response to the pandemic. The virus has killed more than 4,300 people and infected more than 8 million.<p><p>“I know I’m not alone,” Biden told a hearing of the commission on Tuesday. “We are dealing with very different threats from different threats. There are a lot of people with different fears and different concerns. It’s going to be very challenging, but the president has a lot of faith in us.”<p> ']

headline: Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny's whereabouts in Sweden are 'isolated'
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny’s whereabouts in Sweden are "isolated", the head of the Swedish Migration Agency said on Thursday.<p><p>“No indication of his imminent return has been published, nor is he in contact with the authorities,” said Andreas Lindgren, an agency spokesman.<p><p>He added that the whereabouts of Navalny were “not being reported in any official capacity” and that Sweden had no jurisdiction over the matter.<p> ']

headline: Tanzania's Mozambique president says state sanctioned state oil company over oil spill
content: ['<p>AMMAN  - Tanzania’s president on Tuesday condemned state oil company Petroimarko for violating the country’s energy laws, saying his government was responsible for the spill at the Suez Canal that caused widespread damage and endangered wildlife.<p><p>President Abdalla Kamali Museveni earlier said on Twitter that Mozambique’s state oil company Odebrecht-Borigina was a state oil company, not its natural gas subsidiary Petroimarko.<p> ']

headline: 'We are in lockdown' as Afghan security forces battle Taliban in Pakistan, witnesses say
content: ['<p> - Afghan security forces fought a nightmarish insurgency against the Taliban in the Pakistani region for over two weeks in an effort to stem a surge of foreign fighters that has seen a total of 9,000 killed and thousands injured.<p><p>The fight was a desperate measure by the Taliban to ward off the arrival of foreign fighters after the United States handed over more than $1 billion in aid in December - mostly aid to the government in the region.<p><p>“We are in lockdown,” said Hafibullah, a 26-year-old resident of Peshawar. “We do not have a word of what is happening.”<p><p>Pakistan’s government has promised help to Afghanistan’s armed forces to contain the insurgents, but it has not provided such assistance.<p><p>Fighting has escalated since the Taliban seized power in a 2014 coup that deposed a President Hamid Karzai.<p><p>“We are in lockdown. The army is not in control,” one of the witnesses said, adding that several Taliban fighters had also been killed.<p><p>Fighting has also intensified between the security forces and some ethnic Afghan tribesmen, which have fought the insurgents for years.<p><p>Fighting also continued between the Taliban and Pakistani troops, while Pakistani forces killed four Taliban fighters near the eastern border with Afghanistan.<p>']

headline: Suez Canal boss says ship will be ready for next summer - Reuters
content: ['<p>CAIRO  - The Suez Canal Authority has said that ships could be ready for the summer, with capacity for 3,000 vessels expected.<p><p>“As of April 18, we expect there to be 3,000 ships in operation in the coming weeks,” Canal Authority CEO Alejandro Marcello said on Monday.<p><p>The canal, which separates the Suez Canal into three parts, has been strained by a surge of international traffic that has killed more than 568,000 people since a March 1 quake.<p> ']

headline: Cases of male circumcision surge in Southeast Asia
content: ['<p>NAIROBI  - More than one in five male coronavirus cases were reported in Southeast Asia during the past 24 hours, according to a daily tally of cases by the Asian Heart Association.<p><p>The number of cases in Southeast Asia, which borders the United States, rose by 3.5% to 1,926 from Wednesday, said the Association for Disease Prevention and Control (AIDC) on Tuesday, bringing the total to 19.3 million.<p><p>The United States, home to more than a million Muslims, has recorded a surge in cases in recent days. Deaths surged by 40% since the start of the year.<p><p>The number of new cases rose by a further 41% to 26,908 from Wednesday, the AIDC said.<p> ']

headline: Venezuelan army kills 18 rebels, reports say
content: ['<p>CARACAS  - The military has killed 18 rebels in clashes that have killed 18 people and wounded dozens, the Venezuelan military said on Wednesday, amid reports the military has targeted rebels in the eastern Venezuelan region.<p><p>About 75 rebels were killed by the military on Wednesday in the clashes with government troops, the military said. The military said that 18 rebels were killed in operations against rebels advancing from the eastern Venezuelan province of Patagonia, where they were trying to enter Caracas, Reuters reported.<p> ']

headline: White House says Biden is prepared to address Iran nuclear dispute
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - White House spokesman Ned Price said on Tuesday that Biden was prepared to address Iran nuclear issues “in the coming weeks and months.”<p><p>The White House earlier said Biden had expressed “full and frank support” for Iran’s nuclear program and that the Iran nuclear deal should be reviewed in due course, adding that such “a path” was in Biden’s best interests.<p> ']

headline: Kremlin spokesman says its support for Ukraine's ousted leader
content: ['<p>MOSCOW  - The Kremlin said on Wednesday that support for Ukraine’s ousted President Viktor Yanukovich had dwindled to around 25%.<p><p>The Kremlin’s Western support for Ukraine began in the wake of Yanukovich’s ouster as the country was struggling to contain what the opposition called a “political, authoritarian” rise in eastern Ukraine.<p> ']

headline: U.S. to seek more data on Russia's hacking operations as tensions rise
content: ['<p>WASHINGTON  - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Tuesday the United States would seek more data on Russian hacking operations as tensions rise, according to a report in the New York Times.<p><p>The Russian government was not immediately available to comment on the Times report.<p> ']

headline: Suez Canal ships have started refloating and refloating in two-week window
content: ['<p>VIENNA  - The Suez Canal has begun refloating and refloating two-week-long shuttles to reach refloating sites in Morocco and Algeria, officials said on Saturday, as the Suez Canal authority ramps up the flow of cargo across the globe to meet soaring demand.<p><p>The ships have started refloating and refloating two-week-long shuttles to reach refloating sites in Morocco and Algeria, while the Suez Canal authority (SCA) aims to deliver $300 billion of new cargo by the end of September, SCA chairman Eduard Kravitz told a news conference after a visit to Egypt.<p><p>Kravitz said that the vessels “still pose an issue. It may take a long time (to fully refloat) but it is now ready to move forward,” adding that SCA expects to receive $400 billion this year.<p><p>The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) on Saturday completed a series of expeditions to collect about $30 billion in new cargo through the port of Mopatis, which has a capacity of up to 30 million cubic metres.<p><p>The vessels are expected to arrive in the early hours of Saturday, Kravitz said, adding that the container shipping industry in Africa is booming and that Mozambique was already taking in $1 billion worth of containers a day.<p> ']

headline: The government of Myanmar says its people face "increasingly severe and irreparable" economic challenges
content: ['<p> - Prime Minister Min Aung Hlaing said on Thursday the country faces "increasingly severe and irreparable economic challenges" as the country’s armed forces continue to face increasing threats and threats of reprisals from foreign groups.<p><p>“I firmly believe in the right of all Myanmar people to live peacefully, the rights of all people and the security of the people of Myanmar,” Min Aung Hlaing said on Twitter, referring to the armed forces.<p> ']

headline: 'Greece' is seeing COVID-19 deaths rise, says Prime Minister
content: ['<p> - Greek health officials are concerned that a high incidence of COVID-19 in the country’s oldest city of Athens could be an indication that Greece is dealing with an acute crisis, and want to get a grip on the situation so they can tackle the coronavirus crisis faster.<p><p>The government of Prime Minister Boyko Borissov said on Wednesday that deaths from the coronavirus were on the rise in Athens, the country’s oldest city, as doctors tried to put together beds for intensive care patients, as the country faces a new spike in infections.<p><p>“A higher incidence of the virus is a good sign for our efforts,” Borissov told a news conference.<p><p>The Greek Health Ministry said on Thursday that the death toll rose to 169 from 107 on Wednesday, as the country was still recovering from a three-week high on its coronavirus protocols.<p><p>The government had forecast the high death toll at around 2,000. The official death toll is the highest recorded in Greece, where daily death rates have surged from a peak of nearly 500 a year ago.<p><p>Borissov also said hospitals in Athens and elsewhere in Greece were under increasing pressure because of the new pandemic.<p>']

headline: The government in Myanmar says it will not tolerate Chinese military drills near its border
content: ['<p>BANGKOK  - The Myanmar army on Saturday said it will not tolerate any Chinese military drills near its border with China, and the government said it would not tolerate anyone in its territory violating its sovereignty.<p><p>“The armed forces are a people-made military and their armed forces will not tolerate any action that could lead to a military confrontation with the Chinese army,” the army statement read.<p><p>The statement came hours after the government of Aung San Suu Kyi accused China of threatening the country.<p> ']

headline: I don't want a repeat of the pandemic... because there will be more vaccines: a vaccine scientist told Reuters
content: ['<p>GENEVA  - There were no more deaths in the last 12 days of a pandemic that started almost a year ago than at any point during the Cold War, despite repeated warnings of the risks of the pandemic.<p><p>The World Health Organization and the U.N. immunisation campaign have warned of rising numbers of cases in the United States and Europe, including among people under the age of 30 who are in isolation for more than 24 hours daily.<p><p>The virus is spreading like wildfire in Brazil, Australia, and Canada, leaving more than 3.2 million people infected and a third of those in intensive care units.<p><p>“I don’t want a repeat of the pandemic, because there are more vaccines.” said Chris Anderson, a vaccine scientist with the University of Oxford.<p><p>“It’s definitely not going to happen as rapidly, so we’ve got to wait. But we’ll see what happens, and we will see what happens. And we will see what happens.”<p><p>While many countries have taken steps to limit the coronavirus’s rise in the months ahead, efforts to control it have been dogged by delays in testing and vaccination programs.<p>']

headline: Myanmar army says it will fight alongside ethnic rebels to stop violence
content: ['<p>BEIJING  - A Myanmar army spokesman said on Saturday that it will fight alongside ethnic insurgents to stop violence in the country, after reports earlier suggested it had launched an offensive that targeted police stations and military bases.<p><p>It was the second time a member of Myanmar’s armed forces had been killed since the Feb. 1 coup.<p><p>Earlier on Friday, a Reuters witness said an army unit had ambushed an army base in Kachinaung in the western province of Nakhon, killing at least five militants, and wounded several more.<p><p>The military said last week it had launched an offensive on several fronts across the country that it said were in violation of a 2018 peace deal and a U.N. report that Myanmar’s army was in a state of war with other ethnic groups.<p><p>The spokesman, General Min Aung Hlaing, told a news conference that the army had “attacked the military base” and that all forces in the country were ready to fight.<p><p>“This operation will continue as long as it is successful,” he said.<p> ']

headline: The Vatican says new Pope's papal homily 'uncomfortable'
content: ['<p>VIENNA  - The Vatican said on Thursday it had received a letter of protest from a Vatican official, who said the pope’s homily on the Incarnation on the cross was uncomfortable and made him feel uncomfortable, the Associated Press reported.<p> ']
